11/08/20, 11:19 am - Dr Raguram: One of the commonest representations of Lord Krishna is Venugopala. 
Perhaps the finest depictions I have ever seen and that too in terracotta medium was in Bishnupur.  The temples walls of Bishnupur are extensively embellished with carved and molded terracotta decorations made from the locally available laterite clay. These temples are associated with the Gaudiya Vaishnava faith, dating back to seventeenth century. Understandably then the temple walls are covered with terracotta panels recounting the life and exploits of Krishna.
Among them is this exquisitely carved depiction of  Krishna playing the flute in the classic tribhanga pose, with gentle bends at the neck, waist and knee. He is surrounded by gopis who are entranced by his music, with peacocks and deer keeping them company. Do notice the finely chiseled carpet-like patterning of the terracotta facade of the entire façade of the temple.
What does the flute really signify? Hollow and empty, it does not produce any sound of its own. Travails we experience in life are like holes in the flute. We have to breathe life into it and let the melodious notes unfold…

17/10/20, 9:50 am - Dr Raguram: Over the course of next few days I will be posting various depictions of Devi. Chalukyas were the forbears of South Indian sculptures traditions and were the first to
introduce the rock cut architectural tradition in South India. The Chalukyan artists were also the first in conceiving and depicting Mahishasuramardini in sculpturar form in South India.Here Mahishasuramardini is seen with four hands. Her lower left hand is holding the tail of the buffalo and with the trident on her lower right hand, she is piercing its head. One can clearly notice the spear going through the head of the buffalo. She is neither riding a tiger and nor is the asura depicted in human form. This is the sculptuea in Cave 1 at Badami

18/10/20, 9:59 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
18/10/20, 9:59 am - Dr Raguram: Ravana Phadi cave temple was conceived at the same time like that of the cave temples of Badami. But here, the artisans have excelled themselves in creating a prototype of a regular temple by carving it into a huge sandstone boulder. There is a large plain field in front with a nandi facing the temple. Two pillared halls are on either side of the entrance. Once you ascend the steps and enter the cave one notices that the interiors are much larger than any other cave in Badami. All the walls of the cave have exquisite carvings and one among them is Mahishasuramardini. 
Here the goddess is portrayed with eight arms. With the weight of her left leg she is holding the buffalo demon Mahisha down, while spearing it with the trishula. On one of her left hands she is holding the head of the buffalo. She is also carrying a sword and a bow and is seen wearing an elaborate, conical crown. On her left one can spot a lion. Compared to the sculpture of Mahishasuramardini in Badami, here the goddess is more energetic and graceful.
Unfortunately ravages of time and vagaries of neglect have left their impact on this beautiful sculpture. An earlier sketch by an unknown draughtsman in 1853 will give an idea as to how gorgeous it would have been when it was sculpted. . .
18/10/20, 12:08 pm - Nalini N R: Very sad to see the distorted sculpture but the draftman's work helps us to go back to the time, imagine and appreciate the gracefulness of the sculpture.
20/10/20, 7:16 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
20/10/20, 7:16 am - Dr Raguram: Mahishasuramardini is often depicted standing on a decapitated buffalo head or in the act of killing it, from whose head a demon in the form of a man emerges. But the most vibrant depiction of the goddess is in an exquisite bas relief in a small cave in Mahabalipuram which depicts her in battle scene with Mahishasura. She is shown riding a prancing lion and holding various weapons in her eight hands, attacking the demon who is retreating from her onslaught, accepting his defeat. It is the finest depiction of the epic battle scene. I kept wondering as to what could have been the source of inspiration for this majestic creative art.
As I was exploring the Mallikarjuna temple in Pattadakkal, I was struck by a small panel, worn out with years, in a dark corner. In its miniature form it seemed to be a prototype for the grand battle scene at Mahabalipuram! The spirit of experimentation patronized by the Early Chalukya dynasty perhaps has been the source of inspiration for the sculptors to create a majestic, larger version at Mahabalipuram!
Though the Pallavas and Chalukyas have been known for their incessant rivalry, the wars between the two dynasties never came in-between the growth of rich cultural heritage. Their mutual exchange and influence of architectural styles can be seen in the beauty, rhythm and vigor captured in stone by their masterful craftsmen. The Mahishasuramardini panel in Pattadakkal and Mahabalipuram is the perfect example of this remarkable confluence.
21/10/20, 8:06 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
21/10/20, 8:07 am - Dr Raguram: DAY FIVE
The shore temple at Mahabalipuram dates back to 8th century and it is generally believed that it is actually a small part of a temple complex which existed eons ago. It demonstrates the progression of Pallava temple architecture from rock cut structures to free standing structural shrines. Though years of wind and erosion from sea water have worn away the details of many carvings, there is a strikingly large free standing sculpture of a lion on the southern side of the temple. It is actually a miniature temple! A carved alcove in its heart serves as the sanctum, within which is a carving of Mahishasuramardini.  The goddess is shown sitting astride triumphantly on the severed head of the buffalo demon. Two dwaraphalakis are carved on either side of the lion, clasping it. Mahishasuramardini is often portrayed riding a lion or a tiger. Here she has found a place in a lion’s heart! The Upanishadic concept that likens the heart to a cave within which resides a hidden self is emphasized here. Perhaps in portraying Mahshasuramardini in this form, the sculptors are conveying that within each of us is a heart of a lion where courage and power resides to vanquish negative forces!
21/10/20, 12:42 pm - Nalini N R: Sir you have a fantastic eye for details. The sculpture is so beautiful and the hands and legs are so slender and shapely! And the discovery you have made!
21/10/20, 12:48 pm - Nalini N R: Yes. Instead of just hailing the beauty of the sculpture, the interpretation that you have given is very apt. It boosts the spirit to fight.
22/10/20, 8:44 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
22/10/20, 8:44 am - Dr Raguram: DAY 6
I relish discovering places and temples that are off the tourist radar.
Udaipur is not just about lakes and palaces. When I was there sometime back for a CME, after finishing my talk I enquired about a (unusually named) temple referred as Saasbahu temple. With some effort I found a local taxi driver who seemed to know the place, which was just an hour’s drive from Udaipur.
Located in the lap of the Aravalli mountain range, it was a charming structure by the side of a lake, surrounded by mustard fields. There was an aged guard who opened the gates and let me in. The early morning sun was playing hide and seek with the richly carved exterior of the temple
Built in the late 10th century, the larger temple (referred to as Saas) is surrounded by ten subsidiary shrines and is more profusely decorated than the smaller (Bahu) temple which has four shrines and an octagonal ceiling. The story goes that king Mahipala married a queen who was a devotee of Lord Vishnu and he constructed a temple dedicated to Vishnu for his wife to offer prayers. Years later, the king’s son married a princess who was devotee of Lord Shiva so he constructed another temple nearby for his daughter in law. Since the Vishnu temple was constructed first it was known as Sahastrabaahu temple meaning the lord with thousand arms though it included the Shiva temple as well. The name however got corrupted over a period of time to be called “Saas Bahu temple” much before the TV serial!
Made of granite, the carvings are quite remarkable and among them, this one of Mahishasuramardini caught my attention. Even though details of her face have been lost with the passage of time, the flowing lines enhance her graceful poise which is embellished with rich ornamentation. She is portrayed with a sword in her hand after killing the demon whose head is clearly seen on the ground. Though on a pragmatic level decapitation represents the loss of power, perhaps it is also a liberative act indicating that human pride and ego must be severed in order to attain salvation.
22/10/20, 10:33 am - Nalini N R: Thank you Sir for the rare journey into centuries old temples, which definitely have their own pure dedication to sculpture and vibrations. Yes, symbolic representation shouldn't be missed out.
23/10/20, 7:37 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
23/10/20, 7:37 am - Dr Raguram: DAY 7
Sometimes travelling in India is like a leap in the dark. One starts exploring destinations and discovering places which open up an entirely different world of experiences. My visit to Bhoramdeo was one such. While in Raipur for the Annual Conference of the Indian Psychiatric Society, I suddenly decided on a whim, to visit the place about which I had read a long while ago.
At first view, the temple stunned me. Set amidst a thick canopy of tall trees it was serenely beautiful. Soft morning rays of the winter sun dappled their way over the sal and bija leaves, setting the temple aglow with a golden lustre. The central tower composed of receding rows of exquisitely carved sculptures tapering upwards, seemed to replicate the receding hills of the Makali range in the background.
Dating back to the 7th century, it was Alexander Cunningham who discovered this temple which was engulfed by a dense forest, overgrown with vegetation. Taken aback by the sheer artistry of the temple he is said to have commented that ‘it is one of the most beautifully decorated temple seen by him.’ He also contended that it was originally dedicated to Vishnu and subsequently during the period of Gond supremacy in the region, the Vishnu idol was replaced with a Shivalinga in the sanctum. As the Gond tribals of the area worship Lord Shiva as Bhoramdeo, the temple was also named Bhoramdeo.
The outer walls of the temple were embellished with panel upon panel of delicate sculptures, covering a wide range of themes from the religious, the symbolic to the erotic. Because of the profusion of erotic sculptures and its structural similarity, it is often referred to as the “Khajuraho of Chattisgarh”. High up on the tower is a sculpture of Mahishasuramardini. Since it has been carved in chlorite stone, there has been considerable damage to the sculpture. In spite of it her face is serene and the ornamentation is exquisite.
Chipped, battered, broken, and yet elegant, its radiant beauty transcends its imperfection...
23/10/20, 10:04 am - Nalini N R: Sir thanks for giving us a chance to take a glimpse of the hidden treasure.
24/10/20, 8:27 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
24/10/20, 8:27 am - Dr Raguram: DAY 8
One of the most unusual Mahishasuramardini sculptures in India is this iconic Pallava creation at the Kailasanathar Temple at Kanchipuram, Tamil Nadu. Constructed over a 20-year period from 685 to 705 CE, the Kailasanathar Temple is the first structural temple built by the Pallavas, after their earlier experiments with rock-cut temples at Mahabalipuram. The temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and named after his abode on Mount Kailash. There are two Mahishasuramardini sculptures: a larger one on the outer wall of the sanctum and a smaller one sculpted within one of the 58 miniature shrines that are built into the niches of the surrounding wall. Though smaller in size compared to other, it is exquisite.
Unlike the other Mahishasurmardini panels which we have seen so far, this one has no Mahishasura in the frame. Instead we see a triumphant Durga posing in the aftermath of her victory in a strikingly confident posture. Her left leg is placed on the back of the lion which is vividly sculpted. Her left hand is rests casually on the raised left knee. Her right hand is gripping her hip, and there is a noticeable bend at the waist which gives grace and movement to the whole sculpture. Notice the long bow held by her, which is taller than she is! These sculptures in the smaller shrines were once painted with vegetable dyes. One can notice the remnants of it on the wall behind. How resplendent she would have been at that time!
24/10/20, 10:45 am - Nalini N R: Oh what a beauty Sir and your description of the same leaves me speechless as there is nothing to add on. Fingers are exquisitely sculpted and the smile goes with her triumphant posture. It is a feast to the eyes. Wish you all a very happy Durgashtami.
25/10/20, 7:34 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
25/10/20, 7:34 am - Dr Raguram: DAY 9
After some fabulous birding at Mangalajodi in Orissa, I enquired at the place where I was staying as to whether they could arrange a vehicle for me to visit Dakhya Prajapati temple at Banapur. They were surprised at my interests extending beyond the feathered friends and said “Why do you want to go there doctor? There is just an old temple there!” Undeterred, I asked for a taxi and after a journey of one and a half hours we reached the small dusty town of Banapur.
When I got down from the car, I was surrounded by a group of boys who were playing cricket outside the temple. They were curious as to why I was visiting the place and kept following me as I went around the temple which was totally deserted.
Dakhya Prajapati temple is one of the relatively well preserved monuments of the Ganga period. It is dated to the Eastern Ganga dynasty which ruled in the early part of 13th century. It was during this period that temple architecture reached its pinnacle in Orissa. The temple is carved out of khondolite stone, which is named after the khond tribe, in whose terrain it is often sourced. Most of the temples in Orissa, including the Sun Temple at Konarak are built with this type of stone, which unfortunately is easily eroded by weather.
The temple tower is in the Nagara style and is intricately carved with many beautiful figures. These figures were interspersed with delicate scroll work. Among them was a small sculpture of Mahishasuramardini which was enclosed by a stunning border. Durga’s encounter with Mahisha has been a popular subject among artists for centuries. Most often she is depicted either serenely or victoriously, standing on the decapitated head of the buffalo or in the act of killing a buffalo headed figure from whose cut neck the demon emerges. The focus of the depiction here was not on the combat between the goddess and the demon, but on the goddess herself. She is seated here with wearing the karanda mukuta crown resembling a basket. Though her face was eroded, she seemed to be looking directly at the observer, offering her blessings. Mahishasura is usually represented in three forms: in his zoomorphic form he is shown as a buffalo, in the theriomorphic form he is supposed to have the body of a buffalo and the head of a man, and in the anthropomorphic form. Mahishasura can be seen at the bottom in the human form here. The iconography of Mahishasuramardini has never been a stagnant one and has undergone changes over time as the image was incorporated and depicted in different regions of India. As time progressed, the images also became more ornate.
After having a good look at the sculptures, I entered the sanctum and was warmly welcomed by a young man who spoke English. After offering the arathi to the main deity, he narrated the mythology associated with the temple. Dakhya is the son of Brahma and the father of Sati. Dakhya means “able” and Prajapati is the Lord of all creatures. Here he is worshipped in the form of Lord Siva as Dakhyeswar. Hence it is also referred to as Dakhyeswar Siva temple.
As I was leaving, I asked him as to how he spoke such good English! He told me that he worked as a laborer in Whitefield, but grew tired of the urban chaos and returned home. He said “I come here every day and offer puja to the deity…I don’t earn much but I find immense peace in serving him..it is a labor of love” I was deeply touched by his words.
In his own quiet way he was conveying that fulfillment through exalted work is the highest form of virtue in life.
Traveling in not just about discovering places. There is something undeniably magical in these small moments when you meet people who open up new vistas and enrich your understanding of life.
Aren’t we all stones
Dreaming of shapes
That we might become
Awaiting the chisel
Of the Creator?

26/10/20, 7:47 am - Dr Raguram: DAY 10
Over the last nine days, I had posted various sculptural depictions of Mahishasuramardini across India…each one of them distinctly different and impressive. On this tenth day of Vijayadashami let me take you down south to Tirunelveli district of Tamil Nadu.
When the Vijayanagara Empire fell, it splintered into several smaller kingdoms controlled by Nayakas, Telugu-speaking warriors from the Andhra region. The greatest period of temple construction in Tamil Nadu after the famed Chola temples of the 11th-13th centuries occurred during their rule.
The ancient temple at Thirukurungudi, situated an hour’s drive from Tirunelveli is one such gem. As per the Vaishnava tradition, Thirukkurungudi is one among the 108 Vaishnava shrines and is said to be the ‘Southern Home’ of Lord Vishnu and is hence called ‘Dakshina Badri’.
The main deity is Azhagiya Nambi Rayar also referred to as “Sundara Paripoornam”, meaning “Perfect and complete beauty”. True to its name, it is one of the most beautiful portrayals of Vishnu. Not just the main deity, the entire temple complex is replete with some stunningly gorgeous sculptures.
The Chitra Gopuram of the temple is one of the most beautiful structures I have ever seen. Every inch of its façade is richly carved with panels depicting scenes from various epics. Each one of them demonstrates the sculptors' careful attention to detail and depict many mythological themes which are found nowhere else.
The most attractive section in the Chitra Gopuram depicts the slaying of the demon Mahishasura. In one of the smallest of panels in the tower, the talented sculptor has carved the scene in intricate detail. Devi is seen with eighteen hands, each one of them holding a different weapon and objects. Even the folds of her dress have been engraved with much care; every fold and every crease is visible. Her right leg is firmly in position on Mahisha’s neck, while piercing him with a sharp trident. As the Asura warriors watch the scene, the lion is also sinking its teeth into the demon. The victorious smile on her face is unmistakable!
As her arrow
Rests in the quiver
Let us recall these lines . . .
इत्थं यदा यदा बाधा दानवोत्था भविष्यति ।
तदा तदाऽवतीर्याहं करिष्याम्यरिसंक्षयम् ।।
“Whenever trouble arises due to the advent of the demons, I shall incarnate and destroy the foes. “
(Markandeypurana, 91.51: Eleventh Chapter of the Devi Mahatmya)

28/10/20, 12:42 pm - Nalini N R: Probably the only idol in the world that was made using three metals: silver, copper and brass.🙏🏼 Here the face of the Goddess is made of silver, the rest of the body is made of copper and the cloth is made of brass. The melting points of these three metals are different. There is no welding anywhere on this idol, it is an unbroken idol. The same feature is of the lion below the goddess, the whole body is of copper and the ayal is of brass. Even today, attempts to make such idols have failed.

14/01/21, 7:57 am - Dr Raguram: Pongal (like other harvest festivals in India), is a day to worship and express gratitude to the Sun God for helping the crops to flourish by providing energy for their growth. It marks the beginning of Uttarayan, the sun’s transition northwards for a six-month period. 
There are numerous depictions of Hari-Hara (a combined form of Shiva and Vishnu) but it is relatively rare to see a combined form of Surya and Shiva. One such unusual depiction is at Khajuraho. On the right half of this sculpture is Surya, the Sun God. He is holding lotuses: a fully bloomed one in one hand and a bud in the other. The left half is Shiva and he is holding a snake and a water pot.
एक एव हि लोकानाम् सूर्य आत्मादिकृद् हरिः।
The Sun God, a manifestation of Lord Hari, resides in the Soul of everyone in this world

01/05/21, 11:49 am - Dr Raguram: On this Labor Day, let us focus attention on the Worker Bee!
They are born sterile and their sole purpose is to continue to work during their entire lifespan. 
Worker bees are essentially the lifeblood of the hive. Without worker bees, there would be no one to care for the ever important queen, produce honey or pollinate plants and flowers. 
The job for the worker bee changes through their life-span. 
Younger ones handle cell cleaning and foraging outside is for the older bees. When the older ones return to the hive they leave packets on nectar for the house bound worker bees who then deposit them in the marked cells. 
Worker bees live for about five weeks and then die.
They literally work themselves to death to help the survival of the hive…

12/05/21, 10:50 am - Dr Raguram: Once in the city of Vesali there was widespread famine and spreading disease. There were many dead bodies as the conditions overwhelmed the ability to properly dispose of bodies. The local citizens sought out the Buddha’s help, who was nearby in Rajagaha. The Buddha arrived in Vesali a short time later with a large number of monks, including Ananda. Just before the Buddha’s arrival, torrential rains helped the situation somewhat by cleansing the landscape of rotting corpses and clearing the air and water.
Prior to his presenting this discourse, he instructed his attending monks to walk through the city and do what they could to ease the physical suffering of the citizens and to individually present this teaching. 13/05/21, 8:45 am - Dr Raguram: There are moments of reprieve in these gloomy times.
The sky is getting darker and a billowy wind is blowing across. As the raindrops start caressing the leaves, the chirping birds search for shelter. An interesting medley sounds softly floats in the air. 
I keep wondering whether the bird calls are sounding different in these times. There seems to be a discernibly upbeat quality in their songs. Or perhaps given the lack of noise due to the lockdown their calls are heard more vividly. 
The soundscape replete with mellifluous calls of birds soothens the angst of isolation. 
There is an intricate, ineffable relationship between the landscape outside of us and that within. 
In the words of Rumi, “Birdsongs brings relief to my longing” and I retreat into the silence within…

25/05/21, 2:13 pm - Dr Raguram: Today is Narasimha Jayanti.
Narasimha is one of the ten incarnations of Vishnu. He has often been depicted in nine different forms, Nava Narasimha which can be seen in the temple at Ahobilam.
Sculptors from the Hoysala period depicted some of these forms in intricate detail. This one from Halebeedu depicts him seated with the demon Hiranyakashipu in his lap. He is portrayed with six arms; two upper hands hold the shanku and chakra, the bottom two hands are grasping the demon in a tight grip while the two arms in the middle are tearing his entrails apart. Even the intestines have been depicted in detail! Prahlada can be seen in the bottom left offering obeisance. 
As Ananda Coomaraswamy commented, sculptures in Indian temples are not patterned after any ‘living model.’ They represent an unending array of imagery, steeped in symbolism. What could be the symbolism behind the sculpture?
To me he is an iconic symbol of intensive resistance to unjust things, hope against odds, triumph of the good over persecution and evil. He is the annihilator of maleficent forces within and outside of us.

26/05/21, 7:46 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
26/05/21, 7:46 am - Dr Raguram: On the occasion of Buddha Jayanthi today, I was recollecting my sojourn to the Mahabodhi temple.
It had rained the previous evening and the cool breeze of the morning kept me company as I slowly made my way to the temple. Since I was keen to reach the place early, there was hardly anyone at that time. A group of Buddhist monks were walking and chanting melodiously at a distance. I went around the temple and sat in front of the Bodhi tree. Early morning sun was peeping through its leaves.
For more than a month, Siddhartha (as Buddha was earlier called) meditated beneath it and attained enlightenment. It is said that emperor Ashoka's daughter, Sanghamitta took a branch from the original Bodhi tree to Sri Lanka and planted it in Anuradhapura, Sri Lanka. That Bodhi tree is still alive there and is supposedly one of the oldest continually documented trees in the world. The tree I was sitting in front has been grown from a sapling brought from the one in Sri Lanka.
Forest and trees are intimately associated with Buddha. He was reportedly born under the ashoka tree(though some say it was a mango tree), attained enlightenment under the papal tree and entered into mahaparinirvana under the sala tree. Further, four trees are associated with the enlightenment of the Buddha. He sat under a pipal tree for the first seven days, in the bliss of his enlightenment; then he arose and sat under a nyagrodha, the banyan tree for another seven days, in the bliss of his illumination; then he sat beneath a muchalinda (Indian oak) for another seven days, in the bliss of his calm; and, finally, he sat beneath a rajayatana (wild mango) for seven days, in the bliss of his emancipation. The four trees are known as the Tree of Enlightenment, the Tree of the Goatherd, the Tree of Muchalinda, and the Tree of Emancipation, respectively.
There has been a strong association with spirituality and sacred trees in Indian history and I was sitting under one of them to savor a fleeting glimpse of the infinite.
With the chants echoing in the distance, I slowly immersed myself in the experience of feeling His presence. As I lost myself amidst the canopy in front of me, I felt that He was whispering in my ears, “Any tree could be your Bodhi tree…”

18/07/21, 10:51 am - Dr Raguram: A few years ago we visited Omi International Arts Center in Ghent, off the beaten path in the gorgeous Hudson Valley countryside. It is a vast open space of over 100 acres studded with nearly 80 sculptures which blend into the landscape. We spent several hours exploring the magical space and savoring large-scale works of contemporary and modern artists. As I made my way amidst the rolling farmland and undulating meadows, I felt that I was in “Constable Country!”
 John Constable was largely responsible for reviving the landscape painting in 19th century. He began painting canvases in the open air, with striking results. Using finely executed brushwork, he synthesized elements of light and shade to convey the radiance of the Suffolk countryside. 
I was not carrying my camera and this image of the radiant landscape of the OMI Center was taken with the iPhone.

22/07/21, 12:17 pm - Dr Raguram: The Jataka tales are an important part of Buddhist art and literature. They describe the previous births of the Buddha in both human and non-human forms. The tales were often delicately sculpted in stupas. One such depiction of the Mahakapi Jataka appears on the western gateway of the Great Stupa at Sanchi.
The king is shown with a parasol over his head travelling with an entourage. To the right of the king an archer appears with bow and arrow aiming at the monkeys.  Realizing that their lives are in peril, they appeal to the Great Monkey (Bodhisattva) who climbs onto the mango tree, grabbing the branch firmly, stretching himself across the river. The relief show the Bodhisattva as the bridge by which monkeys escape to join the rest of the troop in the forest. Notice the depiction of the river with crocodile and fishes!
In the tale, when the king asked the Great Monkey as to why he risked his life to protect the monkeys he replies, "Great king, I guard the herd. I am their lord and chief. When they were filled with fear of your archers, I leapt a great distance to save them. I managed to hold the branch of the mango tree so that my monkeys could pass over my back and reach safety. Because I could save them, I have no fear of death. Like a righteous king, I could guarantee the happiness of those over whom I reign. Sir, understand this truth! If you wish to be a righteous ruler, the happiness of your kingdom, your cities, and your people must be dear to you. It must be dearer than your life."
A timely reminder these days, especially on this World Mango Day!!

24/07/21, 8:21 am - Dr Raguram: The thirst for knowledge is an eternal quest which requires the help of a Guru. On this Guru Purnima day let us pay obeisance to Shri Dakshinamurthy, the Adi Guru. He is the personification of spiritual wisdom and knowledge. His teaching is through the subtlest form of speech called para vak, which can be felt in the vibrations of silence. 
There are many depictions of Dakshinamurthy in sculptural form. The most beautiful of them is in Kailasanathar Kovil in Kancheepuram. Here you can see him seatped under a tree, giving a sermon. So much so, even the snake that adorns his neck has crawled down to sit and listen to him! There are two antelopes below him. They are a metaphor for a quick thinking human mind. His stance is also quite unusual. With his left foot crossed over his right knee he is gracefully turning towards us. The immaculate attention to the finer aspects is visible in the sole of the left foot, with the arches and instep sculpted in exquisite detail. On top on either side are the Kanakadi Rishis; Sanaka, Sanandana, Sanatana and Sanat Kumara. They are the four sons of Brahma who are considered as the greatest of gyanis. Though old in years due to their exemplary spiritual attainments, they maintained themselves eternally as small children. 
ॐ नमः प्रणवार्थाय शुद्धज्ञानैकमूर्तये ।
निर्मलाय प्रशान्ताय दक्षिणामूर्तये नमः ॥५॥
Salutations to the embodiment of Pranava (Om)
Salutations to the personification of the Pure, Non-Dual Knowledge,
Salutations to the Pure and Tranquil Sri Dakshinamurthy.

29/07/21, 10:28 am - Dr Raguram: Nature has always been a source of inspiration for poets.
Mahakavi Bharathiyar wrote a series of Vachana Kavithai (Prose Poems) titled Kaatchi (Vision). It is a work of immense literary and spiritual significance. In its style and imagination, they are unique in the history of Tamil literature. Some of these verses are akin to verses from the Rig Vediv hymns which laid emphasis on the worship of nature in its most sublime aspects.
It is believed that Mahakavi Bharathiyar studied the Rig Veda under the tutelage of Sri Aurobindo.
This particular verse about the setting sun is redolent with sublime imagery…. 
ஞாயிறே,இருளை என்ன செய்துவிட்டாய்? 
ஓட்டினாயா? கொன்றாயா? விழுங்கிவிட்டாயா? 
கட்டி முத்தமிட்டு நின் கதிர்களாகிய கைகளால் மறைத்துவிட்டாயா?
இருள் நினக்குப் பகையா?
இருள் நின் உணவுப் பொருளா?
அது நின் காதலியா?
இரவெல்லாம் நின்னைக் காணாத மயக்கத்தால் இருண்டிருந்ததா?
நின்னைக் கண்டவுடன் நின்னொளி தானுங்கொண்டு நின்னைக் கலந்துவிட்டதா?
நீங்கள் இருவரும் ஒருதாய் வயிற்றுக் குழந்தைகளா? 
முன்னும் பின்னுமாக வந்து
உலகத்தைக் காக்கும்படி உங்கள் தாய் ஏவி யிருக்கிறாளா? 
உங்களுக்கு மரண மில்லையா? 
நீங்கள் அமுதமா? 
உங்களைப் புகழ்கின்றேன்.

These verses resonate deeply whenever I watch a gorgeous sunset….

Guhan appears at a pivotal moment in Rama’s exile when he reached the banks of the Ganga along with Sita and Lakshmana. He had to cross the waters to go across to the dense forest. It is at this point that Guhan, who was the chieftain of the forest tribe, appears and offers to take them across. A strong bond develops between the two, with Rama calling Guhan his ‘friend’. Rama also adopts him as his fifth brother.

12/08/21, 11:10 am - Dr Raguram: World Elephant Day, observed every year on August 12, draws attention to their importance in our ecosystem and emphasizes the need for their conservation and protection. 
At one time in history elephants played a crucial part in warfare. They had a huge psychological impact in wars because their majestic sight and destructive potential. Their sheer size and ability to get rid of a number of enemy foot soldiers at one sweep created panic in the battlefield. Monarchs from different ruling dynasties like Magadha, Maurya, Gupta, and Chola enlisted these doe-eyed gigantic creatures in the army and they continued to be used by Indian warriors, right unto the seventeenth century. 
Thankfully, the use of war elephants gradually declined at the end of medieval era after the advent of gunpowder. 
This depiction of the war elephant is from a 16th century Nayak era mural at Thiruppudaimaruthur temple

20/08/21, 9:56 am - Dr Raguram: Doorways are much more than mere entrances into homes. 
They are gateways into life. They open up our worlds, yet protecting us from outside. 
Traditional homes in Tamil Nadu have elaborately carved doorways with intricate detailing.
In this small panel in an old house, Goddess Lakshmi is seated on a lotus flanked by two richly carved elephants holding pitchers of water, offering abhisheka . In her upper two hands she is holding lotuses. Having roots in the mud, yet blooming above, they represent spiritual quest and strivings. The lower right hand is in abhayamudra with her palm open, symbolizing reassurance and protection while the lower left hand is in varadamudra, palm facing down bestowing boons.
Varalakshmi Vrata is performed today by women in many southern Indian states for the wellbeing of the family and it is believed that observing it is equivalent to worshipping Ashtalakshmis. 
पद्मसने पद्मकरे सर्व लोकैक पूजिते। 
नारायणप्रिये देवि सुप्रीता भव सर्वदा॥
She who sits in the lotus, holding the lotus,
To whom all worlds pray
Goddess dear to Sri Narayana
I offer my humble prayers to thee…

21/08/21, 9:50 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
21/08/21, 9:50 am - Dr Raguram: Onam is all about colours, love, and of course good food. 
Like all festivals there is an interesting legend behind it! 
The story is woven around the popular myth of the truthful and benevolent King Mahabali, affectionately called Maveli.  He was the grandson of Prahlada and an ardent worshipper of Lord Vishnu. Under his reign, people led a happy and harmonious life. Mahabali’s fame as a judicious ruler began to spread far and wide which made the Devas jealous and they requested Vishnu to curb Mahabali’s powers. 
Vishnu in his incarnation as a dwarf brahmin called Vamana, approached the generous king while he was performing a yagna and asked for alms. Being kind and charitable, Mahabali granted him a wish in spite of his preceptor Sukracharya’s caution. Vamana just asked for three paces of land and the king agreed to it. Lord Vishnu grew in size as Trivikrama and scaled the entire universe in two steps. To keep his word, the noble king offered his head for him to place his third step. 
There is a beautiful panel in the Varaha cave built in the 7th century by King Mahendravarman I, at Mahabalipuram which depicts this story. 
The relief potrays Trivikrama with eight hands which carries 'shanka'(counch), 'gada' (club), 'chakra' (wheel), 'dhanush' (bow), 'khetaka'(shield) and 'khadga' (sword). There are figures around him in three levels. At ground level are four men, two on either side, seated to indicate the earth. At the second level are the sun & moon identified by the halo around their head, indicating the sky. In the third level above there is Brahma on the right and Siva on the left representing the Swargalokha. Beside Brahma is Jambavan who is beating a drum in jubilation. Beneath Trivikrama’s raised leg on his third stride is Mahabali falling down to earth in a sprawling posture. 
Moved by this gesture of King Mahabali, Vishnu grants him permission to visit his kingdom once a year. 
Thiruvonam is considered to be the day when King Mahabali comes from exile to visit his beloved people. 
Wishing everyone a very happy and prosperous Onam!

22/08/21, 10:28 am - Dr Raguram: Raksha Bandan is made up of two words, "Raksha" and "Bandhan" where "Raksha" stands for protection and "Bandhan" signifies the verb to tie. It symbolizes the eternal brother-sister bond which is not confined to just blood relationships.
Like many Hindu festivals, Raksha Bandan has several mythological origins.
Once Lord Krishna injured his wrist when while using his sudarshana chakra against the king Shishupalal. Seeing his hand bleeding, Draupadi who was nearby tore a piece from her sari and tied it around his hand to stem the flow of blood. Lord Krishna was moved by this kind gesture and considered the piece of saree as a sacred thread. He vowed that he would always be there to protect her. He said “Akshyam”, meaning “unending”. This is how her saree became endless when she was disrobed in public by Dushasana.  By protecting her from humiliation Lord Krishna affirmed his enduring bond with Draupadi.  
This panel which is just a few inches in dimension is from Amruteshwara temple at Amrutapura in Karnataka depicts Draupadi vastrabharanam.
It is interesting too to note that Rabindranath Tagore started a mass Raksha Bandhan festival during the Partition of Bengal, encouraging Hindu and Muslim women to tie a rakhi on men from the other community to consider them as their brothers.

07/09/21, 8:48 am - Dr Raguram: Anagalis Moneli orBlue Pimpernel has one of the brightest blue petals in nature and is named after French horticulturist Jean Monelle.

10/09/21, 7:48 am - Dr Raguram: Ganesha, as we know him today, appears as a distinct deity during the Gupta period. With the advent of the Puranic tradition, he emerged as a major God with a sect of his own called Ganapatyas. By the seventh century CE, Adi Shankara included the worship of Ganapati as one of the six systems (shanmata) of the Hindu religion.
There are 32 forms of Ganesha and he continues to be depicted in various pleomorphic forms inspired by the creative spirits of the artists!
One of the magnificent images of Ganesha is in Hampi, often referred to as Sasivekalu Ganesha. This monolithic statue is carved out of a single block of granite rock and is housed in an open pavilion.
Ganesha holds an axe in the upper right hand and a noose in the upper left hand. He holds the axe urging the devotee to destroy unwanted, evil thoughts that can lead one into Adharma. The noose or pasha in Ganesha's left hand is an implement to capture all difficulties. The noose conveys that worldly attachments are a noose around man’s neck. In order to attain spiritual perfection, one should cut the worldly attachments and attain spiritual enlightenment. In his lower left hand he is holding his favourite sweet the  
 “modak”. ‘Mod (मोद)’ means Anand and ‘ka (क)’ means a small portion. Therefore, modak is a small portion of Anand. He is holding a broken tusk in the right lower hand which he used as a writing tool for the Mahabharata epic.
A snake is tied around his prominent belly (which incidentally resembles a mustard seed and hence the name!). The popular tale is that once Ganesha ate lots of food and his stomach was almost bursting. In order to hold it back, he tied a snake around it!
However, the surprise element in this sculpture is at the back when one notices Devi Parvathi holding Ganesha in her lap! This is a very unusual and unique depiction of Ganesha!
As with other Hindu Gods the story of Ganesha is embedded in varying mythological narratives which are replete with multiple symbolic interpretations. It also interweaves with folk elements reflecting a community’s understanding and interpretation of the God in relation to their lifeworld’s.

A very perceptive reflection on forgetfulness is a poem by my  favorite poet, Billy Collins.
FORGETFULNESS
The name of the author is the first to go
Followed obediently by the title, the plot,
The heartbreaking conclusion, the entire novel
Which suddenly becomes one you have never read,
Never even heard of,
As if, one by one, the memories you used to harbor
Decided to retire to the southern hemisphere of the brain,
To a little fishing village where there are no phones.
Long ago you kissed the names of the nine Muses goodbye

Well on your own way to oblivion where you will join those
Who have even forgotten how to swim and how to ride a bicycle.
No wonder you rise in the middle of the night
To look up the date of a famous battle in a book on war.
No wonder the moon in the window seems to have drifted
Out of a love poem that you used to know by heart.

22/09/21, 12:25 pm - Dr Raguram: The greater one-horned rhino is the largest of the rhino species. Its greyish brown hide with skin folds gives it an armour plated appearance. It can deposit as much as 25 kg of dung in a single defecation. The dung piles contain seeds which have been ingested by the rhino which germinate in the nutrient-rich dung. During the day, rhinos spend a lot of time in water or wallowing in mud in order to keep cool.  They are known to make about 10 sounds, including snorts, honks and roars! 
On the World Rhino Day let us recollect this verse from the Khaggavisana Sutta, a Buddhist Pali text…
Without resistance in all four directions,
content with whatever you get,
enduring troubles with no dismay,
wander alone
like a rhinoceros.

26/09/21, 10:28 am - Dr Raguram: Today is the birthday of the poet TS Eliot, someone whom I like immensely. He concludes his magnum opus, Waste Land with these lines of hope;
Datta. Dayadhvam. Damyata.
Shantih Shantih Shantih.
Interestingly, Datta, Dayadhvam and Damyata have their origin in the fifth chapter of the Brihdaranyaka Upanishad. Prajapati, the creator is asked by devas, men and demons for advice. Then the thunder said Da.. Da.. Da… Prajapathi asked them whether they understood the message. All the three groups nodded their heads saying ‘Yes, Master, we understood it very well’. Devas understood Da as Damyata, self-control. Da meant Datta, give, donate for humans. While for the demons Da meant Dayatva, compassion. 
Kanchi Paramacharya highlighted the importance of these three in his song Maithreem Bhajatha, made popular by MS Subbalakshmi
An English translation of this song I found on the web reads:
Serve with friendship and humility
Which will conquer the hearts of everyone.
Look upon others similar to yourself.
Renounce war
Renounce unnecessary competition for power
Give up aggression on others’ properties 
Mother Earth is broad enough to give us all we desire 
God is compassionate to all
Daamyata – So, Restrain yourself
Datta – So, Donate your wealth to others
Dayathvam – So, Be Kind to others
May all people of this world be happy and prosperous.
May all people of this world be happy and prosperous. 
May all people of this world be happy and prosperous.

29/09/21, 7:50 am - Dr Raguram: Early in the morning, in the jungle, our attention was drawn to an extraordinarily wide range of loud calls – whistles, wails, screeches, and gurgles. Soon enough, we spotted the origin of these sounds; a flock of noisy birds with striking orange beaks and yellow markings in it neck and nape. Their glossy black feathers shimmered in the light. Interestingly, they were hopping sideways in the tree trunk actively looking for insects. 
The Hill Mynah has been described as the best talking bird in the world, indeed the champion of mimics! Unlike some other birds, such as the racket tailed drongo, they do not imitate other birds in the wild. In captivity, they can learn to reproduce a range of sounds, including the human voice, with astonishing accuracy and clarity.
As we were watching, it flung its wings and flew away, scattering the medley of calls into the air…

13/10/21, 10:03 am - Dr Raguram: Among the many depictions of Goddess Durga slaying the demon Mahishasura, this sculpture at Halebidu is distinctive. Exquisitely chiselled it depicts the story in a narrative form. Goddess Durga is standing triumphantly with her left leg over Mahishasura, the buffalo that has fallen on the ground. Mahishashura is seen emerging from the body of the buffalo in a human form and a trident is piercing him. Seated next to the buffalo is lion, Durga’s vehicle. Goddess Durga has ten arms (some of which are missing or broken), each holding different weapons and objects given to her by various gods. 
The word Mashishasurmardini consists of three Sanskrit words: Mahisha (buffalo), asura (demon), and mardini (slayer). Mahishasura's legend is told in the major text of the Shaktism, Devi Mahatmya, a part of Markandeya Purana. His transformation through various forms represents the never ending chain of desires within us. When one desire is fulfilled another springs and takes control. The conquest of Mahishasura is also symbolic of conquering and winning over such tendencies in us. The story is also told in the Sikh text Chandi di Var, also calledVar Durga di, which many in Sikh tradition believe was included in the Dasam Granth by Guru Gobind Singh.
Durga appears serene, calm and collected after vanquishing the demon in the sculpture. 
Her graceful demeanour is described eloquently in Mahishasuramardini Stotram which was composed by the great sage Adi Shankaracharya around 810 AD. 
कमलदलामल कोमलकान्ति कलाकलितामल भाललते
सकलविलास कलानिलयक्रम केलिचलत्कल हंसकुले ।
अलिकुलसङ्कुल कुवलयमण्डल मौलिमिलद्बकुलालिकुले
जय जय हे महिषासुरमर्दिनि रम्यकपर्दिनि शैलसुते ॥ १४ ॥
The Goddess who is with the radiance like that of the lotus petals, whose forehead is like that of a clear moon
O the one who is skilled in all the arts, and surrounded with attendants, whose steps are followed by dancing swans
O the one whose is with lotuses and Pogada flowers, which are attracting the bees, O the one with beautiful hair
Victory to you, victory to you, the destroyer of Mahishasura, the one with beautiful-braided hair, the daughter of the mountain.

14/10/21, 9:52 am - Dr Raguram: Today is Saraswathi Pooja. I had seen many sculptural depictions of Saraswathi during my travels. Personally I would rate the portrayal of the goddess at Gangaikondacholapuram as the most beautiful one. It was by sheer chance and through close observation, I had a glimpse of one of the smallest representation of Saraswathi and it was at Khajuraho.
Khajuraho temples represent the exquisite architectural heritage of the Chandellas. The Varaha temple is among the oldest in the western group of temples and is believed to have been constructed around 900 – 925 A.D. Comparatively small in comparison to its neighbours, its grandeur overwhelms you as you ascend the stairs and enter the little pavilion. Directly under the pyramidal roof which is carved with lotus flower, stands an enormous monolithic image of the boar Varaha, the third incarnation of Vishnu. The image is made out of a single block of sandstone that measures 2.6 metres long and 1.7 metres high. The stone shines like burnished metal and on its surface are 675 miniature figures, carved in twelve well-ordered rows. These figures represent many of the important Gods and Goddesses of the Hindu pantheon. These include ganesha, the seven mothers, the seven sages, the eight guardians of space, the nine planetary divinities, the river goddesses, the seas, the Rudras, and the different forms of Vishnu. 
A low parapet wall surrounds the massive figure of Varaha and as I sat on the soft smoothened stone, my attention was drawn to a small figure carved between the nose and mouth of Varaha. 
I was totally surprised to see a diminutive sculpture of Saraswathi with Veena in her arms!
Though small in size, the sculpture powerfully conveys all the essence of the goddess, much like beej mantras. 
Literally the word ‘beej’ means ‘seed’. In the seed are inherent all the characteristics of the tree. The most important thing about beej mantra is pronunciation and the sound associate with it, as each beej is associated with its own frequency. The more accurate the recitation of the beej mantra, easier it is for one to focus on meditation. “Mantra” in Sanskrit is made up of two syllables: “man” (mind) and “tra” (liberate). Thus in its most literal translation the word “mantra” means “to liberate one’s mind”. Essentially beej mantras are tools for expansion of consciousness utilizing the power of sound vibrations.
The beej is “Aing” for Saraswati and is chanted along with name of the goddess and is prefixed with “Om”, the primordial vedic beej mantra.
ॐ ऐं महासरस्वत्यै नमः ||
Om Aing Mahasaraswatyai Namah |
Meaning: I meditate and bow to Maha Saraswati Devi.

15/10/21, 9:46 am - Dr Raguram: Dussehra denotes victory of good over evil and there are two stories that are associated with the festival in India. It is said that it was on this day that goddess Durga defeated Mahishasura after a fierce battle lasting for more than nine days. It is also celebrated to mark the victory of Lord Rama over ten-headed demon king of Lanka, Ravana.
One of the most vivid depictions of this battle scene is in the western gallery of Angkor Wat. Extensive, detailed, carefully chiselled bas reliefs depicting various scenes from Ramayana adorn the gallery. The craftsmanship on the sandstone carvings is quite extraordinary.
The first photo depicts Rama waging the battle with his army and the second one portrays Ravana in his chariot. The stylized portrayal of Ravana is quite distinctive from usual depictions and is reflective of Khmer influence. The dynamism in the rendering of the battle scene is truly outstanding.
Ramayana is a living tradition in Cambodia and the epic is called the Reamker. The story is broadly that of the Ramayana, with a few changes. Rama is known as Phreah Ream, Sita as Neang Seda, Laxman as Preah Leak. The three are sent into exile with one of Rama’s stepmothers seeking to get her son crowned as King. Neang Seda is abducted in the forest and the two brothers ally with Sukreep (Sugreeva) to defeat the demon army of Lanka to get her back. Ravana is Krong Reap, the ten-headed king of Lanka. There is an interesting twist in the tale about Hanuman. In India, Hanuman is revered and regarded as the epitome of celibacy. In the Reamker, Hanuman was directing his monkey army to build a bridge of stones to Lanka. He realized that mermaids were stealing the stones. He decides to capture the mermaid princess, Sovanna Maccha, and teach her a lesson. In the process, Hanuman falls in love with the mermaid princess and marries her, later having a son called Mudchanu!

04/11/21, 7:33 am - Dr Raguram: Deepavali demonstrates how ancient tales in various epics can vary across the country. There are many narratives around Deepavali. One of them which we grew up with, commemorates the vanquishing of the demon Narakasura by Lord Krishna. As kids we would be woken up at an unearthly hour before sunrise and after an oil bath (which I detest!), wearing the new clothes, we would offer obeisance to the elders and rush to light the fire crackers. Sumptuous lunch with Deepavali sweets will be topped with a special lehiyam (a digestive) prepared for the occasion.
In other accounts it also marks the day that Lord Rama triumphantly returns to Ayodhya with Sita after a prolonged exile of 14yeas and defeating Ravana in the battle. It is said that Ayodhya’s citizens welcomed their prince home with thousands of glowing oil lamps on a moonless night. The word Deepavali has its origins from the Sanskrit word deep (lamp) and avali (row). 
This painting is from Ram Gopal Poddar Chhatri in Ramgarh, Rajasthan which Ahalya and myself visited sometime back. Ramgarh is a sleepy little town surrounded by sand dunes in the Shekhawati region and was once amongst the richest towns in India. It was considered as a centre of learning and was known as Doosra Kashi. It is now a treasure trove of painted havelis and chhatris. Chhatris are basically cenotaphs built to commemorate the memory of the rich and the royalty. Though they look unremarkable from outside, their interiors are full of resplendent paintings. The Ram Gopal Poddar Chhatri , built by the Poddar family in 1872, has exquisite murals depicting scenes from the Ramayana, the life of Lord Krishna, and Ragmalas. This impressive painting on the ceiling in particular depicts the arrival of Lord Rama and Sita to Ayodhya and the celebratory manner with which they were received. The luminous quality of the mural conveys the mood of the occasion wonderfully. 
May the light of the diyas spread joy and happiness…
In the words of Rumi, “If everything around seems dark….look again You May Be The Light!”
Warm Deepavali Wishes From Ragu & Ahalya

10/11/21, 9:08 am - Dr Raguram: Akka Mahadevi was a twelfth century Kannada poet, saint and mystic of the Virashaiva Bhakti movement. She was the first woman to have written vachanas in Kannada which are free verse hymns. Her vachanas end with her ‘ankita’ (signature) calling Shiva as Chennamallikarjuna or as poetically translated by A. K. Ramanujan, “Lord as White as Jasmine”. Over time, Akka’s concept of Chenna Mallikarjuna changed from that of the Puranic Shiva to a formless Divine which finds expression in this vachana, superbly translated by my favourite poet AK Ramanujan. 
I was reminded of this vachana when I saw this landscape enveloped in early morning mist…
YOU ARE THE FOREST
you are all the great trees
     in the forest
you are bird and beast
     playing in and out
     of all the trees
O lord white as jasmine
     filling and filled by all
why don't you
     show me your face?

11/11/21, 2:55 pm - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
11/11/21, 2:55 pm - Dr Raguram: If you are wondering what this hole amidst the rocks is… it has a chequered past in the annals of history…
During the 18th century, Chitradurga Fort was under the rule of Madakari Nayaka IV. Hyder Ali, one of the most powerful military leaders of the times, was on a conquering spree and he decided to attack this fort. He tried everything possible to conquer the fort often referred to as Elusuttina Kote (meaning the fort of seven circles). which was one of the most impregnable forts of the time. Finally, he found that there was a small hole (also known as kindi) in one of the walls of the fort. The hole could easily fit one person in it. He also found out that the guard watching this hole goes to his house during lunch hours to have a meal. So he hatched a plan to attack the fort by sending the soldiers one by one through the kindi. One day, Kalanayak, husband of Obavva was guarding the tower as usual. He decided to go home for lunch. While having his meal he asked for water. Since there was no water at home Obavva went to the pond near the kindi, to collect water in a pot. While filling water she heard sounds approaching. She realized that enemy was lined up and was trying to enter into the fort through that hole. Using her presence of mind, she hid behind the hole and waited for the enemy. She just had an ‘Onake’ a long wooden pestle used to pound paddy in the fields, as her weapon. The moment she saw the first soldier coming out of the hole, she hit his head so hard that he died in a single stroke. Similarly, she kept killing all the soldiers who came inside the fort through that tiny hole. The lone women bravely killed all the enemies who tried entering the fort that day.
With the only resource she had, she fought the enemy fiercely and the hole that she guarded is now known as Obavvana Kindi.
The government of Karnataka was planning to honour this women on this day as Onake Obavva Jayanti. This has been held back due to the model code of conduct being in place due to elections to the legislative council. 
Obavva has an enduring presence in the history (irrespective of these issues) and do try and find your way down that hole!

18/12/21, 9:49 am - Dr Raguram: Sacred trees form an important part of the cultural heritage of India. Most temples are associated with trees and each one of them has a sacred Sthala Vriksha. 
This particular tree is called audumbara or cluster fig (Ficus racemose). It is easy to spot with copious bunches of fruits growing from its trunk.  Each and every part of this plant has medicinal properties and has been used extensively in Ayurveda. 
Audumbara tree is most commonly associated with the Adi Guru Lord Dattatreya, a deity believed to embody Vishnu, Shiva, and Brahma. He is considered to reside at the base of the Audumbara tree in a subtle form. Throughout India, adumbara trees are planted in temples dedicated to Dattatreya. Because of this association, cutting it is considered a sin. If an audumbara tree grows in a house, it is deemed to be a blessing as it signifies the presence of Lord Dattatreya in the household. 
Incidentally today is Datta Jayanti…

20/12/21, 8:33 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
20/12/21, 8:33 am - Dr Raguram: Today is Arudra Darisanam…
It is believed that on this holy day (Arudra or Thiruvadirai), Shiva performed the cosmic dance as Nataraja. Legend has it that Lord Shiva performed the cosmic dance as Nataraja at Chidambaram for his devotees Adi Shesha and Vyagrapaadar. Adishesha, the seven-hooded serpent on whom Lord Vishnu rests in milky ocean, wanted to witness this divine dance of creation after hearing about it as also Vyagrapaadar who performed penance and tapas to witness the Ananda Tandavam of Nataraja. Lord Shiva granted their request and performed the cosmic dance at Chidambaram. The Ananda Thandavam is said to symbolize the five divine aspects (pancha krityas) of creation, sustenance, dissolution, concealment, and bestowment of grace. 
Although the occasion is associated with Chidambaram, it is celebrated with equal fervour and joy at other temples too. One such shrine is at Uthirakosa Mangai in Ramanathapurm district. The temple houses a 6 feet tall idol of Nataraja which is carved out of emerald, referred to as Maragatha Nataraja. The idol is covered with sandal paste all around the year and no puja is offered to the deity. On the eve of arudra darisanam the sandal paste is removed for a few hours for devotees to have a glimpse of the Lord. 
Ahalya and myself visited this temple early this year and found this beautiful mural of Nataraja on the ceiling of the mandapa leading onto the garbagriha of the Nataraja shrine. There were a few other murals too, but almost all of them had faded over the years due to neglect except this remarkable one.
In almost all depictions of dancing Nataraja, the lord is seen lifting his left foot while balancing over apasmara (or muyalagan) with his right foot. In this painting he is lifting his right foot while balancing on his left one. The only other place where he is depicted similarly is at Madurai Meenakshi temple. The legend has it the Lord danced with his right foot raised on the request of Pandya King by the name of Rajasekhara, a great devotee of Shiva. The king was very much concerned that dancing with permanently grounded right foot that might cause the Lord pain. Responding to his fervent prayers, the lord himself made the shift from left foot to right foot, which is referred to as “Kaal maari aadiya patalam.''
The metaphor of the cosmic dance unifies ancient mythology, religious art and spirituality seamlessly.
As the Dhyaana Shloka in praise if Lord Shiva, the Lord of Dance states:
आंगिकम भुवनम यस्य
वाचिकं सर्व वाङ्ग्मयम
आहार्यं चन्द्र ताराधि
तं नुमः (वन्दे) सात्विकं शिवम् 
Angikam Bhuvanam Yasya 
Vachikam Sarva Vangmayam 
Aaharyam Chandra Taradi
Tam Numah ( Vande) Saattvikam Shivam 
Whose bodily movement is the entire Universe
Whose speech is the language (of the Universe)
Whose ornaments are the moon and the stars
Him, we worship the pure (serene) Lord Shiva!

25/12/21, 8:00 am - Dr Raguram: The Vatican Museum is a treasure trove. It has 54 galleries with amazing works of art.
As I walked into the Raphael Rooms, I was overwhelmed with the sheer beauty of its frescoes.
Prominent among them was The Disputation over the Blessed Sacrament or the Triumph of Religion which was painted by the artist when he was just 27 year old. It was probably first fresco that Raphael painted at the Vatican. 
In the top most realm is featured God the Father, the Creator of all things visible and invisible. He is depicted holding the world in His hands along with a host of angels by his side. At the centre is God the Son. Seated on a throne of clouds, He gazes benevolently at the viewer. An august aureole encompasses His divine aura. To Christ’s left is seated John the Baptist. He is identified by his traditional iconography, pointing out to Christ as the path to salvation. To Christ’s right Blessed Virgin Mary is seated the with hands pressed at her chest. On either side of them are various saints and prophets. Below Christ’s feet is the Holy Spirit, to whose sides are books of the four Gospels held open. At the bottom is the monstrance which is flanked by groups of theologians in lively debate.
I spent several minutes, unmindful of scores of people passing by, looking at this incredible work of art brimming with life. The clarity, rich colours, harmonious composition and grandeur of this fresco left a lasting impression on me.
It is said that Raphael won the commission to paint the four rooms after stiff competition with both Michelangelo, who was working on the Sistine Chapel and Leonardo da Vinci. This incensed Michelangelo who accused Raphael of plagiarism, spreading rumours that Raphael had sneaked into the Sistine Chapel to have a preview of his work and copied the techniques!   
(BTW this is just one section of the mural!)

09/01/22, 6:01 pm - Dr Raguram: It is curfew time….all noises have ceased..
Amidst the silence, a red vented bulbul announces its presence through its unmistakable call.
As I watch, it raises its head and lets out a quiet phrase of a song.  Starting as a whistle the song soon turns melodious, enlivening the still ambience. 
Its cheery call alleviates the angst of isolation..
Towards the end of his life, the last Mughal emperor Bahadur Shah Zafar had to face similar seclusion when  he was incarcerated by the British and he wrote a beautiful poem about the bulbul:
Bulbul ko bāġhbāñ se na sayyād se gila 
qismat meñ qaid likkhī thī fasl-e-bahār meñ
The bulbul has no complaints from the gardener, or the bird-catcher.
It knows that it is destiny to get caged, even if it is springtime.
Such prescient observation about travails of life during pandemic!

15/01/22, 9:25 am - Dr Raguram: Pongal is essentially a harvest festival and mattu pongal, a day dedicated to cattle, is an integral part of the festivities. Cattle play an important role in agriculture and are an inseparable part of a farmer’s life and. an entire day is dedicated to the cattle, that has been an inseparable part of a farmer's life. On this day, cattle are bathed and decorated and prayers are offered to them as an act of thanksgiving.
As I was savouring the enchanting Nayak era murals inside the main gopuram of Thiruppudaimarudhur, my attention was drawn to this small (size of a postage stamp!),beautifully carved wooden sculpture.  
Today is also a significant day for siblings and is called Kanu Pongal. Sisters pray for the wellbeing of their brothers by offering food to crows. They make small balls of pongal and cooked rice mixed with turmeric and kumkum. These rice balls are then kept on turmeric leaves (Kanu pidi) and served to the crows.
காக்கா பிடிவச்சேன்கண்ணுபிடிவச்சேன், காக்கா கூட்டம் கழிஞ்சாலும் 
எங்க கூட்டம் கலையாமல் இருக்கணும் 
Meaning "I make an offering small balls of food for the crows, even if the family of crow splits, mine should not"
When one would see flocks of crows on other days, they would be significantly scarce on Kanu pongal mornings when they are most sought after!

22/01/22, 9:58 am - Dr Raguram: Thich Nhat Hanh passed away today…
Over the years, he had a significant impact on me personally and professionally, through his teachings on mindfulness and compassion. 
As he remarked, “The Buddha taught that there is no birth; there is no death; there is no coming; there is no going; there is no same; there is no different; there is no permanent self; there is no annihilation. We only think there is.”
He did not want his followers to build a stupa, but if they did build one, he told them they should add three signs on it: “I am not in here.” “I am not out there either.” “If I am anywhere, it is in your mindful breathing and in your peaceful steps.”
He was a ‘spiritual exemplar’ and a source of inspiration for the environmental movement.
When I took a walk a few years ago in the woods behind Angkor Wat, I was reminded of his words…

02/02/22, 11:35 am - Dr Raguram: Wetlands play a crucial role in absorbing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and locking it away in plants, root systems and soil. They are also a vibrant biologically diverse ecosystem that sustain a large number of birds, fish and other small creatures which live in harmony. 
For many of us, water simply flows from a tap and we hardly reflect about it beyond this point of contact and consumption. In the process, we have lost a sense of respect for the complex workings of a wetland and the intricate web of life that this simple waterbody supports.
On this World Wetland Day it is imperative that we commit ourselves to conserve and protect this invaluable, precious ecosystem…

05/02/22, 9:22 am - Dr Raguram: Basant Panchami which is being celebrated today heralds the arrival of spring and is imbued with many legends. The most popular association is with Saraswati, the goddess of knowledge, language and music who is deemed to have been born on this day. 
Amongst the many legends concerning Basant Panchami, there is one which revolves around Kama and his role in bringing Lord Shiva and Parvati together. Shiva, mourning the death of his wife Sati/Uma, retreated to the Himalayas and became a reclusive ascetic. Parvati, a reincarnation of Sati, told her father King Himavat that she would marry only Shiva. When informed of this, Shiva declined and walked away without even a glance at Parvati. Undaunted, she waited for many years but couldn’t win him over. The Gods intervened and approached Kamadeva to wake Shiva from his deep meditation and make him fall in love with Parvati. Heeding to their request, Kamadeva shot his five arrows of love, one of which distracted Shiva, who got bewitched by Paravati’s beauty. But as soon as he realized it was Kamadeva’s ruse, he opened the third eye and reduced him to ashes. Deeply distressed by this, Rati undertook an austere penance for 40 days to Shiva. Shiva finally relented and brought Kamadeva back to life on the day of Basant Panchami. On this day Kamadeva and Rati descend on earth ushering in the first fragrant breeze of spring, a season or rebirth and renewal. This is one of the reasons as to why Basant Panchami is also associated with Shringara Rasam.
This beautifully carved sculpture of Kamadeva and Rati is from the western groups of temples at Khajuraho.
It is not a so well-known fact that the Muslim community has been celebrating Basant Panchami since the 12th century A.D. According to legend, Delhi's Chishti Saint Nizamuddin Aulia's young nephew Taqiuddin Nooh died in this month. Stricken with grief, he withdrew himself. The famous court poet, Amir Khusrau, tried to think of ways to brighten the Saint's mood. Then Khusrau noticed some young women dressed in yellow clothes, adorned with yellow flowers of marigold who were celebrating Basant Utsav. Seeing this, an idea struck Khusrau, who immediately donned a yellow ghaagra, covered his face with a chunni, hung garlands of yellow marigold around his neck, went to the Saint and began dancing and singing, “Aaj Basant Manaaley Suhagan…Aaj Basant Manaaley Suhagan”. Seeing this spectacle and knowing it was Khusrau under the woman’s garb who was singing and dancing with gay abandon, Nizamuddin Aulia burst out laughing and his spell of gloom was swiftly lifted. He then went to the grave of his nephew and sang: ‘Ashq rayz ameedan abro bahar’ (‘Shed tears of joy at the coming of spring and the clouds’). Since then, Basant Panchami is being celebrated at the dargah of Nizamuddin Aulia in Delhi and all dargah's of the Chishti order.
Basant, the season of spring, has also inspired many ragas in Indian music. In the north, there are Basant, Basant Bahar and Basant Mukhari and in the south, Vasantam, Hindola Vasantam, Shuddha Vasantam, Vasanta Varali, and Vasanta Bhairavi. Each one of them embodies the spirit of spring.
On this day let us celebrate the cultural syncretism associated with this festival in the subcontinent and spend the day savouring and immersing ourselves in these ragas!

07/02/22, 8:33 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
07/02/22, 8:33 am - Dr Raguram: Rathasapthamai which is being celebrated today marks the movement of sun (Surya) turning his “ratham” (chariot) drawn by Saptha (seven) horses from winter solstice to (Dakshinayanam) to the summer solstice (Uttarayanam). 
The worship of Surya is deep rooted in antiquity. Sun has been an object of reverence and worship from the start of human settlements and has been represented symbolically in the pottery and seals of ancient civilizations. The transformation of Surya from a symbolic form to an anthropomorphic figure occurred during the Rig Vedic period. In the process of providing a form to the formless an iconic tradition started and Surya was represented in various human forms across different parts of India. The Agama tradition further specified details of depiction of the sun god. One of the most beautiful representation of Surya according to the Suprabhedagama tradition is in at the Virupaksha temple in Pattadakkal. This temple was built by Queen Loka Mahadevi after the successful military campaign of King Vikramaditya II against the Pallavas. Within the dark interiors of the temple, the inner ceiling in the east has this intricately carved image of Surya. 
At the center of this intricately carved bas-relief is Surya, the sun god, riding a seven-horse chariot. He is standing majestically in the chariot holding a lotus flower with each hand, and surrounding his head is a halo of rays emanating outwards. Behind him are the two-headed mythical creatures (Makaras), disgorging yakshas. Accompanying him are his consorts Ushas (Goddess of Dawn) and Chhaya (Goddess of Shadow). Both Ushas and Chhaya are pointing their bows upwards, indicating that they are fighting the darkness. At the bottom of the panel is Aruna, Surya’s charioteer, holding the reins of seven horses, representing the days of the week. The seven horses are named as Gayatri, Brihati, Ushnih, Jagati, Trishtubha, Anushtubha and Pankti. 
Perhaps one of the most exquisite delineation of the attributes of the sun god is in the composition of Muthiswamy Dikshitar ‘Surya Murte Namostute’ set to raga Sourashtram.  
The spiritual connotations of the Sun have been brought out vividly by Rabindranath Tagore: “One day while I stood watching at early dawn the Sun sending out its rays from behind the trees, I suddenly felt as if some ancient mist had in a moment lifted from my sight and the morning light on the face of the world revealed an inner radiance of joy. The invisible screen of the commonplace was removed from all things and all of mankind and this ultimate significance was intensified in my mind and this is the definition of beauty.”

08/02/22, 9:34 am - Dr Raguram: Bhishma or Bhishma Pitamaha was one of the most charismatic characters in Mahabharata and was respected by both the Kauravas and the Pandavaas. His original name was Devavrata and he was the son of King Shantanu and Ganga. His father wanted to marry a fisherwoman, Stayavati, who insisted that only sons born to her should succeed Shantanu to the throne. To facilitate this, Devavrata took a vow of celibacy for life and also pledged to serve anyone who ascended the throne of Hastinapura. 
In the battle of Mahabharata, the Pandavas were unable to make any headway even after many days mainly due to the skill and valour of Bhishma. At this point, Shikhandi, who was born a woman, positioned herself in front of Arjuna to fight against Bhishma. Bhishma knew that Shikhandi was born a woman, who had a grudge against Bhishma because he had interfered in her marriage. Seeing Shikhandi, Bhishma refused to fight and was felled by Arjuna’s arrow. It is believed that Bhishma himself had hinted at this ploy while Arjuna and Krishna met him the previous night.
Arjuna’s arrows had already formed a bed and Bhishma did not fall to the ground. Arjuna used more arrows to form a pillow. As the battle raged, Bhishma held on till Uttarayana to die as he had the boon of ‘Ichcha Mrityu’, the ability to choose one’s time of death.
It is believed that Bhishma revealed the Vishnu Sahasranama Stotram to the Pandavas in the presence of Lord Krishna, an incarnation of Lord Vishnu, on this day which is celebrated as Bhishma Ashtami. 
The battle of Kurukshetra is carved into the southern section of the west gallery, which is located on the perimeter of the lower level of the Angkor Wat. This is a depiction of Bhishma on a bed of arrows. Interestingly it is said that a beam of sunrays falls on this image during the winter solstice

14/02/22, 8:23 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
14/02/22, 8:23 am - Dr Raguram: As John Paul Young sang, “Love is in the air, everywhere I look around, Love is in the air, every sight and every sound.” It is also the time when love turns into serious business in the guise of Valentine’s Day. But what is the real story behind Valentine?
While Valentine’s Day might be associated with romantic love, the real story behind its namesake, Valentine, is full of bloodshed and heart break. He was reported to have had healing powers, especially for those ailing from epilepsy. According to one legend, Valentine signed a letter “from your Valentine” to his jailer’s daughter, whom he had befriended and healed her from blindness. Another legend states that he defied the emperor’s orders and secretly married couples to spare the husbands from war. Unhappy with his actions, Emperor Claudius ordered that he be put to death and he was beheaded. Neither written nor material evidence from the pre-medieval period associates Valentine with love or lovers. Scholars credit Geoffrey Chaucer for turning Valentine into the patron of love. In his Parlement of Foules he wrote, “seynt Volantynys day/ Whan euery bryd comyth there to chese his make. (Saint Valentine’s day, when every bird comes there to choose his mate.) Chaucer was a major influencer in his day – after him, everyone began calling their beloved “Valentine” and writing love poems on 14 February.
Closer home there is a more suitable mythological character, Kamadeva. He has many names: he is called “Ragavrunt”, “Ananga”, “Kandarp”, “Manmath”, “Mansija”, “Madana”, “Ratikant”, “Pushpvan” and “Pushpdhanv”. Kama has a variety of meanings, ranging from sensuality to aesthetic enjoyment, although its overtones are predominantly sexual in the popular imagination. It is also a misconception that kama means love, kama literally means trishNa(Sanskrit), desire or thirst. 
There are striking parallels between the depiction of Kamadeva and Cupid. Both carry a bow and a quiver of arrows. Kamadeva’s bow is made of sugarcane and is sugar coated with the bowstring soaked in honey. Arrows are decorated with flowers and the flowers on his arrows are:  Aravinda(White Lotus), Ashoka, Cuta (Mango Flower), Navamalika (Jasmine), and Nilotpala (Blue Lotus). Kamadeva carries five kind of arrows with him: Maran, Stambhan, Jrumbhan, Shoshan and Ummadan. Kamadeva’s five arrows are associated with five effects. The first arrow is aimed at the heart and it causes initial excitement and a youthful cheerfulness. The second arrow is aimed at the lips and it causes one to cry out of this excitement. The third arrow is aimed at the head/brain and it makes one lose their mind / go crazy with love. The fourth arrow is aimed at the eyes which makes one see things. The fifth arrow is basically designed to hit anywhere causing the person to totally be absorbed with love. 
There are no temples solely dedicated to Kamadeva in India. However, in Assam there is a shrine for him called Madana-Kamadeva temple. Situated in a dense forest, this temple has some marvellous sculptures but unfortunately the structure is quite dilapidated. 
This particular sculpture of Kamadeva is from a small temple at Krishnapuram in Tirunelveli district. It is an astounding sculpture crafted out of a single stone and is exquisitely carved. He is holding the bow made of sugarcane, which is so well hewn that if one drops a pin into the hole on top of the bow, it comes out at the bottom! Unfortunately, in the process of testing this out, people have broken part of the bow, the bane of many a sculpture in India. The sculpture now is encircled within a steel enclosure to prevent further damage to it. 
There is a mantra dedicated to Kamadeva which reads:
Aum Kamadevaye Vidmahe
Pushpa banaye dhimahi
Tanno Ananga Prachodayat
Oh let me meditate to the God of Love
He who carries an arrow made of flowers
May that Ananga (who is without a body) bestow upon me higher intellect and illuminate my mind.
Purusartha is a key concept in Hinduism and refers to the four important goals of human life. They are Dharma (righteousness, moral values); Artha (prosperity, economic values); Kama (pleasure, love) and Moksha (liberation, spiritual values). The path to enlightenment or Moksha is facilitated by the harmonious interaction of Dharma, Artha, and Kama. 
Ultimately, the highest Kama is the longing for Oneness with the Divine.
