16/02/22, 4:04 pm - Dr Raguram: Siva is worshipped in various anthropomorphic forms. His facial depiction usually encompasses five different representations: Satyojatam, Vamadevam, Tatpurusham, Esanam and Agoram. The last one in turn has five forms, one of which is Gajasamharamurti. He is also worshipped as Ayurdevata, which is mentioned in Ayush suktam of Rig Veda which also mentions Him by the Sanskrit name Krithivasa. 
According to legend, once 30,000 sages, who were meditating at Tarukavanam, challenged the omnipotence of Lord Siva. They created many wild creatures through sacrificial fire to kill Siva, but in vain. Finally, they sent an elephant demon (Gajasura). But Siva, dwarfing Himself entered the elephant’s body and then assumed his original form only to slay the demon and emerged wearing its skin. Sages who saw this divine event shed their pride and arrogance and took refuge in Siva. Symbolically the mad elephant represents, anger, ignorance and pride. When we take refuge in Siva, he slays all these demons within us. 
There is also a reference to Gajasamharamurti in Kalidasa’s ‘Kumarasambhavam.’ According to it was demon Nila who came in the form of an elephant to kill Siva. Learning about it, Nandi ordered Veerabadra to slay Nila. Veerabadra killed the demon and presented the skin (charma) to Siva, who wore it while on his way to vanquish Antakasura. Hence he is also referred to as Gajacharmambara.
The only temple dedicated to Gajasamharamurti is at Vazhuvoor in Mayiladuthurai district, Tamil Nadu and it is believed to be the site where Lord Siva killed Gajasura, the elephant demon, and wore his hide around him. 
There are many sculptural depictions of Gajasamharamurti. The most attractive one is at the Hoysaleswara temple at Halebid. He is depicted in a dancing posture with his right foot on the demon Gajasura. The lifted left leg is so delicately carved that one can even see the arch of the heel! The two hands on the top are positioned high, holding the elephant’s skin which is surrounding the God like a Prabavalli. He is holding trishul, damaru, kapala and Khadaga amongst others. He is wearing a tall crown with several small skulls inscribed on it. Several rings can be seen on his fingers. A highly ornate belt called Mekhala is adoring his midriff. As he dances inside the elephant his jewellery is swinging too! Nandi is on his right hand side, looking out. On the left are various Ganas playing the drums. One of them is even adjusting the ropes of the drum to tune it! To his right is Nandi and to the left two ganas playing mrudanga can be seen in the lower part of the carvings. The entire sculpture is suffused with elegance conveying a delicate sense of balance.
Today is Masi magam and among the many legends associated with it, is that of Gajasamharam, reminding us to destroy our ego and surrender ourselves at the feet of the divine.

24/02/22, 9:08 am - Dr Raguram: The formidable looking dwarapalaka are the door-keepers of temples. The name dwarapalaka is a combination of two words Dwaram and Palakas: Dwaram stands for door or entrance and the Palakas for guardians. Carved in pairs, they are the protectors of the main deity and are typically depicted as huge and robust warriors. One can find them at the entrance to the temple and also at the doorway to the sanctum. Their iconography differs according to whether they are in a Shiva or Vaishnava shrines.
One of the outstanding representations of dwaraplakas is at the 14th century vaidyanatheshwara temple at talakadu. Here he is seen holding trishula in his top right hand and a damaru entwined by a snake is in his top left hand. His right hand at the front holds gada (mace) and his left hand at the front is in abhaya mudra. He is wearing a Kirita, and the entire body is adorned with exquisitely chiselled jewellery.
This dwarapalaka is quite distinctive from any others! Look carefully at his chest and abdomen and you can recognize the face of nandi, the vahana of Shiva!
I stood there for some time, totally mesmerized by this marvellous sculpture by an unknown artisan who seems to have dipped his chisel in his soul to create this masterpiece.

01/03/22, 8:58 am - Dr Raguram: According to one of the legends, Mahashivaratri is the day Lord Shiva got married to Parvati.
Goddess Sati took birth as Parvati, the daughter of Himavan to marry Lord Shiva. She practised intense penance to win over Lord Shiva's heart. After years of Tapasya at the Gauri Kund, Parvati finally succeeded in convincing Lord Shiva to accept her as his wife. Shiva reportedly proposed to Parvati at Guptakashi and then tied the nuptial knot at Triyuginarayan. The celestial marriage of Lord Shiva and Parvati took place in the presence of Lord Brahma, who turned a priest to conduct the ceremony and Lord Vishnu, who performed the duties of the bride's brother. The Agni that was witness to the wedding ceremony still exists in the form of an  eternal flame, Akhand Dhuni, near the temple.
This 17th century mural at Veerabadra temple at Lepakshi depicts the marriage of Shiva and Parvati. Shiva is shown wearing the characteristic tiger skin, carrying the deer and axe in the upper hands. Parvati, escorted by attendants stands in front of Shiva, her head slightly bent. She is seen carrying a lotus in her left hand while offering the right hand to Shiva. Do not fail to notice a diminutive Nandi jumping joyfully between the couple! To the left of Paravati is her father Himavan who is carrying a kamandala in his raised hand and is about to solemnize the wedding by pouring water on the hands of the couple. Brahma is seen sitting in front of the sacred fire performing various rituals. 
When I first visited the temple, the murals covered with years of dirt and soot were hardly visible in the dark interiors of the place. Thankfully a careful restoration has brought them alive now, even though some details have been lost. Unquestionably they are the finest examples of mural paintings of the Vijayanagar period.

18/03/22, 11:58 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
18/03/22, 11:58 am - Dr Raguram: Colours play an important role in the festival of Holi. They add vitality to the festival, making it one of the most vibrant of celebrations. Each of the colours is deemed to have a symbolic significance. Blue for instance is the colour of Krishna's complexion and also of the sky and the oceans. 
And colours are the smiles of nature.
Birds are beautiful jewels in the sky. There are many brightly coloured birds in the world, and the most flamboyant ones are the parrots. During our birding sojourn in Australia, Ahalya and myself saw some of the most multihued parrots, prominent among them being the Rainbow Lorikeet. 
Rainbow Lorikeet, definitely deserves its name! True to its name, one can see all the colour palettes of rainbow in its feathers. Its head is deep blue with a greenish-yellow nuchal collar, and the rest of the upper parts (wings, back, and tail) are green. The chest is orange/yellow in colour. The belly is deep blue, and the thighs and rump are green. Their species name, haematodus, comes from the Latin word for blood, and is a reference to the rich red found on its breast.
The colour of the feathers of birds serves various functions; thermoregulation, climatic adaptation and a fine balance between sexual signalling and camouflage. Birds need to balance being attractive to potential mates while having some kind of camouflage against potential predators. When hunted from above, the Rainbow Lorikeet blends with the foliage of the trees with its green back. It has been suggested that the colourful patches confer evolutionary advantage in courtship and mate recognition. 
Rainbow lorikeets have two unique features. They possess a tongue with brush-type tissues helping them to collect nectar and pollen. The other distinctive feature is their agile legs which help them to hang upside-down and feed on bottlebrush flowers. It is a dazzling sight when flocks of them fly with the rays of the sun streaming through their gorgeous plumage!
On the occasion of Holi, in the words of Maya Angelou, let us “Try to be a rainbow in someone’s cloud.”

07/04/22, 11:02 am - Dr Raguram: Each of the lecture theatres in JIPMER were named after a historical medical luminary and their portrait used to be displayed outside. Every time I entered theatre Bernard I used to be fascinated by a painting which depicted him in a deeply reflective mood. Claude Bernard was an exceptional man. He posited that there is a delicate balance between physiological processes within the human body and the environment outside of it. He termed them as ‘milieu interior’ and ‘milieu exterior’. He drew attention to how physiological mechanisms are crucial in maintaining constancy of the internal environment to sustain a status of health in response to changes in the external environment.
Understandably over the years medical professionals have focused their attention on the internal environment to preserve individual health. Unfortunately, in the process, the crucial role of the environment in which we are immersed everyday in our lives and its vital role in modulating individual health has been lost sight of.
On the occasion of the World Health today and on the background of looming climate changes, it is imperative to remind ourselves that climate crisis is health crisis. Our health is intricately related to health of the planet and we should strive to make every effort to conserve and protect the Mother Earth.

09/04/22, 11:36 am - Dr Raguram: Navratri is celebrated in different seasons, five times a year across our country. They are Chaitra Navratri, Ashadha Navratri, the Sharada Navratri, and the Paush/Magha Navratri. Of these, the Sharada Navratri heralds the onset of autumn and the Chaitra Navratri the season of spring. Today is the date of Shukla Paksha Ashtami of Chaitra month, also referred to as Maha Ashtami, dedicated to Goddess Durga.
One of the outstanding depictions of Goddess Durga slaying the demon Mahishasura is at the 13th century Hoysala temple at Somanathapura. The Devi is seen triumphantly standing on top of the he buffalo that appears to have fallen on the ground. Mahishasura is seen emerging from the body of the buffalo. If you look carefully, you can notice Mahisha’s intestines coming out of his stomach! Standing to the left of the Goddess is her vehicle, a partly broken lion, which is seen killing an asura. Even though some of the arms Goddess Durga are missing or broken, the vigour and vitality in depiction is a tribute to the sculptor Mallithamma, who sculptures adorn many Hoysala temples.

23/04/22, 9:58 am - Dr Raguram: Indian Coral Tree is among the earliest flowering trees in spring and is extremely colourful and picturesque. It adds colour to the skyline with its conspicuous vibrant red coloured flowers. When in bloom the coral tree is like an aviary, attracting numerous bird species like this Golden Fronted Leaf Bird here.

03/05/22, 10:26 am - Dr Raguram: Basavanna whose birthday is today, was a revolutionary saint and an ardent social reformer. He composed vachanas in simple language, which are very thought provoking. This particular one translated by AK Ramanujan is my favourite.
He outlines as to how various parts of a temple are analogous to several body parts and a temple is the primordial template of the human body. Though the rich may construct temples to show their wealth and power, Basavanna highlights that our body is itself is a temple which houses the immortal god. 
The last lines: things standing shall fall, but the moving will ever stay, is so prescient. A temple built with stones and mortar might fall but the immortal spirit will move on, not confined to the physical space.
Words from a thousand years ago never ring more true now….

05/05/22, 7:58 am - Dr Raguram: Dedicated to Lord Cheluvanarayana Swamy or Thirunarayana, Melukote is a small but beautiful temple in Mandya district, Karnataka. On the occasion of 1005th birth anniversary of Sri Ramanujacharya, let us explore his association to this place.
Sri Ramanujacharya was one of the most important exponents of the Sri Vaishnavism tradition and spent major part of his life at Srirangam.  To avoid persecution, Sri Ramanujacharya had to leave the place and after travelling along the course of Cauvery, he reached Thondanur, a flourishing centre of Jain theology, ruled then by the Hoysala king Bitti Deva. Bittideva, a Jain king of the region became his ardent disciple and in the process, changed his own name to Vishnuvardhana. According to the legend one day Sri Ramanujacharya was running short of the white sand to put a holy mark on his forehead. That night, Lord Tirunarayana came in his dream and instructed Sri Ramanujacharya to go to Melukote where he would find the white sand as also a deity of Lord Tirunarayana. After intense search, the deity of the Lord Tirunarayana was found near an anthill and a temple was erected over the it, over time. 
Prior to this, there was an old temple in Melukote which was destroyed by invaders who plundered its wealth and also took away the Utsavamurthy, ‘Cheluva Pillai’ to Delhi. Lord Tirunarayana once again appeared in Sri Ramanujacharya’s dream and instructed him to bring the deity back to Melukote. He travelled to Delhi and found that the idol was with the king’s daughter who was treating the deity as her spouse. When she came to know that the idol was about to be taken away from her, she could not bear the separation and travelled back to Melukote along with it. After reaching Melukote, she started meditating in front of the temple as she was not allowed inside. Noticing her intense devotion and dedication, Sri Ramanujacharya allowed her inside and she merged with the Lord. Sri Ramanujacharya installed an idol of Bibi Nachiyar which is worshipped along with the main deity, even today.
This legend is remarkably parallel to that of Tulukka Nachiyar in Srirangam. 
These narratives inform us that in spite of instances of intense interfaith crises, there have always been moments of remarkable synergy in our history.

16/05/22, 8:19 am - Dr Raguram: On the Buddha Purnima day, it is interesting to note that all the important events in his life were associated with trees. He was born under a sal tree and he experienced his first deep meditation under a rose-apple tree. Years later, his enlightenment took place under a Bodhi tree and he attained Mahaparinirvana lying between two mighty sal trees. Buddha considered a kind person to be like a banyan tree, growing along road side offering respite and succour to the tired traveller with its cool shade. 
This panel in Sanchi portrays a banyan (Nyagrodha) tree with a throne beneath (representing Buddha). For several weeks after attaining the enlightenment, Buddha was hesitant and diffident to make known The Truth to the world. Then Brahma, Indra, the four Lokapalas (Regents of the Four Quarters) and the archangels of the heavens approached him and implored him to expound his revelations. The four figures side by side in the foreground are the four Lokapalas. The nyagrodha tree symbolizes the principle that a seemingly insignificant cause can produce a great effect, just as the tiny seed of the nyagrodha develops into an sprawling tree.
Nyagrodha also figures in an interesting narrative in the Chandogya Upanishad.  Uddalaka a great saint sent his son Svetaketu when he was twelve, to the ashram of a renowned teacher for studies. Svetaketu was a bright boy and in twelve years, he mastered all scriptures that could be taught. Seeing a man proud of his knowledge, his father asked him, “Do you know that by knowing which all can be known? That which cannot be taught but can only be known?” He asked the boy to get a fruit of the Nyagrodha tree, cut it open, and remove a seed. He then asked him what he saw. “Nothing” the boy replied. “That is the subtlest essence of all. That essence that you do not perceive, from that arises the big tree. That essence is the reality. That essence is the Spirit of whole universe. That which cannot be explained or taught but by knowing which you know all there is to know.”. Then the Sage took his son in to his arms and whispered this great truth in to his ear, “You are THAT, Svetaketu. Tat Tvam Asi
Religious orientations and teachings may differ but the search for ultimate reality stems from the underlying interconnectedness of individual and universal consciousness. 
As Thich Nhat Hanh commented perceptively about this quest, “The mind can go in a thousand directions, but on this beautiful path, I walk in peace. With each step, the wind blows. With each step, a flower blooms.”

18/05/22, 6:24 am - Dr Raguram: I lose myself in a museum!
Whenever we trave,l we make it a point to savor the museums of the place, leisurely.
As you stroll through a museum, it becomes part of your, somehow.
Museums are places of discovery and learning. Visit to a museum often is a part of a student’s life from early days, abroad. It is a wonderful sight to see children milling around the exhibits curiously, while being briefed about them by their teachers.
Less said about the status of museums in India, the better. There is an overwhelming sense of neglect in many of them, with some notable exceptions. The exhibits are often displayed haphazardly with poor lighting with little information about them. Gallery walks are a rarity in most.
Madhya Pradesh Tribal Museum at Bhopal is an outstanding example of how a museum should be! Designed by Revathi Kamath, pioneer of mud architecture in India, it is a series of aesthetically designed colorful galleries that offer interesting and informative insights into the rich cultural heritage of various tribes of the region. One can spend hours amidst the beautifully lit artifacts and exhibits. 
Take a walk through this museum at: https://photos.app.goo.gl/eh4ChAvfXt72BMRJ7
Incidentally today is the International Museum Day!

20/05/22, 7:20 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
20/05/22, 7:20 am - Dr Raguram: The third friday in May is considered as the Endangered Species Day, to draw attention to threatened species and the importance of protecting them. It was established by David Robinson and the Endangered Species Coalition in 2006. 
One of the critically endangered bird species in India is the Great Indian Bustard. Once in the running to become India’s national bird, it is literally fluttering for survival. Its prime habitat, the grasslands are being slowly denuded due to various industrial projects. The Great Indian Bustard is considered among the largest flying birds in the world and because of its large size they usually take low flights which often bring them fatally in touch with overhead power lines. Even though the Supreme Court had stipulated that the power lines need to be taken underground, the progress has been very slow as companies continue to violate the order. The situation is not helped by the presence of feral dogs which eat the bustard’s eggs and also attack the young ones. Earlier found across several states of India, the numbers have dramatically declined over the years, especially in peninsular India.  
It was a most privileged moment for me, sometime ago, to see a male strolling across, with its held high, in a grassland. As I was watching it intently, I failed to notice the female, who sauntered across gently. Soon both of them disappeared in the vast grassland and to my great surprise and joy they mated! That moment continues to remain alive in my memory.
Sadly when I visited that habitat again, not a single GIB was there.
With less than hundred Great Indian Bustards in the country and their alarming decline over the years, it is real possibility that they may become extinct in the future. 
As we ravage their habitat
And let the grasslands dwindle
This gracious bird
Will just cease to be…

22/05/22, 1:51 pm - Dr Raguram: There is profound beauty in the vast, arid landscape of The Little Rann of Kutch. Its incredible biodiversity supports an astonishing range of flora and fauna, many of them unique to the region. The International Biodiversity Day today, draws attention to the crucial role of biodiversity in maintaining a healthy ecosystem. 
An important native member of the ecosystem of the Little Rann of Kutch is the Indian wild ass. In Kutchi language, the Indian wild ass is called ghorkhar. It is the only region in India where they live in the wild, one of the main reasons being that unlike donkeys and horses, it was never successfully domesticated. Groups of them graze nonchalantly unmindful of the scorching heat amidst patches of grasslands. They are notoriously shy and quickly bolt with amazing speed, once they spot an inquisitive human observer! Seeing herds of these majestic creatures sprinting across the parched land with streaks of dust in their wake is an unforgettable sight!

24/05/22, 8:37 am - Dr Raguram: The day began with this beautiful song, Dwaitamu Sukhama, Advaitamu Sukhama, wherein Saint Thyagaraja expresses the dilemma faced by many seekers. 
Dwaita and advaita offer two very different answers for the fundamental question of all philosophy: what is the nature of the world and that of the internal self? Dwaita claims that there are fundamentally two entities, jIvAtma and paramAtma, with the internal self being jIvAtma and the external world being a multi-faceted manifestation of paramAtma. Advaita posits that there is but only the paramAtma and the internal self is also a manifestation of the paramAtma. 
They are often positioned as two different, dissimilar paths.
An elegant, insightful perspective is provided in a verse from Ashtavakra Gita.
kva dharmaḥ kva ca vā kāmaḥ kva cārthaḥ kva vivēkatā |
kva dvaitaṃ kva ca vā(a)dvaitaṃ svamahimni sthitasya mē || 19-2 ||
For me, established in my own glory, there is no religion, 
sensuality, possessions, philosophy, duality or even non-duality.

25/05/22, 8:31 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
25/05/22, 8:31 am - Dr Raguram: On this World Otter Day, I recollect my first sighting of the smooth coated otters in the backwaters of Chimmony. It was a glorious evening with the setting sun framing the backwaters with brilliant hues and as we were cruising along in a boat, suddenly I noticed a group of otters, just in front of us.  They were barking like dogs at us with khar kharr sounds. Neer-nai as they are often referred to as, might appear drab brown at a casual glance.  But these sleek little water-wanderers were graceful as they ambled along the crevices of the rocks. Some were coming out of the water with their snouts just visible, making waves of whirls in the calm water. A group of them swiftly emerged out of the crevices and were staring at us, upright! We spent a few minutes watching them before they quietly slinked away. 
These Smooth Coated Otters are closely related to the Giant Otters of South America and are Asia’s largest otters. They are highly social and are often seen in packs. They mostly feed on fish (more than 90% of their diet is fish) and that makes them quite unpopular among fishermen. However, trained smooth-coated otters are often used by fisherman to herd fish into nets. Unfortunately, their population is threatened by loss of wetland habitats, poaching, and contamination of waterways by pesticides. 
Otters
Glide amidst the rocks
Straight into my heart…

05/06/22, 8:22 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
05/06/22, 8:22 am - Dr Raguram: As we usher in another World Environment Day, it is a sad and stark fact that the health of our environment is not in good shape. A slew of factors ranging from global warming to deforestation have left their impact on an already fragile planet.
The campaign this year focuses on "Living Sustainably in Harmony with Nature." 
A little bird has been practising this quietly, for centuries…the Barn Swallow!
Barn swallows have always been linked to people, even adapting former nesting grounds in caves and cliff faces for manmade structures and living harmoniously with the humans. In many parts of the world, having Barn Swallows nesting on one's property is considered a sign of good fortune. Unfortunately, scores of them were slaughtered for their feathers in the Victorian era for decorating ladies’ hats. Concerned with this practice and the decimation of the birds, George Bird Grinnell wrote his famous editorial in ‘Forest and Stream’ in 1886 opposing it. That editorial led to the formation of the Audubon Society and the advent of the conservation movement in the United States. 
These twittery, flittery birds love to eat the insects that we consider pesky. They consume 60 insects in an hour which can even go up to 850 per day. That's how much each bird eats. Working efficiently as effective pest control agents they do their bit silently to maintain the environment.
Let this diminutive bird inspire us on this day!
As Shakespeare wrote, “True hope is swift and flies with swallow’s wings.”
05/06/22, 2:15 pm - Nalini N R: Yes Sir. Each one of us will have to take the responsibility. But man has become so self centered being in the city unlike tribals who consider environment as their God!
08/06/22, 8:39 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
08/06/22, 8:39 am - Dr Raguram: On the World Ocean Day, let us recall that life on earth probably began in hydrothermal vents in the depths of the oceans. But it was not the ocean we know today. It was warmer, more acidic and rich in iron. As life evolved, the oceans continued to provide home to many living things. In fact, a greater number of organisms live in the oceans than on land.  Covering more than 70 per cent of the earth’s surface, they are humanity’s most important natural resource. Oceans feed us, regulate our climate and generate most of the oxygen we breathe. 
Unfortunately, they also face major threats: global climate change, pollution, habitat destruction, invasive species, and a dramatic decrease in ocean fish stocks. These threats to the ocean are so extensive that more than 40 percent of the ocean has already been severely affected and no area has been left untouched. 
The World Ocean Day is a timely reminder to develop a shared vision of a sustainable use of oceans. 
As for me, the ocean with its enormity and mystery, has always been a continuing source of enchantment. There is no music more relaxing than the rolling of ocean waves.
My most memorable trip along the ocean was in California highway 1. It is perhaps one of the most astoundingly scenic roads in the world. Smelling the salty and briny sea breeze of the Pacific Ocean, seeing its vastness and feeling so small in the middle of its quiet stillness…these are emotions only the ocean can stir.
Poets capture these moments beautifully, like in these words of Meena Alexander, “Sometimes the syllables of poetry  well up, waves on the surface of the sea, and they  burst as flying fish might, struck by light.”
As TS Eliot wrote in Four Quartets, “The river is within us, the sea is all about us, ” and we have to tend to both with sensitivity and concern…

09/06/22, 8:28 am - Dr Raguram: Sunset has always inspired poets.
Poets of the Sangam era (300 BCE to 300 CE) were no exception. Sangam literature contains 2381 poems in Tamil composed by 473 poets, It includes Tolkappiyam, Ettuthogai, Pattuppattu, Pathinenkilkanakku, and two epics, Silappathikaram and Manimegalai.
Kalithogai is part of the eight anthologies (Ettuthogai), It contains one hundred and fifty poems which were written by various authors. This particular one was written by the poet Nallanthuvan. 
அகல் ஞாலம் விளக்கும் தன் பல் கதிர் வாய் ஆகப்

He has an unbounded and immortal presence across Tamil Nadu, inspiring intense devotion. A god who fosters multiple narratives, each and every community, has a story about their own divine ancestry featuring Lord Muruga.
Some of the earliest sculptural depictions of young Lord Muruga is in the Somaskandamurthy panels
which can be seen in the first freestanding temple in Tamil Nadu, the Kailasanatha Temple in Kanchipuram.

17/06/22, 7:04 am - Dr Raguram: காக்கை சிறகினிலே நந்தலாலா
நின்றன் கரிய நிறம் தோன்றுதையே நந்தலாலா
In the black colours of the crow 
I have a glimpse you Nanda (Krishna)
These are the opening lines of “Kaakai Siraginile,” one of the most beautiful poems of Mahakavi Bharathiyar. It is a simple octet with references to a crow’s feather and a tryst with fire in the quest of Nandalala, the young Krishna. As with most poems, a direct translation doesn’t do justice to the nuances of the song itself. 
Why did the poet choose the crow? 
Crows are generally considered scavengers and generally not portrayed in good light. As someone known for raising his voice against social injustice, was Bharathiyar implying that even in such creatures, he sees the divine nature of Krishna. Was he also indicating that people can see Him everywhere in nature?
The poem embodies the eternal truth that the seeker can perceive the presence of the formless in all its forms.

18/06/22, 8:29 am - Dr Raguram: Paul McCartney who is turning 80 today is a favourite singer of mine.
Shortly after returning from India where he was learning the art of Transcendental Meditation, he wrote "Blackbird" which was featured in the ‘White Album.’ I keep listening to this tranquil guitar ballad often. This song was written solely by Paul McCartney. However, he acknowledged the role of John Lennon and hence the song goes under the name Lennon-McCartney.
Paul wrote this song on the background of the civil rights movement in US. The black bird in the song refers to a group of black students who faced racial discrimination in Little Rock Central High School Arkansas. As he said later, “This was really a song from me to a black woman, experiencing these problems in the States. Let me encourage you to keep trying, to keep your faith; there is hope.’”
It is a song of empowerment, reflecting the singer’s longing for change. 
No matter how dark our circumstances may be, there is always a glimmer of hope to be found.. 
Blackbird fly, blackbird fly
Into the light of a dark black night

21/06/22, 7:46 am - Dr Raguram: Among all yoga asanas Vrksasana or tree pose is one of the most beautiful and serene one imbued with symbolic significance. It is also one of the oldest known yoga poses and is depicted in ancient sculptures.
An earliest representations is in “Bhagiratha’s Penance” or “The Descent of the Ganges” in Mahabalipuram which is dated to the 7th century. Bhagiratha stood in Vrksasana for one thousand years which persuaded Brahma and Shiva to create the Ganges.
In the first photograph one can notice a man standing on top left in the Vrksasana pose. Interestingly on the bottom right is a cat with a similar pose. Probably the cat is pretending to be a peaceful yogi fooling the mice (seen at its feet) before it eats them!
The second photo which portrays the asana in detail is from a pillar in the Thirukurungudi temple. It is slightly different from the former with one leg in Ardha Padmasana (Half-Lotus) and hands in Anjali Mudra (prayer position).
Symbolically, the tree is said to be strong and well grounded. It grows both upwards and downwards, ensuring stability. The grounding action of the standing leg represents the roots of a tree, and the stretching of the arms overhead represents the branches reaching upwards. It is believed that when one holds the pose, prana (life force) goes up facilitating the release of a transformative energy. 
Dualities vanish
If, for a moment
We become a tree…

When he plays his flute and takes hold of my heart

I remembered that yesterday was the World Music Day.
Lord Krishna is inseparable from his flute and the lure of his music is irresistible.
One of the most beautiful depiction of this is in the Chitra Gopuram of Thirukurungudi temple in Tirunelveli district.
Carved with exquisite detail, it portrays Lord Krishna holding the flute with his two hands with shanku and chakra on the other two hands. The sages, devatas, cowherds, people, animals and birds are totally entranced by the mellifluous music emanating from the flute. The snake at his feet is no exception. The sculptor animates the scene by portraying a mischievous monkey stealing butter from the cowherd!
There is a beautiful story about how Radha is jealous of the flute because it is always with the Lord. Once she asks the flute, “what is it that you have which I lack, that he is always with you?" The flute replies: "Perhaps he likes me because I am empty."
When we empty ourselves, the lord enters and fills that space.

The wind was sculpting millions of fine sand particles to form tantalizing shapes with remarkable patterns. 
Every sand particle brushing against my hands was an experience.
As Rachel Carson commented “in every grain of sand there is the story of the earth.”
I can still feel those grains of sand in the hour glass of my memory….

04/07/22, 8:21 am - Dr Raguram: As humans we have the privilege to express ourselves through our speech. On many occasions we find that a simple gesture of the hand can express our thoughts equally well and perhaps much better. 
Specific hand gestures that symbolize and convey various meanings are referred to as Mudras. Mudra Vidhanam, written by Anna and published by Ramakrishna Mutt lists at least 137 mudras. When a sculptor creates a deity, he adds various mudras to express the idea symbolized by it.
For instance look at these images. First one is from Gangaikondacholapuram and the second from the bronze gallery from Chennai museum. You will notice the gesture of the right hand, where the forefinger is joined with the thumb and the other three fingers remain separate. This is often referred to as Chinmudra. 
The thumb represents Brahman because without the thumb the hand cannot function. The middle, ring and the small finger represents the body, mind and intellect respectively. Index finger represents the ego because it keeps pointing at others most of the times! When we hold our hand normally the index finger is attached to the other three fingers and is far away from the thumb. This indicates that we normally think of ourselves as the body, mind and intellect, separate from the Brahman. As long as we have this notion, we will have a beginning and an end. When the index finer (ego) separates itself from the body/mind/ intellect and unites with the thumb (representing the Brahman), it forms a circle, which has no beginning and end. It symbolizes the union of the jivatma with the Paramatma, which is the essence of all realisation. 
Some symbols convey the deeper meanings with sublime simplicity…

11/07/22, 10:05 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
11/07/22, 10:05 am - Dr Raguram: Nikola Tesla, whose birthday today was a remarkable genius. He gave us alternating current, wireless radio, x-rays, radar, hydroelectric power and transistors.  Yet he is the most under-rated inventors of modern history.
Like many creative prodigies, he also experienced synaesthesia, in which stimulation of one sensory pathway leads to automatic, involuntary experience in a second sensory pathway. In Tesla’s case it was auditory to visual. When a word was spoken to me, the image of the object it designated would present itself vividly to my vision.
There were some oddities in his life, like the preoccupation with number three, amongst others.
One of the fascinating encounters he had was with Swami Vivekananda who was keen that one day “the Vedantic cosmology will be placed on the surest of scientific foundations”. Fascinated with the Vedic cosmology, Tesla began using the Sanskrit words akasha (all-pervading material of the universe) and prana (energy) to describe mass and energy in his work. However, he was unable to prove empirically a unified primal energy beyond akasha and prana. 
In his own words, “In the Universe there is a core from which we obtain knowledge, strength and inspiration. I have not penetrated into the secrets of this core, but I know that it exists.”

12/07/22, 8:26 am - Dr Raguram: The mango season is on the wane and having savoured it, sweet memories linger on..
Absence of simplicity in life is akin to a mango without its sweetness. 
All too often, we fritter away our lives in pursuit of the tangible. Simplicity is about minimizing our needs and maximizing the meaningful aspects of life. When a mathematician tries solve a difficult problem, he first frees the equation of all impediments and reduces it to its simplest terms. Like wise to simplify our lives we need to distinguish the necessary and the real from the clutters of the material world in which we are immersed.
Many illustrious people have explored the terrain of simplicity, the most prominent of them being Henry Thoreau. He went to the Walden Pond to learn what were the “true necessaries of life”. He recorded his experiences spread over a decade in journals which were later compiled in the book Walden. 
Often Thoreau sat on the banks of the Walden Pond reading Charles Wilkin’s 1785 translation of the Bhagvat Gita. In his own words, “In the morning I bathe my intellect in the stupendous and cosmogonal philosophy of the Bhagvat Gita…” This particular verse from Chapter 17 draws attention to the significance of simplicity. 
मन: प्रसाद: सौम्यत्वं मौनमात्मविनिग्रह: |
भावसंशुद्धिरित्येतत्तपो मानसमुच्यते || 16||
Serenity of thought, simplicity, silence, self-control, and purity of purpose are the austerities of the mind. 
Today is also the birth anniversary of Thoreau which is celebrated as the World Simplicity Day.
It is probably a perfect day to pick up Walden and remind ourselves that pursuit of simplicity in life need not be a distant dream.

14/07/22, 9:36 am - Dr Raguram: Yesterday was Guru Purnima and it is not mere coincidence that it was also the day in 6th century BCE when Buddha delivered his first sermon after his enlightenment at Bodhgaya. It is recorded as the Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta, which means "The Setting in Motion of the Wheel of Dharma." It took place in the Deer Park at Varanasi to the group of five ascetics, namely Kondañña, Assaji, Bhaddiya, Vappa, and Mahānāma. 
In this sermon, the Buddha outlined the core conceptual framework of Buddhism. He began with the doctrine of the Middle Way, which emphasizes that the path to enlightenment lies between extremes of self-indulgence and self-denial. Then Buddha explained the Four Noble Truths, which are: Life is dukkha, dukkha is driven by craving, there is a way to be liberated from both and that way is the Eightfold Path. Eightfold Path encompasses: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right concentration. 
Dukkha is a Pali word is often translated as unhappiness, pain or suffering. Suffering is inevitable in our lives, it is part of our human condition. By learning to be still and coming face to face with our pain and disappointments we have the opportunity to transform ourselves.
An ancient tribal saying states it succinctly, “Before we can see properly we must first shed our tears to clear the way.”

16/07/22, 9:42 am - Dr Raguram: Much like meditation, observing nature is an act of mindfulness. In the process, a deep connection emerges which is infinitely soothing. 
It was early morning and we were the first few in the hallowed precincts of Muir Woods. As I was watching the sun streaming through the leafy branches of trees, I was reminded of the words of John Muir “between every two pine trees there is a door leading to a new way of life.” Yet at the same time it was a reminder as to how fragile our world has become. I was wondering whether there is a term that encapsulates this experience and I stumbled upon this word Ambedo.
“Ambedo is a kind of melancholic trance in which you become completely observed in vivid sensory details, briefly soaking in the experience of being alive, an act that is done purely for its own sake.”

18/07/22, 8:17 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
18/07/22, 8:17 am - Dr Raguram: The World Listening Day on 18th of July is a reminder for us to take time and listen to the sounds of nature. It honours the birthday of Canadian environmentalist Murray Schafer one of the pioneers of the Acoustic Ecology movement. The theme this year is Listening Across Boundaries.
We are incessantly immersed in sounds of nature…whether it is the rustling of the leaves in the wind, the pitter patter of rain drops on the window pane or the natural orchestra of bird calls in the morning.
As our environment changes so too the sounds. Engrossed in the random cacophony of urban living, sitting at our computers or checking our mobiles, we are inattentive to the other sounds surrounding us. 
The sounds of nature have long inspired artists be it in the realms of poetry or music. Beethoven found inspiration in nature. He loved to take walks in the countryside and take notes on the natural world he observed. The first movement of the Pastoral Symphony, ‘Awakening of cheerful feelings on arrival in the countryside,’ immediately evokes a sense of relaxation.  It's about seeing nature as a source of harmony. The second movement, ‘Scene by the brook’ evokes sounds of cuckoos and nightingales. In the third movement we hear the ‘Merry gathering of the country folk’ and the next movement heralds the onset of the storm. As the storm slowly dies down, there is the cow waltz in the last movement. Interestingly cow waltz is still played on the alphorn in Switzerland to encourage cows to produce more milk! It is not surprising then that the Pastoral Symphony was played performed at the United Nations World Environment Day as a “global statement for the preservation of nature”.
The health benefits of exposure to sounds of nature has been extensively documented. For instance, Stephen and Rachel Kaplan spent twenty years exploring the impact of natural sounds and in their Attention Restoration Theory, or ART, proposed that this can help us improve our focus and ability to concentrate. 
Listening is a way of being in the world and feeling the vibrations of nature opens up an entirely new world of enriching experiences.
Next time you take a walk, listen deeply and immerse yourself in the serenity of the sonic landscape of nature. You might hear the melodic chirping of a lone bird sitting on a tree branch.
As the Chinese proverb states, “Keep a green tree in your heart and perhaps a singing bird will come”.   
Listen
To the sounds of nature
The whispers of the wind
Waves lapping the shores
Chatter of the sparrows
Flutter of the birds
And the silence in between…

22/07/22, 8:12 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
22/07/22, 8:12 am - Dr Raguram: Our brain is a mysterious jungle and there have been many remarkable people who have ventured into its enigmatic trails, providing us with valuable insights.
On the World Brain Day, let us remember Santiago Ramon y Cajal, the father of neuroscience who was also an aspiring artist. Armed with a rudimentary microscope which he bought with his savings, he set out to disentangle and catalogue the brain’s neuronal wildlife. He drew what he saw through the lens with delicate precision, offering tantalizing glimpses about the inner workings of the nervous system. His efforts were rewarded with the Nobel Prize along with Camillo Golgi. Where Golgi only saw an impenetrable jungle, Cajal was able to parse each tree with detail. 
An interesting research revealed that Nobel Laureates were more likely to have arts and crafts hobbies than Royal Society and National Academy members. It may be that such activities offer endless opportunities for creative explorations both inside and outside the scientific realm. His work has often been compared to that of Andreas Vesalius, the Renaissance physician whose exquisite drawings of his own anatomical dissections revolutionized medicine. Cajal’s immense artistic skills similarly led him to profound insights into brain development and function, most of which have stood the test of time.
Cajal was also a prolific writer and wrote more than 200 books including science fiction!
His advice to young researchers was simple, “Any man could, if he were so inclined, be the sculptor of his own brain.”

25/07/22, 9:09 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
25/07/22, 9:09 am - Dr Raguram: The landscape of Corbett is quite magical. One can spend hours amidst the vast grasslands, gently undulating hills, marshy depressions and riverine belts. It is the oldest national park in the country and is named after Jim Corbett whose birthday is today.
Corbett was a hunter with a heart. He tracked and killed 19 tigers and 14 leopards which were responsible for slaying around 1,200 people, without suffering even a scratch! He would mostly work alone, venturing into the jungles with his faithful dog Robin by his side. He also wrote six books which offer fascinating accounts of his trysts with the wildlife. His ‘Man eating leopard of Rudraprayag’ is exciting narrative of a leopard that spread terror killing more than hundred people. Apart from being an account of the relentless pursuit of animal for more than a year, it also offers rich insights into lives in the Garhwal region. It is an ode to the people who inhabit the terrain and the resilience with which they face the hardships that assail them. On the highway to the town,  there is a tree by the side of the road where one can find a notice which reads: “This was the tree on which Jim Corbett sat and shot dead the Man Eating Leopard of Rudraprayag in 1926.”
Corbett died on April 19, 1955, days after finishing his sixth book, Tree Tops. A year later, the state of Uttarakhand renamed the national park he helped found as Jim Corbett National Park. In addition to the national park that bears his name, there’s a species of endangered Indochinese tiger, Panthera tigris corbetti, that bears his name.
In spite of his prowess as a hunter, Corbett was a naturalist at heart and voiced the need for wildlife conservation in India long before it became a popular refrain. 
A child of the Kumaon region, its forests inspired his lifelong effort to protect animals and people alike.
In his own words, “The book of nature has no beginning, as it has no end. Open this book where you will, and at any period of your life, and if you have the desire to acquire knowledge you will find it of intense interest, and no matter how long or how intently you study the pages, your interest will not flag, for in nature there is no finality.”

27/07/22, 7:49 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
27/07/22, 7:49 am - Dr Raguram: Rajendra Chola I, one of the greatest rulers of Tamil Chola dynasty of India was born in the Tamil month of Aadi on Tiruvadirai day, which was yesterday. During his reign, he extended the influence of the already vast Chola empire up to the banks of the river Ganges in the north and across the ocean. He brought the waters of the Ganges to anoint his new capital and acquired the title ‘Gangaikonda Cholan’ (he who brought the Ganges). His navy was unmatched and sailed to kingdoms that are now Malaysia, Maldives, Indonesia and Cambodia. Through his naval victories he controlled the maritime trade in the Indian Ocean. During the course of his reign, he defeated Mahipala, the Pala king of Bengal and Bihar, and to commemorate his victory, built a new capital called Gangaikonda Cholapuram. It was to be the capital for about 250 years. Here, Rajendra built a majestic temple Gangaikonda Choleeswaram. It is a glorious representation of Chola architecture and is a rich repository of some of the most exquisite sculptures one can ever set eyes upon. 
For instance, as one ascends a long flight of steps leading to the sanctum, on the right side, carved in a large niche is a beautifully carved sculpture of Siva, Parvathi and Chandesa.  Siva is adorned with intricate jewels with his immense locks of hair resembling a crest. To his left is Parvathi, with a jewelled crown. Both have one leg folded up. Below them is the devotee Chandesa. Siva is in the process of winding a garland of flowers around Chandesa's head who, with folded hands accepts the honour. A striking feature of this panel is that the three main figures face different directions. As you walk up the stairs you realise that Chandesa is looking at you. Some scholars and historians have suggested that it could be Rajendra Chola himself who is represented here as Chandesa, sitting at the feet of Siva. 
Rajendra Chola was not merely a fearsome warrior but also a connoisseur of arts, as can be seen in this gorgeous panel and the outstanding architecture of the temple. 
Unfortunately, the legacy of Rajendra Chola remains buried in the annals of Indian history. It is only in the past few years that his legendary contributions have begun to receive the attention which they richly deserve. In honour of this pioneer maritime king, a portrait of Rajendra Chola was installed in the Mazgoan docks in 2016 and a training ship, TS Rajendra, has also been named after him.

29/07/22, 7:51 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
29/07/22, 7:51 am - Dr Raguram: There is always a surprise element in spotting a tiger.
One early morning, we were tumbling along the dust tracks in Corbett. On hearing the alarm calls of the langurs the vehicles in front of us speeded ahead. Our driver avoided the rush and took a side road. 
A brown fish owl caught my attention and when I turned my gaze away from it, there it was, sauntering nearby, ignoring our presence. The tiger sat on the ground, with the dappled sunlight on its golden coat. Slowly it lifted its head, growled, got up and bolted into the thicket. I was in a daze. Those few minutes are etched in my memory forever. 
Over the years during all our visits in the jungle, invariably we had a glimpse of the Lord of the Jungle.
The last one was at Panna. We were at Sarai at Torria and had the privilege of spending time with our host Raghu Chundawat. Raghu has been documenting and researching the lives of the big cats in Panna for decades. In 2009, the national park made headlines when it lost every single tiger due to poaching. Raghu raised the alarm, compiled a report titled “Missing tigers of Panna” and sent it to the Ministry of Environment & Forests. He had to pay a heavy price for drawing attention to the sordid state of affairs at Panna. His research permits were cancelled and he was denied entry to the Park, even as a tourist. He was accused of running a ‘hidden agenda’ by the head of Project Tiger and was probed about his possible role in poaching! The intimidation and harassment continued till a Special Investigation Team set up by the National Tiger Conservation Authority confirmed that there are no tigers left in Panna. A scientist who should have recognized for daring to speak up for the tigers of Panna found himself being systematically intimidated and harassed. Unfortunately, this is the bane of tiger conservation efforts in the country which is to a large extent bureaucratized. 
Just as the tiger returns to Panna, the reserve itself is up against a new threat: Ken-Betwa river-linking project. If implemented, it will submerge prime forest spread over 4,000 hectares and destroy 11 lakh trees. Moreover, the tiger reserve itself will be bifurcated, leaving even less forest space for the beleaguered tigers.
It was our privilege to receive the autographed copy of Raghu’s book, ‘The Rise and Fall of the Emerald Tigers’ which is based on his decade-long research in Panna National Park. It covers a vast canvas highlighting the importance of investigating and understanding the ecological needs of tigers and also drawing attention to the dark side of conservation practices in the country.
Redolent with these memories, we made our way back from Panna, fervently hoping for a larger vision about conservation of tigers which is sensitive to inspiring efforts by committed individuals and informed by research inputs.

01/08/22, 5:39 am - Dr Raguram: Moby Dick is a multi-layered novel in which Herman Melville (whose birthday is today) handles several themes. One salient refrain is the story of man's attempt to defeat nature. Nature itself is personified through the white whale, one of the sea’s greatest marvels. They are a part of nature themselves. Any act of violence against them becomes an act of violence against nature as well. If nature is a thing of wonder that should be treated with great respect, its creatures should be treated in the same manner. 
Finally, the sea takes down the men aboard the ship and the elusive Moby Dick slips away.  Nature continues to carry on as it has for the past several thousand years, regardless of those who attempt to control or destroy it and the final sentence of the novel resonates with this message: “Now small fowls flew screaming over the yet yawning gulf; a sullen white surf beat against its steep sides; then all collapsed, and the great shroud of the sea rolled on as it rolled five thousand years ago.” 
William Turner was a sublime artist of the sea and painted a series of seascapes. Herman Melville was fascinated by his paintings. It is said that shortly before writing his maritime masterpiece, he travelled to England and saw some of Turner’s paintings. Aspects of Moby Dick are strikingly evocative of Turner’s style.

மழையே மழையே மண் புறம் பூசி உள்ளாய் நின்று
மெழுகு ஊற்றினாற் போல் ஊற்று நல் வேங்கடத்து உள் நின்ற
அழகப்பிரானார் தம்மை என் நெஞ்சத்து அகப்படத்
தழுவ நின்று என்னைத் ததைத்துக்கொண்டு ஊற்றவும் வல்லையே?
Rain, pouring rain
My dazzling lord
Lives encased in clay
Molten wax within.
Can you rain down
And wash away the clay?
To melt my heart
With his radiant embrace

" It is an insightful comment about understanding the lives and tribulations of the marginalized ‘other’, who continue to face discrimination and oppression across various structural inequalities.

04/08/22, 8:41 am - Dr Raguram: Shelley whose birthday is today was not merely a talented poet. He was much ahead of the time in championing the cause of vegan diet for a sound mind and healthy body. He was also the man who first propounded the idea of massive, non-violent protest as the most appropriate and effective response to authoritarian oppression. 
In his short life, he wrote some of the most dazzling lyrical poems. I am particularly fond of the poem, “To a Skylark”. One day while walking in Italian countryside with his wife Mary, Shelley heard the melodious notes of the skylark. In the poem consisting of 24 stanzas, he describes the grace and beauty of the skylark's birdsong. He addresses the bird directly and praises the purity of its music, which is later contrasted with sad, hollow human communication. It is quintessentially an ode to the unmatched splendours of the natural world. Interestingly, Shelley uses the phrase "harmonious madness" referring to the beauty of the song of the skylark. He asks the bird to teach him “half the gladness / That thy brain must know,” for then he would overflow with “harmonious madness,” and his song would be so beautiful that the world would listen to him, even as he is now listening to the skylark.
This photograph is of a graceful Rufous Tailed Lark with a stanza from the poem.

06/08/22, 11:14 am - Dr Raguram: Flowers have a habit of blooming in the most unexpected of places…which we may not even notice.
Sometimes a poet pauses, observes and reflects on it as Alfred Tennyson (whose birthday falls today) does in his poem ‘Flower In A Crannied Wall.’
It is a short six line poem in which he muses on the connection between man, god and the cosmos. He visualizes man as flower, god as the root of the flower and the wall as cosmos. He wonders whether by plucking the flower from the wall, one can fathom its roots and understand all of its deep connections. 
The poet suggests that even the tiniest creations of the universe, those that could be found anywhere, are part of the whole of creation. Through honing the ability to understand every aspect of it, one can unravel the mystery of our connection to the divine and the cosmos.
Essentially anything , any object, no matter however mundane it may be, when truly and mindfully experienced, opens up a doorway to enlightenment.

07/08/22, 9:09 am - Dr Raguram: Yesterday I had posted about Tennyson’s quest to ‘understand’ the connection between man, god and the cosmos through plucking a flower in the roadside and exploring its roots.
Can one experience that connectivity merely by ‘looking’ at a flower?
Basho who is revered as the greatest of Japan’s haiku poets observes a nazuna flower (sheperd’s purse) blooming by the wayside on a hedge and writes:
When I look carefully
I see the nazuna blooming
By the hedge!
He is content merely to "look" to sense the deep mystery of the flower. Immersing oneself through contemplative observation of an ordinary flower and pondering over its beauty, one could unravel the mystery of creation. In the process, the distinction between ourselves and nature breaks down. We become one with the universe and a reassuring sense of harmony and connection with the world permeates our consciousness. A state often referred to Eutierria.  
British naturalist and environmental writer Michael McCarthy wrote eloquently about such experiences, “There can be occasions when we suddenly and involuntarily find ourselves loving the natural world with a startling intensity, in a burst of emotion which we may not fully understand, and the only word that seems to me to be appropriate for this feeling is Joy.”
Let us reclaim and discover our joyous belonging to the natural world . . .

08/08/22, 10:55 am - Dr Raguram: Ardez is a small, quaint village located on the southern slope of the Silvretta alps, in the midst of lush meadows. It is an outstandingly well preserved village with typical Engadine houses. These houses have massive walls with deep set windows and archways. What makes them unique are their playfully decorated facades. These are referred to as Sgraffiti, which is derived from the Italian “sgraffiare” (to scratch). Beautiful patterns, drawings are engraved on the walls and many of them are exquisitely painted too. We spent several hours savouring each nook and corner of this charming village.
And on a corner of an old house was this cat staring straight at us. 
Cats have provided the inspiration for an incredible range of fiction, memoir and poetry. TS Elitot for examples, was a ‘cat man’. He owned many during his life and gave them various funny and outlandish names. He wrote ‘Old Possum’s Book of Practical Cats’ which outsold his magnum opus ‘The Waste Land’! When you notice a cat in profound meditation,
The reason, I tell you, is always the same:
His mind is engaged in a rapt contemplation

09/08/22, 12:47 pm - Dr Raguram: Libraries open up windows to the world and inspire us to explore. As Saul Bellow commented, ‘people can lose their lives in libraries’. On this National Book Lovers Day, let us remember a poet who spent his entire life as a librarian, Philip Larkin. On the occasion of the centenary of his birth today, let me share one of his poems, ‘The Trees’. 
The trees are coming into leaf
Like something almost being said;
The recent buds relax and spread,
Their greenness is a kind of grief.

Is it that they are born again
And we grow old? No, they die too.
Their yearly trick of looking new
Is written down in rings of grain.

Yet still the unresting castles thresh
In full grown thickness every May.
Last year is dead, they seem to say,
Begin afresh, afresh, afresh.
The poem consists of three stanzas with four lines each and highlights the natural cycle of nature and the cycle of life. It is about life, end of life and renewal. We grow old, but the trees have mastered the trick of looking new each year, marking the cycle of each year with a ring…

10/08/22, 1:39 pm - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
10/08/22, 1:39 pm - Dr Raguram: World Lion Day, which is today is to create awareness about one of the most majestic species to walk the earth and celebrate the animal kingdom's most beautiful and fearsome creature.
Lions have been an important symbol in various kingdoms for thousands of years and appear as a theme in all cultures across the world. As the “King of the beasts," it is a symbol of majesty, strength, courage, justice, and confidence. 
Artists have been depicting lions for millennia and the list of lions in art is endless. 
In temple architecture in India, lions figure all through history and prominently during the regime of the Pallavas.
The structural temples of the Pallavas belong to two groups: Rajasimha group (A.D. 690-c.800) and the Nandivarman group (800-c.900 A.D.). The famous ‘Kailasanatha Temple’, considered as the largest sandstone temple in the world, is the best representation of the Rajasimha group of temples, while the ‘Vaikuntha Perumal Temple’ is an example of the Nandivarman group. Lion motifs started appearing under Rajasimha, marking the beginning of a pillar design in Kailasanatha temple and it reached the zenith in the Vaikuntha Perumal Temple in Kanchipuram. This temple is a masterpiece of Pallava architecture. Most impressive and unique feature of the temple are the pillars. Each one of them has a meticulously carved lion on it. They support the enclosed passage inside the temple which have a wealth of weathered but extremely detailed wall panels. 
Lions have particularly caught the public attention of late, thanks to their representation over the new parliament building. The lion represents the Buddha, formerly Shakyamuni, a member of the Shakya (lion) clan. With their mouths open, the lions seem to convey the message of dharma and the Four Noble Truths.
A timely reminder in these times…

12/08/22, 8:01 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
12/08/22, 8:01 am - Dr Raguram: Elephants played a crucial role in military, political and cultural history of India.
On this World Elephant Day, let us recall their role in warfare.
The Mahabharata mentions the use of elephants in battle, though chariots were the preferred vehicle of the elite warriors. Almost every ruler in India had an army of elephants and used them effectively in battles. There are vivid descriptions of their role in the battle field. Arthashastra of Kautilya provides plenty of information on elephants, their training and conduct in wars. 
With heavy armour to protect them, elephants were trained to trample the enemy and stab soldiers with their tusks which were armed with special blades, called elephant swords. Sometimes these elephant swords were coated with poison to make them even deadlier. During a charge, elephants would slash to pieces whomever they came in contact with. In some instances, the war elephants had an iron chain with an iron ball at the end attached to their trunk to kill enemy soldiers. 
At one sweep elephants could get rid of enemy foot soldiers, scare away horses, and trample chariots. There was also the practice of intoxicating elephants as inebriated elephants could cause much more panic and break enemy formations with ease.  The Chalukyas of Vatapi were well known for their use of drunken elephants to wreak destruction on the enemy troops. Only males, especially if they were sixty years old were used in the battle. The armies didn’t raise war elephants, they hunted them in the wild, tamed and trained them.
Innovative methods were employed to scare the elephants in the battle. It was found out that the elephants were afraid of the high-pitched squealing of the pigs. To make sure that they squealed louder, they were coated with tar, resin, or oil, set on fire and despatched towards the enemy elephants!
With the advent of artillery and muskets on a larger scale, the use of war elephants decreased over time. However, they continued to be used to carry the royalty and commanders into battle.
This mural in Thiruppudaimaruthur portrays war elephants in the  'Tamirabarani battle' which took place in 1532 at Aralvaimozhi Pass, near Thovalai in Kanyakumari district between the King of Travancore, Bhoothala Veera Udaya Marthanda Varma and Emperor of Vijayanagara,  Achyutadeva Raya.

16/08/22, 1:32 pm - Dr Raguram: As we celebrated 75 years of India’s independence yesterday, another exceptional event escaped our attention. It was also the 150th birth anniversary of Sri Aurobindo, the revolutionary turned mystic. 
The decisive moment in his life was when he was incarcerated in the Alipore bomb case. Spending a year in solitary confinement, he experienced a series of spiritual awakenings. Deeply influenced by these, his life’s trajectory changed. On the strength of an 'Adesh' (Divine command) from above, he moved to Pondicherry. In his words, “Pondicherry is my place of retreat, my cave of tapasya”. Yoga that strived for personal salvation was not for him. He sought the unity with the outer along with the exploration of the inner through his ‘integral yoga’
The core of Sri Aurobindo’s political philosophy is that the state exists for the individual and not the individual for the state. He commented, “The government is for the people. It must provide for stability as well as progress. Stability may be achieved by unity and co-operative action, and progress by free individual growth. The government should be run by people who are selfless, unegoistic, scrupulously honest and capable. Their allegiance should be to the whole country; they should serve the interests of the whole country and not of any party. 
A timely reminder!

17/08/22, 9:00 am - Dr Raguram: Today is the birthday of Ted Hughes who was the Poet Laureate of England. 
Ted Hughes has been fascinated with the forces of nature, the world of animals and wrote number of poems exploring them. 
Notable among them is the ‘The Hawk Roosting’. It is a powerful poem about a bird of prey as it sits overlooking its domain. The poem gives voice to a natural predator as it meditates on its innate nature, waiting fiercely for his prey.
I sit in the top of the wood, my eyes closed.
Inaction, no falsifying dream
Between my hooked head and hooked feet:
Or in sleep rehearse perfect kills and eat.

The convenience of the high trees!
The air's buoyancy and the sun's ray
Are of advantage to me;
And the earth's face upward for my inspection.

My feet are locked upon the rough bark.
It took the whole of Creation
To produce my foot, my each feather:
Now I hold Creation in my foot

Or fly up, and revolve it all slowly -
I kill where I please because it is all mine.
There is no sophistry in my body:
My manners are tearing off heads -

The allotment of death.
For the one path of my flight is direct
Through the bones of the living.
No arguments assert my right:

The sun is behind me.
Nothing has changed since I began.
My eye has permitted no change.

19/08/22, 9:27 am - Dr Raguram: The Krishna Janmashtami marks the birth of Lord Krishna. Lord Krishna was the eighth incarnation of Lord Vishnu and was born as the eighth son of Vasudev and Yashoda on the on the eighth (ashtami) day in the month of Bhadrapada. The Vishnu Purana and Bhagavata Purana have lengthy descriptions of the story of his birth.
The life of Lord Krishna has been a source of perennial inspiration to the poets and the artists in India and he is portrayed in numerous paintings and sculptures in many parts of the country. Depictions of Lord Krishna vary greatly across time period, region as well as styles.
One of the most outstanding sculptural  representation of events from Lord Krishna’s life can be seen in the Amruteshwara temple at Amruthapura in Karnataka. It is one of the oldest known Hoysala temple and is an outstanding representative of Hoysala architecture. Ruvari Mallitamma, the great architect of the Hoysala dynasty, is said to have started his career as a sculptor here. It is a small temple and the exterior wall of the mantapa has panel sculptures depicting scenes from Hindu epics and legends. If one walks in a clockwise direction, he can notice twenty-five small panels portraying various events in the life of Lord Krishna in meticulous detail. This one depicts baby Krishna being placed in a cradle. 
Sri Tallapaka Annamacharya composed a lovely song Uyyala Balunuchedaru, describing gopikas placing the baby Krishna in the cradle.

The Bright Blue Bird
A bright blue bird
From a distant tree
Flies into my house
When it flies out
It leaves behind
Its bright blue
The blue hops down
becomes first one word,
and then, another,
till finally, it assumes the face of a poem
Before long, the floor is an upside down blue sky
and the blue of the poem has made its way
into my ink filler,
into my notebook.

30/08/22, 5:35 am - Dr Raguram: Among all the gods in the Hindu pantheon, Lord Ganesha is truly an exception. His iconographic representations span a large oeuvre. He ca be portrayed sitting, standing, dancing, with astounding variations. However, amidst the varied representations, his depiction with an elephant head and human body has remained consistent. Elephant head symbolises Jnana Shakti (knowledge, wisdom) and the human body is an icon of Kriya Shakti (creative energy in action). 
Lord Ganesha urges us to make optimal use of these qualities in our everyday lives.
This sculpture of a joyous Ganesha is from a small corner of the gopuram at Arulmighu Azhagianambi Rayar Thirukovil at Thirukurungudi.

04/09/22, 7:31 am - Dr Raguram: Krishna Janmashtami is closely followed two weeks later by the birthday of Radha, which is celebrated today.
The inseparable love and affection between Radha and Krishna is symbolic of the eternal striving of a devout mortal for the Divine.
“Atma To Radhika Tasya”: She is the soul and energy that resides in Krishna.
The love between Radha and Krishna has been immortalised by poets, musicians, painters and writers.
Jayadeva’s Gita Govinda is an important text that describes their relationship in exquisite detail.
For instance in act seven song fourteen verse 17, he narrates the feeling of Radha when Krishna casts a glance on her:
dayita-vilokita-lajjita-hasitä
bahu-vidha-küjita-rati-rasa-rasitä
käpi madhuripuëä
“The glance of her beloved incites a bashful laughter in her, Tasting the ambrosia of love, she murmurs like a cuckoo, voicing her pleasure with a sudden surge of ecstatic euphoria”.
 Very many schools of painting have rendered such scenes with stylistic variations. 
Thousand of Radhakrishna paintings adorn galleries and museums across the world.
Each one of them is sheer visual poetry.
This particular mural is from the Ram Gopal Poddar Chhatri in Ramgarh in the Shekhawati region of Rajasthan.

09/09/22, 7:20 am - Dr Raguram: Queen Elizabeth II died “peacefully” at her home at Balmoral Castle yesterday. Human mortality is a poignant moment. 
Tolstoy took up the challenge of exploring it in his novella ‘The Death Of Ivan Ilyich”. 
It is a lyrical account of a man in the throes of impending death. Tolstoy narrates the fear, the denial, the pain, the pity, and the inevitability of death with much sensitivity. Ivan Ilyich finally looks death in the eye and that direct confrontation destroys the terrible fear which had tormented him all along. 
“Where was death? What death? There was no fear, because there was no death. 
Instead of death there was light.
“So that’s it!” he suddenly said aloud. “Such joy!”
‘The Death Of Ivan Ilyich’ is one of the most profound meditative works of literature ever written about the end of life.
The story of Ivan Ilyich is deeply relevant for insightful palliative care.
Incidentally today is Tolstoy’s birthday

11/09/22, 8:45 pm - Dr Raguram: Today is the death anniversary of one of the greatest Tamil poets, Mahakavi Bharathiyar.
The first All India Writers Conference took place in Madras in the 1960s. My mother was a key member of the organizing committee. As a young boy I moved around the venue, taking autographs of all the writers from across the country. Among them was the historian RA Padmanabhan, who was solely responsible for documenting Bharathiyar’s life and works. He took the autograph book from me and wrote in his beautiful handwriting, “Bharathiyai Padi”, meaning Read Bharathi. I was totally inspired by this and began savouring and discovering the remarkable writings of this great poet, over the years.
Though subject to tremendous inner tribulations, Bharathi sought and perceived harmony in all his life experiences. Nature in all her manifestations was an abiding source of inspiration for him which he narrated in many of his works.
For Bharathi, not only human beings, but even common birds like crows and sparrows were representatives of Cosmic Consciousness. He wrote:
Kakkai Kuruvi engal jaathi - neel 
Kadalum malaiyum engal koottam
Nokkum thisaiyellam naam andri vaerillai 
Nokka nokka kaliyaattam
(Crows and sparrows are our fellows,
The sea and the hills are our kinsmen.
Wherever I look, I find none but myself, 
Mere looking around brings boundless joy)
My quest to fathom the vast creative outpourings of this remarkable poet continues unabated…

12/09/22, 4:45 pm - Dr Raguram: Yesterday I wrote about how Mahakavi Bharathiyar sought to glimpse the cosmic consciousness through a crow in his poems.
Ikkyu was a beloved  figure in Japanese Buddhism. On one occasion when he was meditating in a boat, he heard the call of a crow and realized the ever elusive enlightenment. 
He was a renegade Zen monk, much ahead of his time. Once he was walking in a town’s streets in his monk’s robes, carrying a long red sword. He was an incongruous sight. When asked what he meant by his act, he responded, “This is a wooden sword; it cannot cut. The priests that run rampant in this world are like my wooden sword here…handsome fakes that are utterly useless”.
If only we realise that wisdom…

13/09/22, 5:51 pm - Dr Raguram: Today is Roald Dahl Day, a special day to remember the prolific author who wrote scores of children's books. 
He was incredibly creative and came up with more than 500 new words such as Oompa-Loompas and scrumdiddlyumptious and the Oxford University Press even came up wit a special dictionary of his imaginary words!
I particularly like his book Matilda', which was later made into a movie. It is about an exceptionally talented, precocious little girl, who is, unfortunately, was never properly recognised by her parents. Amazingly self-motivated, she explores ways of quenching her thirst for knowledge. She was a voracious reader and a dreamer. 
As the author remarks, “The books transported her into new worlds and introduced her to amazing people who lived exciting lives. She went on sailing ships with Joseph Conrad. She went to Africa with Ernest Hemingway and to India with Rudyard Kipling. She travelled all over the world while sitting in her little room in an English village”. 
The books conveyed a reassuring message to Matilda that she was not alone in a largely uncaring world.

15/09/22, 8:30 am - Dr Raguram: Today is the birthday of the talented Nigerian writer Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie.
Last year I chanced upon a slender book of hers, ‘Notes on Grief“. Her father died suddenly when the COVID-19 pandemic was raging across the world. It is a searing, reflective account by the author as she struggles through the most unsettling of human experiences, grief.
Often we find it difficult to say the right words and express our feelings to offer succour to those in throes of grief. As the author comments evocatively, “you learn how much grief is about language, the failure of language and the grasping for language”.
Grieving is both a public as well as private act and there have been many poignant personal memoirs about it. These have created spaces where people can share their experiences freely and openly. They are not accounts of  “the stages of grief “ which professionals are accustomed to, but intimate, organic responses to loss. Grief is a kinetic mixture of love and pain. The process of mapping the contours of these experiences can often be therapeutic. It is a passage to another state of ‘being’ in the journey of life. 
That said, grief doesn’t disappear…it reverberates deeply within, all through our lives.
As WS Mervin wrote:
Your absence has gone through me
Like thread through a needle.
Everything I do is stitched with its color.

17/09/22, 8:10 am - Dr Raguram: Today is Ken Kessey’s birthday. He was a maverick who was adept in donning various hats. He was a wrestler, a set designer, writer and an enthusiastic propagator of psychedelics. 
His forays into the interior landscapes of the mind began when he volunteered at a hospital to be a subject of experiments with psychomimetic drugs. There was a dramatic change in his explorations when he took a job as a night attendant in a psychiatric ward of a big hospital. Watching the patients there convinced him that they were locked into a system that was the very opposite of therapeutic, and it provided the raw material for his magnum opus ,''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest.''
It is a truly remarkable novel which offered insightful accounts of institutionalisation and its psychological impact. It was later made into a popular movie that won many Oscars. However Kessey was not happy with the production and refused to watch the film. 
I am particularly drawn to this passage in the novel:
“You got to understand that as soon as a man goes to help someone, he leaves himself wide open.”
The encounter between a client and the therapist is not a one way process. Invariably the tumultuous emotional turmoil of the client leaves its footprints on the therapist too. In order not to feel overwhelmed and helpless, the therapist has to acknowledge and be aware of it as the impact might play out in their personal lives and in therapy too. In order to be helpful, the therapist must acquire the capacity to locate himself/herself in two parallel realities: the personal and the professional lives and their demands.
Therein lies the necessity and importance of personal supervision for the therapists…
