21/09/22, 8:38 am - Dr Raguram: Today is the birthday of Leonard Cohen, one of the most passionate songwriter and musicians.
His was an extraordinarily turbulent life. Depression was his lifelong nemesis. Treatments were of little help. After reading Balsekar’s book, ‘Consciousness Speaks’ he came down to Bombay and stayed on for a year, meeting him everyday. At the end of his stay, the depression lifted miraculously and in his own words, “There is a crack in everything. That’s how the light gets in”
Though I like many of his songs (who can forget Suzanne!”, ‘Bird On The Wire’ has a particular appeal for me. It was written during his early years, while he was staying on the Greek island of Hydra. During this period, he fell in love with Marianne Ihlen and theirs was a tempestuous relationship. It was not easy living and the town had no electricity amongst other problems. When the government finally installed the necessary infrastructure, the wires stretched across Leonard Cohen’s windows. As Marianne Ihlen recounted, “While we’re sitting there, birds were landing on the wire like notes on a music sheet.” She brought Cohen his guitar and he began to compose the song that became one of his greatest successes.
After they’d been together for eight years, the relationship came apart, bit by bit, “like falling ashes,” as Cohen put it. Later in her life Marianne was diagnosed to have cancer.
Hearing about it, Leonard Cohen wrote a poignant letter:
“Well Marianne, it’s come to this time when we are really so old and our bodies are falling apart and I think I will follow you very soon. Know that I am so close behind you that if you stretch out your hand, I think you can reach mine. And you know that I’ve always loved you for your beauty and your wisdom, but I don’t need to say anything more about that because you know all about that. But now, I just want to wish you a very good journey. Goodbye old friend. Endless love, see you down the road”.
In her last hour her friend held Marianne’s hand and hummed “Bird on the Wire,” as her life slowly ebbed away…

22/09/22, 7:48 am - Dr Raguram: During the 1960’s Chennai underwent a long drought. There was no rain for a couple of years consecutively and as a result the entire city was in the grip of acute water scarcity. It was a tough period when people were desperately trying to get even a bucket of water. I distinctly recall getting up early and trying to get some water from the handpump. An hour of effort would fill two or three buckets of water. Water was a precious, elusive commodity and our everyday lives were woven around it. 
This was the setting for one of the greatest of Tamil novels, Thanneer (water), written by Ashkomitran whose birthday falls today. He narrates with much  sensitivity people's endless search for the elusive water. They wait in long queues bearing insults to get some water. The officials pay scant attention to their travails, digging up roads and linking drain water pipes with drinking water pipes in the process. It is ironic that the main character of the novel is named Jamuna, one of the most polluted rivers in India. Chennai was veritably a wasteland akin to the Sangam landscape, Paalai. The author wonderfully juxtaposes the crisis for water with the lives of three women who are struggling to overcome injustice in their own individual lives. 
At a personal level I could connect with the novel deeply and have had long conversations about it with the author who was a close family friend.
Water is a key element for human survival and I wonder whether we will end up not very far in a similar situation and plight as narrated in this novel.

23/09/22, 8:50 am - Dr Raguram: Ramdhaari Singh Dinkar whose birthday falls today, was a doyen of Chhayavadi literature in Hindi. He was a poet of rebellion and his poetry was infused with ‘veer rasa’. Greatly influenced by Rabindranath Tagore, he translated his works to Hindi. When he received the Jnanpith award,Harivansh Rai Bachchan wrote that he should get four Jnanpith awards - for poetry, prose, languages and for his service to Hindi. 
In his ‘Sanskriti ke Chaar Adhyay’, he wrote that despite various cultures, languages and topography, India stands united, because "however different we may be, our thoughts are one and the same".
He was truly a man ahead of his times and in ‘Samar Shesh Hai’, he wrote:
“Kumkum? Lepun kise? Sunaun kisko komal gaan?
Tadap raha aankhon ke aage bhookha hindustan,
Sakal desh mein halaahal hai, Dilli mein haala hai.
Dilli mein roshni, shesh Bharat mein andhiyala hai”
(“To whom should I sing sweet melodies?
The nation is starving in front of our own eyes.
The whole country is churning the poison, while Delhi is enjoying its wine.
Darkness is prevailing in the whole country while Delhi shines”)
When I was looking for an English translation of his poetry, came upon an excellent translation of his poem, ‘Parichay’, and have quoted a few lines from it which appealed to me,in my photograph…

25/09/22, 8:12 am - Dr Raguram: Colour is all around us and plays a crucial role in paintings. In figurative art where the subject matter is recognizable from the real world, they are employed to complement and enhance their representation. What if there’s no element of figures in a painting?
Decades ago when I was strolling through the National Gallery of Art in London, I walked into a room where there was a large painting of rectangles in brilliant hues, alternatingly radiant. A woman was sitting, totally engrossed in the painting with tears rolling from her eyes. I gingerly stepped out of the room without disturbing her.
Several days later, I went again to the museum and sat in front of the painting. The large canvas was suffused with a delicate yet powerful luminosity. Slowly my eyes soaked in the colours which seemed to percolate deeply within. It was an experience beyond words, beyond language. It was akin to a meditative state when the chatter of the mind quietens and there’s an inexplicable stillness.  
In the words of Sogyal Rinpoche,  “Our true nature could be compared to the sky, and the confusion of the ordinary mind to clouds. Some days the sky is completely obscured by clouds. When we are down on the ground, looking up, it is very difficult to believe there is anything else there but clouds. Yet we only have to fly in a plane to discover a limitless expanse of clear blue sky. From up there the clouds we assumed were everything seem so small and so far away down below”
Sharing a painting of Rothko on his birthday…

26/09/22, 7:28 am - Dr Raguram: Our lives are long journeys of explorations, many of them in unexpected, uncharted territories. In our sojourns, we confront and negotiate the great imponderables like the meaning and purpose of life, the inevitable end of life and the mystery of what lies beyond. In each of these encounters we come close to ourselves and discover things anew.
TS Eliot, whose birthday falls today, expressed this succinctly in the poem, ‘Little Gidding’, which forms part of the “Four Quartets”.
He wrote:
“We shall not cease from exploration
And the end of all our exploring
Will be to arrive where we started
And know the place for the first time.”

30/09/22, 7:29 am - Dr Raguram: The poet WS Merwin whose birthday is today, had a spiritual connection with nature, especially in his later years. On the last day of the world
I would want to plant a tree
what for
not the fruit
the tree that bears the fruit
is not the one that was planted
I want the tree that stands
in the earth for the first time
with the sun already
going down
and the water
touching its roots
in the earth full of the dead
and the clouds passing
one by one
over its leaves

Prayers of many summers come
to roost on a moment

and they resume their journey
flying by night
with the sound
of blood rushing in an ear

04/10/22, 6:08 am - Dr Raguram: During Navarathri, Shakti is worshipped in her three manifestations. The first three days are for the worship of Mahakali (power of performing activities), Lakshmi is venerated during the next three days and the last three days are dedicated to Saraswathi, who symbolises the power of knowledge. Saraswathi, supreme icon of wisdom and the arts, is often depicted seated, holding a veena in her hands. Raja Ravi Varma’s painting of a seated Saraswathi can invariably be found in many Indian homes.
Sculptural representations of Saraswathi dancing are comparatively infrequent and are often found in the temples of the Hoysala period. This particular one is from Chennakesava temple at Somanathapura. Intricately chiseled, it exudes innate beauty and grace. The Goddess is seen dancing with one leg planted on the ground while raising the other one, bent at the knee. This is referred to as the urdhvajanuchari pose. She is holding an eka tantri veena in her hands and the ornamentation is detailed and exquisite. She is dancing to the beats of the drummer who can be seen in the lower right corner. Since the material used was soft chloritic schist stone, some of the details have been lost with vagaries of time, made worse by uncaring visitors who rub their hands over it with sheer disdain.
Dynamic, creative energy seems to flow from every inch of this visual interpretation of  Goddess Saraswathi.
In the words of Mahakavi Bharathiyar…
குலவு சித்திரம் கோபுரம் கோயில்
ஈதனைத்தின் எழிலிடையுற்றாள்
இன்பமே வடிவாகிட பெற்றாள்
In beauteous paintings, temple towers
She manifests
As an epitome of joyful grace

05/10/22, 8:13 am - Dr Raguram: The salient myth associated with Vijayadasami is that of the Goddess vanquishing the demon Mahishasura. It is interesting to note that Brahma, Vishnu and Shiva combined their powers to trounce the demon who had been granted his wish that he would not be annihilated by a male of any species. However he never thought that a woman would be capable of defeating him. But this underestimation of the power of women turned out to be his downfall. 
This myth is a pointer to the inherent, underestimated and unacknowledged energy of the feminine spirit. Moreover it draws attention to the fact that the ‘evil’ often resides within us and it is imperative to address and annihilate it.
This sculpture is from the temple at Gangaikondacholapuram. In contrast to many fierce depictions of the Goddess, one can perceive the tranquil expression on her face after she subjugates and decimates the demon.

07/10/22, 7:56 am - Dr Raguram: Considered as the ‘great voice of Victorian England,’ Tennyson had a troubled legacy. He was subjected to trenchant denunciations by literary critics during his lifetime. It impacted his mental health and ailing from depression, he lamented: 
“When in my youth the growls!
In mine age the owls! 
After death the ghouls!”
But his works had considerable public appeal. When he died on October 6th 1892, scores of people applied for tickets to his funeral in Westminster Abbey.
Tennyson built upon the foundations of Romantic poets and shared their reverence for nature. He commented ,“Words, like nature, half reveal and half conceal the soul within.”
Artists often use Tennyson’s poetry to inspire their works. I found my muse in a corner of a garden which aptly embodies these words of his…
“Flower in the crannied wall, 
I pluck you out of the crannies, 
I hold you here, root and all, in my hand, 
Little flower—but if I could understand 
What you are, root and all, all in all, 
I should know what God and man is.”

10/10/22, 7:33 am - Dr Raguram: Libraries figured prominently during my formative years. I accompanied my writer mother whenever she visited them (which was quite often), for her reference work. I used to enjoy climbing up the ladders just to feel the leather bound old books stacked in tall shelves in the cavernous Connemara Library.
RK Narayan (whose birthday is today10th October), captured that experience quite eloquently. He wrote “faint aroma of gum and calico that hangs about a library is as the fragrance of incense to me. I think the most beautiful sight is the gilt-edged backs of a row of books on a shelf. The alley between two well-stocked shelves in a hall fills me with the same delight as passing through a silent avenue of trees. The colour of a binding-cloth and its smooth texture gives me the same pleasure as touching a flower on its stalk.”
During my school days, the stern looking librarian would silently hand over RK Narayan’s books which I used to read and reread many times. Swami and friends kept me company on many afternoons.
Later in life, RK Narayan commented on issues of topical interest. For instance, he remarked, “If someone should ask, ‘how should an Opposition function?’, the best answer would be, ‘in the manner of a traditional mother-in-law who watches the performance of household work by a daughter-in-law and follows her about with her comments.”
That kind of mother-in-law seems elusive now!

12/10/22, 10:24 am - Dr Raguram: Sometimes  in the morning I sit on the deck, looking at this Buddha, listening to the sonorous rendering of Mahaparinibbana Sutta which describes the last days of Buddha. Though the recitation is in Pali, an all pervading sense of peace transcends the lyrics.
 In his teachings Buddha emphasised the concept of Nibbāna, a Pali word for the extinguishing of a fire. A burning fire clings onto its fuel. When it extinguishes, it lets go of it, merging into the cosmos, reaching a state of unbounded freedom. 
Buddha elaborated this analogy further in his Addittapariyaya Sutta, commonly known as the Fire Sermon, when he addressed his disciples:
“And what is all that is burning? Bhikkhus, the eye is burning, visible forms are burning, visual consciousness is burning, visual impression is burning, also whatever sensation, pleasant or painful or neither-painful, nor pleasant, arises on account of the visual impression, that too is burning. Burning with what? Burning with the fire of craving, with the fire of hate, with the fire of delusion; I say it is burning with birth, ageing and death, with sorrows, with lamentations, with pains, with griefs, with despairs.”
Though the imagery is stark, Buddha draws attention to how  suffering is caused by these sensory inputs which fill our minds and hearts with simmering fires of desire and hatred. The quest in life is to quell these fires and find peace within.

13/10/22, 7:47 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
13/10/22, 7:47 am - Dr Raguram: My tryst with Buddhist thought and teaching continues…
Over the years, I have been drawn to the teachings of Thich Nhat Hanh.
Caught in the throes of the Vietnam war, he was in a dilemma. Should he confine himself to the monastery and practice meditation or go out and help people? He decided to venture outside and assist people in distress and also be mindful in doing so. This transition from introspection to action laid the foundation for the practice of  ‘Engaged Buddhism’.
He outlined fourteen precepts of Engaged Buddhism. Two of them in particular have made a deep impression on me. To begin with, truth has to be found in life and not through conceptual knowledge. It is important to engage and learn throughout life by observing within and becoming aware of oneself. The other one is to be cognizant of the existence of suffering in the world and explore ways of attending and redressing it. He articulated his thoughts about the reality of suffering perceptively in his book, No Mud No Lotus, ““If you know how to make good use of the mud, you can grow beautiful lotuses.”
Thich Nhat Hanh also drew attention to how mindfulness can increase our awareness about Mother Earth. “People usually consider walking on water or in thin air a miracle. But I think the real miracle is not to walk either on water or in thin air, but to walk on earth. Every day we are engaged in a miracle which we don't even recognize: a blue sky, white clouds, green leaves, the black, curious eyes of a child—our own two eyes. All is a miracle.”
These words resonate within whenever I take a stroll and observe the beauty and mystery around me.
Thich Nhat Hanh (whose birthday was on 11th October), opened a vivid personal window of awareness for me…

15/10/22, 8:04 am - Dr Raguram: Hindi poet Suryakant Tripathi Nirala died on this day in 1961.
He gave voice to the marginalised sections of the society in his works. In a poem titled, “Wah Todti Patthar” he narrated the torment of a woman breaking stones for a living. This has been  translated into English by another poet, Arvind Krishna Mehrotra. There is also another version by the historian Romila Thapar. 
BREAKING STONES
Beside a road in Allahabad,
I saw her
       breaking stones.
 
No tree to give her shade,
A dark skin,
Firm, tightly-cupped breasts,
Eyes fixed on the ground,
Thoughts of the night before
Going through her mind,
She brought down the heavy hammer
Again and again, as though it was
A weapon in her hand.
Across the road—
A row of trees, high walls,
The mansions of the rich.
 
The sun climbed the sky.
The height of summer.
Blinding heat, and the loo blowing hard,
Scorching everything in its path.
The earth under the feet
Like burning cotton wool,
The air filled with dust and sparks.
It was almost noon,
And she was still breaking stones.
 
As I watched,
She looked at me once,
Then at the houses opposite,
Then at her ragged clothes.
Seeing there was no one around,
She met my eyes again
With eyes that spoke of pain<br.
But not defeat.
 
Suddenly, there came the notes of a sitar,
Such as I had not heard before.
The next moment her young body
Quivered and as sweat
Trickled down her face, she lifted
The hammer, resuming work,
As though to say,
       I’m breaking stones.
(The photo is not mine and is from the net!)

17/10/22, 8:19 am - Dr Raguram: The Elkhorn Slough near Monterey Bay in California, is a magical place teeming with wonderful birds and marine mammals.

பொய்கைப் பள்ளிப் புலவுநாறு நீர்நாய்
வாளை நாளிரை பெறூஉ மூர

துன்னலம் பெருமபிறர்த் தோய்ந்த மார்பே.
You are coming from a town where otters
Smell of sea fish that they eat everyday;
Though I might wither away in your absence, its fine
I won’t embrace the chest that hugged other women.

18/10/22, 7:49 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
18/10/22, 7:49 am - Dr Raguram: There are many schools of thought and myriad interpretations concerning Zen. 
I first read the book, ‘Introduction to Zen Buddhism’ by DT Suzuki (whose birthday is today), decades ago. This edition had a wonderful foreward by CG Jung. 
Zen differs from all other philosophical and religious meditative practices in staying clear of conjectures and presuppositions. Even focusing attention on Buddha has to be avoided as he too is an image. On the other hand, the emphasis is on the immediacy of experience that is beyond words, spontaneous and not premeditated. 
As Suzuki commented, “No amount of wordy explanations will ever lead us into the nature of our own selves. The more you explain, the further it runs away from you. It is like trying to get hold of your own shadow. You run after it and it runs with you at the identical rate of speed.” 
Often such illuminating experiences emerge from nature itself…

19/10/22, 7:26 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
19/10/22, 7:26 am - Dr Raguram: Brown Pelican is an interesting bird to watch, especially when it engages in the ‘head throw’ behaviour. It throws its head into the air while arching its back to stretch its neck and gular pouch. The pouch measures from six to ten inches in depth and is capable of holding several gallons of water. This manoeuvre is reportedly a means to maintain the health and elasticity of pouch skin, But the ‘head throw’ becomes handy when it attempts to catch a fish.   Pelicans are plunge divers and dive into the water with force. Once they catch a fish and come upto the surface, they engage in ‘head throw’ action to swallow the fish head first.
It was wonderful to observe the ‘head throw’ behaviour which lasts for just a few seconds.
As the American humorist Dixon Lanier Merrit wrote in 1913
A wonderful bird is the pelican
His bill can hold more than his belican
(This is often misattributed to Ogden Nash!)

20/10/22, 8:11 am - Dr Raguram: Kurunthokai is the second of the Eight Anthologies in Sangam literature. 
Composed between 100 CE and 300 CE, it contains works by 295 poets.
This particular verse No133 was written by the poet Uraiur Muthukannan Sathanar
புனவன் துடவைப் பொன் போல் சிறு தினை
கிளி குறைத்து உண்ட கூழை இருவி
பெரும் பெயல் உண்மையின் இலை ஒலித்தாங்கு, என்
உரம் செத்தும், உளெனே தோழி, என்
நலம் புதிது உண்ட புலம்பினானே.  
This commentary is by U Ve Swaminatha Iyer who is singularly responsible for bringing classical tamil poetry into the limelight.
கிளி உண்டமையால் கதிர் இழந்த நினைத்தாள் பெரும் பெயலுண்மையால் உலர்ந்து வாடாமல் இலை விட்டதுபோல, தலைவர் உண்டமையால் நலன் இழந்த யான் அவரது நினைத்து உயிர் வைத்துள்ளேன்
In this verse, the heroine laments to her friend:
Hilly tribes plough the land and grow golden yellow millets. Parrots eat the grains and leave the stalks denuded.Yet, when it starts to rain the half eaten stalks sprout fresh leaves. 
I am in a similar situation. I lost my maidenhood with him. Yet I live in the hope that he will come back as promised, like the rain reviving the half eaten stalks.

25/10/22, 9:19 am - Dr Raguram: Narakasura who figures prominently in the Deepavali legend has many stories associated with him. He was deemed to have been born from the union of Bhudevi and Varaha. This is a beautiful relief sculpture of Varaha and Bhudevi in the second cave at Badami.
According to the narratives from the North east of India, he was a king who ruled over Pragjyotishapura, which is modern day Assam. He was besotted with the beauty of Devi Kamakhya and wanted to marry her. The Goddess playfully put a condition on him that if he was able to build a staircase from the bottom of Nilachal hills to the temple within one night before the cock crowed to indicate dawn, then she would marry him. Narakasura accepted the condition and worked with all his might and was about to accomplish the task before dawn. When Kamakhya Devi got this news she made a cock to crow to convey the impression that it was already dawn. Angered by this, Narakasura  chased the rooster, slew it and then entered into a battle with the Devi. During the course of the battle, Kamakhya Devi revealed herself as Maa Kali. Realising his mistake, Narakasura fell at her feet and requested that he be remembered as a devotee and not as a demon after his death. Maa Kamakhya granted the same and killed Narakasura with her trident on the Chaturdasi day. The incomplete staircase is known as the Mekhela Ujua Path and is used by devotees even today, to walk to the Kamakhya temple. 
When I was reading about this, I was reminded of Led Zeppelin’s ‘Stairway To Heaven’. 
And as we wind on down the road
Our shadows taller than our soul
There walks a lady we all know
Who shines white light and wants to show
How everything still turns to gold
And if you listen very hard
The tune will come to you at last
When all are one and one is all, yeah…

27/10/22, 7:50 am - Dr Raguram: During my Commonwealth fellowship (decades ago!)I used to explore various parts of  the United Kingdom almost every weekend, thanks to the student's pass in the British Rail. The beautiful, untamed Welsh landscape had a special allure for me. During one such visit, I requested my student who was working in Carmarthen to take me to Dylan Thomas’ writing shed. We made our way along Dylan's Walk to a simple, small structure perched on the edge of a cliff. When I peered through the window, I could see some cigarette butts, empty beer bottles and paper strewn on the floor in that sparsely furnished room. The setting sun cast its light through the window, which offered a lovely glimpse of the estuary. I could imagine Dylan sitting there, looking at the landscape which he loved dearly,writing his poems. It was the place where he completed his ‘Under Milk Wood’. 
Dylan died young at the age of 39 after a heavy drinking bout complicated by pneumonia. His life and works have had a lasting impact on many. Bob Dylan changed his last name from Zimmerman in homage to the poet. One can spot Dylan Thomas (just above Marlon Brando) on the iconic cover of the Beatles’ album Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band.
Poetry opens our inner world and that is particularly true about Dylan’s  powerfully articulated poem, ‘Do Not Go Gentle Into That Night’ written on the background of his father’s ailment. It set off cascades of inner conversations within me when I was tending to the elderly in our family during their final days. I was caught in a conundrum: as a physician should I facilitate ‘rage, rage against the dying of light’ or quietly observe a life gently ebbing away. This is a predicament for everyone involved in end of life care.
On his birthday today I also wonder whether these lines have a larger canvas and ambit of impact. In the throes of unrelenting climate change, we realise that the earth we live in has a fragile existence and an uncertain future. Dylan was perhaps encouraging us to rage, rage against that  dying light.
Of course there's a lot more to rage about, these days…

08/11/22, 9:04 am - Dr Raguram: Today is Kartik Purnima. According to one of the legends (a lengthy one which I have summarised for sake of brevity), Vidyunmali, Tarakaksha  and Viryavana were three rakshasa sons of Taraka. After getting a boon from Brahma they built three cities, Tripura. They also requested that the only way they could die was if somebody could destroy all three cities with a single arrow. Brahma granted their wish.On Kartik Purnima, Lord Shiva vanquished all of them with a single arrow, putting an end to their reign. This manifestation of Shiva is called Tripurantaka. ("Tri" means Three, "pura" means cities and "antaka" means destroyer.) When the Devatas heard this, they rejoiced and declared the day as Dev Diwali, Diwali for the gods.
This is an exquisite mural in the ceiling of the Rangamantapa of Virupaksha temple at Hampi, which depicts Tripuranataka. In it, four-armed Shiva is shown in a chariot with his right leg in front and the left leg behind and raised. The left hand is holding the bow string on which the arrow is set. The right hand is holding the arrow in horizontal position, which is about to be released. Shiva is sporting a blue dhoti and his body is adorned with jewels. Behind him is a Nagini holding an umbrella and above his shoulder is a kinnar (a celestial musician, half human and half horse) carrying a bell. The sun and the moon at the top of the picture represents twilight. The Tripuras are represented with three circles. When the wheel of the chariot got stuck in the sand, it could not come out even with Lord Shiva’s efforts. In the mural one can see Lord Vishnu in the form of a bull and digging the earth to bring the chariot out.
There is a temple devoted to Tripurantaka, built around 1070 by the Western Chalukyas in Balligave town of Shivamogga district, in Karnataka state.
Incidentally I also found out that there is a cicada in India naed as Meimuna Tripurasura!

11/11/22, 7:40 am - Dr Raguram: Along with His Holiness the Dalai Lama, Thich Nhat Hanh has had a deep impact on me, personally as well as in my therapeutic work. I was also drawn to his teaching wherein he emphasized the interconnectedness of the Buddhist way of being and love of nature. According to him, even a simple act of walking mindfully can be a meditative practice. In his words:
Look again, you will see me in you and in every leaf and flower bud.
Walk and touch peace every moment.
Walk and touch happiness every moment.
Each step brings a fresh breeze.
Each step makes a flower bloom.
Kiss the Earth with your feet.
Bring the Earth your love and happiness.
The Earth will be safe
when we feel safe in ourselves.
(11th November was Thich Nhah Hanh’s birthday)

27/11/22, 8:10 am - Dr Raguram: Jekyll island with its scenic seascapes is one of the charming places in Georgia.
One day while walking amidst tall oak trees dripping with fuzzy tendrils of moss, we chanced upon a building in ruins. A small plaque outside the house mentioned it as the Horton House and offered some details about it.
William Horton was one of the earliest settlers in Jekyll island and built the house in 1736. It was built of tabby, a unique material which was commonly used along the Georgia coast during the 18th and 19th centuries. Tabby was made by burning oyster shells to create lime, then mixing it with water, sand, ash and broken oyster shells. The mixture was then poured into moulds to form blocks with which the structure was built.
Though the house has survived the American revolution, war between the states and hurricane, it is in ruins now with time scarred mould laden walls.
There is something melancholic about an abandoned house in ruins.
As I stepped into a crumbling room with a broken window, the languid rays of the setting sun shone through the trees.
In that fleeting moment, I was transported into the world of those people, long forgotten, who would have looked through that window on many evenings.
And the place came alive….

29/11/22, 7:25 am - Dr Raguram: Both Ahalya and myself are Beatles aficionados. We have a good collection of their music (as LPs!) and listen to them often.
George Harrison was the most spiritual of all the Beatles. His tryst with Eastern music and religion was kindled by Ravi Shankar. The first time he used a sitar riff was in ‘Norwegian Wood’. He read extensively. In his own words, "I had read enough from the Vivekenandas and Yoganandas, to comprehend how to see God: by using the Yogic system of transcending through the relative states of consciousness to get to the most subtle level of pure consciousness. It is at that level that the individual experiences pure awareness, pure consciousness, the source of all being…” 
His engagement and involvement in spiritual pursuits finds reflection in many of his songs. I particularly like ‘The Inner Light’. The lyrics are inspired by a section of the Tao Te Ching, written by Lao Tsu, a contemporary of Confucius. There are 81 short chapters of Tao Te Ching. "Inner Light" is the title of Chapter 47, which in translation reads as:
Without going outside, you may know the whole world
Without looking through the window, you may see the ways of heaven
The farther you go, the less you know
Thus the sage knows without travelling
He sees without looking
He works without doing
Harrison's tweaked theses lines a bit, yet essentially conveying its inherent meaning:
Without going outside of your door
You can know all things on earth
Without looking out of your window
You could know the ways of heaven
The farther one travels
The less one knows
The less one really knows
Arrive without travelling
See all without looking
Do all without doing
When George died on 29th November 2001, Ravi Shankar was by his side as verses from the Bhagavad Gita were chanted. His ashes were later immersed in the Ganges as per his wish.

20/12/22, 8:20 am - Dr Raguram: After birding around the Coyote hills, when we ventured into the Arastradero Preserve, in Santa Clara county, the call of the acorn woodpecker welcomed us. Its call was reportedly the inspiration for the cartoon character, Woody Woodpecker! The story goes that Walter Lantz, the creator of the cartoon character and his new bride, Grace, were on their honeymoon in a cabin in California. They were disturbed by a loud sound as if someone was laughing. When they went out to check, they spotted an Acorn Woodpecker, pounding away at the roof nonchalantly and Woody was born!
The terrain of the preserve was largely grassland with great old oak trees. When I saw this magnificent tree with its bare branches, I was struck by its resemblance to mysterious neural networks in our brain.
There is always something of an unknown presence embedded in such knotty tangles…

21/12/22, 10:11 am - Dr Raguram: Shab e Yalda which is ushered in tonight is one of the ancient Persian festivals. On the longest and darkest day of the year, people get together to celebrate the “rebirth of the sun”. According to an old Persian belief, sunrise the following day will remove darkness from people’s lives with its radiance. It brings together family and friends to pass the longest and darkest night of the year in good company and cheer and as a tradition, verses from two famous poets, Hafez and Sa’adi are recited on the occasion.

06/01/23, 10:49 am - Dr Raguram: On the occasion of Arudra Darisanam dedicated to the cosmic dance of Lord Siva, let me recall my visit to Banteay Srei, the jewel of Khmer Art. Each and every section of this small temple is exquisitely carved. This beautiful depiction of Aada Vallan or Dancing Siva is on the eastern side of the temple. Below him is Indira riding his Airavata, which is depicted as a monster-like figure with an elephant head. Indira (unfortunately his head is missing) is seen holding the elephant trunk on the right hand and the monster head on the left hand. The two other Airvatas are on the corners of the bas relief. On Siva’s left is a percussionist playing on the drum. On the right of Siva is a depiction of an emaciated woman, Karaikkal Ammaiyar. She was a Bhakti poet and one of the three women amongst the 63 Nayanmars, a group of saints devoted to Lord Siva. 
Sekhizhar in his monumental work ‘Periyapuranam’ narrates the story of Karaikkal Ammaiyar. She began her life as Punithavathi and was married to Paramadattan. One day Paramadattan sent two mangoes to her telling her to keep them for his lunch. An hour or so later Lord Siva came as a mendicant, begging for alms. As food wasn’t ready, Punithavathi offered him one of the mangoes. When her husband returned, Punithavathi served him the other one. When he asked for the other one, she was desperate and prayed to Lord Siva and a ripe mango fell into her palm. Finding the fruit bigger and tastier, he asked her where she got it. When she related what had happened, Paramadattan was unconvinced and asked her to procure another such fruit. Punithavathi prayed again and received one more fruit but it vanished when her husband tried to touch it. Taken aback, Paramadattan realised that she had divine qualities and deserted her. Stung by this, she left home to pursue an ascetic path and prayed to Lord Siva to release her from the shackles of the physical body. Hence many iconographic depictions of her portray her in an emaciated form. 
There is a small temple dedicated to her in Karaikkal. Every year Mangani (Mango) festival is celebrated commemorating this story. During this festival Lord Siva is taken in procession as Bikshadana with his begging bowl and people throw mangoes from the rooftops. 
Karaikkal Ammaiyar composed beautiful verses in praise of Lord Siva:
இறவாத இன்ப அன்பு வேண்டிப்பின் வேண்டு கின்றார்
பிறவாமை வேண்டும்,
மீண்டும் பிறப்புண்டேல் உன்னை என்றும் மறவாமை வேண்டும்
இன்னும் வேண்டும்நான் மகிழ்ந்து பாடி
அறவாநீ ஆடும் போதுஉன் அடியின்கீழ் இருக்க.
I pray for the infinite happiness of Your love
I do not want to be born again
If I do, I do not want to forget You forever
If I do, I want to be happily singing in Your praise
Under Your feet as You are dancing”.

07/01/23, 10:24 am - Dr Raguram: January 5th is celebrated as the National Bird Day in the USA to draw attention to the beauty and importance of birds in the ecosystem.
While birding in the Coyote Hills near San Francisco, I spotted a bird at a distance sallying in the air in a graceful way, much like a butterfly. When it settled down on a branch, I had a close look and it was Say’s Phoebe.
In Greek mythology, Phoebe was the goddess of the hunt and the moon, the daughter of Gaea and the twin sister of Apollo. I was wondering whether this petite flycatcher is called phoebe owing to its prowess in hunting insects. Instead, I gather that the name derives from the kind of sound it makes! American naturalist Thomas Sa was the first scientist to encounter the bird, at a site near Cañon City, Colorado, in 1819 and it was named after him by Charles Bonaparte, a nephew of Napoleon. They have been in the U.S. for a long time. Palaeontologists discovered Say’s Phoebe fossils in Arizona, California, New Mexico, and Texas dating back to about 400,000 years ago (the late Pleistocene).

12/01/23, 7:50 am - Dr Raguram: Haruki Murakami, one of my favourite writers, turns 74 today. His latest book Novelist as  Vocation was published in English a few months ago. A collection of essays, it was first published in Japanese seven years ago. The narrative flows in the manner of many of his novels, which are usually written in the first-person. I want to open a window in their souls and let the fresh air in. This is what I think of, and hope for, as I write—purely and simply.”

14/01/23, 10:48 am - Dr Raguram: 13th December is the last day of the Tamil month Margazhi  which ushers in the Pongal festival. It occurs on the last day of Dakshinayana, a six month cycle of the Sun’s course moving south, which is followed by a six month cycle of the Sun’s course moving north called Uttarayana. 
During Bhogi, people clean their houses, get rid of unwanted things, symbolically setting them on fire. Perhaps it reminds us that we need to give up all our negativities, and unwanted thoughts in the smouldering fire. 
Mythologically it is an invocation to a divine force, Lord Indra, "the God of Clouds and Rains' ',seeking his benevolence to bring in good rains and help the farmers. 
This is a beautifully carved sculpture of Lord Indra with Indrani on his vehicle Airavat, from the 13th century Chennakeshava temple at Somanathpua, near Mysore

19/01/23, 9:58 am - Dr Raguram: The Raven has featured in ancient stories from around the world and in almost every culture. In the book of Genesis, Noah first sent a raven from the ark to determine if the floodwaters had receded. They are perhaps one of the smartest of birds. 
Ravens have fascinated people through history. Edgar Allan Poe, whose birthday is today, was no exception and wrote the poem The Raven in 1845. Who can forget these memorable lines…
“Deep into that darkness peering, long I stood there wondering, fearing,
Doubting, dreaming dreams no mortals ever dared to dream before;
But the silence was unbroken, and the stillness gave no token,
And the only word there spoken was the whispered word, "Lenore?"
This I whispered, and an echo murmured back the word, "Lenore!" —
Merely this, and nothing more” 
This iconic poem launched him from a virtual nobody to an overnight success, but his newfound popularity wasn’t always easy for the writer. Children were known to follow him through the streets, flapping their arms and croaking like a raven. Poe’s response? Shouting “Nevermore!” at them until they ran away.
Incidentally Edgar Allan Poe was a birder!

22/01/23, 9:36 am - Dr Raguram: Lord Byron (whose birthday is today) expressed a sense of wonder and joy about nature in his poems. Born with a club foot, he was deeply uncomfortable with it and had to wear special boots to hide it. He was also a victim of childhood sexual abuse at the hands of a drunken nursemaid. For him nature was a healer; a refuge and place of shelter. 
His love of nature finds expression in Childe Harold’s Pilgrimage:
“I live not in myself, but I become
Portion of that around me; and to me,
High mountains are a feeling…
Are not the mountains, waves, and skies a part
Of me and of my soul, as I of them?
Is not the love of these deep in my heart
With a pure passion”
His own inner need for solitude finds expression in these perceptive lines…
“There is a pleasure in the pathless woods,
There is a rapture on the lonely shore,
There is society, where none intrudes,
By the deep sea, and music in its roar:”

25/01/23, 9:07 am - Dr Raguram: Virginia Woolf (whose birthday is today) had an enduring tryst with bipolar illness all through her life. In her fight against her hounding illness which she often referred to as ‘waves’, she held onto writing to prevent herself from sinking. In her own words, “One ought to sink to the bottom of the sea, probably, and live alone with one’s words.” It was a prescient observation as years later, unable to cope with the devastating illness, she filled her overcoat with stones and drowned in the river Ouse. 
TS Eliot, a close friend, persuaded her to write about her experiences with her ailments and the result was the contemplative essay, ‘On Being Ill’. She wrote it in throes of yet another ravaging bout of illness. This has been reissued in 2012 with contributions from her mother and a friend. It is an insightful narrative about travails of illness and its impact on caregivers.
She voiced her profound loneliness in these evocative words, “We do not know our own souls, let alone the souls of others. Human beings do not go hand in hand the whole stretch of the way. There is a virgin forest, tangled, pathless, in each; a snowfield where even the print of birds’ feet is unknown. Here we go alone…”

29/01/23, 9:36 am - Dr Raguram: When I was ambling along the corridors of the Durga temple at Aihole sometime ago, I noticed a sculpture of a serene, elegant, bejewelled person in a pillar. What caught my attention was a figure of a woman with legs of horse on his left. Unfortunately, her face was disfigured. At that time I was not sure of its iconographic importance.
Yesterday on the occasion of Ratha Saptami, when I was reading about the legends associated with Surya, I wondered whether this sculpture represents Surya and his wife. 
According to the legends, Vishvakarma’s daughter, Sanjana was married to Surya. After bearing him three children, she found his brilliance too oppressive and the heat unbearable. Hence she took the form of a shadow, Chhaya to take her place. Chhaya did not disclose her identity to Surya and had two sons and two daughters from him. Later when Surya realized that Chhaya was not Sanjana he was extremely annoyed and banished Chhaya away.  He went in search of Sanjana and enquired about her whereabouts with her father Vishvakarma who he told him that she was living in the forest. Surya went in search in the forest and found her in the form of a mare and united with her. 
Chhaya who represents darkness was the manifestation of Sanjana who is deemed to be the source of all conscious thought. Ignorance is darkness which is dispelled by the light of awareness.  Not surprisingly, the symbol associated with Sanjana is walnut which has a striking similarity with human brain!
There is plenty to ponder in mythology!

03/02/23, 8:52 am - Dr Raguram: World wetland day is celebrated every year all across the world to commemorate the Convention on Wetlands which was held on 2nd of February in 1971 in the city of Ramsar, Iran at the Caspian Sea coasts. The Ramsar Convention emphasizes the importance of conservation and sustainable management of wetlands. Wherever we live: city, town, village or country, we are surrounded by wetlands which are unfortunately in throes of decline due to excessive urbanisation, shrinking buffer zones and contamination. In an era of intense climate change, wetlands are like the River Styx which separated the world of the living from Hades, the world of the dead. 
It is imperative to recognize the value that wetlands add to our lives and the joy of observing the beautiful flora and fauna that they nurse.

14/02/23, 9:43 am - Dr Raguram: Sanskrit literature is replete with beautiful verses celebrating love. Most notable among them is Chaurapanchasika , a compilation fifty short lyric poems written in the eleventh century A. D. by the poet Bilhana. 
There are many versions about the origin of this work. One of them states that a king with a lovely daughter engages the famous poet Bilhana to educate his daughter. To prevent any romance blossoming between the two, he tells the princess that her guru is visually challenged and tells the guru that his student has deformities in her face. To ensure that they don’t see each other, he hangs a curtain between the two. One day while lessons were in progress, the poet is thrilled by the full moon on a cloudless sky. He breaks into a poem, and princess wonders how a blind man can sing about the moon with such brilliance. Excited, she pulls down the curtain and finds that Bilhana is a handsome young man while he finds he finds her to be a personification of female beauty. The two instantly fall in love and decide to marry, but the enraged king sentences them to death. As Bilhana is being led to his execution, he starts singing the fifty verses. Deeply moved by it, the king orders his release and formally gives his daughter in marriage.
Interestingly, in  1948, two producers made movies in Tamil based on this story of Bilhana. Unfortunately, the third version with the legendary MK Thyagaraja Bhagavathar as Bilhana was never completed as the actor was arrested.
Among many translations of this remarkable work, I find the one by Sir Edwin Arnold quite interesting. One of the verses reads: 
Still when her eyes, as lotus petals long,
Like Fortune’s  goddess lotus-born, I see,
And see her wearied by her bosom's load,
With both my arms clasping her close to me
As honey bee his darling lotus sips,
I would grow drunk on mead within her Iips.
These lines find a picturesque expression in this beautiful sculpture from Khajuraho.

18/02/23, 8:35 am - Dr Raguram: According to one of the legends, Lord Shiva and Devi Parvathi tied the nuptial knot on Mahashivaratri. Their union has a deeper connotation: Purusha (mindfulness) is represented by Shiva, while Prakriti (nature) is epitomized by Parvathi. 
This classic Shiva Parvathi sculpture is from Hoysaleshwara temple in Halebeedu. It depicts Parvathi seated on Shiva’s lap which is referred to as atikarohana. They are bedecked with intricately carved jewellery and carry different weapons and ornaments in their arms. The details are so mesmerizing, providing a three dimensional perspective. What is interesting to note is the presence of mongoose, a vahana of Parvathi at her feet. 
Composed by Adi Shankaracharya, Shiva Parvathi stotram holds a special importance amongst all Shiva Stotras. It extols the divine qualities of the god and goddess in 12 stanzas. On this Mahashivaratri day let us recall a verse from this:
नमः शिवाभ्यां पशुपालकाभ्याम्, 
जगत्रयीरक्षण बद्धहृद्भ्याम् ।
समस्त देवासुरपूजिताभ्याम्,
नमो नमः शङ्करपार्वतीभ्याम् 
Namah Shivabhyam pashupalakabhyam
Jagattrayee rakshana baddha hrudbhyam
Samastha Devaasura pujitabhyam
Namo namah Shankara Parvatibhyam 
I bow to God Shiva and Goddess Parvathi, the protectors of all beings
Who are the divine guardians of all the three worlds
The divine pair worshipped by all the Devas and Asuras
I bow to you, again and again, God Shiva and Goddess Parvathi

21/02/23, 10:23 am - Dr Raguram: In all my forays into the library during my training days at NIMHANS, I was drawn into one particular journal, simply titled as Psychiatry. Tucked between its plain yellow covers were articles that opened up my perspective into the interpersonal context of psychological suffering. One of the founders of the journal was Harry Stack Sullivan, whose birthday is today. Sullivan through his framework of interpersonal psychotherapy articulated that one’s personality and behavior has to be viewed and examined on the background of close, intimate, relationships. He felt that descriptive psychiatry failed to look beyond diagnosis and view the whole person in his/her social context. He extended this orientation to understand what was often viewed as an incomprehensible disease process, schizophrenia. This laid the foundation of the Chestnut Lodge which pioneered intensive, individualized treatment of schizophrenia. Chestnut Lodge was also the locale of the book “I never promised you a rose garden’.
Enforced isolation during the Covid era, drew our attention to the unsettling fact that loneliness can be a severely distressing state. Yet it has eluded the attention of mental health professionals. Sullivan was among the very few who attempted to examine it.  He regarded loneliness as one of the most intense and painful of human experiences and described people with schizophrenia as, “the loneliest of the lonely”.
Personally, the work of Sullivan widened my gaze beyond the veil of symptoms onto the real person shrouded behind them.
22/02/23, 8:54 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
22/02/23, 8:54 am - Dr Raguram: We are all drawn into the larger than life canvas of the Father of the Nation. Yet, we fail to notice the gentle brush strokes and fine textures that enhance its subject and the incredible person responsible for it, Kasturba Gandhi. Married at a very young age, she deftly juggled multiple roles: as a devoted wife to a demanding husband, a caring mother and a satyagrahi. It was not an easy task and its demands impacted her health significantly.
22nd February was the last day in the life of Kasturba Gandhi. She was imprisoned along with Mahatma Gandhi in the Aga Khan Palace, Poona and was not keeping good health for a while. When Kasturba realised that her end was near she said, "Do not sorrow after my death. It should be an occasion for rejoicing." Then she whispered a line from her favourite Gujarati hymn, ‘Hari no marag che shoora no, nahi kayar nu kaam jone (The path to God is for the brave to tread, not for cowards). Then she slipped into an altered state of consciousness. When he was told about it, Bapu rushed to her room. took her hand in his and asked, ‘Shun thay che, Kastur?’ In a feeble, trembling voice, Kasturba replied, ‘Shun thay che smajhatu nathi. Mare java no vakhat thai gayo.’ She rested her head on Gandhi’s chest and soon her life ebbed away. 
The next day she was cremated in the grounds of the Aga Khan Palace. Gandhi sat through the cremation till the pyre was extinguished. When someone suggested him to move away he replied, "This is the final parting, the end of 62 years of shared life. Let me stay here till the cremation is over."
When her children Devadas and Ramdas went to collect her ashes, they found to their great surprise, an intact a pair of red and green glass bangles worn by Kasturba since marriage.

23/02/23, 9:43 am - Dr Raguram: When I joined NIMHANS, my teacher Dr RL Kapur told me to read Karl Jasper’s ‘General Psychopathology’. I went over to the library to look for it. In those days, books in the library were all locked up securely in steel cupboards and the keys were with a strict looking female attender. When I requested her to look for it, she went straight to the pathology section and announced in a loud voice that there is no such book. I persuaded her to look for it in the psychiatry section and to my great relief it was there in a bottom shelf. It was the first edition, translated into English by Hoenig, who had spent a year at the All India Institute of Mental Health in 1955. It was a difficult book to read, but I gamely gave it a try over several weeks and re-read it during my training days. Later, I personally wanted to possess a copy of ‘General Psychopathology’ and finally got one in an old book shop. It has a pride of place in my collection. I was going through it today on Jasper’s birthday and was struck by its continuing relevance in the current climate of psychiatric practice. 
The main emphasis of Jasper was on a phenomenological approach to psychiatric illnesses. It is essentially a form of qualitative enquiry that emphasized experiential, lived aspects of a particular phenomenon as described by the person. In Jasper’s own words “Since we never can perceive the psychic experiences of other in any direct fashion, as with physical phenomena, we can only make some kind of a representation of them. There has to be an act of empathy, of understanding ...which comes from the patient’s own self-descriptions, which can be evoked and tested out in the course of personal conversations.” In a Jaspersian sense, psychiatric diagnosis is not a “simple question-and-answer interrogation” but a “particular observation” in the context of an empathic interaction.
Unfortunately, with the advent of the Neo Kraeplinian frameworks of diagnosis, the emphasis has shifted to ‘eliciting’ symptoms which are then straight jacketed to fit into diagnostic criteria. This has led to a robotic checklist approach shorn of insights about the experiential terrain of symptoms. The person who ultimately knows his/her experiences is the patient himself/herself. The psychiatrist’s role is to facilitate expression of this experience through a compassionate, empathic stance tinged with an attitude of curiosity.

06/03/23, 8:02 am - Dr Raguram: During our training period at NIMHANS, after receiving our monthly pay, Ahalya and myself will invariably make our way to Premier Book Shop to stock up on books. During one such visit, Shanbhag guided us through the shelves overflowing with books, picked up one and said, “Doctor, you must read this!” 
It was Gabrial Garcia Marquez’s ‘One Hundred Years Of Solitude’.
When I started reading the novel, it was much akin to sojourns in dreamscapes. To borrow a phrase from Beatles, it was a Magical Mystery Tour! Every page was suffused with intricate details, intersecting history, mythology and tradition. The lives and tribulations of the Buendia family came alive in the author’s mesmerizing narrative. 
In a memorable passage after the death of Jose Arcadio Buendia, Gabo’s writes, “When the carpenter was taking measurements for the coffin, through the window they saw a light rain of tiny yellow flowers falling. So many flowers fell from the sky that in the morning the streets were carpeted with a compact cushion and they had to clear them away with shovels and rakes so that the funeral procession could pass by.”
Yellow butterflies were one of his often used literary imagery and he used to comment that nothing awful would happen to him if there are yellow flowers around.
During his memorial service thousands of yellow butterflies made of paper were released to celebrate the life of this remarkable author. 
Today is Gabo’s 96th birthday…

07/03/23, 8:12 am - Dr Raguram: It was an unusually sultry morning and there was a long queue in front of St Peter’s Basilica in the Vatican City. Undeterred, I waited patiently behind a group of tourists from America who were chatting animatedly. As soon as I entered its hallowed precincts, I made my way straight to have a glimpse of Michelangelo’s Pieta. During his lifetime Michelangelo made three Pietas, of Virgin Mary mourning the dead body of Christ and this is the most beautiful of them all. Though Mary embracing her dead son is not explicitly mentioned in the holy book, the scene has proven to be a popular subject among artists for centuries.
Safely ensconced behind bullet proof glass, Virgin Mary was in a seated position, wrapped in robes and cradling the lifeless body of Jesus. His head was slumped back on her shoulder. When I looked at it closely, I felt that the sculpture was shaped like a pyramid, with the top of the head of Virgin Mary being its peak and the sculpture expanding to accommodate her seated legs. Her petite face with gentle demeanour exuded serene tranquillity. Michelangelo’s painstaking attention to detail and the unique treatment of the hair, the skin and the intricate folds in the fabric is a lasting testimony to his outstanding artistry.  
Pieta was the only sculpture where Michelangelo inscribed his name. Unfortunately, with the crowd milling around, I couldn’t have a close look to locate it. 
Michelangelo was a multi-talented individual who also wrote sonnets on variety of subjects. He produced hundreds of madrigals and sonnets, often putting down his chisel while at work to write down a line or two of verse.
These beautiful lines are from the sonnet titled The Model and the Statue:
When that which is divine in us doth try
To shape a face, both brain and hand unite
To give, from a mere model frail and slight
Life to the stone by Art’s free energy.
(Yesterday, 6th March was the birthday of this remarkable artist/poet)

08/03/23, 9:16 am - Dr Raguram: International Women’s Day is observed to recognize and honor the achievements of women. On this day let us recall the life and works of a remarkable woman, Elizabeth Barrett Browning. Educated at home, she wrote an epic poem at the age of twelve. Her first major work was ‘An Essay On Mind and Other Poems’ which was published when she was twenty years old. These lines from it, offer a tantalizing glimpse of her talent:
So when the pilgrim sun is traveling o’er
The last blue hill, to gild a distant shore
He leaves a freshness in the evening scene
That tells the Creation where his steps have been
Unfortunately, much like Frida Kahlo she was beset with various ailments all through her life including a spinal fracture. This was not a dampener in her creative journey and she continued to immerse herself at work, producing some extraordinary verses.
Elizabeth was not just a talented poet, she was deeply involved in addressing many forms of social injustice, such as the slave trade in America, child labour in the mines and the mills of England and the restrictions forced upon women in 19th-century society. Standards of sexual conduct were so rigid at that period in time that any woman who bore a child out of wedlock, even if she had been a victim of male aggression, was shunned and scorned by the society.  She urged that society should be more compassionate in its treatment of women who had been victims of sexual violence. Moved by the plight of children working in mines she wrote a long poem, ‘The Cry of The Children’, with these poignant opening lines:
Do ye hear the children weeping, O my brothers,
Ere the sorrow comes with years ?
They are leaning their young heads against their mothers, 
And that cannot stop their tears.
Elizabeth Barrett Browning was an extraordinary poet but she was also more than that. Hers was a voice for the oppressed and she had the courage to profess her views that went against the grains of society. 
The theme of this year’s International Women’s Day is ‘Embrace Equity’. Elizabeth Barrett Browning personified this all through her life and in her works.

15/03/23, 7:01 am - Dr Raguram: From the moment we are born, we begin our journey towards death. Understandably this prospect often evokes intense fear. It is suggested that one can negotiate this fear in three ways: through knowledge as epitomized by Nachiketa, by adopting a path of bhakti like Markandeya and by sheer power of love as symbolized by Savitri. 
During Karadaiyan Nombu which is observed today, women offer prayers for the longevity and wellbeing of their husbands and celebrate great encounter of Savitri and Yama, the God of Death. 
Savitri was the daughter of the King of Madradesha. She was exceedingly beautiful and when she reached marriageable age, though many princes admired her, none of them came forward to marry her, overawed by her beauty. Her father told her to go forth and select her own husband. Savitri visited many kingdoms but could not find the husband of her choice. On her way back home, she saw a young man in a forest serving an old couple with utter devotion. She was immediately drawn to him and informed her choice to her father. When Narada heard about it, he informed her that the young man she had chosen, Sathyavan, had a very short life and would die after a year. Savitri’s parents were shattered on hearing this and requested her to reconsider her choice. A determined Savitri married Sathyavan and went to the forest and assumed her new role with great joy. But deep within, she was afraid and could not forget Narada’s prophecy. As the day of death drew near, she began to fast and offer prayers with utmost piety. Finally, on the dreaded day, she decided to accompany her husband when he went into the forest as she did not want to be separated from him even for a short while. Yama made his appearance and starting pulling Sathyavan with his noose. To his astonishment he saw Savitri following him and asked her to return back. But Savitri said that it was her dharma to accompany her husband everywhere and she could not give it up. Pleased with her words he granted her many boons with which she restored the kingdom and eyesight of her father in law. But she still continued to follow him. Finally, impressed by her intense devotion, Yama restored the life of her husband and blessed them.  
Interestingly festivals are associated with particular type of food. Karadaiyan Nombu is no exception. On this day, a special dish ‘Karadai’ is prepared from rice flour, black eyed peas, jaggery and coconut  and it is believed that Savitri prepared this special dish and offered it with butter to Lord Yama as a thanksgiving gesture for returning the life of Satyvan.
There are few representations of Yama in sculptural form. This image is from Khajuraho and depicts a four armed Yama. His vehicle, buffalo can be seen on the lower right hand corner. If one looks carefully, one can notice a cock in his right hand. There is an interesting story behind it. One day Yama attempted to kick his mother in a fit of rage. Incensed by this, Sanjana, his mother cursed that he would have a perennial wound infested with maggots which would never heal. Heeding to his request, Surya granted him a cock which ate all the vermin in his leg. And hence the cock in his hand!

20/03/23, 9:23 am - Dr Raguram: White-crowned Sparrows are quite fascinating. They are extremely alert and they stay awake for up to two weeks during their migration. A migrating White-crowned Sparrow was once tracked moving 300 miles in a single night! It is a delightful sight to see them scuttling across the ground with their chirpy notes.
What do sparrows represent? They were associated with liberation in ancient Egypt. It was believed that they would catch the souls of the recently deceased and carry them to heaven. This was the inspiration for a while for sailors to get sparrow tattoos in the hope that the bird would catch their souls if they died at sea. 
Sparrows often have a spiritual connotation. Mahakavi Bharathiyar wrote a couple of poems on this dainty bird. Here, he urges us to let go of the chains of bondages that hold us back and liberate ourselves from the fetters that bind us…like the sparrow
விட்டு விடுதலை யாகிநிற் பாயிந்தச்
சிட்டுக் குருவியைப் போலே
May you escape from all shackles
And revel in freedom
Like this Sprightly Sparrow
(On the occasion of the World Sparrow Day)

21/03/23, 6:41 am - Dr Raguram: ‘Poetry is painting that speaks,’ Plutarch observed.
Throughout history, poets have painted their canvas with lyrical and idyllic verses.
The landscape of poetry in India is vibrant and multihued and there is a treasure trove waiting to be unearthed across languages.
On this World Poetry Day, let me share a poem by Malathi Maithri which has been translated from Tamil by Lakshmi Holmstrom.
OBSERVE THE CRANE
The crane waits
at the verge of the river-bed,
fish swimming in its memory.
In search of its reflection, the moon
wanders, vanishes.
Swirls of roots tear into the earth,
with hunger.
The wind, sweeping up its troubles,
hurls the heat in all directions.
Pulverized, the heart swirls
like dust in a storm.
It is not just the earth
that overflows through its cracks
in heat and rage.
The crane
absorbs into itself all that heat
and boils within.
If only the crane would sink into
the water swirling in its memory
and beat its wings,
the river might gather its form once more
from the scattered drops,
and walk again.
River, watch.

23/03/23, 6:23 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
23/03/23, 6:23 am - Dr Raguram: The World Poetry Day yesterday was also the birthday of a poet whom I admire deeply, Billy Collins.
He was the Poet Laureate of US and was instrumental in setting up a very interesting program, ‘Poetry 180’ for high schools. He chose 180 poems for the program which are available online and are worth a look: https://www.loc.gov/programs/poetry-and-literature/poet-laureate/poet-laureate-projects/poetry-180/all-poems/
John Constable who described himself as, “I am man of the clouds” assiduously captured nature’s most ephemeral occurrence, clouds, in over fifty paintings. These are some of the most magnificent images of clouds ever painted. In this poem, Student of Clouds, Billy Collins reflects on Constable’s cloud paintings and populates the canvas with his beautiful words. 
The emotion is to be found in the clouds,
not in the green solids of the sloping hills
or even in the gray signatures of rivers,
according to Constable, who was a student of clouds
and filled shelves of sketchbooks with their motion,
their lofty gesturing and sudden implication of weather.
Outdoors, he must have looked up thousands of times,
his pencil trying to keep pace with their high voyaging
and the silent commotion of their eddying and flow.
Clouds would move beyond the outlines he would draw
as they moved within themselves, tumbling into their centers
and swirling off at the burning edges in vapors
to dissipate into the universal blue of the sky.
In photographs we can stop all this movement now
long enough to tag them with their Latin names.
Cirrus, nimbus, stratocumulus
dizzying, romantic, authoritarian
they bear their titles over the schoolhouses below
where their shapes and meanings are memorized.
High on the soft blue canvases of Constable
they are stuck in pigment but his clouds appear
to be moving still in the wind of his brush
inching out of England and the nineteenth century
and sailing over these meadows where I am walking,
bareheaded beneath this cupola of motion,
my thoughts arranged like paint on a high blue ceiling.

30/03/23, 7:33 am - Dr Raguram: On the occasion of Sri Rama Navami let me offer you some glimpses from the Ramayana at the Amruteshwara temple in Amruthapura in Chikmagalur district. It is a small yet beautiful 12th century temple built by Amruteshwara Dandanayaka, during the reign of King Hoysala Veera Ballala II. On the south side of the parapet wall, the story of Ramayana is depicted in over seventy small panels. 
This series of panels depict an episode from Kishkinda kandam which is the fourth book and one of the seven kandams in Valmiki's Ramayana. After Shabari tells Rama about Sugreeva, Rama goes in search of him and reaches Rishimukha mountain. Seeing Rama and Lakshmana, Sugreeva feels uneasy and wonders whether they were sent by Vali and asks Hanuman to meet them (Panel 1). Reassured that Rama and Lakshmana poses no danger, Sugreeva accompanies Hanuman and meets them. After listening to them, Rama promises Sugreeva that the wrong done to him would be redressed and that he would be reinstated as the king of the Vanaras (Panel 2). To imbue confidence in Sugreeva, Rama hurls his arrow which penetrates seven sala trees as well as the subterranean places of earth and returns to his quiver (Panel 3). Overcome with the immense prowess of Rama, Sugreeva submits himself to Rama, who urges him to challenge Vali for a duel. In their first encounter, Rama is unable to distinguish between the two and asks Sugreeva to wear a garland the next time, so that he could identify Vali. Rama then kills Vali (Panel 4). Rama reinstates Sugreeva on the throne as the king of Kishhkinda (Panel 5). Since the panels are quite small, zoom in to see the details!
Stories from Ramayana are an integral part of various art forms in India, whether it is music, dance or folktales. In Amruteshwara temple stories of Ramayana are imbedded in its architectural style. These intricately carved panels are like unfolding narratives which are sequentially depicted like chapters in a book before the advent of paper and print!
If you travel to Hampi, you can see a craggy hill on the south bank of the river Tungabadra, which is believed to be the Rishimukha Parvata where Hanuman is reported to have met Rama and Lakshmana.

31/03/23, 6:33 am - Dr Raguram: Vincent van Gogh whose birthday was yesterday, was admitted into the asylum at Saint-Rémy-de-Provence which was once a monastery. It originally held many patients, but by the time he was admitted, the male wing was almost empty and he was also given an extra room to use as a studio. This is the painting of the studio by van Gogh where he produced over 140 of his works, including the iconic "Starry Night".  He also painted the view from his window, including the rolling hills 21 times but none of them show the bars on the window of his room! In a letter to his brother Theo, he wrote, "Through the iron-barred window I can make out a square of wheat in an enclosure, above which in the morning I see the sunrise in its glory."
01/04/23, 8:03 am - Dr Raguram: I have been listening to piano concertos of late and have been besotted with Rachmaninoff’s Piano Concerto No 2. It unfolds effortlessly and one is drawn deeply into its fluid, melodic notes. Rhythmic tones from the piano seamlessly and subtly flow into the orchestra. The momentum builds up with several delicate touches. It is full of emotional intensity and has a hypnotic effect on me. 
I started reading about Rachmaninoff (whose birthday is today) and found that he was mentored by none other than Tchaikovsky.  After Tchaikovsky’s untimely death, Rachmaninoff faced a setback in his career.  His first major work Piano Concerto 1 was savagely criticized and he went to meet Tolstoy for some succour. To his great dismay he found Tolstoy to be emotionally distant and dismissive of his work. In throes of deep depression, he sought the help of Dr Nikolai Dahl, an internist in neurology who had a deep interest in Jean-Martin Charcot’s work with hypnosis and was using it in therapy.  After several months of therapy, Rachmaninoff recovered his creative urge and composed Piano Concerto 2, which he dedicated to Dr Nikolai Dah. Full of passion, melancholy, yearning, and ultimately triumph, it remains till today as one of the most influential classical works.
In his own words, “Music is enough for a whole lifetime, but a lifetime is not enough for music.”

02/04/23, 11:32 am - Dr Raguram: There is an interesting sculpture of Hans Christian Andersen in Central Park, New York. It depicts the author of Ugly Duckling, reading a book with a duckling at his feet. Quite often, children climb on top of him and sit on his lap! Countless generations of children (and adults alike!) have grown up relishing his fairy tales. The Danish word for fairy tale is Eventyr and Hans Christian Anderson authored hundreds of them which continue have a universal appeal. He is the eighth most-translated writer in the world, trailing right behind Vladimir Lenin and his works have been translated in more than 125 languages. 
Raised in poverty and having lost his father early in life, he had to work in a factory as a child to support his mother. He endured many hardships and suffered from countless fears and phobias.  His greatest fear was one of being buried alive, something which disturbed him so much that he made a note every night before bed to alert anyone who found him that he was merely sleeping and not dead. In spite of all the adversities in his life, he was able to transform his pain into art and as he reflected: "Most of what I have written is a reflection of myself. Every character is from life. I know and have known them all" 
Hans Christian Andersen (whose birthday is today) was much more than a children’s writer and multiple layers of meanings are embedded in his stories. He founded a genre that has a unique and enduring appeal.

07/04/23, 7:58 am - Dr Raguram: It was late afternoon and as we were cruising through the Death Valley, a congregation of dark clouds rolled in over the blue sky. The sun peeped through the grey clouds caressing the mountains with swirls of golden hues. It was as if the rays were destined to create a great work of art on nature’s easel which poets often excel in expressing in words. I was reminded of Wordsworth’s poem, “Composed Upon An Evening of Extraordinary Splendor and Beauty”. He describes the magical sight of the glowing evening:
No sound is uttered,--but a deep
And solemn harmony pervades
The hollow vale from steep to steep,
And penetrates the glades.
Far-distant images draw nigh,
Called forth by wondrous potency
Of beamy radiance, that imbues,
Whate'er it strikes, with gem-like hues!
In the preface to his 1800 collection of poems, “Lyrical Ballads,” he argued that men and women who live in close association with the natural environment are uniquely in tune with “the essential passions of the heart” because their very humanity is “incorporated with the beautiful and permanent forms of nature.” He also lamented that this relationship has frayed over time and wrote in “The World Is Too Much With Us,” 
The world is too much with us; late and soon,
Getting and spending, we lay waste our powers;—
Little we see in Nature that is ours;
We have given our hearts away..
Lines to ponder on Wordsworth’s 253rd birthday today!

08/04/23, 10:16 am - Dr Raguram: The Wind in the Willows by Kenneth Grahame (whose birthday is today), is an enchanting narrative woven around the adventures of four woodland animals, the Mole, the Water Rat, the Badger and an often mischievous Mr Toad. Though each of them is different from the other, the bond between them becomes stronger over time. It is an inventive, imaginative tale which can be read and interpreted at many levels. There is also a hidden subtext which conveys a moral or two, like the importance of fidelity, fortitude, being honest and the power of friendship. 
Beyond the idyllic tone of the book, there is a poignant tale. The Wind in the Willows evolved from the bedtime stories that Graham narrated to his son, Alastair. Alastair was born premature and was partially blind. Since he was small and squinty, he was nicknamed “Mouse” and had to endure ridicule and bullying all through his life which unfortunately did not end happily. One day at Oxford, where he was studying, he downed a glass of port and took a late night stroll. The next morning, his decapitated body was found on the railways tracks near the university. An inquest determined his death to be suicide but out of respect for his father, it was recorded as an accident. Grahame never recovered from the loss of his only child and became increasingly reclusive, eventually abandoning writing altogether.
The descriptions of nature in the book are truly wonderful. The narration is imbued with a love of nature with lyrical passages, like this one:
“When tired at last, he sat on the bank, while the river still chattered on to him, a babbling procession of the best stories in the world, sent from the heart of the earth to be told at last to the insatiable sea.”
Incidentally, Chapter 7, “The Piper at the Gates of Dawn”, is also the name of Pink Floyd’s first album in 1967.

09/04/23, 8:09 am - Dr Raguram: Easter commemorating the resurrection of Christ, was the earliest feast day decided upon by the ancient Christian church. One of the most beautiful depictions of Easter is by Raphael which he painted when he was just in his teens.
In this painting one can see Christ in the centre, hovering in the air above the tomb. Four guards are on either side with raised hands pointing out to him. In the left hand corner are Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James, and Salome who are on the way to anoint Christ. Two angels flank Christ on either side with their hands raised in blessing. Interestingly there are two symbolic representations in the painting; snake referring to the Satan and white crane indicating its strength and endurance during migration.
George Herbert, one of the great devotional poets in English, wrote couple of poems on Easter. In one of them, Easter Wings, he wrote:
O let me rise
As larks, harmoniously,
And sing this day thy victories:
Then shall the fall further the flight in me.
The poet suggests that those who stay close to God through religious devotion can “fly" above, or find redemption from, their suffering.
Interestingly, he arranged these lines in print to resemble the shape of bird’s wings

10/04/23, 7:25 am - Dr Raguram: Madness has engaged the attention of writers and thinkers for long and Kahlil Gibran (whose death anniversary is today) was no exception. “The Madman” was his first published work in English.  It is an innovative collection of over 30 parables and poems exploring what occurs once we strip away our masks to look within and bare ourselves to God. Gibran describes this state as one of both freedom and vulnerability. In his words, “I have found both freedom and safety in my madness; the freedom of loneliness and the safety from being understood, for those who understand us enslave something in us.”
Khalil Gibran continued this path of enquiry in his best remembered publication ‘The Prophet’. In this book, he reflects on subjects as varied as love, death, self-knowledge, joy and sorrow, reason and passion, in simple yet philosophical language. It has been translated into forty languages and has sold a million copies worldwide. “The Madman” continues to be read and cherished for its timeless understanding of our shared humanity.
Gibran, in his writings, has touched upon almost all the important areas of human life in relation to God, nature, and others, in an elegant, inspiring style.
Ultimately, Gibran’s poems urge the reader to contemplate and reflect on the profound truths of human existence. 
The imagery in these lines from his poem, ‘Out Of My Deeper Heart,’ is particularly stunning: 
Out of my deeper heart a bird rose and flew skyward.
Higher and higher did it rise,
yet larger and larger did it grow.
At first it was but like a swallow,
then a lark,
then an eagle,
then as vast as a spring cloud,
and then it filled the starry heavens.
Out of my heart a bird flew skyward.
And it waxed larger as it flew.
Yet it left not my heart.
