03/11/23, 9:40 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
03/11/23, 9:40 am - Dr Raguram: It was late evening when we visited the cradle of Carnatic music, Thiruvaiyaru, a few months ago. We made our way to the samadhi of Tygaraja on the banks of the river Cauvery. It is a simple, single story building, shorn of any embellishment. Silence enveloped us as we stepped in as there was hardly anyone inside. The walls were inscribed with first two lines of krithis of the master composer. Tyagaraja’s idol is installed at a place where he attained samadhi. The idol was decorated with a garland of rudraksha and he was seen holding a sheaf of palm leaves in his left hand. The idol was personally designed and installed by a singer Nagarathnamma, often referred to as Bangalore Nagarathnamma, whose birthday is today. 
Bangalore Nagarathnamma was an exceptional person. She was born in Nanjangud to a devadasi Puttu Lakshmi. Though she was initiated into the devadasi tradition at the age of five, she was a keen learner and became adept in many languages including Sanskrit. She developed an abiding interest in music and emerged as one of the finest carnatic singers of her time. Impressed by her talents, Maharaja Jayachamarajendra Wodeyar appointed her the Asthana Vidushi. She was probably the first woman to occupy such an exalted position in the royal court! She moved to Madras to consolidate her position as established herself as a popular concert artist. Her rendering of Tygaraja’s krithis enthralled huge audiences. She was the first female artist to pay income tax in Madras!
Tyagaraja occupied her mind in her waking hours as much as in her dreams. In one such dream, she saw an elderly person asking her to build a structure with her vast wealth. The dream came again after a few days and she described it to her mentor, Bidaram Krishnappa as to what it meant. He told her that the person she saw in her dream was none other than Tyagaraja himself and that she should build a memorial to him at Thiruvaiyaru. Tyagaraja’s  samadhi at that time was desolate and forlorn. The place was filled with wild growth of plants and bushes with snakes crawling and wild animals roaming. Seeing it’s sad condition, she built a mandapam over the samadhi. 
Tygaraja’s samadhi was also the place where annual music festival, Tyagaraja Aradhana,  used to be held every year. Women artists were prohibited to perform in it. Nagarathnamma invited female artists and arranged for them to perform behind the mandapam. It was huge hit. Subsequently women artists started featuring in the annual Aradhana. She bequeathed her vast fortune and property to the Aradhana trust with a clear rider that” This property shall be allowed for the purpose of conducting the Tyagaraja Aradhana only as long as women artistes are allowed to perform in it.” When she died in 1952, she was laid to rest next to Tyagaraja. To this day, she remains the only woman to be buried there.
A true feminist, Nagarathnamma shattered glass ceilings wherever she went and contributed much to the inclusion of women and especially devadasis into carnatic music at a time when society was very much Victorian in its morals. She was much ahead of her time and established the first Association for Devadasis in Madras Presidency. As its president, she took several steps towards offering financial and social support to her fellow devadasis. 
DV Gundappa wrote a moving tribute to this remarkable woman. When he met her towards the end of her life, she commented “I was Nagarathna (precious jewel on the snake’s head) by birth, then became bhogarathna (jewel of pleasure) and now I am rogarathna (jewel of disease)” DVG added that she should also be called ragarathna (jewel of musical ragas) and tyagarathna (jewel of sacrifice).

15/11/23, 8:53 am - Dr Raguram: Often people from different walks of life leave their imprint on us. Here was a person whom I had never met, but one who left a lasting impression on me through his commitment towards social justice and human rights. He is the only person who has been hailed as a “Bhishma Pitamah” of the Indian judiciary. Today is the birthday of Krishna Iyer who made the judicial system more humane. 
On this day, it is imperative to reflect on two of his perceptive observations on the role of judiciary:
“the Gandhian diagnosis of offenders as patients and his conception of prisons as hospitals mental and moral – is the key to the pathology of delinquency and therapeutic role of punishment. The whole man is a healthy man, and every man is born good. Criminality is curable deviance. If every saint has a past, every sinner has a future, and it is the role of law to remind both of this.” 
“Litigants are legal patients suffering from injustices seeking healing for their wounds. Would you tell a sufferer in the hospital that because he disclosed a certain symptom very late, therefore, he would be discharged without treatment for the sin of delayed disclosure? Humanism, which, at bottom sustains justice, cannot refuse relief unless, by entertaining the plea, another may sustain injury.”
It was Krishna Iyer’s abiding belief that the Supreme Court of India should perform as a Supreme Court for the people of India

17/11/23, 9:46 am - Dr Raguram: Li Bai was one of the most prominent poets in Chinese literature, who had an abiding interest Daoism. He wrote more than thousand poems, replete with striking imagery, infused with Daoistic metaphors. The notion of ‘Dao’, way or path, emphasizes that ideal world is to be found not by following an external route, but by a spiritual path, through state of mind, an attitude.  In Daoism, a good life is a life that’s simple, spontaneous, in harmony with nature, unencumbered by societal regulation and free from the desire to achieve social ascendancy; a life lived in accordance with nature.  Daoism doesn’t completely disregard the existence of the self, instead it acknowledges that the self exists, but it emphasizes that the person has to be “selfless”.  Instead of the “I” it’s “Others” and the person should strive to live in harmony, in a balanced life with others and nature. It is wonderfully enunciated in this quote "The perfect man has no self; the spiritual man has no achievement; the true sage has no name".

19/11/23, 9:52 am - Dr Raguram: Margaret Atwood (whose birthday was yesterday), is a prolific, award winning writer with more than fifty books of fiction, poetry and critical essays. The project envisioned that in the course of a hundred years, a hundred writers will contribute a manuscript to it. The manuscripts will remain unread except for their titles till 2114, when they will be printed on paper made from a thousand pine trees that have been planted.

20/11/23, 8:52 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
20/11/23, 8:52 am - Dr Raguram: One of the most famous opening sentences in literature is from Leo Tolstoy's novel Anna Karenina: "All happy families are alike; each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way." Tolstoy's own marriage seems to have fallen into the second category. Though he and his wife, Sophia, had 13 children together, they were an unhappy couple in the later part of their lives. Tolstoy contemplated leaving his wife on many occasions and finally on the night of Nov. 10, 1910, he secretly fled, leaving a note to his wife, “I am doing what old men of my age usually do: leaving worldly life to spend the last days of my life in solitude and quiet.” Taking only a few things, he boarded a train with his personal physician Makovitsky. Taking a circuitous route, involving several train changes, they planned to travel further to Bulgaria. But on the way, Tolstoy caught a cold, which led to pneumonia and he was taken of the train at Astapovo. He declined any medical intervention as he wanted to "submit himself to God’s will." He passed away in the early morning of 20th November 1910.
Tolstoy’s final moments are a poignant reminder of what he wrote in The Death of Ivan Illyich; “What death? There was no fear, because there was no death. Instead of death there was light. So that’s it! He suddenly said aloud. “Such joy!” 
Dr Raguram

02/12/23, 7:43 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
02/12/23, 7:43 am - Dr Raguram: From a distance, the little grebe looks like an unremarkable small duck. When you observe it closely, the first thing that strikes one is its stunningly bright chestnut coloured throat. Its eyes are beady yellow with a tiny black pupil. It is fascinating to see it diving under the water, with ease, surfacing some distance away.
Its scientific name is Tachybaptus ruficollis. The genus Tachybaptus is from the Ancient Greek takhus which means fast, just like tachycardia is a fast heartbeat, and bapto which means ‘to sink under’, similar to the word baptism. The specific name ruficollis is from the Latin rufus which means red and the Modern Latin collis, which means necked, which is originally from the Latin collum, or neck.
It has been named Switzerland’s Bird of The Year 2024.
Shakespeare in his Venus and Adonis gave a lovely description of this bird:
“Like a dive-dapper peering through a wave
Who, being look’d on, ducks as quickly in.”

03/12/23, 10:51 am - Dr Raguram: When I was in the medical school, my grand uncle Dr RV Rajam asked me to read the book, ’The Lives of a Cell: Notes of a Biology Watcher’ by Lewis Thomas. It was a collection of essays on varied topics ranging from medicine to music, written in a lively, light hearted, poetic way. It was said that he could write "as naturally as birds build a nest." In his own words, he let them “loose . . . to fly around in the dark, bumping into each other, mating in crazy ways”. The book was full of fascinating nuggets of information. “ants are very much like humans. They farm fungi, raise aphids, as a livestock, launch armies into wars, use chemical sprays to alarm, and confused enemies, capture slaves”. He was prescient in his observation about the advent of the Internet in future. “We are becoming a grid, a circuitry around the earth. If we keep at it, we will become a computer to end all computers, capable of fusing all the thoughts of the world into a syncytium.” The book opened my eyes to many things, our existence, our environment, social beings, our origin and a variety of interesting topics. ‘The Lives of a Cell’ is eleventh on the Modern Library’s list of the best 100 nonfiction books of the century. I started collecting his subsequent books and each one of them is a gem. 
Lewis Thomas was a strong advocate of a scientific approach to understand and decode the mystery of biology and medicine. However, voicing a cautious note, he observed, “Science will...produce the data..., but never the full meaning. For perceiving real significance, we shall need...most of all the brains of poets, also those of artists, musicians, philosophers, historians, writers in general”.
Dr Raguram

04/12/23, 7:14 am - Dr Raguram: Viktor Frankl’s ‘Man in search of meaning’, has had a profound impact on me. I came across the work of the poet Rainer Maria Rilke (whose birthday is today), for the first time when Frankl quoted from a poem by him, “How much suffering there is to get through!” I started reading Rilke’s poetry and was struck by its lyricism and imagery like in these lines:
“She who reconciles the ill-matched threads
of her life, and weaves them gratefully
into a single cloth… ”
We hold disparate threads in our life, some of them infused with pain and sorrow. Our task in life is how we reconcile the threads we’ve been given and turn them into a personally meaningful cloth.  A good life doesn’t come from having “good threads”.  It comes from being an adept weaver, in knowing how to reconcile oneself the ill-matched parts of our life to each other. 
And Rainer Maria Rilke observed:
“Be patient toward all that is unsolved in your heart and try to love the questions themselves, like locked rooms and like books that are now written in a very foreign tongue. Do not now seek the answers, which cannot be given you because you would not be able to live them. And the point is, to live everything. Live the questions now. Perhaps you will then gradually, without noticing it, live along some distant day into the answer.”

05/12/23, 9:26 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
05/12/23, 9:26 am - Dr Raguram: Milton Erickson (whose birthday today) is an intriguing figure in the history of psychiatry. More so since most of his work was in the field of hypnosis, which was summarily dismissed by Freud. Erickson eschewed theories because he felt that they limit the way in which practitioners view the patient and the problem, “We always translate the other person’s language into our own language”.
Many of Erickson's interventions ran counter to the theoretical postulates of major schools of therapy. He emphasized the need to incorporate the resources and abilities available to the patient, to assist them in problem resolution through a variety of innovative methods, including the use of metaphors and humour. In the 1940s, it was virtually unheard of for a psychiatrist to do family therapy as he often did and his strategic family interventions are still influential today. He was also not favour of extended therapy sessions and laid the foundation for the brief therapy movement. 
He firmly believed that life is lived in the present and directed towards the future. He felt that one cannot change an unchangeable past, “In order to ride a bicycle, you do not need to know physics. So too, individuals can achieve behavioural change without developing insight into the unconscious forces that may have determined the behaviour”. 
His observation that, “Each person is a unique individual. Hence, psychotherapy should be formulated to meet the uniqueness of the individual's needs, rather than tailoring the person to fit the Procrustean bed of a hypothetical theory of human behaviour”, is a useful reminder in these times when we are immersed in a surfeit of schools of therapies, each one claiming greater effectiveness than the other.

07/12/23, 8:25 am - Dr Raguram: Yesterday was the death anniversary of Baba Saheb Ambedkar who fervently espoused the cause of the oppressed, exploited, deprives sections of the society. He was not merely a dalit icon, but someone who tirelessly worked towards emancipation of women. During the All India Depressed Classes Women’s Conference held in Nagpur in 1942, he remarked, “I measure the progress of a community by the degree of progress which women have achieved.” He strongly advocated the role of education in mitigating the discrimination faced by them. In this, he was carrying forward the legacy of Jyotiba and Savitribai Phule, who started the first school for girls at the historic Bhide Wada in Pune around 1932. It opened the gates for the emergence of a subculture wherein the oppressed women started giving expression about their struggles and lived experiences through the written word. They haven’t looked back since then. There is a growing body of writings from the dalits and the marginalized, brimming with vibrancy, especially in the past decade.
I particularly like the poems of Jacinta Kerketta, who belongs to the Adivasi community of West Singhbhum district. She essentially writes in Hindi and some of her poems have been translated into English recently. In her poems, Jacinta highlights the injustices committed on the Adivasi communities and particularly the struggles of women. Her poems, like this one, abounds with wonderful, poignant, imagery:
(क्यों महुए तोड़े नहीं जाते पेड़ से? Kyon Mahue Tode Nahi Jate Ped Se?)
(Why the Mahua is not Plucked from the Tree?)
Mother, why do you wait all night
for the mahua to drop?
Why don’t you not
just pluck all the mahua from the tree?
Mother says –
They live in the womb all night long.
When the time for their birth comes
They fall by themselves to the earth.
At dawn, when they’re soaked in the dew
We pick them up and bring them home.
When the tree is going through
Labour pains all night long
Tell me, how I can
shake the branch hard?
Say, how I can forcibly 
pluck the mahua from a tree?
We just wait
Because we love them.

08/12/23, 11:32 am - Dr Raguram: I was keen to reach the temple at Bodhgaya early, before the crowds start streaming in. When I entered the temple precincts there was hardly anyone except a group of Buddhist monks who were chanting melodiously. The ebb and flow of their chanting with sporadic chirping of birds set the tone for a reflective state of mind. I made my way to the Bodhi tree and sat down. Here was the place where Shakyamuni came after practising a lifestyle of severe asceticism for six years. After enduring many hardships, he realized that that a deeper understanding of life was still eluding him. He sat and meditated under this tree and became the Buddha, “an awakened one.” Bodhi Day which is observed on 8th December marks this moment that took place 2500 years ago. In addition to its spiritual significance, the Bodhi Day reminds us of the importance of peace, compassion, and mindfulness in our everyday lives. 
Within each of us is a tiny light, entangled in the fibres of our lives. As Ramana Maharishi observed, “Your own Self-Realization is the greatest service you can render the world.”
(If you look carefully at the photograph, you can have a glimpse of a covered slab at the foot of the Bodhi tree. It marks the exact position where Buddha sat in meditation. Traditionally, it is referred to as Buddha’s Vajrasana and is the oldest piece of architecture in Bodh Gaya)

10/12/23, 7:39 am - Dr Raguram: “If we love Flowers, are we not ‘born again’ every Day,” reflected Emily Dickinson whose birthday is today. She was better known in her hometown of Amherst, Massachusetts, as a gardener rather than a poet. She was often observed by neighbours on evenings, tending her flower beds. She identified herself strongly with flowers like the tiger lily, daisy, and rose and was particularly partial to wildflowers. Her first formal act of composition as a girl was not a poem but an herbarium. 
The garden was the true inspiration for Emily Dickinson and flowers figured with richest symbolic language in her poems. As she wrote, 
“I hide myself within my flower
That fading from your Vase
You, unsuspecting, feel for me
Almost a loneliness”
For her, every single flower is a microcosm of complex ecological relationships between numerous organisms and their environment. She captured this understanding in an exquisite poem, in which the flower emerges not as the pretty object of admiration but as an enchanting, silent symphony of interconnected resilience. 
BLOOM
“Bloom — is Result — to meet a Flower
And casually glance
Would cause one scarcely to suspect
The minor Circumstance
Assisting in the Bright Affair
So intricately done
Then offered as a Butterfly
To the Meridian —
To pack the Bud — oppose the Worm —
Obtain its right of Dew —
Adjust the Heat — elude the Wind —
Escape the prowling Bee
Great Nature not to disappoint
Awaiting Her that Day —
To be a Flower, is profound
Responsibility”

11/12/23, 7:47 am - Dr Raguram: Mountains might not seem like they do much, but in reality, they are one of the most important creations of nature. To raise awareness about mountains, the United Nations signifies December 11 as International Mountain Day. They contain almost half of the total biodiversity hotspots on the planet. Mountains host a significant amount of flora and fauna, which are vulnerable and at risk of extinction. Unfortunately, they are being overexploited by humans and are torn apart to make way for buildings and cities. 
Mountains are nature’s most beautiful gift to us and let us strive to take care of them. 
William Wordsworth expressed the beauty and allure of mountains poetically in ‘Lines composed a few miles above Tintern Abbey
“Therefore am I still 
A lover of the meadows and the woods
And mountains; and of all that we behold
From this green earth; of all the mighty world
Of eye and ear, both what they half create
And what perceive; well pleased to recognize
In nature and the language of the sense
The anchor of my purest thoughts, the nurse
The guide, the guardian of my heart, and soul
Of all my moral being.”

16/12/23, 10:18 am - Dr Raguram: George Santayana (whose birthday is today), was a renowned philosopher, essayist, novelist and poet, known for his profound insights into human nature. He has become very well-known for his aphorisms. His most famous one "Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it" is inscribed on a plaque at the entrance of the Auschwitz concentration camp.  I keep wondering whether we have drawn any lesson from it. In a lighter vein, Mark Twain famously commented, “History doesn’t repeat itself, but it does rhyme.” 
Santayana wrote number of iconic poems like this one, titled ‘Decima’. A decima is a ten-line stanza of poetry. It is also referred to as decima espinela after the Spanish poet Vicente Espinel  who used it extensively in his compositions.
DECIMA
Silent daisies out of reach,
Maidens of the starry grass,
Gazing on me as I pass
With a look too wise for speech,
Teach me resignation,—teach
Patience to the barren clod,
As, above your happier sod,
Bending to the wind's caress,
You—unplucked, alas!—no less
Sweetly manifest the god.

18/12/23, 9:18 am - Dr Raguram: Today is the birth centenary of TS Satyan often considered as the ‘father of photojournalism’ in India. His work was all about people, across various streams of life. One particular image that has made a deep impact in me was a photograph of Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, showing Nehru walking in the corridor of the Parliament House with his back towards the camera. This was a period of time when Nehru was severely criticized for his policies regarding China which waged a war with an unprepared Indian army. The isolation and loneliness experienced by him has been artfully expressed in a simple frame.
Satyan had an unparalleled eye to capture the extraordinary in the ordinary. In his own words, “My people are not the rich and the famous. They are the simple, ordinary folk. They do not hit the headlines, yet my people are people who matter.  They were there when I picked up the camera six decades ago, and they have been there every time I have gone back to capture the interesting moments in their lives. In giving me privileged access at every step of my career as a photo journalist – even in their moments of despair or drudgery – they have never let me forget that photography is at once both an exquisite art-form and a means of communication. And that to lose sight of one aspect is to lose sight of both. Call it intimate intrusions, but it is these simple, ordinary people who dominate my oeuvre. Through a tiny aperture they allowed me to freeze-frame the cycle of life: birth, growth and death. In between, they showed me babies being born, babies being bathed, babies being suckled. They have let me in when children were learning, children were playing. They have allowed me to peep at adults at work, at worship, at recreation and adults at their everyday chores. And they have let me do so on the road, at the well, beside rivers, in crowds and in solitude. In the process, by making their private life public, they have enabled me to discover the extraordinary in the everyday." 
I had a close association with him in the later part of his life and deeply cherish the interactions. I visited him a few years before his death. It was after a major retrospective of his work. He looked at the prints which were neatly stacked, turned to me and said, “I would like you to take these”. I was deeply moved, touched and requested him to just select a few for me to treasure. Every time I look at them, the magic of a creative genius keeps unfolding.…

19/12/23, 8:36 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
19/12/23, 8:36 am - Dr Raguram: Paul Klee (whose birthday was yesterday), left an indelible mark on the world of visual arts with his unique style and innovative approach to painting. A great artist, he was also an inspiring teacher, fine musician, and persuasive writer. Klee was ambidextrous. He wrote with his right hand and painted with his left. Klee’s paintings often blur the line between reality and imagination. His famous dictum was that drawing is a matter of taking a line for a walk.
Reflecting on the artistic process, he wrote, “From the root, the sap rises up into the artist, flows through him, flows to his eye. Overwhelmed and activated by the force of the current, he conveys his vision into his work. And yet, standing at his appointed place as the trunk of the tree, he does nothing other than gather and pass on what rises from the depths. He neither serves nor commands he transmits. His position is humble. And the beauty at the crown is not his own; it has merely passed through him”.
Paul Klee felt that the study of nature was one of the central principles of artistic creation. Birds and fish assume a special place in his work. They exerted a particular fascination on him because unlike humans, who are bound to the earth by gravity, they can move completely freely in air or water. This gives them their own territories which are difficult for humans to access.
Antonin Artaud famously observed, “ ln Paul Klee, the objects of the world fall into order and it seems as if he was only writing down their dictation”.

20/12/23, 8:08 am - Dr Raguram: Beau Taplin is a poet from Australia who has captured the essence of human emotions and experiences through eloquent words and enchanting themes. In his words, “I like to draw inspiration from wherever I can, so no river runs dry. The connections I have shared with people have always been a significant part of who I am, so a great deal of it comes directly from personal experiences… As far back as I can remember, I have searched for the hidden magic in things, those moments that seem to glimmer and shine with their own inner light, and so my great hope and intention with my verses and volumes is to simply encourage you to do the same. To see how the rabbit hole, this deep magic, belongs not only to stories, but can be found right here beneath the soles of your feet; in the soft light of morning, amongst the woods and the streams, in dance, in music, or a lover’s kiss”.
Beau Taplin is among the new generation of poets like Rupi Kaur, who reach out to larger audiences through social media. His brief verses/notes in Instagram continue to enthral his devoted followers. He writes, “Everyone you meet has a part to play in your story. And while some may take a chapter, others a paragraph, and most will be no more than scribbled notes in the margins. Someday, you'll meet someone who will become so integral to your life, you'll put their name in the title.”

21/12/23, 8:59 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
21/12/23, 8:59 am - Dr Raguram: Kodo Sawaki is regarded by many as the greatest twentieth-century Zen master. He had a difficult start in life as his early life was full of travails of various kinds. He weathered them all and after receiving his ordination, spent many years living in an abandoned hermitage devoting himself to the practice of Zazen. He became famous throughout Japan for the sesshin (intensive meditation retreat) that he gave to people from all walks of life, without making any personal distinction or discrimination. Kodo Sawaki called his monastery a “moving monastery”. He gave Zen a new life and “brought fresh air to the decaying Zen” by staying away the frozen rituals. His tendency to travel alone and his refusal to settle down at any monastery in the classical sense earned him the nickname, “Homeless Kodo”.
Kodo Sawaki taught that the practice of zen is not about achieving enlightenment, but rather about living in the present moment and being mindful of our actions and thoughts. He emphasized the importance of zazen, or seated meditation to cultivate a sense of inner peace and clarity. Kodo encouraged people to live a life of simplicity and to find joy in the small moments of everyday life.
When he was 86, Kodo felt gravely ill and spent the last three months of his life at Antai-ji, a temple transformed by him into a place for a pure practice. From his bed, he spent a long time looking at the Takagamine mountain and, three days before his death, he told a nun: “Look at that. Nature is magnificent. In all my life, I have never encountered a person to whom I could have submitted and who I could have admired. But this Takagamine mountain looks upon me form the heights saying: ‘Kodo, Kodo’”. 
These were his last words. He passed away on the 21st of December, 1966

22/12/23, 7:27 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
22/12/23, 7:27 am - Dr Raguram: Srinivasa Ramanjuan (whose birthday is today) is an enigma and continues to be one. To borrow a phrase from a radio address by Winston Churchill in 1939, to understand his creative process, “It’s a riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma…” “The enigma of Ramanujan’s creative process is still covered by a curtain that has barely been drawn,” observed the mathematician Bruce Berndt.
Like many geniuses, Srinivasa Ramanujan was a dreamer. Many of this profound insights were ‘revelations’ unravelled in dreams. Recording one such dream, he wrote, “While asleep, I had an unusual experience. There was a red screen formed by flowing blood, as it were. I was observing it. Suddenly a hand began to write on the screen. I became all attention. That hand wrote a number of elliptic integrals. They stuck to my mind. As soon as I woke up, I committed them to writing.” Throughout his career, “scrolls of the most complicated mathematics” would unfold before him in dreams. In a dream early in his life, the goddess Namagiri bestowed him with the gift of precociousness by writing on his tongue. Later, during a difficult period in his life, his abdomen appeared to him as an appendage of “indefinable mathematical surges”
Revelatory dreams have been mentioned for many thousands of years, across cultures in the East and Near East. In Greek mythology, Oneiroi were the spirits, daimones, or gods of dreams in Greek mythology.  Each night the Oneiroi would depart from Erebus, like a flock of bats leaving their caves. As the Oneiroi departed from Erebus they would pass between one of two gates. One gate was made of horn, and the Oneiroi who passed through this gate would bring to mortals truthful, prophetic god sent dreams. The second gate was made of ivory, and the Oneiroi who passed through this gate brought only false dreams, or those dreams without meaning. Virgil wrote in the epic poem Aeneid:
Two gates the silent house of Sleep adorn;
Of polish'd ivory this, that of transparent horn:
True visions thro' transparent horn arise;
Thro' polish'd ivory pass deluding lies.
Ramanjuan seems to have passed through the gates of horn to provide us with immense, intriguing mathematical insights.
In the garden of dreams
He wandered deeper
And an enchanted forest unfurled…
Dr Raguram

03/01/24, 9:19 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
03/01/24, 9:19 am - Dr Raguram: Rudaki was a poet, singer, and musician who is regarded as the first major poet to write in New Persian. He wrote several thousand poems and unfortunately only a few survive. In Iran, Rudaki is acknowledged as the "founder of New Persian poetry" and in Tajikistan as the "father of Tajik literature". Rudaki was also an innovator of poetic form. Aside from writing in forms inherited from Arabic poetry, he is thought to be the first poet to have written in the rubaiyat form, which is a quatrain consisting of two couplets. 
Interestingly he translated Panchatantra stories which gained popularity in the medieval Europe as, 'The Fables of Bidpai'. The Persian version by Rudaki is known as ‘Kalileh o Demneh’. 
His poetry is replete with interesting imagery and vivid description of nature. Observing the clouds one day, he wrote:
Look at that cloud,
how it cries like a grieving man, 
Thunder moans like a lover with a broken heart.
Now and then the sun peeks from behind the clouds
Like a prisoner hiding from the guard.
This particular poem is about the Hoopoe. Hoopoe has had an important status in Persian literature and often considered as a guide that directs the mystics toward God. Rudaki wrote:
I saw a hoopoe near Sarakhs 
Whose little song reached the clouds.
She was wearing a little cloak Of many different colors.
I stand before you in awe.
Dr Raguram
04/01/24, 8:53 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
04/01/24, 8:53 am - Dr Raguram: All of us are accustomed to seeing with our eyes and also communicate with the written word. When blindness sets in and one cannot see, one has to rely on the sense of touch. It is such a poignant and inspiring sight in our cities to see the blind negotiate the travails of travel with the touch of the white wand. Can the sense of exquisite touch help them also to read and communicate?
This was the quest of Louis Braille (whose birthday is today), who lost his vision early in life. When he was 12, a French soldier by the name of Charles Barbier introduced him to “night writing,” a system he had invented that used patterns of 12 raised dots to simulate letters so soldiers could communicate across battles in secret. Braille’s magic wand was a group of six dots in which the vertical line consists of three dots, and the horizontal of two. The combination of these dots produces characters to each of which a particular meaning is assigned, just as the seeing does to the alphabets in print. It is amazing how six dots can be so combined to represent so many things. Braille refined this by the time he was 15 and published his Braille Code in 1829. Unfortunately, it did not receive international attention until 1868, a full 16 years after Braille’s death.
The Braille Code liberated the “People of the Night”, who had resigned to the dark abyss of blindness. It opened doors of learning and was instrumental in weaving bonds of companionship between those who could not see. 
What is remarkable about Braille is that he was only a child when he developed his revolutionary invention. He had no training, no funding, no public or institutional support, no commercial motive or business plan and only the dream to open the doors of knowledge to the blind.
As John Lee Clark, a blind poet wrote about Braille:
The world rests on my lap.
If my finger is the sky,
Then under it the fields prosper.
Row after perfect row of buds
Bid me gather all I can.
The harvest is food for thought
Dr Raguram
05/01/24, 10:09 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
05/01/24, 10:09 am - Dr Raguram: It was a bright morning and as we were making our way in the Coyote Hills Regional Park, we heard a loud, rattling sound. And when we looked around, a bird with bright colours under its wings caught our eyes. It perched on the outer branches of a tree, feasting on the berries. It was the Northern Flicker. As we were watching, it, hopped down onto the ground, foraging for insects. Its scientific name is Colaptes auratus. Colaptes means “to peck.” Northern Flickers are often referred to as the “anteaters of the sky.” Unlike other woodpeckers, which usually remain high in the treetops, Northern Flickers venture down to ground level to search for their favourite meal, ants. They are ably assisted in this task by their slightly curved bill. Their dusky brow plumage helps them to blend with the colours of the forest floor. Most woodpeckers in North America have black white stripped plumage, which helps them to blend in with tree bark.  Northern Flickers stand apart and are considered the ‘black sheep’ of the woodpecker family because they have brown feathers and forage for food on the ground. The Northern Flicker is one of the few North American woodpeckers that is strongly migratory. 
(On the occasion of the National Birds Day which is observed on January 5 in USA to raise awareness about the role of birds in our ecosystem)

06/01/24, 9:46 am - Dr Raguram: Among the many calls that I received this New Year, I was deeply touched by a particular one. It was from a lady whom I had known for the past few years. She rang up and said, “Doctor let this New Year be good for you and all those who help others”. What is distinctive about the caller is that she is a crematorium worker who handles all the paper work there.
I met her a few years ago, helping a friend who had lost a family member, to fill the forms. When I was about to leave, she asked me whether I was a doctor. Hearing the affirmative answer, she shared her psychological travails which were being attended to by a dear former student. I reassured her stating that she was in good hands while emphasizing the need to be regular with treatment. She profusely thanked me and thereafter kept in touch with me periodically. 
Working in a crematorium can be a daunting task, more so being a woman. At a time when the term ‘stress’ is flaunted widely, I was keen to know more about her and how she coped with her situation. Her answer was simple, “I earn a livelihood doctor, for the sake of my children, for their better future”. I gathered that her husband was a drunkard without any regular work and she had to tend for two young children, with very little support from the extended family. She works six days a week with few breaks or any holiday. At the end of a busy working day, she gets back home, has a bath and starts cooking for the night. Her husband scolds and often beats her, if by chance the food is delayed. He is also sexually demanding and if she refuses, starts suspecting her. In spite of these ordeals when I chance to see her at work, I invariably find her attending to her task with a smile on her face. 
By accepting the job, she has joined a cadre of Indian women who are entering arenas from which they have traditionally been excluded. That she has chosen to work in a space with significant stigma associated with it, where even men feel uneasy to be in, is a testament to her resilience. 
A plant that can teach us resilience is the bamboo. It can withstand twice as much force bearing down on it while being stretched, pulled or bent. According to a Japanese proverb: “In time, even the strongest wind tires itself out, but the bamboo remains standing tall and still.” 
There is an interesting Zen parable, ‘Be like a bamboo’:
A Zen Master was walking through the forest down a narrow trail with one of his students along a steep incline. The student lost his footing and slipped; just as he began tumbling down the hill, the student reached out and grabbed a small bamboo tree. The bamboo bent nearly all the way over as the student continued to hold on tightly. He pulled himself up and brushed off the dirt with the Zen Masters help.
“Did you notice that when you fell, you grabbed a hold of the bamboo and it bent nearly all the way over and still supported you.” the Zen Master asked.
“Yes,” the student replied. The Zen Master gripped the bamboo and pulled the bamboo over.
“Be like the bamboo,” the Zen Master said as he let go of the bamboo and it sprang back to its up-right position. “It is pushed around by the wind and yet it always bounces back and grows upward, toward the sun, enlightenment. Have you ever felt as though you were going to snap? Have you ever felt as though you were at your breaking point, emotionally?”
“Yes,” the student replied.
“Then bend, do not break, such is the way with bamboo. It endures the stress and finds a way to bounce back!” the Zen Master stated. “This is called resilience.”
Throughout our journey in life, we meet people along the way and we connect with the heart of a few from whom we draw inspiration. They become a poem or a story in my life to live by.

09/01/24, 8:55 am - Dr Raguram: I have a time worn book of ‘Second Sex’ by Simone de Beauvoir (whose birthday is today) and it is incredible as to how it is so relevant today, decades after its publication. Weaving together perspectives from biology, psychoanalysis, anthropology, sociology, psychology, history she narrates as to how gender demarcation came into being and women lead a life as the ‘Second Sex’; “Humanity is male, and man defines woman, not in herself, but in relation to himself.” She theorizes about every phase of a woman's life, from infancy to old age, and the events outlining each phase with insight and erudition. No woman before her had written with such candour about the most intimate aspects of women. Adopting an existentialist framework, she emphasizes on the social construction of femininity. Women are not born knowing what it means to be a woman, how to behave, what jobs to do, how to feel, but are rather socialized into the role of ‘woman,’ often by men; “One is not born, but rather becomes, a woman.” 
She concludes ‘Second Sex’ with optimistic undertones, hoping that either gender will eventually see eye to eye and accept each other as subjects and equals.
“On the day when it will be possible for woman to love not in her weakness but in her strength, not to escape herself but to find herself, not to abase herself but to assert herself on that day love will become for her, as for man, a source of life and not of mortal danger.”
It is an important read in these times when there is an attempt to define the role of women according to staid ideologies.

10/01/24, 9:05 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
10/01/24, 9:05 am - Dr Raguram: I had posted yesterday about Simone de Beauvoir’s ‘Second Sex’, wherein she urges women to 
have the freedom to escape from prescribed social roles and seek their own identity. This perspective has been articulated well in many works of fiction. Daisy Rockwell's translation of Geetanjali Shree's Hindi novel ‘Ret Samadhi’ ‘’रेत समाधि’ which I read some time ago, is one such engaging narrative. It traces the life trajectory of a woman who is recently bereaved and her journey to discover aspects of self that were deeply buried within her. 
The strength of any work of fiction is that it can be read at different layers, each with its own attendant meaning. Grief after a loss of a partner has been essayed in many novels. Usually it follows a predictable path, focusing on the loss and its emotional impact within the individual. What is different in this work is the broader narration of separation and loss in the historical context of partition and the quest of the protagonist to seek her personal identity embedded in it. 
The novel is tale of transformative powers of crossing the ‘borders’, of geography, gender and prescriptive roles, reaffirming that the inner landscape has no borders. “Anything worth doing transcends borders”. 
The protagonist’s travel is also a journey into her own self, opening doors of discovery. In her words, “Always, at least once, every woman, whether this one or that one, whether small or big, finds herself at the door, one foot poised in the air, like a dancer striking a mudra, a pose, in order to re-enter the home or that door which she has renounced and already left far behind, asking herself in that moment, Is this my world in which I’m setting foot, or is it that which is receding behind me, where I had gone, or whence I’ve come?”
As for the story, “Once you’ve got women and a border, a story can write itself. Even women on their own are enough. Women are stories in themselves, full of stirrings and whisperings that float on the wind, that bend with each blade of grass.”
There is extensive use of metaphors like doors and windows. “there was a painter, Bhupen Khakkar. He told stories with brush…He knew that a story cannot be locked into a box, or a canvas, or a gaze. So he never tried. On the contrary, he always left a small window, an empty space, so the story could move on at will and take another path if it so desired. Because stories never end. They jump through windows and cracks…or create them by shaking, causing the earth to quake"
The novel is replete with lyrical passages, like this one, “Ma sips her morning tea as though drinking in a bird’s song”.
All together a fascinating read!

11/01/24, 10:23 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
11/01/24, 10:23 am - Dr Raguram: William James (whose birthday is today), is most famous for his psychology textbook,’ Principles of Psychology’ which was published in 1890. It consisted of two volumes with over 1400 pages and took him 12 years to write. He did not produce any original research, did not perform any experiment, yet he became the driving force behind psychology. 
Of the many topics he addressed during his life time, he is most famous for his theories about emotions and consciousness. Concerning emotions, James believed that a person is exposed to a stimulus, has a physiological reaction, and then interprets that reaction as emotion. So, first comes physiological arousal, then the subjective interpretation of those processes as emotion. An independent researcher in Denmark, Carl Lange, developed a similar theory of emotion at roughly the same time as James did. Their view of emotion came to be known as the James-Lange theory of emotion. Though it was later thought not to be an accurate theory of how emotions work, its framework was quite influential in drawing attention to the interaction between physiological processes and emotion. 
William James also conceptualized consciousness as a river or a stream, constantly changing and never the same. He had an abiding interest in religion and faith. He believed that divine existence can be justified by the emotional benefits it brings to one’s life. His book ‘The Varieties of Religious Experience: a study in human nature’, examines varied forms of religious experiences such as mystical experiences, conversion, saintliness, and spirituality from a psychological perspective. I was quite surprised to learn that the emphasis given in Alcoholic Anonymous is largely due to the influence of this book.  It seems that when Bill, a co-founder of AA, was trying to fight his way back to sobriety, chanced upon a copy of the book and was deeply impressed by James' "great wisdom." It also helped Bill to finally achieve sobriety  and the impact of the book can be seen in the formulation of AA's basic ideas.
James was an inspiring teacher. His students included such luminaries as Theodore Roosevelt, author and philosopher George Santayana and Gertrude Stein.
I particularly like this observation of his, “A great many people think they are thinking when they are merely rearranging their prejudices.”

13/01/24, 10:01 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
13/01/24, 10:01 am - Dr Raguram: In my forays into the Zen landscape, I discovered the poetry of Ryokan. His poems are direct and unpretentious, infused with profound insights. For example, he wrote:
The rain has stopped, the clouds have drifted away,
and the weather is clear again.
If your heart is pure, then all things in your world are pure.
Abandon this fleeting world, abandon yourself,
Then the moon and flowers will guide you along the Way.
He is reported to have led a live of extreme simplicity. He showed love for all living things to the extent of placing lice under his robes to keep them warm, allowing thieves to take freely from his possessions, and letting one leg protrude from his mosquito net at night to give the mosquitos food. As a Zen priest, he never established his own temple, and lived by alms. Instead of preaching, he enjoyed companionship and conversation with many ordinary people. His practice consisted of sitting in zazen meditation, walking in the woods, playing with children, making his daily begging rounds, reading, writing poetry and on occasion drinking sake with friends. He was adept in calligraphy and was also known as one of Japan's great calligraphers.
He was deeply influenced by the teachings of Dogen, the 13th century monk, about whom I wrote sometime back. Ryokan never published a collection of verse while he was alive. One of his last verses reads;
Life is like a dewdrop,
Empty and fleeting;
My years are gone
And now, quivering and frail,
I must fade away.
As Rabindranath Tagore wrote, “Let your life lightly dance on the edges of Time like dew on the tip of a life.”

15/01/24, 8:08 am - Dr Raguram: India with its diverse and rich cultural heritage celebrates multitudes of festivals throughout the year. The harvest festival holds a distinct place among them. The onset of harvest season is observed all across the country under various names based on the region where it is celebrated. It is essentially an act of thanksgiving to the farmers. Farmers who tend to the land with care and concern are the backbone of our society. We may need the help of a doctor or a lawyer sometime in our lives, but we need the farmer every day, three times a day to provide us with food. 
Saint Poet Thiruvalluvar’s magnum opus Thirukkural consists of 133 chapters having 10 couplets each. Each one of them consisting of just one line and a half, like a short haiku. Thiruvalluvar devotes an entire chapter (104) wherein he extols the glory and greatness of agriculture and the important role of farmers. 
இரவார்  இரப்பார்க்கொன்று  ஈவர் கரவாது 
கைசெய்தூண் மாலை யவர்.
Those who plough do not ask but give with both hands
To those that ask, the bounty they have tilled
On this festival day let us pay obeisance to our indefatigable farmers who are battling tremendous odds to keep us satiated.
As the Pongal brims over the pot
Let us pray to the lord
That joy bubbles in farmer’s heart 
Forever

16/01/24, 8:17 am - Dr Raguram: Today is Mattu Pongal. On this day cattle are given a well-deserved day of rest and a pride of place. They are washed, their horns are painted and covered with shining metal caps. Multi-coloured beads, tinkling bells, sheaves of corn and flower garlands are tied around their necks. They look majestic in all their finery. It is essentially a day of thanksgiving to the cattle friends by the farmers. Cattle play important roles in different stages of cultivation. Even after the fields are harvested, they are used to separate the ear of the grains from the stalk by walking over the stalks. Besides their importance in ploughing fields, their manure also serves as natural fertilisers. While the practice of using cattle as farm labour has all but disappeared in Tamil Nadu today, there is still a thriving dung economy. For example, ‘Thozhuvam Farmer Producer Organization’ in Madurai directly sources cow dung and markets value-added products such incense sticks, dung handicrafts, and more. Their main agenda is to safeguard the traditional Pulikulam and Theni hill cattle breeds that are on the verge of extinction.
There are beautiful descriptions of cattle in Sangam poetry. For example, Orampokiyar wrote more than 100 poems and in one verse in Aiynkurunooru., he offers a beautiful description of a buffalo:
'துறை மீன் வழங்கும் பெரு நீர்ப் பொய்கை,
அரி மலர் ஆம்பல் மேய்ந்த நெறி மருப்பு
ஈர்ந் தண் எருமைச் சுவல் படு முது போத்து,
தூங்கு சேற்று அள்ளல் துஞ்சி, பொழுது பட,
பைந் நிண வராஅல் குறையப் பெயர்தந்து,
குரூஉக் கொடிப் பகன்றை சூடி, மூதூர்ப்
போர் செறி மள்ளரின் புகுதரும் ஊரன்
an old buffalo, his back wet and cool, his horns curved,
grazes on bright-flowered lilies
in a pond full of water and fish
sleeps all night in the oozing mud,
and then when dawn comes
walks out, crushing fish with their feet,
drapes himself with bright creepers,
and enters the ancient town like a warrior victorious in battle.
(The unique terracotta temples at Bishnupur, around 140kms from Kolkata, feature intricate carvings showcasing the skills of the artisans who created them).

18/01/24, 8:28 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
18/01/24, 8:28 am - Dr Raguram: Most us would have read ‘Winnie the Pooh’ by AA Milne (whose birthday is today). He wrote seven novels, five nonfiction books and 34 plays, along with numerous stories and articles. But ‘Winnie the Pooh’ which was published in 1926, eclipsed and erased the memory of his other works. It featured characters based on his son, who was the inspiration for Pooh’s best friend, Christopher Robin and his stuffed animal toys. The Hundred Acre Woods, where Pooh’s adventures take place, was based on the 500 Acre Woods near Milne’s home. 
A few years after Winnie-the-Pooh was published, Milne began to resent the fame that it brought on him and his family. He stated, “I feel that Christopher Robin has already had more publicity than I want for him. I do not want CR Milne to ever wish that his name was Charles Robert.” His son also disliked this attention, as the legacy of Christopher Robin and Pooh Bear followed him all throughout his life, making it difficult for him to make a name as his own person. In his memoir, ‘The Enchanted Place’, he wrote, “In pessimistic moments, when I was trudging London in search of an employer wanting to make use of such talents as I could offer, it seemed to me, almost, that my father had got to where he was by climbing upon my infant shoulders, that he had filched from me my good name and had left me with nothing but the empty fame of being his son.”
Strangely, there have been several attempts to ban the book. In 2009, Russian authorities banned it for being pro-Nazi, after an image of Pooh with a swastika was discovered amongst an extremist’s collection. In the United Kingdom, the book was banned from public schools, as the character Piglet might offend Muslim and Jewish students who abstain from pork for religious reasons. And in 2017, the Chinese government began censoring Winnie the Pooh on social media platforms after critics used the character to mock Xi Jinping and his policies.
What is more galling is the attempt to identify psychiatric disorders among the characters in the book. In 2000, paediatrician Sarah Shea and her team released a journal article titled “Pathology in the Hundred Acre Wood: a neurodevelopmental perspective on A.A. Milne.” It proposed that each of the Winnie-the-Pooh characters displayed symptoms of a different mental disorder. Unfortunately this trend caught on and there have been several attempts in this vein over the years.
In spite of all this, ‘Winnie the Pooh’ resonates with people of all ages due to its relatable characters and heart-warming stories, addressing themes such as friendship, love, and the pursuit of happiness.
"Sometimes, if you stand on the bottom rail of a bridge and lean over to watch the river slipping slowly away beneath you, you will suddenly know everything there is to be known" Pooh. 
Dr Raguram
19/01/24, 7:53 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
19/01/24, 7:53 am - Dr Raguram: When I look at a painting by Paul Cezanne (whose birthday is today), I am attracted to his innovative use of colour, particularly its relationship with form. His visual language is uniquely personal. There is a magical quality in his canvases which are replete with use of multitude of colours and distinctive brush strokes. He explored an amazing range of subjects throughout his career: landscape, portraiture, figures and still life. I am particularly fond of his still life paintings. In the hands of an unimaginative artist, still life can be quite stilted, but not in Cezanne’s hands. He was particularly drawn into painting fruits, particularly apples which take on an inexplicable lustrous luminosity in his paintings. He confided to a friend that "they [fruits] love having their portraits done. They exhale their message with their scent. They reach you with all their smells and tell you about the fields they’ve left, the rain that made them grow, the dawns they watched. When I’m outlining the skin of a lovely peach with soft touches of paint, or a sad old apple, I catch a glimpse in the reflections they exchange of . . . the same love of the sun, the same recollection of the dew, a freshness." 
How should one look at his paintings? In his own words, “Shut your eyes, wait, and think of nothing. Now, open them … one sees nothing but a great coloured undulation. What then? An irradiation and glory of colour. This is what a picture should give us … an abyss in which the eye is lost, a secret germination, a coloured state of grace … loose consciousness. Descend with the painter into the dim tangled roots of things, and rise again from them in colours, be steeped in the light of them.”
Now look at Cezanne’s apples and see them come alive!

20/01/24, 7:01 am - Dr Raguram: You cannot miss the European Robin when you take a stroll in the gardens of London. unlike its counterpart in America, it is a colourful bird with a striking orange breast. As you watch, it makes forays to the ground to catch insects and quickly flies back to its shady perch. The French naturalist Georges Cuvie gave the bird its current name Erithacus rubecula. The epithet rubecula is derived from the Latin, ruber ‘red’.
The Victorian postmen used to be known as robins because part of their tunic was orange red. When Christmas cards first came into vogue they were brought by robins! And robins started featuring in the in the Christmas cards too.
There is a wealth of Christian mythology associated with it. The legend is that the robin was moved when it saw Christ on the cross and began to pluck the thorns out of the crown of thorns.  The blood stained the robin and hence its orange red breast. According to an Irish tale, a robin flew in to see the infant Jesus in the manger. The infant reached out to touch the bird causing it to blush in deference and hence its colour!  
Shakespeare refers to the charming song of the European Robin in Two Gentlemen of Verona. 
Valentine: Why, how know you that I am in love?
Speed: Marry, by these special marks: first, you have learned, like Sir Proteus, to wreathe your arms like a malcontent; to relish a love song like a robin redbreast; to walk alone like one that had the pestilence; to sigh like a schoolboy that had lost his ABC; to weep like a young wench that had buried her grandam; to fast like one that takes diet; to watch like one that fears robbing; to speak puling like a beggar at Hallowmas.
Emily Dickinson wrote a lovely small poem about it:
If I can stop one heart from breaking,
I shall not live in vain;
If I can ease one life the aching,
Or cool one pain,
Or help one fainting robin
Unto his nest again,
I shall not live in vain. 
It is believed that when a robin appears, it is a sign that a loved one is near.

21/01/24, 8:55 am - Dr Raguram: It is always so wonderful to see the Malabar Giant Squirrel prancing from one tree branch to another. It will pause for a while to eat fruits with its tiny hands and scramble to the upper reaches of the canopy in a flash of a second. The multi-coloured magician is adept in nimbly disappearing without a trace. They build their nests, called dreys, in close proximity to each other and use them as decoys to fool predators. The joy of observing them up close is truly memorable.
I had my first glimpse of it several decades ago in Bandipur. I had gone with a group of students and when we ventured into the forest, I heard a very unusual call. As I was scouting to locate its source with the binocular, I was delighted to find to find the Malabar Giant Squirrel in the upper reaches of a tree a few hundred feet away. Overjoyed to sight it, I passed the binoculars around so that others could see it. While they were engrossed watching it, I turned back and was shocked to find a lone tusker not too far away. I gently tapped them and whispered, “Hey, there is a tusker here”, only to be meet with a response, “Don’t joke Sir”. Their reaction soon turned into alarm when they turned around and saw the tusker. Overwhelmed with increasing fright, we all gave a loud shout and ran for our lives. Catching up with my breath after some time, when I looked back, I saw the tusker turning its back and making its way into the forest. 
Oblivious to this drama, the Giant Squirrel was foraging amongst the branches of tree with sheer abandon at a distance. 
(Incidentally 21st January, is a Squirrel Appreciation Day!)
Dr Raguram
23/01/24, 9:11 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
23/01/24, 9:11 am - Dr Raguram: Sometime back we visited Avani in Kolar district (a detailed description is at: (https://www.profraguram.com/musings--reflections/avani). Avani attained prominence due to myriad legends associated with it. Most importantly, it is said to be the site of Uttara Ramayana. There is a small beautiful, Ramalingeshwara temple which dates back to 10th century. A hillock strewn with boulders forms an interesting backdrop to this ancient temple. It is believed that Sita retreated to this hill after her trial by fire and gave birth to Lava and Kusha who grew up in the hermitage of Valmiki. There are several caves; one of them is considered to be Valmiki’s ashram and another one where Sita lived and cooked for her children. 
I was keen to find out whether there are other places identified as Sita’s Kitchen. To my great surprise, I discovered that there are several Sita’s Rasoi (kitchen) dotted across the subcontinent. At least two of Sita’s kitchens have been documented in Ayodhya, but only one survived the demolition of the Babri Masjid. I understand that within the complex on the Ramkot in Ayodhya, there is a building bearing the painted phrase “Janmasthana Sita Rasoi” (Birthplace Sita’s Kitchen). The garbhagriha contains a rolling board, rolling pin, chulha and an image of Sita.  
When I searched for other ‘Sita’s Rasois’, I found documentation of several others: Lalapur near Allahabad, Chitrakoot, Brahmavarta in UP and Nasik in Maharashtra amongst others. Each one of them is adjacent to Valmiki’s ashram and similarly contain a rolling pin, board and a chulha. 
I also looked for mention of Sita and her kitchen in many of the Ramayanas. There were none. An array of localized narratives and memories associated with Sita and her kitchen seemed to have evolved over time across the country. It would be a fascinating exercise to explore how these memories of the past have been constructed, celebrated and sometimes politically appropriated too. 
While Rama is valorised and huge temples are built to honour him, for some inexplicable reason, Sita has been relegated and confined to the kitchen. Is her power and authority confined to the kitchen alone? Cooking, to a large extent has been embedded in the patriarchal construction of femininity. If the kitchen is a feminine abode, it might also be a site of resistance.
In the animated film, ‘Sita Sings The Blues’, Nina Paley relocates her as a woman who retells her own story in her own voice in an altogether different context. Sita’s songs not only give her a voice.
Perhaps it is time to retell the Ramayana from the perspective of Sita.

25/01/24, 9:32 am - Dr Raguram: Nambinarayana temple is at Thirukurungudi, a serene village in Tirunelveli district. It is a beautiful temple with hundreds of sculptures and carvings. Of the several lovely ones in the main gopuram, an interesting one depicts a seated Rama contemplating as to how he can journey across the sea to reach Lanka. For three days he fasted and meditated, praying to the God of the sea, Varuna, to appear and to help him find a way to cross to Lanka. There was no response, nothing but the endless, repetitive sound of the waves. Rama, infuriated by this unbearable silence picked up his bow and began to shoot arrows into the sea. The creatures of the sea began to die, and the waters began to burn. The army of monkeys who had come to help Rama were aghast and alarmed at this display of violence against the sea and her innocent creatures and tried to dissuade him to stop the onslaught. Just as Rama was about to unleash the all-powerful weapon, Brahmastra, Varuna appeared out of the sea. He bowed to Rama and calmly explained that there was nothing to be so upset about and that he would ensure that the waves would remain still while a way was found for Rama’s forces to cross the sea, and that they would remain calm until they had completed their crossing. Then, Hanuman came up with a solution and assured Rama that he along with other monkeys would build a bridge. 
In this small carving you can see Rama and in front of him is Varuna. Lakshmana is standing behind him. He is surrounded by the army of monkeys. Hanuman at his feet and another one by Rama’s side are trying to dissuade him from taking any drastic action. 
The bridge as a metaphor, conveys multifaceted meanings. It symbolizes a sense of connectedness and union, both physically and psychologically. Even the process of building the structure is not merely an individual act, but a collective one driven by a common cause to link and join together that which is disparate and separate. Something to ponder and reflect on…

The First World War unleashed humanity’s power to harm and kill, a trend that has gotten worse with the advent of the nuclear power. The poem is replete with lots of Biblical allusions. The “falconer,” representing our attempt to control the natural world, has lost its “falcon” in the ever expanding “gyre” (of progress?). The poet alludes to an evolving situation when "Things fall apart; the centre cannot hold." 
“The falcon cannot hear the falconer;
Things fall apart; the centre cannot hold;
Mere anarchy is loosed upon the world,
The blood-dimmed tide is loosed, and everywhere
The ceremony of innocence is drowned;
The best lack all conviction, while the worst
Are full of passionate intensity.”
Though written decades ago, these lines, imbued with timeless allegory, resonate even now,

01/02/24, 8:04 am - Dr Raguram: Every time I step into the bronze gallery of the Chennai museum, I am overwhelmed by the sheer beauty of the priceless exhibits encompassed in its glass display cases. The most impressive pieces are that of Siva as the cosmic dancer, Nataraja.  
Whenever I look at them, I recollect the words of Fritjof Capra, (whose birthday is today),in ‘The Tao of Physics’, relating the Nataraja’s dance with modern physics: 
“Every subatomic particle not only performs an energy dance, but also is an energy dance; a pulsating process of creation and destruction…without end…For the modern physicists then, Shiva’s dance is the dance of subatomic matter. As in Hindu mythology, it is a continual dance of creation and destruction involving the whole cosmos; the basis of all existence and of all natural phenomena...the metaphor of the cosmic dance thus unifies ancient mythology, religious art and modern physics.” 
He went on to comment, “The mystic and the physicist arrive at the same conclusion; one starting from the inner realm, the other from the outer world. The harmony between their views confirms the ancient Indian wisdom that Brahman, the ultimate reality without, is identical to Atman, the reality within.” 
In the words of Appar, the seventh century Shaivaite poet saint, who went to Chidambaram to see the cosmic dance of Siva, 
குனித்த புருவமும் கொவ்வைச் செவ்வாயில் குமிண்சிரிப்பும் 
பனித்த சடையும் பவளம்போல் மேனியில் பால் வெண்ணீறும் 
இனித்தம் உடைய எடுத்த பொற்பாதமும் காணப்பெற்றால் 
மனித்தப் பிறவியும் வேண்டுவதே இந்த மாநிலத்தே 
“If you could see 
the arch of his brow 
the budding smile 
on his lips red as the kovvai fruit 
cool matted hair 
the milk-white ash on coral skin 
and the golden foot raised up in dance 
our birth on this earth is fulfilled” 
In sculptures, paintings and verses, Nataraja continues to dance...beyond time.

02/02/24, 8:19 am - Dr Raguram: It was a breezy early morning and I was standing on the banks of a large swathes of wetland. The air resonated with myriad calls of birds that inhabited the vast terrain. I was totally amazed at the wide variety of birds in front of me. Suddenly, I noticed a flash of light and it was the bronze winged jacana. The early morning sun was caressing its beautiful plumage with lustrous hues. It was foraging on the aquatic vegetation, daintily balancing itself on the water with its long feet and toes, with the elegance of a ballerina.These wetlands provide crucial breeding, nesting and feeding habitats for countless numbers of birds. 
Wetlands and human beings are all part of a delicate and interconnected ecosystem.They play a vital role in treating and detoxifying a variety of waste products and are often described as earth’s kidneys. In addition, through sequestering and releasing a major portion of fixed carbon they are important regulators of global climate change.
February 2nd of each year is observed globally as World Wetlands Day to raise awareness about the value of wetlands for nature and society. The theme this year is ‘wetlands and human wellbeing.’ It emphasizes how all aspects of human well-being are linked to the health of the world’s wetlands and calls on each of us to value their importance. 
While it is heartening to notice that three new wetlands are added to the Ramsar sites in Karnatka, it is equally saddening to witness increasing habitat fragmentation, polluting  runoff and invasive species that plague the wetlands especially in rapidly urbanizing areas, like Bangalore.
As Sandra Postel, a renowned expert on freshwater ecosystems cautioned, “For many of us, water simply flows from a faucet, and we think little about it beyond this point of contact. We have lost a sense of respect for the wild river, for the complex workings of a wetland, for the intricate web of life that water supports”

04/02/24, 9:45 am - Dr Raguram: One of the earliest writings of J Krishnamurti was 'The Song of Life' which was published in 1931. It is a profound, thought provoking work, offering deep insights about JK as a seeker and a poet. The final lines of the poem are in this photograph and I have taken the liberty to quote it in its entirety;
I have no name;
I am as the fresh breeze of the mountains.
I have no shelter;
I am as the wandering waters.
I have no sanctuary, like the dark gods;
Nor am I in the shadow of deep temples.
I have no sacred books;
Nor am I well-seasoned in tradition.
I am not in the incense burning upon the high altars;
Nor in the pomp of ceremonies.
I am neither in the graven image;
Nor in the rich chant of a melodious voice.
I am not bound by theories;
Nor corrupted by beliefs.
I am not held in the bondage of religions;
Nor in the pious agony of their priests.
I am not entrapped by philosophies;
Nor held in the power of their sects.
I am neither low nor high;
I am the worshipper and the worshipped.
I am free.
My song is the song of the river calling for the open seas;
Wandering, wandering;

06/02/24, 8:59 am - Dr Raguram: Farid ud-Din Attar was considered by Rumi to be “the master of sufi poetry”. The “Conference of the Birds” by him is an engaging parable about the mystical quest for the Truth. It features a host of birds led by the hoopoe, who acts as their spiritual guide in their quest. In their journey, the birds travel through the seven valleys of the quest, love, understanding, independence and detachment, unity, astonishment, and finally to a state of nothingness. In this allegorical text, many of us can locate ourselves amidst these different valleys. 
Let us strive to head to the words of the Hoopoe;
“The ocean can be yours; why should you stop  
Beguiled by dreams of evanescent dew?”

LEAVES
Years do odd things to identity.
What does it mean to say
I am that child in the photograph
at Kishamish in 1935?

of a leaf of the acacia tree
felled seventy years ago

flicker of shade and sunlight

08/02/24, 8:53 am - Dr Raguram: In one of the safaris in Kanha, the driver took us on a dirt track, away from other vehicles. As I was soaking in the soothing ambiance of the forest, I noticed a tiger just ahead of us. He kept us company for over the next fifteen minutes. Suddenly he stopped right in front of us. He was looking at me and our eyes locked. His stunning eyes never wavered. I experienced a profound connection through that intense gaze. I was immersed in listening to the unspoken language of his eyes. At that moment I understood what Martin Buber (whose birthday is today) meant when he commented that "An animal's eyes have the power to speak a great language." It is a powerful reminder that the most fulfilling and genuine moments in life are found through the act of connecting deeply with another being.

11/02/24, 8:50 am - Dr Raguram: London is full of blue plaques. They dot the walls of buildings throughout London, marking the places where scientists, artists, politicians and activists who lived and worked there. When I was on a Commonwealth Fellowship, I made it a point to visit as many of them. One address I was keen to locate was No 1, Fitzroy Road where WB Yeats lived for a while. It was also the building where Sylvia Plath, a poet whom I admire deeply, spent her last days before ending her life on February 11th 1963.
Poets die young and not so often by suicide. Perhaps the act of writing poetry fascinates the wounded and in the process also opens up fresh wounds. Syvia Plath was no exception. In her thinly veiled autobiographical novel, ‘Bell Jar’, she wrote, “Death must be so beautiful. To lie in the soft brown earth, with the grasses waving above one's head, and listen to silence. To have no yesterday, and no to-morrow. To forget time, to forgive life, to be at peace”. Pensive by disposition, she kept ruminating about it, which found expression in these lines which she wrote ten days before ending her life:
“The blood jet is poetry,
There is no stopping it”.
There are a multitude of ways in which Sylvia Plath’s life and her final act has been analyzed and debated. Beyond these lenses of scrutiny her existential angst was enmeshed in a troubled past and a tumultuous relationship with her husband Ted Hughes. Perhaps the most insightful and poignant account about Syliva Plath’s suicide was by her friend A Alvarez in his book, ‘The Savage God’, which we reviewed in NIMHANS in the late 70s. In the first page of the book, there is a quote by Cesare Pavese, regarded as one of Italy's most important twentieth-century poets, which says it all:"No one ever lacks a good reason for suicide."

12/02/24, 8:08 am - Dr Raguram: In a series of groundbreaking studies conducted in the late 1930s, psychologist Kurt Lewin (who was born on this day), identified three core styles of leadership; Authoritarian (autocratic) leadership. Participative (democratic) leadership and Delegative (laissez-faire) leadership.
Over the past decade we are witnessing the rise of populist, authoritarian, strong-man politicians across the globe. Its seductive appeal necessitates a detailed sociological enquiry! However, a political leadership that rules on the basis of fear, threat, intimidation, and advocating one worldview as superior while silencing diversity of opinions and dissent is in my opinion will lead to fragmentation of society. Unfortunately an authoritarian world view is not confined to the political arena. It seeps into and influences people's attitudes, impacts institutional ethos in centres of learning and more importantly, festers lack of trust. The more we portray the ‘others’ as threat, the greater the harm to the fabric that binds and holds us all together.  
The harmful impact of authoritarian attitude in a leader is accentuated once it is tinged with narcissistic traits, resulting in an overwhelming need for control with an inflated sense of self-worth. They strongly adhere to the  belief that they should be in charge and expect others to conform to their views and desires, often holding people with differing viewpoints in contempt. These leaders insist on strict conformity to their beliefs and tend to view the world in binary terms; you are either with them or against them. This black-and-white perspective creates a hostile environment where individuals are categorized as friends or foes based on their willingness to conform. Such a rigid stance stifles open dialogue and learning from others. 
As George Orwell observed presciently in 1984, it leads to “processions, meetings, military parades, lectures, waxwork displays, film shows, telescreen programs all had to be organized; stands had to be erected, effigies built, slogans coined, songs written, rumours circulated, photographs faked.”

13/02/24, 8:35 am - Dr Raguram: Sarojini Naidu, born on 13th February 1879,  was one of the most outstanding figures of the independence movement. An equally talented poet in English, she was known as “The Nightingale of India”. Her poetry brims with strong emotions expressed in lyrical verses. An ardent admirer of nature, she was also a great lover of birds. 
I am particularly drawn (given my passion for them!) to her poem ‘Bird of Time’, wherein she expresses the workings of time through the movements of a bird. Just as we don’t expect a bird to be still, time too is fleeting. Life and death, sorrow and hope, time encompasses them all in this poem.
BIRD OF TIME
O Bird of Time on your fruitful bough
What are the songs you sing? …
Songs of the glory and gladness of life,
Of poignant sorrow and passionate strife,
And the lilting joy of the spring;
Of hope that sows for the years unborn,
And faith that dreams of a tarrying morn,
The fragrant peace of the twilight’s breath,
And the mystic silence that men call death.

O Bird of Time, say where did you learn
The changing measures you sing? …
In blowing forests and breaking tides,
In the happy laughter of new-made brides,
And the nests of the new-born spring;
In the dawn that thrills to a mother’s prayer,
And the night that shelters a heart’s despair,
In the sigh of pity, the sob of hate,
And the pride of a soul that has conquered fate.
In one of last letters she wrote, ” While I live, it will always be the supreme desire of my Soul to write poetry —one poem, one line of enduring verse even. Perhaps I shall die without realising that longing which is at once an exquisite joy and an unspeakable anguish to me”.
