16/02/24, 8:39 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
16/02/24, 8:39 am - Dr Raguram: Nicheren (February 16, 1222 - November 14, 1282) was one of the most influential Japanese  priests who preached tenets of Mahayana Buddhism. An important sutra of Mahayana Buddhism is the ‘Lotus Sutra’ which was written between 100 B.C. and 200 A.D. Already well known in India, it became one of the important sutras of Chinese Buddhism and later in Japan.. 
It is named the ‘Lotus Sutra’ because the lotus symbolises the oneness of cause and effect since the lotus is a flower that blooms and seeds at the same time. Moreover, it also signifies  the purity of Buddhahood, blooming in the midst of our ordinary lives just as the lotus blossoms in muddy pond water. What the ‘Lotus Sutra’ essentially emphasizes  is that all living beings, whether they realize it or not, have the capacity to become enlightened. Everyone, without exception, can unlock the perfect wisdom and great compassion that reside in the depths of life. 
Nichiren established the practice of reciting the ‘Lotus Sutra's’ title,” Nam-myoho-renge-kyo”, to make the path to enlightenment accessible to all. It is no ordinary phrase and is the essence of the entire ‘Lotus Sutra’. The phrase "Namu-myoho-renge-kyo" literally translates to "I take refuge in the Lotus of the Wonderful Law". Nam: Comes from the Sanskrit word namas, which means to devote or dedicate oneself. Myo: is usually translated as wonderful. Ho: Means law. Renge, meaning lotus blossom. The lotus flower is pure and fragrant, unsullied by the muddy water in which it grows. Similarly, the beauty and dignity of our humanity is brought forth amidst the sufferings of daily lives. Kyo literally means sutra. Chanting the mantra is called daimoku. The purpose of chanting daimoku is to attain perfect and complete awakening. It is an expression of determination, to embrace and realize our Buddha nature. Nichiren taught that to chant “Nam-myoho-renge-kyo” is to bring forth the Buddhahood that exists inherently within all of us.
Dr Raguram

17/02/24, 7:57 am - Dr Raguram: In the 60s Eshwari Lending Library in Chennai was my stomping ground. One day I picked up a book ‘The Chosen’ by Chaim Potok, sheerly by chance. When I started reading it, I was put off initially by an extensive description of a baseball match in the first 30 pages of the book. I persisted nevertheless and couldn’t put the book down after that. The novel opened me up to another time and another world which I was not familiar with,till then. 
It is a story about two Jewish teens from different backgrounds; Reuven Malter, hailing from an Orthodox family and Danny Sanders from a Hasidic background. It details the bond between the two and the relationship each has with his father. Relationships between fathers and sons figure prominently in ‘The Chosen’, especially in the choices of the sons' careers. Danny's father expects him to become a rabbi and leader of his Hasidic sect, following the tradition of generations, while Reuven's father lets him choose his own path. Daniel has decided not to become a Tzaddik, but to follow his heart, attend graduate school and become a psychologist. Reuven has made up his mind to become a Rabbi, despite his great talent for logic and mathematics. Reuven and Danny both have one thing in common, trying to decide on whether they should be something that was chosen for them or something they want to be.
I had just finished PUC at the time I read the book and was drawn to the main theme of the book, ‘Choosing and Being Chosen’. Hailing from a family wherein my grandfather was a well known doctor, the implicit expectation was that I should follow his path. I wasn’t so sure at that time as I was drawn more to liberal arts. Perhaps I was ‘chosen’ to become a doctor and that too a psychiatrist!
When I read this book again, I was particularly drawn to this passage in the book, “Human beings do not live forever… We live less than the time it takes to blink an eye, if we measure against eternity.  So it may be asked what value is there to a human life.  There is so much pain in the world. What does it mean to suffer so much if our lives are nothing more than the blink of an eye?…  I learned a long time ago … that a blink of an eye in itself is nothing.  But the eye that blinks, that is something.  A span of life is nothing.  But the man who lives that span, he is something.  He can fill that tiny span with meaning, so its quality is immeasurable though its quantity may be insignificant.  …  A man must fill his life with meaning, meaning is not automatically given to life”.

18/02/24, 8:26 am - Dr Raguram: Another book I had picked up those days at Easwari lending library was the novel ‘Zorba the Greek’. Much like ‘The Chosen’, it is the story of two men: Zorba, a Greek working man and a wealthy, young narrator and their incredible friendship. The two of them  couldn’t be further apart. The narrator is cerebral, modest, and reserved; Zorba is unfettered and spirited.The younger man reads all day. He’s an aficionado of Buddhist philosophy, the exact opposite world view of Zorba who has such lust for life. These two characters represent two distinct ways of life. The implicit question throughout the book: which is better? Being a “stable” person and being accepted and respected in society, or being an indulgent  person living his life full. Both are searching for answers. The Narrator has a  desire to change, but he adamantly resists Zorba’s philosophy, despite admitting to admiring it and  wishing he could assimilate it with his own. The relationship between these two characters symbolizes the conversation between the head and the heart, the mind and the spirit, what Nietzsche referred to as the Apollonian and the Dionysian impulses. Kazantzakis masterfully interweaves these dual perspectives of human nature. The book is also an important reminder to embrace the transience of life, to seize the moments that bring us joy, unfettered by intellectual curiosity. A passage in the book by the narrator illustrates this perspective:
“I remember one morning when I discovered a cocoon in the back of a  tree just as a butterfly was making a hole in its case and preparing  to come out. I waited a while, but it was too long appearing and I was impatient. I bent over it and breathed on it to warm it. I warmed it as quickly as I could and the miracle began to happen before my eyes faster than life. The case opened; the butterfly started slowly crawling out, and I shall never forget my horror when I saw how its wings were folded back and crumpled; the wretched butterfly tried with its whole trembling body to unfold them. Bending over it, I tried  to help it with my breath, in vain.  It needed to be hatched out patiently and the unfolding of the wings  should be a gradual process in the sun. Now it was too late. My breath had forced the butterfly to appear all crumpled, before its time. It struggled desperately and, a few seconds later, died in the palm of my hand. That little body is, I do believe, the greatest weight I have on my  conscience. For, I realize today that it is a mortal sin to violate great laws of nature. We should not hurry, we should not be impatient, but we should confidently obey the external rhythm”.
A viewpoint summarized in the gravestone of the author, Nikos Kazantzakis,"I hope for nothing. I fear nothing. I am free."
(And who can forget Anthony Quinn bringing the most life-affirming character of Zorba alive  in the movie version of the book with the Zorba the Greek song brimming with life?)

20/02/24, 8:28 am - Dr Raguram: When I visited Yosemite sometime ago, I felt overwhelmed with the enormous expanse of its enchanting landscape. It was much like losing myself in a vast heritage temple which was built aeons ago. I felt humbled in the presence of its towering granite cliffs, lush meadows, forested valleys and dramatic seasonal waterfalls. It was a mystical experience. 
One person who brought out its magical realm in tangible ways for us to relish was Anselm Adams, whose birthday is today. Yosemite was Ansel Adam’s muse.When he looked through his camera lens, he saw more than it's rocks, trees, and rivers. He saw art. Adams explored and recorded the grandeur of nature in stunning black and white photographs,conveying its beauty in lyrical ways. His elegant compositions with tantalizing play of light across its incredible terrain exude a certain sense of calmness. 
As Adams observed, “The whole world is, to me, very much alive, all the little growing things, even the rocks…I can’t look at a swell bit of grass and earth, for instance, without feeling the essential life, the things going on, within them”. 
I put myself in Adam’s shoes, when I stood in front of the half dome, where he has taken many of his stunning photographs and froze that moment in this frame

22/02/24, 8:06 am - Dr Raguram: Takahama Kyoshi (born on 22nd February1874) was a great haiku poet in the history of modern Japanese haiku literature. He wrote more than two hundred thousand haikus in his lifetime. 
He defined haiku as the poetry of ‘ka-cho-fuhei’, literally meaning “an elegant way of describing bird and flower”. Not surprisingly then, nature in all manifestations figure prominently in his haikus.
One day Kyoshi was sweeping his garden, trying to get rid of cobwebs. To his great dismay, when he  returned later, he found another spider had spun a new web. Though annoyed for a second, he realized that it is the natural behaviour of the spider to keep spinning webs. In a moment, he identified with the spider. He himself has to keep creating haiku as long as he lives, much like the spider. That's the call and beauty of life.
And he sat down and wrote this beautiful haiku:
“Born as a spider
No choice but to spin
His spider web”
The spider is aware that the web it spins will not last long. Yet it doesn’t tire itself in spinning one. The cadence of our existence is in lending an ear to the melody of life’s ephemeral quality and embracing it.
In the timeless words of Gulzar:
“आने वाला पल , जाने वाला है
हो सके तो इस में
ज़िदंगी बिता दो
पल जो ये जाने वाला है”

23/02/24, 8:44 am - Dr Raguram: For a long time I shied away reading, ‘The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich’, as the very thought of reading about a misanthropic, racist, megalomaniac ruler who caused so much human misery, was sheer anathema for me.
I dipped into the book several years later. Usually I read books at a stretch, but not with this voluminous one spread over a thousand pages. 
Once I finished reading it, my first thought was one of appreciation about the author, William Shirer, whose birthday is today. A talented journalist, he had interviewed Mahatma Gandhi several times and wrote an interesting book about these encounters.
But nothing prepared him for the demonic, spellbinding charisma he witnessed when he took up residence in Berlin in 1934 where he began to chronicle the rise of the Third Reich under Adolf Hitler. His contempt is not for Hitler so much as for the “little men of German”, for the culture that acceded to Hitler and Nazism so readily
Charlemagne is often considered as Germany’s First Reich. He was followed by the Second Reich, Bismarck who felt betrayed by the supposed treachery of Jews. When all of Germany was awaiting the Third Reich as a saviour, Adolf Hitler stepped in. 
Shirer is mainly concerned with charting the rise to power of this ruthless man, how he bullied and threatened his way to convince a large population, which was unreflectively taken by his promise of a ‘Thousand Year Reich’, which only lasted a total of 12 years, 4 months, and 8 days. But during that brief span it wrought havoc and destruction on a scale never witnessed before, that resulted in their own ruin.
Shirer is no historian. As he observed, “Journalism is the first draft of history”, His scrutinizing lens is that of an observant journalist. There is no overarching historical explanation of the Third Reich, but a rich account of its rise and fall.
The book is a reminder that there is danger in giving up our sense of selfhood for the illusory unity of a frenzied mass movement, championed by a narcissistic, charismatic leader.
Couple of quotes to reflect upon from the book:
“The broad masses of a population are more amenable to the appeal of rhetoric than to any other force”.
“With a shrewdness that never deserted him Hitler carefully calculated the precipitation of one crisis upon another so that he was always moving in the driver's seat at the center of the stage”.
“The most dangerous people in the world are not those who carry guns and bombs, but those who carry blind hatred in their hearts”.
And lastly:
“Doubt is the beginning of wisdom”.

24/02/24, 8:05 am - Dr Raguram: Sometime ago I had posted about the intriguing interface between the private and the public self.
Jorge Luis Borges, whom I admire deeply, wrote the shortest of short stories, ‘Borges and I’. It is a fascinating read, raising an interesting question, “Is Borges the man or  Borges the writer”? When a writer articulates his experiences and expresses them on paper,does he assume a different persona? In an essay which he wrote in 1919, TS Eliot wondered whether, “the more perfect the artist, the more completely separate in him will be the man who suffers and the mind which creates”. Borges is a lover of paradox and doesn’t attempt to ‘resolve’ this question. His story ends tantalizingly with these words, “I do not know which of us has written this page”.
BORGES and I
The other one, the one called Borges], is the one things happen to. I walk through the streets of Buenos Aires and stop for a moment, perhaps mechanically now, to look at the arch of an entrance hall and the grillwork on the gate; I know of Borges from the mail and see his name on a list of professors or in a biographical dictionary. I like hourglasses, maps, eighteenth-century typography, the taste of coffee and the prose of Stevenson; he shares these preferences, but in a vain way that turns them into the attributes of an actor. It would be an exaggeration to say that ours is a hostile relationship; I live, let myself go on living, so that Borges may contrive his literature, and this literature justifies me. It is no effort for me to confess that he has achieved some valid pages, but those pages cannot save me], perhaps because what is good belongs to no one, not even to him, but rather to the language and to tradition. Besides, I am destined to perish,definitely and only some instant of myself can survive in him. Little by little, I am giving over everything to him, though I am quite aware of his perverse custom of falsifying and magnifying things].
Spinoza knew that all things long to persist in their being; the stone eternally wants to be a stone and the tiger a tiger. I shall remain in Borges, not in myself (if it is true that I am someone), but I recognize myself less in his books than in many others or in the laborious strumming of a guitar. Years ago I tried to free myself from him and went from the mythologies of the suburbs to the games with time and infinity, but those games belong to Borges now and I shall have to imagine other things. Thus my life is a flight and I lose everything and everything belongs to oblivion, or to him.
I do not know which of us has written this page.
(From Labyrinths: ‘Selected Stories and Other Writings’) 
This final sentence of the story entices the reader to venture into the labyrinth of labyrinths to explore who is ‘really’ fictional in this mirror world!!

25/02/24, 8:59 am - Dr Raguram: Both Ahalya and myself are ardent Beatles aficionados. We must have listened to ‘Sgt.Peppers Lonely Heart Club’ umpteen number of times. Each time it is a revelation of the group’s immense talents and originality. Each and every song in it is a gem, Amidst them, the  ‘Within and Without You’, stands out for its melodious tones inspired by Indian music.George Harrison (whose birthday is today) was learning sitar from Pandit Ravi Shankar at that time and used it in the song beautifully. The tune was partially based on a lengthy suite Shankar had written for All-India Radio.It has a sinuous quality and its sweeping tunes cast a spell.
One can consider this song as the most philosophical in the entire album. George was quite influenced by the book, ‘Autobiography of a Yogi’, by Paramahamsa Yogananda. Its underlying theme is the importance of self knowledge. in order for a person to freely love and realize self-knowledge, he/she must become less attached to the things of the world which might deter him from reaching such a state. Harrison is encouraging the listener to go “within” themselves. And at the same time, in order to successfully do so one has to be “without” himself. And to be “without” himself involves casting aside one’s worldly concerns. In essence, this is one of the well-recognized aspects for effective meditative practice.
When you've seen beyond yourself
Then you may find peace of mind is waiting there
And the time will come when you see we're all one
And life flows on within you and without you

27/02/24, 8:07 am - Dr Raguram: A good poem opens up a new world and takes you on a memorable journey. Henry Wadswoth Longfellow’s, ‘Nature’ is one such. 
The simple, unpretentious opening lines of the poem portray a familiar scene that happens in most of our homes; a mother trying to put her child to sleep. The child’s ‘broken playthings’ are scattered on the floor, and he is  “half willing" to abandon the play and retire for the night. He lingers, staring longingly at the toys he has left behind.
The next few lines venture into a new territory all together. The poet compares the  mother whom he just described eloquently, to mother nature. Both are essentially caretakers of all of us. Nature is to man, what a mother is to her child. As we advance in years, nature gradually takes away all our earthly possessions and gently guides us to the world beyond. Since often we are greatly attached to our earthly life and our belongings, we are never too willing to proceed towards that goal. But nature leads us just like the mother leading the child to sleep,taking away our "playthings" one at a time. The poet suggests that our earthly desires and attachments are like playthings that we must eventually relinquish to discover the unknown mysteries of life..
Why did this poem appeal to me? I was drawn (and still continue to be!) by the simple imagery of a mother putting a reluctant child to sleep, which slowly blends itself into a very powerful metaphor of a nurturing nature that prepares us for our journey beyond this world. There is much wisdom in these lines;
NATURE
As a fond mother, when the day is o'er,
   Leads by the hand her little child to bed,
   Half willing, half reluctant to be led,
   And leave his broken playthings on the floor,
Still gazing at them through the open door,
   Nor wholly reassured and comforted
   By promises of others in their stead,
   Which, though more splendid, may not please him more;
So Nature deals with us, and takes away
   Our playthings one by one, and by the hand
   Leads us to rest so gently, that we go
Scarce knowing if we wish to go or stay,
   Being too full of sleep to understand
   How far the unknown transcends the what we know.
(Henry Wadswoth Longfellow born on this day on 1807)
Dr Raguram

29/02/24, 8:03 am - Dr Raguram: Tore Ørjasæter (March 3rd,1886 - February 29th1968) was a Norwegian poet who was rooted in the folk tradition and wrote many lyrical poems about nature. Unfortunately only very few of them have been translated into English. Cries of Gulls is one such gem:
CRIES OF GULLS
Sheer rock and steep faces of Lofot,
bird-cliff and thousands
of seagulls that circle round mast and hull.
Let themselves glide on powerful wings
towards the open sea, - it breathes towards them
and receives like an open mind.
Soon after the storm has abated,
the sea’s bosom still goes on heaving.
The swell lifts the heavy sea
closer up to the horizon
that constantly escapes and dies out quietly
to new heights on the skyline
that once more breathes out and escapes
like time dies out within the age.
Oh these free cries of gulls
towards the open sea! It is like breathing
out one’s longings and never landing.

01/03/24, 9:04 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
01/03/24, 9:04 am - Dr Raguram: Rhythmic highs and lows of life can spark the creative urge within ourselves. But when the intensity of the swings are severe, it causes immense suffering to those in the midst of it. Rober Lowell, whose birthday is today, suffered from a severe form of bipolar illness which started early in his life. Mental illness ran deep in his family and his life was laden with instability; for thirty years he was in and out of mental hospitals. The manic episodes were extremely disruptive with florid psychotic symptoms, requiring hospitalization, which were invariably followed by periods of depression. 
Fire is a central image in Lowell’s works. His manic episodes were akin to a blaze of fire which took some effect to be quelled. He wrote, “By the time I reached the hospital I was completely out of my head—strange physical sensations—I was a prophet and everything was a symbol; then in the hospital: shouting, singing, tearing things up—religion and antics. Then depression (extreme) aching, self-enclosed, fearful of everyone and everything anyone could do, feeling I was nothing and could do nothing” He termed his manic phase as the “holocaust of irrationality” and depression as the “long, burdensome dull period” with months of “wading in the muck and weeds and backwash of a depression. Depression is an illness for oneself, mania an illness for one’s friends”.
Above all, he was a poet and during one of his admissions, he wrote: 
The resident doctor said,
“We are not deep in ideas, imagination, or enthusiasm—
how can we help you?”
I asked,
“These days of only poems and depression—
what can I do with them?
Will they help me notice
what I cannot bear to look at?” 
Lowell wrote brilliantly about the embers of his illness in an autobiographical piece, “Near the Unbalanced Aquarium”, which is included in his book ‘Memoirs’. The effect of the medication was “like the slowing and ache of a medium fever. One’s thoughts are not directly changed and healed, but the terrible, over-riding restlessness of one’s system is halted so that the mind can see life as it is”. He was given Lithium much later in his life, once it was available for use. Among all the medications and ECTs that were given to him, Lowell found that Lithium was the most effective one. Reflecting about it, hw wondered to his friend, “It's terrible, Bob, to think that all I’ve suffered, and all the suffering I’ve caused, might have arisen from the lack of a little salt in my brain”
What is remarkable is that Lowell continued writing despite the immense suffering due to his mood disorder which wreaked on his life. His courage and determination enabled him to channel the creative fire within, which unfortunately consumed him. 
(There have been many biographies of Robert Lowell, my personal favourite is the exceptional,l ‘Setting the River on Fire’, by Kay Redfeld Jamison)

03/03/24, 8:02 am - Dr Raguram: Humans and wildlife have interacted closely for millions of years, especially during the prehistoric era. The habitat of the prehistoric people were caves. Dwelling there, they embellished the caves with paintings imbued with natural colours. A common theme in their paintings was wildlife, which was not surprising since they lived in close proximity with them. Wildlife was an integral part of their daily lives.  
I had the first glimpse of the richness of the prehistoric cave paintings ranging from the Upper Paleolithic period (around 30,000 years ago) to the mediaeval period, in Bhimbetka. It is one of the most densely painted rock shelters in India. As I walked into its vast terrain, one particular rock shelter caught my attention, which is often referred to as the Zoo Rock. A vast array of various wild animals, painted in profile, covered its rock face. Deers, elephants, leopards, wild buffaloes, bears and boars were galloping on its aged backdrop. The primary colour was white, which dates back  to the Mesolithic period, while a few from later periods were mostly in red. Though the colours had faded with time, the entire scene was brimming with energy, showcasing the close relationship between these ancient painters and the wildlife around them. 
Unfortunately this relationship has frayed over time. The global loss of wildlife is significantly alrarming. According to a 2022 World Wildlife Fund report, global wildlife populations have declined by 69% since 1970.
I am reminded of the story, ‘The Epic of Gilgamesh’, which narrates the great city builder Gilgamesh’s friendship with a “wild man,” Enkidu. Enkidu leads a contented life without human contact, “coated in hair like the god of the animals,” grazing at the water hole with a herd of gazelles, “his heart delighting with the beasts in the water.” Gilgamesh forcibly humanizes Enkidu by sending Shamhat, a priestess, to seduce him. After many days of lovemaking, Enkidu is spurned by the wild animals. He gets a haircut, eats bread, drinks ale and returns with Shamhat to the city.
As modern city dwellers, we are much like the alienated Enkidu, estranged from the rich wildlife around us, making occasional forays to have a glimpse of them amidst the declining forest covers. On the occasion of World Wildlife day and on the background of increasing man-animal conflicts, can we cultivate a more mindful interaction with wild animals at a both personal and  public level and commit ourselves towards sustained conservation and peaceful coexistence?
(And of course, you can see them all at ‘Vantara’…relocated and displaced from their natural habitat. Is that the future of wildlife in India?!)
Dr Raguram

04/03/24, 8:37 am - Dr Raguram: I went for the interview in JIPMER, preparing  myself for all kinds of questions that could be asked in the ‘subjects’. When I stepped in with much trepidation into the room, I was overwhelmed by the presence of half a dozen serious looking gentlemen. An imposing man seated in the centre looked at me and asked, “Young man, why do you want to study medicine?” Without hesitation, I blurted “because I love literature”. The response was on the spur of the moment, totally unrehearsed. My answer must have surprised him and he asked me to mention physicians who were also writers. I spoke for a few minutes about Anton Chekov, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and William Carlos William, amongst others. It was much later that I discovered that the gentleman who asked me the question was the venerable writer GK Gokak who later became President of the Sahithya Academy.
There is always an interesting tryst between the professional call and the personal passion and sometimes they converge. A long list of physician-writers down the ages right from the mediaeval physician, Maimonides, down to Abraham Verghese in recent times, will bear testimony to this. 
William Carlos Williams was a pediatrician and general practitioner. He "worked harder at being a writer than he did at being a physician," His enormous output ranges across short stories, poems, plays, novels, critical essays and an autobiography. In his ‘Doctor Stories’, he gave a glimpse of work; hysterical mothers, obstinate children and poor families with nine kids unable to spare a few dollars for his services. There is an unflinching, straightforward tone in his stories. All the while, he was diligently mining his material for his true call, poetry. 
His poems are simple, spare, with striking imagery. For instance, his lengthy poem, ‘Birds and Flowers’ ends with these beautiful words;
“Though the eye
turns inward, the mind
has spread its embrace — in
a wind that
roughs the stiff petals —
More! the particular flower is
blossoming . . “.

05/03/24, 8:06 am - Dr Raguram: London has the world’s first underground railway system and it is always busy with hordes of busy commuters. It is also the most efficient way to travel in the city, provided there are no strikes or unplanned closures.
For me, one of the pleasures of travelling by the tube was to read the poems that used to adorn the stations. Simply called, ‘Poems from the underground’, it was a veritable collection of verses from across the world. It was also a wonderful introduction to poets whom I neve heard of before. One such poet was Anise Koltz, often referred to as “the great lady of Luxembourg literature.” These particular lines of her, which I had made a note of, were particularly striking.
THE BIRDS WILL STILL SING
“Break my branches
saw me into bits
the birds will still sing
in my roots”
Birds inhabit the same world we do, and yet, they seem capable of transcending it. Though many of them lead lives on the brink of ruin, they still sing. These sparse, powerful, words in the poem convey that even in the midst of destruction unleashed by humans, spirited voices will emerge, rooted in resilience.
This is the anthem for Gaza too…

06/03/24, 8:43 am - Dr Raguram: Georgia O'Keeffe was one of the first female painters to achieve worldwide acclaim.She struggled with depression and anxiety throughout her life. In the midst of it all, she connected with several others who were going through similar psychological tribulations and also got in touch with Frida Kahlo. These connections helped her immensely in her healing process. She also found solace and inspiration in nature. Over the course of her illustrious career she painted around 200 images of flowers, focusing on their innards. Many critics, largely males, claimed that these images were replete with sexual symbolism,which O’Keefee denied vehemently stating that she had only painted the blooms she saw. It is hard to say exactly what O’Keeffe intended to symbolise in her flower paintings. Nevertheless, they are the most iconic images imbued with  undulating forms and soft gradations of tones, exuding a mystical quality. 
In O’Keeffe’s own words: “When you take a flower in your hand and really look at it, it’s your world for the moment. Most people in the city rush around so they have no time to look at a flower. I want them to see it whether they want to or not.”

08/03/24, 9:28 pm - Dr Raguram: There are many legends associated with Mahashivaratri which is being celebrated today. According to one, it was the day when Shiva drank the poison that emerged from the ocean during Amritmanthan, to protect the world. He drank it but held it in his throat instead of swallowing it. Thus, his throat changed to a blue colour and he was then given the name, Nilkantha. According to another legend, when Ganga was descended from heaven after the request of Bhagirath, it was enormous and uncontrollable, so Lord Brahma requested Shiva to control her fall. Shiva agreed to it and he held the rapid flow of Ganga by tying it up in his hair. According to yet another legend, this was the night when Shiva and Parvati got married, an amalgamation of Purusha (mindfulness) and Prakriti (nature). 
I have a particular interest in the mural tradition of south India and went over to the Virupaksha temple sometime back to have a look at the murals that adorn the ranga mantapa. It was fascinating to see the ceiling resplendent with murals depicting scenes from the purana and various narrative episodes from history. Prominent among them is a large panel depicting the marriage of Shiva and Parvati. In the attached photo, starting from the left, one can find Narada, a horse headed Tumburu.. Vishnu and Lakshmi are in the next section. The middle portion depicts the marriage of Shiva and Parvati in exquisite detail.. Brahma is officiating the marriage of Shiva and Parvati with Himavat performing Kanyadan. Three bejewelled women are seen on their right. In the last section on the right, one can notice the three legged Bhringi. The attention to detail, especially the designs in the textiles is quite striking. I was wondering as to how these murals would have looked in their heyday. Temples are not merely places of worship; embellished with magnificent sculptures and paintings, they are repositories of a rich aesthetic tradition which needs to be preserved and protected. I was happy to note that an innovative attempt has been made to digitise these murals. There is an overwhelming need for similar initiatives to conserve many such artistic treasures across the country, which are unfortunately in various stages of neglect.
Dr Raguram

09/03/24, 8:55 am - Dr Raguram: There have been many fictionalized accounts of child abuse. Almost all of them are very unsettling to read as they deal with one of the most harrowing aspects of human behaviour.
Keri Hulme’s ‘The Bone People’, is one such. It was the first work of fiction from New Zealand to win the Booker Prize.
There are three main characters in the novel: a person modelled after the author, a widower who finds and adopts a young mute boy and, finally, the child. It becomes clear quite early that the child suffered abuse even before he was found with no memory on a beach. Unfortunately, he is also abused by his adoptive father. The novel deals with guilt vs impulse for violence of the father, the trauma of the child and the woman's debate over the acceptability of this behaviour. The novel offers a moving, intimate insight into the lives of these three flawed, struggling people. The descriptions of child abuse are quite gut renching.
Ker Hulme took twelve years to write it and it was rejected by many before it was published by a women’s collective. It has a rambling style, switching between first persona and third person narratives, interspersed with poetry. 
It is not a perfect novel, much like the flawed characters it portrays, but there is an unmistakable originality in narration. Some of the imagery in this novel is absolutely breathtaking and there are poetic, evocative descriptions of the New Zealand coastline :
“The color has faded out of the sky. It is grey, becoming darker as the world turns herself round a little more. The clouds are long and black and ragged, like the wings of storm battered dragons.”
(Born on 9th March, 1947, the author died after a prolonged struggle with dementia on 2021)

10/03/24, 8:49 am - Dr Raguram: MEDITATION ON THE AUTUMN LEAF
Thich Nhat Hanh
"I asked the leaf whether it was frightened because it was Autumn and the other leaves were falling.
The leaf told me, “No. During the whole Spring and Summer I was completely alive. I worked hard to help nourish the tree, and now much of me is in the tree. I am not limited by this form. I am also the whole tree, and when I go back to the soil, I will continue to nourish the tree. So I don’t worry at all. As I leave this branch and float to the ground, I will wave to the tree and tell her, ‘I will see you again very soon.”
That day there was a wind blowing and, after a while, I saw the leaf leave the branch and float down to the soil, dancing joyfully, because as it floated it saw itself already there in the tree. It was so happy. I bowed my head, knowing that I have a lot to learn from the leaf.” 
” … So please continue to look back and you will see that you have always been here. Let us look together and penetrate into the life of a leaf, so we may be one with the leaf. Let us penetrate and be one with the cloud or with the wave, to realize our own nature as water and be free from our fear. If we look very deeply, we will transcend birth and death.
Tomorrow, I will continue to be. But you will have to be very attentive to see me. I will be a flower, or a leaf. I will be in these forms and I will say hello to you. If you are attentive enough, you will recognize me, and you may greet me. I will be very happy."

15/03/24, 8:02 am - Dr Raguram: WS Merwin was a widely celebrated poet, winner of two Pulitzers and the  poet laureate of America. He wrote 26 books of poetry, eight books of prose and translated 22 more, including Neruda's love poems, He was a practising Buddhist and a passionate proponent of deep ecology. Merwin lived on an old pineapple plantation in Hawaii which he painstakingly restored to its original rainforest state and died there on 15th March 2019.
Merwin’s poems may seem to be simple. As you read them, the words take hold of you. The sentences come alive, with beautiful imagery of the world around us. “I don't like using the word environment," he commented. "I don't like the word nature. I don't like using them because they make it seem as though we're not nature. Anything we do to the rest of the world we're doing to ourselves."
Sometimes while birding, when I hear the song of a bird which I haven’t heard before I keep wondering as to what it could be. It lingers on as a mystery in my memory. Merwin uses this imagery evocatively in this poem, drawing attention to the wonder and mystery of the ‘unknown’.
THE UNKNOWN BIRD
Out of the dry days
through the dusty leaves
far across the valley
those few notes never
heard here before

one fluted phrase
floating over its
wandering secret
all at once wells up
somewhere else

and is gone before it
goes on fallen into
its own echo leaving
a hollow through the air
that is dry as before

where is it from
hardly anyone
seems to have noticed it
so far but who now
would have been listening

it is not native here
that may be the one
thing we are sure of
it came from somewhere
else perhaps alone

so keeps on calling for
no one who is here
hoping to be heard
by another of its own
unlikely origin

trying once more the same few
notes that began the song
of an oriole last heard
years ago in another
existence there

it goes again tell
no one it is here
foreign as we are
who are filling the days
with a sound of our own
(Dr Raguram)

In these moments I am not just an observer of the world outside my window, but an explorer of my internal landscape.The falling snow becomes a companion in my journey, like a wandering minstrel.

21/03/24, 8:33 am - Dr Raguram: 20th March is celebrated as World Sparrow Day. On this day I would like to share a story about the Pine tree and the Sparrow from the Cherokee folklore.
Back when the world was young and all of the animals and trees could talk to each other, winter was on the anvil. The Sparrow was injured and was not strong enough to fly away, so he sent his family on to the Southern regions and decided to stay behind and heal. Since he was injured he knew he would not survive the winter without shelter. So he asked various trees for help.
Sparrow went from tree to tree asking them to shelter him in the cold months. One by one they gave him excuses and refused to give him shelter. There was only one tree left, the lowly Pine tree. So with no hope left Sparrow made his plea to the Pine tree. Sparrow said "Pine, I am injured and not able to fly south, would you let me shelter in your branches until my family returns?"
Pine was a humble tree and thought to himself  "What can I do?" but his heart heard the plight of Sparrow and said "My branches are small and my leaves are more like needles but you are welcome to be with me." And so Sparrow spent the cold winter with Pine tree. 
Spring came and when the Creator saw what had happened he called a council of the trees and said to them. "You who have so much and would not share with Sparrow will now lose your leaves in the cold time.  But Pine, because you gave so much you shall keep your leaves in the coldtime.” 
And that is why the Pine tree keeps its green cover throughout the year. 
It is a reminder that in our professional lives we come across many who are like the injured Sparrow, in search of a shelter to heal.  It behoves us to offer them space to recoup and recover so that they can bring their journey afresh, with renewed hope. 
Dr Raguram

22/03/24, 6:47 am - Dr Raguram: Poems are like flowers, stemming from the heart and blossoming in delicate petals of words. We all use words, we all want to communicate and poetry does it seamlessly. It is a very powerful art form. In the words of William Wordsworth “poetry is the breath and finer spirit of all knowledge.” Expanding on this aspect, Ursula Le Guin commented, “Science describes accurately from outside, poetry describes accurately from inside. Science explicates, poetry implicates. Both celebrate what they describe. We need the languages of both science and poetry to save us from merely stockpiling endless ‘information’ that fails to inform our ignorance or our irresponsibility.”
Le Guin’s poems offer glimpses of her deep and abiding love of the natural world; ”I guess I’m trying to subjectify the universe, because look where objectifying it has gotten us. One way to stop seeing trees, or river, or hills, only as ‘natural resources,’ is to class them as fellow beings,as kinfolk.”
In this poem titled, ‘Kinship’, she explores the primordial ties that connect all life forms.
Very slowly burning, the big forest tree
stands in the slight hollow of the snow
melted around it by the mild, long
heat of its being and its will to be
root, trunk, branch, leaf, and know
earth dark, sun light, wind touch, bird song.
Rootless and restless and warmblooded, we
blaze in the flare that blinds us to that slow,
tall, fraternal fire of life as strong
now as in the seedling two centuries ago.
(Reflections on the World Poetry Day, 21st March)

23/03/24, 6:50 am - Dr Raguram: Saigyo was a 12th century Japanese poet who became a Buddhist monk very early in his life. The most popular form of Japanese poetry is the haiku, the 17-syllable poem whicht reached the height of its development in the seventeenth century. But the haiku is derived from an older poetic form, the waka, which had been around for a thousand years before the haiku. The word waka means "Japanese poem," and it is a form so basic to Japanese literature that Japanese still study and write it today. It encompases five principal forms; tanka, chōk,a bussokusekika, sedoka, and katauta. The last three fell into disuse over time and wanka is now identified principally with the tanka. Saigyo was one of the greatest masters of tanka which is described as, “something which takes root in the soil of the heart and blossoms forth in a forest of words.”
Saigyo travelled all over Japan, living as a hermit in the mountains and writing poems which expressed his Buddhist principles and love of nature. Peering out through the window of his hut or sitting on a rock, he portrayed nature and the universe around him, as he saw them. For example, alone in his hut, he compares himself to the reclusive bird, warbler in a poem titled ‘The Bush Warbler Idling,’
“Seeping through the haze,
the voice
of the bush warbler—
few people passing,
mountain village in spring”.
Saigyo was deeply attracted to cherry blossoms and wrote many poems about it. In his final days, he moved to a hermitage in the mountains near Kyoto, which was surrounded by cherry blossom trees. He wished to die under the cherry blossom tree and wrote:
“let me die in spring
under the cherry blossoms
on that day
in the Second Month
when the moon is full”
Saigyo eventually accomplished his wish, and died peacefully in the year 1190 on 23rd March at the age of 73, beneath a blossoming cherry tree

24/03/24, 9:53 am - Dr Raguram: With the advent of online book collectives like the Amazon, scores of independent bookstores have pulled down their shutters. Yet there are a few that have survived this onslaught. The experience that envelops you when you step into such a brick and mortar bookstore is unsurpassable. As you walk through the aisles brimming with books, inhaling the inimitable smells emitted by them, the noise of the world outside slowly fades away and you are transported into the dreamy realm of the written word. Premier book shop in Bangalore was one such oasis.
I cannot resist visiting bookstores on my travels. The Strand at New York is a gargantuan cave with a huge collection of the old and new. The Green Apple in San Francisco comes a close second. Both have endless rows of books closely stacked together and one can spend hours getting lost amongst them! By comparison, the City Lights bookstore in the heart of North Beach, San Francisco is tiny. Named after the Charles Chaplin movie, it was founded by poet Lawrence Ferlinghetti in 1953 and was the first all paperback bookstore in the United States. It specializes in publishing and selling avant garde literature which one may not find in any other bookstore. City Lights was the first to publish Allen Ginsberg’s ‘Howl’ and has a wide selection of Jack Kerouac’s works. One can pick a book, sit in the steps of the basement and spend hours browsing a book with no one looking over your shoulders. Interestingly, when you step out of the store, you walk into Jack Kerouac alley whose walls come alive with colourful murals.
Ferlinghetti was also a poet and I thought of sharing one of his poems on his birthday which sounds so relevant now.
PITY THE NATION (After Khalil Gibran) 2007
Pity the nation whose people are sheep
And whose shepherds mislead them
Pity the nation whose leaders are liars
Whose sages are silenced
And whose bigots haunt the airwaves
Pity the nation that raises not its voice
Except to praise conquerors
And acclaim the bully as hero
And aims to rule the world
By force and by torture
Pity the nation that knows
No other language but its own
And no other culture but its own
Pity the nation whose breath is money
And sleeps the sleep of the too well fed
Pity the nation oh pity the people
who allow their rights to erode
and their freedoms to be washed away
My country, tears of thee
Sweet land of liberty!

26/03/24, 7:40 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
26/03/24, 7:40 am - Dr Raguram: The woods are lovely, dark and deep,
But I have promises to keep,
And miles to go before I sleep,
And miles to go before I sleep.
These lines of Robert Frost are firmly etched in the memory of most of us. Jawaharlal Nehru kept them by his bedside. They inspire us to take a ‘turn’ through enchanting, deep woods in our life and continue our quest with renewed vigour. Perhaps  it also indicates that our final destination can be one of eternal sleep, death. By embracing the unpredictability of our last breath, it urges us to savour every moment in the journey of our lives.
The notion of woods as ‘dark and deep’ alludes to the fact that our experiences in life can be touched by ‘darkness’. Robert Frost’s poems emerged from the dark, deep depression that engulfed him for most of his life. He lost both his parents early and had a difficult early childhood. Both his mother and wife suffered from depression. Only two of his children survived. His son died by suicide and his daughter was committed to psychiatric facility. 
Robert Frost gave expression to his sense of isolation, sorrow and despair in this poignant poem:
ACQUAINTED WITH THE NIGHT
“I have been one acquainted with the night.
I have walked out in rain—and back in rain.
I have outwalked the furthest city light.

I have looked down the saddest city lane.
I have passed by the watchman on his beat
And dropped my eyes, unwilling to explain.

I have stood still and stopped the sound of feet
When far away an interrupted cry
Came over houses from another street,

But not to call me back or say good-bye;
And further still at an unearthly height,
One luminary clock against the sky

Proclaimed the time was neither wrong nor right. 
I have been one acquainted with the night.”
Each of us may experience a touch of ‘darkness’ sometime in our lives. Only poets like Frost can alchemize those experiences into glittering verses.
(Penned on the birthday of Robert Frost)

27/03/24, 7:53 am - Dr Raguram: I haven’t read much Chinese poetry. Sheerly by chance, I came up with the work Ai Qing. He was a notable poet during the Mao Zedong era in China. He spent more than twenty years in a hard labour camp, emptying latrines as a punishment for criticizing the government and for his ‘wrong mental condition’. What was his crime? During the brief ''hundred flowers'' period, he had written four fables pleading the party to show more understanding and respect for writers. In one of them, titled ''The Gardener's Dream,'' he wrote about a gardener who cultivated only roses. One night he dreamt that scores of different flowers pleaded to be let into his garden. When he awoke, the gardener thought to himself , ''Because I have shown favouritism to one type of flower only, I have caused discontent among all the other types of flowers. I am becoming more and more convinced that my world is too narrow.''
Breaking with traditional forms of Chinese poetry, Ai Qing innovatively adapted free verse, writing with simple, clear lines that could be understood by all readers. His poems flow like a sparkling stream… like this one:
What kind of bird is that
In that forest 
Singing, singing, singing, 
As though it is calling for someone, 
As though it is recounting something,
It does not stop though it is raining, 
Even its voice is wet 
Ai Qing compares himself to a bird that reaches out to the listeners, undeterred by the rain, pouring out songs. These lines derive and are anchored in myriad tribulations that he underwent in his life, writing poems amidst adverse circumstances.
His poem ‘Trees’ which I have attached with this note, opens with the line, ‘one tree, another tree’, rather than two trees, emphasizing how separate they are. Yet, they are united by the earth through their roots. It is a beautiful way of stating that no matter how isolated we appear on the surface, we are linked to each other through our roots.

30/03/24, 7:12 am - Dr Raguram: Bipolar disorder is a difficult illness. Journeying across its varied emotional landscape can be a daunting task as one is caught up in eddies of unpredictable swings of mood that can vary across a spectrum. It starts pervading one's whole being and often a person becomes an amalgamation of wounds in various stages of healing.
Textbooks offer impassioned descriptions of the illness with signs and symptoms to detect and categorize. The lived experience of the illness lurks beyond the pages of academic tomes. It is a welcome augury that many have authored insightful books about their experiences of living through the illness. Sometimes poetry captures these embodied experiences with remarkable poignancy. The constant battle between extreme highs and lows is often depicted through vivid imagery in poems, conveying the intense emotions that come with the disorder and the overwhelming feeling of being out of control. Once, a patient of mine with bipolar illness brought a piece of paper in which she had penned a few lines about it.
IN MY LIFE
In my  life    
I ride
On the rainbow
Sometimes.
Colours 
Flow through
My veins.
Surging eddies
Of energy
Soon fade away.
Colours lurk behind
Dark clouds.
All that is left
Is inky blackness.
It draws me 
In a vicious swamp
Till my breath
Becomes a mist
And I lose myself
Trying to find
My way
Amidst the dark clouds
In search
Of a ray of light..
As we usher in another World Bipolar Day, it is imperative to lend an ear and listen deeply to the lived experiences of people afflicted by it.

01/04/24, 7:24 am - Dr Raguram: Beauty comes in all colours. Black can be even more beautiful. Often birds are besotted with colourful birds. But with its striking black plumage and bright orange-yellow bill, the blackbird is an unmistakably bewitching bird today. I first saw it in the forests of BR Hills and it was a fascinating experience to hear its fluting, musical call too.
Blackbirds have been around for long. It has played a significant role in folklore and mythology in many cultures. There is a lovely folktale from Zambia, which has also been translated into an award winning childrens’ book..
Long ago, in the forests of Zambia, the blackbird was voted as the most beautiful bird,ever. The other birds, who were coloured red, yellow, blue, and green, were so enamoured with the blackbird’s colour that they begged it to paint their feathers black so that they could be beautiful too. The blackbird warned them "Colour on the outside is not what's on the inside. You don't act like me. You don't eat like me. You don't get down in the groove and move your feet like me." The other birds were insistent that they be painted black so that they can look beautiful too. Bowing to their demands the blackbird said "We'll see the difference a touch of black can make. Just remember, whatever I do, I'll be me and you'll be you”. Rather than painting them all black, it gave them a touch of black on their feathers, which is noticeable in birds to this day. Thus they embraced each other’s differences while maintaining their own distinctive individuality.
There is a lovely poem, ‘A Blackbird Singing’ by the talented Welsh poet RS Thomas,who was born on 29th March, 1913.
A BLACKBIRD SINGING
It seems wrong that out of this bird,
Black, bold, a suggestion of dark
Places about it, there yet should come
Such rich music, as though the notes'
Ore were changed to a rare metal
At one touch of that bright bill.

You have heard it often, alone at your desk
In a green April, your mind drawn
Away from its work by sweet disturbance
Of the mild evening outside your room.

A slow singer, but loading each phrase
With history's overtones, love, joy
And grief learned by his dark tribe
In other orchards and passed on
Instinctively as they are now,
But fresh always with new tears.
The poet was perhaps using the blackbird as a metaphor of black Africans.In spite of various travails endured by them, they keep their memories afresh through their music, imbued with a tinge of tears.

02/04/24, 7:47 am - Dr Raguram: I have an abiding interest in temple architecture and have been photographing and documenting ancient sculptures and mural paintings. There is something distinctive about sculptures that adorn Hindu temples. I was searching for a befitting description of these aesthetic creations and found it in the words of Octavio Paz, “Gothic architecture is the music turned to stone; one could say that Hindu architecture is sculpted dance.” No one could have said it better. Though steeped in history, these sculptures come alive (in spite of years of neglect and deterioration) and cast a lingering spell on the viewer. A notable example is the depiction of 108 Karanas  from the Natya Shastra of Bharata Muni which adorn the passages of all the four gopurams in Chidambaram..
Ocatavio Paz, poet, Nobel laureate and diplomat, spent several years in India and wrote a small, engaging book, ‘In Light of India’, reflecting on the history and ethos of the nation. Observing the sculptures of Elephanta Caves, he wrote, “I entered a world made of shadows and sudden brightness. The play of the light, the vastness of the space and its irregular form, the figures carved on the walls: all of it gave the place a sacred character, sacred in the deepest meaning of the word.”
In addition, Paz explored themes of identity, cultural heritage, and the complexities of India in this book. It is an insightful account, weaving together the intricate layers of its cultural tapestry and the impact they have on shaping individual identities and the collective consciousness of the nation. His observation was quite prescient, “We are witnessing now, at the end of the century, the resurrection of ethnic and psychic passions, beliefs, ideas, and realities that seemed to have been long buried. The return of religious passion and nationalist fervour hides an ambiguous meaning: Is it the return of ghosts and demons that reason had exorcised, or is it the revelation of profound truths and realities that had been ignored by our proud intellectual constructs?” 
Paz was an outstanding poet (more of it later!) and a glimpse of it in this short poem about the hummingbird which almost sounds like a Haiku.
Stillness
not on the branch
in the air
Not in the air
in the moment
Hummingbird
(Octavio Paz March 31st 1914 - April 19th 1998)

06/04/24, 7:45 am - Dr Raguram: Once when I was birding in the Bhoramdeo Wildlife Sanctuary, I noticed this bird landing on a delicate, frail branch of a tree. The branch was swaying in  the early morning breeze. Suddenly there was a gust of wind and I wondered whether the brittle branch would break. At that moment, the bird took off, finding strength in its wings. 
As I watched, I kept wondering whether it was akin to a phase in the journey of recovery of patients with psychiatric illnesses. Recovery from ‘major’ psychiatric illnesses can be a challenging plight. Often, it  is a daunting task as the patient travels along the uneven, unsettling social landscape,negotiating demands, expectations and most importantly social stigma. It is almost a Sisyphean task. 
My MD thesis was on First Rank Symptoms of Schneider and since I worked in the same unit for over three decades, I was in a position to follow up many of the patients and  be a participatory witness in their journey. Contrary to the often touted ‘favourable’ recovery of schizophrenia in ‘developing’ countries like India, I have rarely seen a complete recovery in most of them. It is not the ‘psychotic’ symptoms that impair their recovery, but a host of emotional turmoils that are embedded in unsettling ‘real’ social contexts. Since the illness starts during the early adult period in their lives, which disrupts their academic and vocational pursuits, finding employment can be a difficult issue. It is also an unenviable task to manage their sexual strivings, which largely remains unaddressed by professionals. They can negotiate these demands to some extent, if there are safe, nurturing, supportive, immediate relationships. In the midst of it all, as their therapist, I strive to kindle and sustain hope in them to unravel their innate strength to cope with these formidable situations. In the words of Victor Hugo,
Be like the bird
Who, pausing in her flight
Awhile on boughs too slight
Feels them give way
Beneath her and yet sings,
Knowing that she hath wings.

08/04/24, 7:55 am - Dr Raguram: Yet another solar eclipse…this time a total one is visible along a narrow track stretching from Texas to Maine in the USA and crowds of people are flocking to watch this celestial event. Unfortunately I will miss it this time. The first time I had a glimpse of it was in 1980. Few of us from NIMHANS who were keen not to miss the event, hopped onto a bus and travelled to Karwar as it was touted to afford the best view. We positioned ourselves on a small hillock overlooking the sea. There was lots of activity on the beach below with children and adults enjoying a stroll in the evening. The sea gulls were squawking noisily and merrily. A few had brought special glasses to view it. I was merely watching the light passing through tree leaves. To my fascination, the eclipse was projected onto the ground as the light passed through gaps in the leaves and I was  able to track the progress of the eclipse. As the eclipse advanced, the activity on the beach faded away and the gulls were suddenly quiet. Without a prelude, the sun disappeared totally, a black disc covering it like a lens cap. There was an eerie silence and the entire landscape was bathed in surreal colours. Slowly light peeped through like a thin golden ring around the sun. Though it lasted for just a few minutes, it was an enthralling experience during which I felt an intense sense of connectivity to another realm, a vast uncharted universe. In that brief moment when the all life- giving sun disappeared behind a black veil and re-emerged, it was a reminder that all things have an end and a new beginning. Navigating through life's valleys, we may experience a phase of darkness, till the ray of light illuminates and rejuvenates us. Embracing the inevitable cycle of darkness and light provides us an opportunity to reflect and expand our awareness towards a more meaningful existence.
Amidst one of the most tumultuous periods in his life, Mahatma Gandhi wrote, "In the midst of darkness, light persists.”

09/04/24, 6:25 am - Dr Raguram: Ugadi, derived from the words yug (era) and adi (new), marks the start of a new era according to the lunar calendar. It is believed that Lord Brahma created the world on this day. According to a mythological story, a demon named Somakasura stole the Vedas from Lord Brahma. Somakasura later hid the Vedas in the sea. When Lord Vishnu came to know of this situation, he took the Avatar of a fish, the Matsya Avatar, to fight Somakasura under the sea. Lord Vishnu killed Somakasura and returned the Vedas to Brahma. After receiving the Vedas back, Lord Brahma started creating the world on this day. Ugadi is perhaps the only festival that exalts Lord Brahma.
There is an extraordinarily beautiful tall,long limbed, Brahma sculpture in the Brahmpureeswarar temple near Thanjavur, which is one of earliest Chola temples, constructed under the joint reign of Aditya-I and Parantaka-I Chola. According to ancient temple iconometry, sculptures are carved on the basis of the Tala system. Each Tala is equal to 12 Angulas.This particular sculpture of Brahma has been carved according to the Dasa (ten)tala system. On either side of Brahma are two Rishis writing down the Vedas chanted by him, on palm leafs. Curiously, in the midst of the makara torana on top was a small figure of Aalilai Kannan!

12/04/24, 8:36 am - Dr Raguram: Waterfowl employ a variety of "feeding modes" to satisfy their daily energy needs. It is interesting to see the mallards feeding in shallow waters. They prefer water that is less than three feet deep, and which has plenty of aquatic vegetation to feed on. They forage by dabbling, dipping their heads and necks underwater to grab shallow plants, while their tails and feathers stay above the water. Mallards are considered the generalists of the waterfowl world and they forage on a wide variety of food, seeds, waste grain, vegetation, and just about anything they can swallow. This is helped to a large extent by its broad and relatively unspecialized bill. They are incredible survivors, and can adapt to a wide range of habitats.
In Ogden Nash’s words:
Behold the duck.
It does not cluck.
A cluck it lacks.
It quacks.
It is specially fond
Of a puddle or pond.
When it dines or sups,
It bottoms ups.

15/04/24, 7:02 am - Dr Raguram: I was in the eighth standard when I first heard about Guru Nanak. Our school had a moral education session on the last Saturday of every month.Students were called upon to speak on various religious/spiritual traditions which was  followed up by a talk by a leading figure from that background. I was given the opportunity twice: the first time to speak on the ‘Sermon on the mount’ and the second time on ‘Guru Nanak’. I went to the school library to read about him and was attracted by the three pillars of Sikhism he outlined;  Kirat Karni (honest living), Vand Chakna (sharing with others) and Naam Japna (focus on God). At that time I didn’t know much about God but honest living and the spirit of sharing and giving appealed to my young mind and left a lasting impact. Perhaps it also laid the foundation for my interest in serving the needy, in later part of my life.
I cannot claim to have read all his works and shabads but I am drawn to his message of 'Ik Onkar': "Ik Onkar, Satnam, Karta Purakh, Nirbhau, Nirvair, Akal Murat, Ajuni Sae Bham, Guru Prasad." There's only one God, his name is the only truth, he is the only creator, he is fearless, he is without hate, he is immortal, he is beyond birth and death, and only by his grace one can chant his name. 
“Ḏasė ḝisĝ ravi­ĝ parabẖ ėk. Ḏẖaran akĝs sabẖ meh parabẖ pėkẖ. Jal thal ban parbaṯ pĝṯĝl.” “He can be found in all the ten directions, on land, in water, in the forests and mountains”
Guru Nanak died when he was seventy. In accordance with the Sikh tradition, on the day of his death, as he was sinking the community gathered around Nanak. Those of Hindu background insisted they should cremate his body, while Muslims wanted to bury him as a great saint. Nanak said, “Place flowers on both sides of my body—flowers from the Hindus on the right side and flowers from the Muslims on the left. If tomorrow the flowers of the Hindus are still fresh let my body be burned, and if the flowers of the Muslims are still fresh, let it be buried.” He requested that those present to place a sheet over his head and body, and instructed everyone to leave him.The Sikh, Hindu and Muslim devotees returned the following morning on September 22, 1539 A.D. They carefully lifted and removed the sheet and they were astonished to discover that there was no trace of Guru Nanak Dev Ji's mortal body. Only fresh flowers remained and not a single bud had wilted of any of the blossoms which had been left by either Sikhs Hindus or Muslims, the night before.
ਸਭ ਮਹਿ ਰਵਿ ਰਹਿਆ ਪ੍ਰਭੁ ਏਕੈ ਪੇਖਿ ਪੇਖਿ ਨਾਨਕ ਬਿਗਸਾਈ 
The One God is pervading in all. Gazing upon Him, beholding Him, Nanak blossoms forth in happiness
(Guru Nanak Jayanti 15th April)

16/04/24, 7:49 am - Dr Raguram: Nature has always been a great source of inspiration to artists, right from the times of petroglyphs. As one of the most inspiring muses known to man, it provides endless inspiration to artists and has become a central theme in many famous artists' artworks. Artists not only recreate the natural world but also create new ways of perceiving it. 
The theme of the World Art Day on 15th April this year is ‘A Garden of Expression. Claude Monet, arguably the most important painter of gardens in the history of art, organized his garden at Giverny as though it were a huge painting. Inspired by Japanese prints, he diverted the water from river Epte into the gardens and developed an extensive pond and planted lilies.  But fearing the effect the water lilies might have on their livestock, the farmers wrote to local officials to block his plans. Fortunately, Monet was able to obtain permission to proceed after facing lots of difficulties. He painted hundred of lilies and titled the series as 
The Nymphéas. The word nymphéa comes from the Greek word numphé, meaning nymph, which takes its name from the classical myth that attributes the birth of the flower to a nymph who was dying of love for Hercules. In fact, it is also a scientific term for a water lily. In all these paintings he focused solely on the surface of the pond, with its cluster of vegetation ﬂoating amid the lilies. Painted on the backdrop of World War 1, these tranquil paintings perhaps provided ”a refuge of peaceful mediation” in turbulent times. Much like the Starry Nights of Vincent van Gogh, these are the most iconic images of the impressionist era of paintings. 
I was privileged to see the recreation of Monet’ garden in the New York Botanical Garden,several years ago. It was like walking amidst the canvases of Monet. There was the iconic Japanese footbridge, an amazing range of flowers of myriad hues and a lovely pond with floating lilies. I was totally immersed in watching the reflection of light on the shimmering waters of the pond, studded with beautiful lilies. Mone’t paintings of the lilies came alive at that moment. 
If William Blake saw the world “in a grain of sand”, Monet viewed the water lilies as an extension of his life, “without the water the lilies cannot live, as I am without art.”
Dr Raguram
17/04/24, 7:39 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
17/04/24, 7:39 am - Dr Raguram: When Lakshmana fell unconscious during the battle with Meghnad, Jambavan suggested that only a herb with healing powers, sanjeevini, can revive him. Hanuman immediately flew in search of the mountain where the herb was to be found. In spite of his best efforts he couldn’t identify the herb and uprooted the whole mountain and flew back.  
This particular episode from Ramayana teeming with exquisite details is depicted in this beautiful painting, which is part of the first illustrated version of Valmiki Ramayana. The project was commissioned by the great Mughal Akbar and text of the great epic was translated into Persian. Abdul Qadir Badaoni was deputed by the emperor as the chief translator in partnership with Naqib Khan under the direction of a learned Hindu scholar, Deva Misra. It involved  several layers of translation. Brahmins at the court first translated the verses from Sanskrit into Awadhi. Court translators then rendered their transliteration into Persian verse, and court painters added their interpretations of the various scenes.
It was profusely illustrated with a vivid and sophisticated colour palette blending Indo-Persian aesthetic principles adroitly. It contained one hundred and seventy-six miniatures within three hundred and sixty-five finely calligraphed folios. The imperial copy of the Ramayana is now in Maharaja Sawai Man Singh II Museum in Jaipur. Several copies of the original were made, one especially for Akbar’s mother, Hamida Banu Begum. This copy is preserved at Doha’s Museum of Islamic Art. One of the sub imperial copies is at the Freer Gallery of Art in Washington,which is remarkably congruent to the imperial copy. This has been digitized and available for viewing. It is a lasting testimony of the religious tolerance and all-inclusive spiritual world view of  Akbar. He envisioned his initiatives such as translation of the Ramayana not merely as an aesthetic exercise, but also as an efficient tool for dissemination of knowledge and spirituality, promoting religious tolerance and harmony. 
(Penned on the occasion of Rama Navami)

19/04/24, 7:52 am - Dr Raguram: Lord Byron, whose death anniversary is today, passionately espoused the cause of Greek independence. In his epic work Don Juan, which included the poem The Isles of Greece, he pleaded with the Greeks to remember their heritage and unite to fight for their freedom.
“Trust not for freedom to the Frank
They have a king who buys and sells;
In native swords and native ranks
The only hope of courage dwells”
On December 29, 1823 Byron sailed to join Prince Aléxandros Mavrokordátos, the leader of the rebel forces in western Greece, to join their struggle for freedom and also trained troops. He was staying in the town of Missolonghi where he died of fever on April 19, 1824. His last words were reportedly , “Come, come, no weakness. Let’s be a man to the last. Shall I sue for mercy? I must sleep now”. The body was shipped to England and was buried on 16th July 1824, at Hucknall Torkard.
When I re-read his poem, ‘Darkness’ today, I wondered whether he was prescient in holding up the mirror for us to the ecological impact of climate change. In 1816 Europe, amongst other places in the world, experienced a drastic climate shift that produced famine, riots and mass death because of a large disease outbreak. All these were as a result of the eruption of Mt. Tambora in Indonesia. As a result, 1816 was called ‘The Year without Summer’, as temperatures dropped so much that there were some local recording drops of 3-5 degrees Fahrenheit on average, as was the case in New England. Byron wrote the poem ‘Darkness’, in the aftermath of this catastrophic changes of weather and the long poem ends with these apocalyptic lines:
It is a long poem and ends with these words:
They slept on the abyss without a surge—
The waves were dead; the tides were in their grave,
The moon, their mistress, had expir'd before;
The winds were wither'd in the stagnant air,
And the clouds perish'd; Darkness had no need
Of aid from them—She was the Universe.

22/04/24, 7:35 am - Dr Raguram: On this World Earth Day, let me share a letter written by Thich Nhah Hanh.
Dear Mother Earth,
Every time I step upon the Earth, I will train myself to see that I am walking on you, my Mother. Every time I place my feet on the Earth I have a chance to be in touch with you and with all your wonders. With every step I can touch the fact that you aren’t just beneath me, dear Mother, but you are also within me. Each mindful and gentle step can nourish me, heal me, and bring me into contact with myself and with you in the present moment.
Walking in mindfulness I can express my love, respect, and care for you, our precious Earth. I will touch the truth that mind and body are not two separate entities. I will train myself to look deeply to see your true nature: you are my loving mother, a living being, a great being—an immense, beautiful, and precious wonder. You are not only matter, you are also mind, you are also consciousness. Just as the beautiful pine or tender grain of corn possess an innate sense of knowing, so, too, do you. Within you, dear Mother Earth, there are the elements of Earth, water, air and fire; and there is also time, space, and consciousness. Our nature is your nature, which is also the nature of the cosmos.
I want to walk gently, with steps of love and with great respect. I shall walk with my own body and mind united in oneness. I know I can walk in such a way that every step is a pleasure, every step is nourishing, and every step is healing—not only for my body and mind, but also for you, dear Mother Earth. You are the most beautiful planet in our entire solar system. I do not want to run away from you, dear Mother, nor to hurry. I know I can find happiness right here with you. I do not need to rush to find more conditions for happiness in the future. At every step I can take refuge in you. At every step I can enjoy your beauties, your delicate veil of atmosphere and the miracle of gravity. I can stop my thinking. I can walk relaxingly and effortlessly. Walking in this spirit I can experience awakening. I can awaken to the fact that I am alive, and that life is a precious miracle. I can awaken to the fact that I am never alone and can never die. You are always there within me and around me at every step, nourishing me, embracing me, and carrying me far into the future.
Dear Mother, you wish that we live with more awareness and gratitude, and we can do this by generating the energies of mindfulness, peace, stability, and compassion in our daily lives. Therefore I make the promise today to return your love and fulfil this wish by investing every step I take on you with love and tenderness. I am walking not merely on matter, but on spirit.

23/04/24, 7:43 am - Dr Raguram: On this World Book Day, let me pen a few words about a book that I read yesterday; ‘The Rumi Prescription: How an Ancient Mystic Poet Changed My Modern Manic Life’ by Melody Moezzi. Diagnosed to have Bipolar Disorder, she experienced severe bouts of depression, mania and had to be hospitalized on occasions. Medications helped her to balance her moods, but merely keeping the disorder in check did not satisfy her. She decided to channel her energy into writing and published her experiences of the illness in a powerful book, ‘Haldol and Hyacinths’.  Much like the hyacinth flower, which rarely grows perfectly straight, Moezzi urged the need to embrace the disorder and rely on the support from loved ones to keep afloat. The book was very well received. After many interviews in the media and countless promotional events, she felt utterly drained, not just physically and emotionally, but spiritually. In her words, “Consumed by an insatiable longing for more and bigger and better successes down the line, I lost track of the
present and grew so addicted to affirmation that I had no energy left for creation”.
It was at this stage that she rediscovered the timeless teachings of Rumi, with the help of her surgeon father. The book is organized in an innovative way with chapters titled as diagnosis and prescription, dealing with many of the tribulations the author underwent; wanting, isolation, haste, depression, distraction, anxiety, anger, fear, disappointment, and pride.  These are all inherent aspects of each of our lives and the author deftly uses Rumi’s poems as ‘prescriptions’ that we can imbibe. Let me outline some of these prescriptions:
On Haste and the need to Slow Down:
“You went out in search of gold far and wide
But all along you were gold on the inside”
On Depression:
“Where there are roses, thorns abound.
In the grand bazaar of life, joy without sorrow cannot be found”
On Anxiety:
“Forget your plans and embrace uncertainty.
Only then will you find stability”
On Disappointment
“Bread on your head and knee-deep in a river,
How are you so starved and withered?
You already own all the sustenance you seek.
If only you’d wake up and take a peek”
These verses of Rumi must be read in the context of the personal narratives of the author in the book. I strongly recommend it!
Let me end with this verse of Rumi:
“On the road to enlightenment, wise and mad are one.
In the way of Love, self and other are one.
For those who drink of the wine that connects souls,
In their religion, the Kaaba and the house of idols are one”

25/04/24, 7:41 am - Dr Raguram: In light of the recent deeply divisive, agonising  , electoral comments, it is perhaps time to read and reflect about Kabir and his writings. 
Kabir’s poetry urges us to rise above identity politics and to seek an essence that transcends notions of selfhood. In his works, he draws attention to multiple manifestations of this ‘essence’ and encourages us to celebrate them. 
“Chaahe Gita bachiye ya padhiye Quran
Tera mera pyaar hai har pustak ka gyan”
“It matters not if you read the Gita or the Quran
All holy texts preach love.”
More importantly, he emphasized how the process of  ‘othering’, in whatever way we view them as being ‘different’ from ‘our’ ways of knowing and being, keeps us locked up in firm, unempathetic stances. As mental health professionals we are deeply aware of the impact of ‘othering’ in stigmatising, marginalising and devaluing those who are considered and  responded to as being ‘different’.
Hence it is appropriate to recall Kabir’s words
“Bura dekhan main chala, bura na milya koye
Jo mann khoya aapna toh mujhsa buran na koye”
“I set out to find bad men, but couldn’t find any
When l looked within myself, l found there was no one worse than me.”
In Kabir's worldview, hatred has no place and one needs to look within oneself before directing fingers at others. 
In the words of Kabir, I reiterate:
“Aisi Baani boliye | Mann ka aapa khoye ||
Auran ko sheetal kare | Aaphu sheetal hoye ||”
“Let your speech be such that the ego of ‘I’ and ‘mine’ dissolves.
That the words you speak soothe everyone, and soothe you as well”
