30/04/24, 7:11 am - Dr Raguram: Every time I spot a blackbuck I am amazed by its graceful elegance as it saunters across the grassland. They figure prominently in Hindu mythology. In Sanskrit texts, blackbucks are called “Krushna Mrug” (black deer). They are also considered the vehicles of Vayu (the wind god) and Chandra (the moon god).
Sangam poetry has vivid, wonderful descriptions of nature and animals. I was wondering whether there is a reference to the blackbuck. Finally I located one in verse 317 in Kurunthogai, which was penned by Madurai Kandarathnanar, In it, a close friend of a lady, consoles her that the man whom she loves deeply will return soon from his travels. 
புரி மட மரையான் கரு நரை நல் ஏறு
தீம் புளி நெல்லி மாந்தி, அயலது
தேம் பாய் மா மலர் நடுங்க வெய்து உயிர்த்து,
ஓங்கு மலைப் பைஞ் சுனை பருகும் நாடன்
நம்மை விட்டு அமையுமோ மற்றே-கைம்மிக
வட புல வாடைக்கு அழி மழைy 
தென் புலம் படரும் தண் பனி நாளே?
The context is that the man and the lady were deeply in love when the he parted away to gather wealth for their wedding. The lady languishes and loses her health in his absence. Observing her friend’s anxiety, the confidante says to her, “The fine, dark male with white patches, mate of the alluring and innocent female black buck, eats the sweet and sour gooseberry, and then, making the nearby honey-dripping huge flowers shiver with its hot breath, it drinks from the fresh springs in the soaring mountains of the lord. How can he stay away from you, in those moist and cold days, when the excessively strong northern winds scatter the rain clouds, making them move south?”. With these words, the confidante assures the lady that the man would return before the commencement of the rainy season. 
What a wonderful expression to soothe and calm an anxious, aspiring, loving, heart!
”The blackbuck stops
Our eyes meet
Tranquil stillness”
(In my amateurish verse!)

01/05/24, 6:52 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
01/05/24, 6:52 am - Dr Raguram: On this Labor Day let us acknowledge the incredible efforts of someone who toils tirelessly, the worker bee. It is the smallest amongst the three (queen, worker and drone) in the honey bee colony The characteristic feature of the worker bee is its prominent proboscis which helps in collecting nectar from the flowers.
The worker bee has a very busy schedule. Depending on her age, she has many different roles to perform in the hive. When she is young, she is  a nurse bee, feeding bee larvae. She also takes on  the job of processing incoming nectar, feeding the queen, as well as making and capping the honey. Older worker bees leave the hive to collect the necessary resources from which the colony survives. Collecting nectar and pollen can be a dangerous task, due to risks from predators and pesticides. Their search expeditions and forays can take them four to five miles from their hive. When they return, they play an important role in maintaining the temperature and ensuring adequate ventilation of the hive. 
The lifespan of the worker bee is short. The time comes when it has to decide whether the hive is better off without her. It then make one last flight and often she does not have enough energy left to fly back and dies  From the moment they’re born, the worker bees are actively involved in executing various tasks for the collective good of the hive, which they fulfil with remarkable dedication till their end.
With a brain the size of a sesame seed, the worker bee is a source of inspiration. The work they do is not confined to the hive. They play a crucial role through their efforts in pollination in sustaining the ecosystem and life on earth. What they take from the landscape, they give back generously. We, as humans with much larger brains, have a lot to learn from them!
Dr Raguram

02/05/24, 8:23 am - Dr Raguram: Sometimes by sheer chance, one discovers an interesting book. This time it was ‘In The Shade Of The Spring Leaves’,a biography of a Japanese author, Ichiyo Higuchi, containing nine stories and extracts from her diary. It was a revelation. 
After finishing the book, I discovered that Ichigo Higuchi was a very important writer of the Meiji period and Japan’s first modern female writer. She was born in 1872 and died in 1896 at the tender age of 24. Born into a peasant family, her mother was not keen for her to be educated.  Finally at the age of 14 she was allowed to attend poetry school as a concession. That marked the beginning of an illustrious literary career. Higuchi picked the pen name “Ichiyō”, meaning “one leaf,” which has a deeper references to a specific form of Zen meditation. In her short life, wrote four thousand classical poems, many short stories, and kept a detailed, 60-volume diary. In one of the entries in the diary, quoted in the book, she writes;
“The rain stopped, green and fresh new leaves rise above the eaves. Pointless it is to wait for someone in my quiet house. I hear the voice of the vendor. And delve into reading a collection of Tang poems.”
Her stories are replete with lyrical passages like this one from‘Snowy Day’, “ Silver sprinkles the earth. Softly, snowflakes fall like dancing butterflies; wings flutter, but there is no sound.  Six-petalled crystals come to rest on withered trees, spring’s first flowering”.
Ichiyo Higuchi took me on a compelling journey and I travelled on the wings of her writings to discover an entirely new creative landscape.

03/05/24, 7:25 am - Dr Raguram: According to Greek mythology, orchids were made from the remains of a young man named Orchis. He was the son of a nymph and a satyr, and while attending a festival of the wine god Bacchus, he became drunk. He abused the priestess Bacchantes and was torn apart by the other guests at the party. When his sorrowful father asked Zeus to make him whole again, he refused but allowed flowers to grow from his remains. These were the first orchids. It should be noted that there are many variations of this story, but all do end with the creation of orchids from his remains.
Orchids exude undeniable charm and are symbolic of everything from life, love and happiness. As Eckhart Tolle, in his book A New Earth commented,”Humans would increasingly be drawn to and fascinated by them [orchids]....They provided inspiration to countless artists, poets, and mystics..more fleeting, more ethereal, and more delicate, they are like messengers from another realm, like a bridge between the world of physical forms and the formless."
I am enamoured of the ephemeral beauty of the orchids and when I looked closely at the heart of this moth orchid,
“Would I could bury my soul
Deep in its bosom
Listening to its
Hidden secrets”

06/05/24, 8:43 am - Dr Raguram: Ralph Waldo Emerson wrote a memorable poem, ‘Hamatreya’ in 1847. It is based on a passage of the Vishnu Purana. The title of the poem is a shortened form of “Hail Maitraya”. Here, the poet records what the sage named Parashara taught his disciple Maitreya in response to the disciple’s query regarding the real worth of earthly possessions. Emerson guides us to be aware of the futility of our boasting and pride and points towards an awareness of earth’s living relationship to each one of us.  According to him, earth laughs at the boastful attitude of people who feel that they possess her. None can possess her and ultimately all of us are possessed by her. 
The flower in the image I’ve posted today is called by various names; Shiv Kamal,  Kailaspati and Nagalingam. Imbued with cultural and religious significance, it has petals resembling the hood of a Naga or serpent around its stamen which is considered as Shiva Linga. The tree, often referred to as cannonball tree has important medicinal properties. 
In my growing years there was a huge nagalinga tree in front of our house. Every morning, hundreds of flowers would be strewn all over the ground and there would be a contest amongst the children as to who could pick up the most. We spent many hours playing cricket under its vast canopy and when the ball went near its trunk, we would retrieve it with some trepidation as we were told that snakes might be lurking around the tree. 
One fine day, the owners of the property decided to cut it down to build new housing. All of us watched with dismay as the magnificent tree fell on the ground. We lost our much loved companion as also the birds and the squirrels, who lost a sturdy, reliable place to nest and rest. In the ensuing years the owners too had to undergo various shades of tribulations.
For me personally it was a kind of grief and an unsettling reminder of our disconnect from the non-human world, which has only gotten worse over the years.
Perhaps it’s time to read and reconnect with these timeless lines of ‘Hamatreya’.
“Where are these men? Asleep beneath their grounds:
And strangers, fond as they, their furrows plough.
Earth laughs in flowers, to see her boastful boy”.

07/05/24, 7:38 am - Dr Raguram: I became aware of the teachings of Rennyo on reading the book “Rennyo:The Second Founder of Shin Buddhism”. Various Buddhist sects celebrate and follow Buddha’s teachings through different practices, rituals, with emphasis  on different aspects of his teachings. While other schools of Buddhism seek to “attain” or “realize” enlightenment, the Shin Buddhist path focuses on simply listening and opening one’s heart to receiving it. “The pursuit of enlightenment can become something like chasing after a mirage in the desert: You think you have arrived, only to find it disappear “. Shin Buddhism emphasizes that one doesn’t have to become a monk or sit for hours in meditation and can experience this in everyday life through tuning the ears and the heart to listen to life unfolding around oneself.
Rennyo wrote 85 letters to convey his teachings. Let me draw attention to two excepts from it which made an impact on me. The first one is”White Ashes” in which he urges us to reflect on life’s impermanence:
“The people we leave behind and the people who go before us, are more numerous than dewdrops that rest briefly on leaves and branches. Hence, I may have a radiant face in the morning, but in the evening, become no more than white ashes.”
In the second one on awareness, he comments:
“As the sun shines upon the earth, awakening into growth the seeds that lie dormant in the soil, may the Light of Wisdom shine into our minds and truly awaken us to our ignorance and by this insight stir us to strive for a life of deeper understanding and enlightenment.”
An observation much in tune with that of Sri Ramana Maharishi, “Your own Self-Realization is the greatest service you can render the world”.

THE SECOND EXILE
That evening when Lord Ram returned to his home
He remembered the jungles where he had spent his years of exile
When he must have seen the dance of madness that December 6

From where have so many demented ones landed on my home

11/05/24, 7:18 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
11/05/24, 7:18 am - Dr Raguram: While birding in Seychelles last year, I noticed a fairly large sized bird hidden amongst the tree tops. From a distance, it looked like a dove. However, on close observation, it looked distinctive with a beautiful blend of browns, purplish-reds, and blueish-grays, with a brown eye with a red circle around it. At the end of the day, I checked my observations online and found out that it is referred to as Malagasy turtle dove. 
There are only six doves that bear the name “Turtle Dove”. They belong to two groups, the Nesoenas and the Streptopelia. The Malagasy Turtle Dove (Nesoenas picturata) is the only one in the Nesoenas. Its closest relative is the Pink Pigeon and together they form a lineage apart from both the typical pigeons and the other turtle doves.
Madagascar turtle doves produce a liquid called "crop milk" in their upper digestive tract that they regurgitate and feed to their young. While it is called milk, it does not contain lactose and is a blend of water, protein, fat, minerals and amino acids. I was told by the locals that it is quite adept in stealing copras that are left in the open to dry!
Often in the processe of glimpsing something anew, nature unveils itself and enthralls you!

16/05/24, 7:19 am - Dr Raguram: A few years ago I read a very perceptive story about ageing and declining memory,”In Sight of the Lake”, by Alice Munro, who passed away yesterday.. It is a non-linear story that goes back and forth about an old, widowed woman. She decides to visit a gerontologist to get help for her memory loss and drives to the village only to find that the doctor is not there. More distressingly, it’s the doctor’s day off. She also realizes that she has forgotten the piece of paper with the directions and has got the dates.wrong. She wanders around the town and finds out that the doctor works in a nursing home nearby. When she reaches the place, she feels trapped inside. She is now aware that it's the place she has already been in. She narrates her experience of being lost in search of the doctor to the nursing attendant. The story ends with the attendant’s response, “That’s the same thing you tell me every time.”
Growing old is like a trip through a difficult, unfamiliar country and there have been many accounts of it in the literature. What is particularly poignant about this short story is that it was written in a period of time when the author herself was in the throes of early dementia. It was among other reasons why she couldn’t travel to accept the Nobel prize in person. 
Works of art often emerge from a slew of experiences, sometimes deeply personal. In the process, the tenuous border between the artist and the character she essays, becomes blurred. Deeply enmeshed internal stories of the author get transformed as powerful, poignant narratives in the literary landscape. It is not an easy task. In Murakami’s words, “Sometimes I can't even remember what I was trying to say in the first place. It's like my body's split in two and one of me is chasing the other me around a big pillar. We're running circles around it. The other me has the right words, but I can never catch her.” 
Alice Munro seems to have bridged this gap with ease in this harrowing story about declining memory and loss of self hood.

17/05/24, 6:13 am - Dr Raguram: Endangered Species Day on the third Friday of May was created to increase awareness as to how fragile the existence of some animals,plants and insects is. According to the IUCN, at least 40% of animals, insects and plants are at risk of extinction across the world. On this day, let me draw attention to an endangered bird, the Steppe Eagle..
Little Rann of Kutch is a magical landscape. Ahalya and myself spent several days exploring and savouring the immense biodiversity of the region in the company of Mr Jugal Kishor Tiwari, famed ornithologist and ecologist. One of our first sightings was the Steppe Eagle. Perched on a sandy mound, it was surveying the vast territory for suitable prey. It looked stunning with its rich brown plumage. Steppe eagles migrate to India from their breeding grounds in Central Asia and Eastern Europe. They play an important role in nature by helping to control populations of prey animals and maintain a balance in the ecosystems. It is categorized as an endangered species, because of major declines in their populations over the past few decades. Reasons for this are varied; environmental changes, overhunting by predators, poaching, the changing or destruction of habits by humans, or natural disasters, to name a few.
There’s a tremendous need for a worldwide conservation effort to prevent such species from being lost forever. No species has ever had such wholesale control over everything on earth, living or dead, as we now have. It is our responsibility to initiate measures at conserving species that are endangered. 
In the words of EO Wilson, “Look closely at nature. Every species is a masterpiece, exquisitely adapted to the particular environment in which it has survived. Who are we to destroy or even diminish biodiversity?”
Dr Raguram
18/05/24, 7:20 am - Dr Raguram: When I first laid hands on Edward Fitzerald’s translation of Omar Khayyam’s ‘Rubaiyat’ I was mesmerised by its haunting beauty. In just four lines, the poems explored themes of love, fate, mortality, and the transient nature of life with elegance and simplicity. The verses offered a contemplative perspective on life, urging us to seize the moment and find joy in the face of life’s uncertainties. He alludes to the temporality of life in these deeply reflective words:
“I saw the potter in the market yesterday 
Pounding and pounding upon a piece of clay 
“Behold,” said the clay to the potter 
Treat me gently for once like you, now I am clay.”
The tapestry of our lives is woven with diverse threads, some of them bleak and dark. Khayyam urges us to dance in the present and relish the beauty of each moment, embracing the ephemeral lives we lead, wholeheartedly and with joy. 
“Since neither truth nor certitude is at hand 
Do not waste your life in doubt for a fairyland 
O let us not refuse the goblet of wine 
For, sober or drunken, in ignorance we stand”.
Khayyam’s verses are like delicate blossoms that bloom with timeless beauty and endless charm. It is hard to resist their irresistible allure.
“Come, fill the Cup, and in the Fire of Spring
The Winter Garment of Repentance fling:
The Bird of Time has but a little time to flutter
And the bird is on the wing”.
It is a reminder to seize the moment, while we still have the wings and to soar!
(Omar Khayyam was born on this day, 18th May, in Nishapur, northern Persia)

20/05/24, 6:50 pm - Dr Raguram: Bees have been around for long. In Ancient Egypt, tears of the Sun God Ra turned into bees upon touching the ground.and in Ancient Greece, bee was a cult symbol for  Artemis, goddess of wild nature. In Indian mythology, Honeybees form the string of  Kama’s bowmade of sugarcane. In the words of the poet Kalidasa, Kama, “bears the bow of Love; and on that bow, the lustrous string is made of bees….Weaves a string of Bees with deft invention, To speed the missile when the bow is bent.”
It is believed that Brahma resides as a bee of Vishnu’s navel-lotus, humming vedic texts. There is also a mention about a goddess, Brahmari in Srimad Devi Bhagavatam;book 10, chapter 13.  Bhramari, who slayed the demon Arunasura, is considered as the goddess of bees. Lakshmi tantra (9,41-43), also mentions her, “During the sixtieth era there will be one demon, called Aruṇa who will do much harm to men and sages. Then I shall appear in bee-form incorporating innumerable bees, and I shall slay the mighty demon and rescue the three worlds. From then on people will praise me forever and address me as Bhrāmarī.” Iconographically she is portrayed with scores of bees emanating from her hands. Brahmari is worshipped on the eighth night of the Navarathri festival. There is a temple for her in Kasauni. It is said that Adi Guru Shankaracharya spent sometime in the temple, which is situated at the top of a mount enclosed by a fort. Bhramari Pranayama is a yogic technique that consists of concentrating on the sound emulating a bee along with breath control. The vibration of sound produced is said  to enhance the level of consciousness. So the next time you hear the hum of a bee, do not panic!
(Penned on the occasion of the World Bee Day, 20th May)
Dr Raguram

23/05/24, 7:13 am - Dr Raguram: Buddha’s followers never officially celebrated his birthday, till it was formalized in May 1950, at the first conference of the World Fellowship of Buddhists in Colombo, Sri Lanka. It was agreed upon that the day of the full moon in May would be auspicious, due to Buddha attaining nirvana on a full moon day. 
The natural world was ubiquitous in the Buddha’s life and teachings. Forests and woodland parks were the most common setting where people met the Buddha and listened to his teachings. Nature provided the backdrop and the context for his teachings and the natural settings played an important role in his awakening and his teachings. The important connection he saw between nature and the practices he taught is encapsulated in some of his utterances like this one;
“If we could see the miracle of a single flower clearly our whole life would change. ” 
On this Buddha Purima day, it would be wonderful to become aware that sources of immense awareness is all around us in our everyday lives…let us pause and reflect.

02/06/24, 8:56 am - Dr Raguram: All of us are curious about the outcome of the elections and are besieged with countless exit polls which vary in their calculations which are at best astrological. Talking of curiosity, no other feathered creature has aroused interest owing to its uncanny nature, like the owl, in literature, across ages. They are perhaps the most commonly mentioned birds in literature. Watching the endless discussions about electoral trends, I am reminded of a tale from Aesop Fables, ‘The Owl and the Birds’. It narrates how the ordinary birds ignore the warnings of the wise owl. Later when they are proved wrong and the owl is proved to have been right, they turn to it for pearls of wisdom, but the owl is now silent and ‘no longer gives them advice, but in solitude laments their past folly’.
There is another interesting story in the eighteenth century English author John Gay’s, ‘Fifty-one Fables in Verse’.  In one of them a grumpy owl laments that he is not being paid sufficient attention. Overhearing it, a sparrow comments that the birds have now learned that looks can be misleading and that just because the owls happen to appear wise and venerable does not necessarily mean that they are so. It goes on to say that if the owl concentrates on what it is good at, namely catching mice, the farmers will applaud and respect its work, rather than looking for false respect for its looks. 
A group of owls is called a ‘parliament’. It has its origins in the 1950s children's classic ‘The Chronicles of Narnia’ by CS Lewis. Lewis adopted the title of the Chaucer’s allegorical poem "The Parliament of Fowls to describe a council of owls who meet at night to discuss the affairs of Narnia.

07/06/24, 10:34 am - Dr Raguram: Sometimes, a small, unobserved detail in a painting can be an object of intense scrutiny. Take for instance the painting, ‘The Sorcerer of Hiva Oa’, by Paul Gaugin. It was painted by him during his sojourn in 1902 on the small Pacific island of Hiva Oa in French Polynesia's Marquesas. The main focus in the painting is that of the sorcerer who is adorned with a dramatic red cape. If one looks at the bottom right, there is a dog holding a bird in its jaws. Over the years, the identity of this bird has been an object of intense curiosity and speculation. One suggestion was that it could be a large flightless New Zealand bird, ‘Takahe’. The problem with this surmise is that Hiva Oa is far away from New Zealand and couldn’t have travelled that far. Moreover, it was pointed out the Takahe’s head is dark blue, whereas in the painting the head of the bird is green. Much later, in 1937 Norwegian voyager Thor Heyerdahl spotted a strange bird while visiting Hiva Oa.  He saw a hen-sized flightless bird scurrying rapidly between tall ferns and was told by the islanders that this was the Koao. Could it be the now extinct Marquesas Swamp Hen? Or was it the Takahe, one of the rarest birds native to New Zealand? Finally, in 1988, 600-year-old bones of a bird was found in Marquesas which was identical to the description of Koao, but unfortunately there was no way to find out the colouration, which could have solved the riddle!  
Artists are endowed with keen powers of observation. Did Gaugin notice the bird and painted it? It is interesting that a small detail from a painting by a great artist kindled an ornithological mystery, which remains unsolved till now! 
(Penned on the birthday of Paul Gaugin, 7th June 1848)
Dr Raguram

15/06/24, 9:33 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
15/06/24, 9:33 am - Dr Raguram: The stories of Jorge Luis Borges can be read in a matter of minutes, yet the impact upon the reader is profound. Take for instance the story, ‘The Book of Sand’: the three pages long story is a deeply engaging narrative about a mysterious book which appears to have an infinite number of pages. It was sold to him by a bookseller who bought it in India, from a low caste man. When the narrator opens the surprisingly heavy book, he finds the script to be unfamiliar, laid out in double columns, with page numbers. which do not run in any sequential order. It also contains clumsily drawn illustrations on some pages of the book. The narrator is unable to find either the first or last page of the book and as he browses through it, more and more pages appear. Overwhelmed by curiosity, he becomes obsessed with the book over time. He also notices that he can never find the same page twice in the book. He comes to view the book as ‘monstrous’, and wants to destroy it, but fears that if he tries to burn the book, it might result in an infinite fire whose flames would engulf the whole world. He feels that “the best place to hide a leaf is in a forest” and disposes of the book by taking it to the Argentine National Library and hiding it in one of the musty shelves in the library’s basement. 
The beauty of the story is that every time I read it, a new perspective emerges. Is the writer alluding to the hold of curiosity in human imagination or is it a meditation on the nature of infinity? Perhaps it refers to our deepest strivings to probe, understand, and make sense of the vast, unfathomable essence that is woven into the grand cosmic tapestry.
The infinite has always been of interest to people, mathematicians, physicists and philosophers. But very few can decode and render it in magical words like Borges!
(Jorge Luis Borges August 24, 1899 - June 14, 1986)

16/06/24, 9:25 am - Dr Raguram: Gordon Parks, Sr. was a hugely talented polymath. He was a photographer, filmmaker, composer, writer, journalist, novelist and a poet. On Father’s Day I thought of sharing one of his beautiful poem ‘The Parting’, wherein the father prepares his son to find his own life path amid signposts signalling devious directions and roads "paved with roses and thorns." Success, the father concludes, will be determined by whether the son, in the autumn of his own life, can thankfully manage a smile. 
THE PARTING 
Two roads passed my father’s house,
paved with roses and thorns.
They went everywhere, with tolls
unfixed on unmarked distances,
paved with roses and thorns.
Papa said a few things when I was packed to go:
The feel of your feet will reconcile the differences in which road you take.
Signposts along the way will give devious directions.
It is your right to question, but don’t ignore them.
Each one is meant for something.
Summer grass underfoot will be kinder than weeds.
Yet during winter storms, it will be the taller stalks, leaning above the snow, that will catch your eye. And you will learn that all things are not the same.
You must select your friends with the same care I gave to selecting your mother.
Avoid things that die too easy, and get your soul ready to die well.
As you grow older, you will pray more and worry less.
Well, what I’ve told you might amount to everything, or maybe nothing.
Just be thankful if, in autumn, you can still manage a smile.

17/06/24, 7:31 am - Dr Raguram: The Norman Rockwell Museum is located in Stockbridge, Berkshire County amidst carefully tended, lush gardens overlooking the picturesque Housatonic River Valley. It is home to the largest collection of his original works. When I was looking today at some of the photographs I took of the displays in the collection, one particular canvas titled, ‘New in the neighbourhood’ stood out. It portrayed a family moving into a new locality. Five kids are portrayed in the painting and noticeably, there is a distance between the white kids who are looking at the two black children with some curiosity. If one looks closely, an adult is seen peering from behind the window curtain. The entire painting draws attention to issues in assimilation of people viewed as being ‘different’. 
In his 1903 book, ‘The Souls of Black Folk’, DuBois wrote about the social philosophy of ‘double consciousness’: “It is a sense of always looking at one's self through the eyes of others, of measuring one's soul by the tape of a world that looks on in amused contempt and pity… two unreconciled strivings; two warring ideals”.  During the period of segregation, African Americans essentially lived in segregated communities not by choice, but forced into these places by racial prejudice and led parallel lives. 
Sometime I wonder whether we are also slowly and steadily moving into such situation in India. A recent news that residents in a housing complex in Ahmedabad were preventing a person from a minority community from moving into her allotted unit raises concerns. Out of an unseen and ever-lingering fear and mistrust, people belonging to the minority community will gradually move into separate, demarcated areas. This will result in an unfortunate situation of ghettoization of both communities. Secularism and comradeship will soon vanish in these spaces.

And everyone else is They:
But if you cross over the sea,
Instead of over the way,
You may end by (think of it!) looking on We
As only a sort of They!”
Rudyard Kipling in ‘Debits and Credits’

20/06/24, 9:04 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
20/06/24, 9:04 am - Dr Raguram: In a world bristling with distractions the simple act of picking up a book, opens up doors of enlightenment, knowledge, and personal transformation. It is a catalyst for personal growth and self-discovery. The person who unveiled the power of the written word to uplift, educate, and empower was PN Panicker. 
Puthuvayil Narayana Panicker is known as the Father of the Library Movement in Kerala. The activities of the Kerala Grandhasala Sangham that he initiated triggered a popular cultural movement in Kerala which contributed to the universal literacy in the state in the 1990s. Panicker led the formation of Thiruvithaamkoor Granthasala Sangham (Travancore Library Association) in 1945 with 47 rural libraries. The slogan of the organization was 'Read and Grow '. Later on, with the formation of Kerala State in 1956, it became Kerala Granthasala Sangham (KGS). He travelled across Kerala proclaiming the value of reading. He succeeded in bringing some 6,000 libraries into this network. He founded the Kerala Association for Nonformal Education and Development (KANFED) in 1977. KANFED was instrumental in starting the Kerala State Literacy Mission, which led Kerala to its universal literacy movement. Kerala became the first state which achieved universal literacy. 
Panicker died on 19 June 1995, at the age of 86. His death anniversary, is observed in Kerala as Vayanadinam (Reading Day) since 1996. The Department of Education in Kerala also observes Vayana varam (Reading Week) for a week from June 19 to 25. In 2017, Govt of India declared June 19th as National Reading Day.  
As Victor Hugo commented perceptively, "To learn to read is to light a fire; every syllable that is spelled out is a spark."

21/06/24, 11:27 am - Dr Raguram: Historically, both yoga and Indian classical dance traditions share Vedic roots in the ancient texts of Patanjali Yogasutra and Natyashastra, respectively. For both, the body is a temple and the dance/asana is one’s prayer. The emphasis on stilling the mind through concentration on the inner and outer bodies, moving the practitioner toward an experience of freedom. 
Natya yoga is the name given to a type of yoga that combines yoga and dance-like movements as a spiritual practice. It has similarities to Hatha yoga, but it has a different approach in that it also integrates elements of dance and mime, rather than static asanas. Quite a number of asanas of Hatha Yoga are in parallel with some of the 108 karanas of the Natyashastra. Karanas are basically yogic poses in rhythm. The karanas are dance counterparts of asanas and like the alignment of asanas, the karanas focus on the center line of the body in relation to gravity paying attention to the pathways of energies that flow through the body.
Thillai Nataraja Temple in Chidambaram is one of very few temples that have all 108 karanas from the Natya Shastra. They are depicted in the stone carvings on the passage walls in the gopurams of the temple.  Most of the dance poses in this temple resemble various yoga poses. The karanas arise from fundamental yogic postures. Many of the 108 karanas employ various yogic postures like Garudasana, Natarajasana etc. When yoga is used with stylistic expression it becomes an instrument to evoke Rasa.
The photograph depicts Lalāṭatilaka, which is 50th Karana, where the left leg is placed on the ground with the feet flat in and the knee bent. The right leg is lifted up and bent and the toes virtually touching the forehead. The hand is held in Anjali mudra and the face and the head are tilted back.
पृष्ठतः कुञ्चितं कृत्वा व्यतिक्रान्तक्रमं ततः ।
आक्षिप्तौ च करौ कार्यौ क्रान्तके करणे द्विजाः ॥ 111-112 ॥
pṛṣṭhataḥ kuñcitaṃ kṛtvā vyatikrāntakramaṃ tataḥ ||4-111||
ākṣiptau ca karau kāryau krāntake karaṇe dvijāḥ |
Natya Yoga conceives body as a temple and dance as an offering

24/06/24, 11:49 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
24/06/24, 11:49 am - Dr Raguram: Ambrose Bierce who was born on this day in 1842 is largely known as the author of the interesting, ‘The Devil’s Dictionary’. He also wrote several trenching stories about the harsh realities of war. Bierce was a Union soldier during the Civil War and he gave expression to his traumatic memories in his stories, in a collection titled, ‘Civil War Stories’. 
‘The Mocking Bird’, is particularly poignant short story from this collection. Private William Grayrock is posted on picket duty and on hearing the approach of someone he cannot see, he shoots blindly into the night and is certain he has hit a man in the darkness. He is lauded for protecting the regiment from intruders, but Grayrock is beset with guilt and goes in search and to his great dismay finds that he has shot his long last twin brother. Overcome with intense grief, he doesn’t return to the camp and wanders off.  
The story juxtaposes the harsh realities of war with memories fond family relationships. As he goes in search of the person he had shot, Grayrock dreams about his childhood friendship with his brother and their attachment to their most precious possession, a mockingbird. “Through all the golden days floated one unceasing sound-- the rich, thrilling melody of a mocking-bird in a cage by the cottage door. It pervaded and possessed all the spiritual intervals of the dream, like a musical benediction. The joyous bird was always in song; its infinitely various notes seemed to flow from its throat, effortless, in bubbles and rills at each heart-beat, like the waters of a pulsing spring”.  As “he was passing a thicket of laurel, a bird rose from the midst of it and perching on the branch of a tree above, poured from its joyous breast so inexhaustible floods of song as but one of all God's creatures can utter in His praise. There was little in that--it was only to open the bill and breathe; yet the man stopped as if struck --stopped and let fall his rifle, looked upward at the bird, covered his eyes with his hands and wept like a child”.  When he finally notices the dead body of his twin brother, “the shrilling bird upon the bough overhead stilled her song and, flushed with sunset's crimson glory, glided silently away through the solemn spaces of the wood”. 
The mocking bird is a crucial metaphor in this haunting story. The bird is reportedly quite caring when it comes to protecting its family from predators and sadly witnesses an avoidable tragedy involving two brothers whose memories are entwined with it. 
The story is also about the futility of war. The American Civil War created deep divisions between the North and South and also divided many families. Some family members fought for the Union, while others sided with the Confederacy. It ripped the country apart and in many of those deadly battles, brothers fought against their own brothers, at times killing each other. 
As François de Salignac de la Mothe-Fénelon, a French theologian, poet and writer, commented perceptively, “All wars are civil wars because all men are brothers... Each one owes infinitely more to the human race than to the particular country in which he was born.”
Traumatic memories of war linger on for long in the psyche of the individual and often remains unresolved. Ambrose Bierce’s death remains an unsolved mystery. Did he commit suicide, or pneumonia took a toll on him or was he killed by Mexican federal forces? In his last known communication, he wrote, “As to me, I leave here tomorrow for an unknown destination.”
Dr Raguram

25/06/24, 8:39 am - Dr Raguram: Judith Wright was a prolific Australian poet, critic and short-story writer, who published more than 50 books. She was also an uncompromising environmentalist and social activist campaigning for Aboriginal land rights. Late in life, she settled to a remote property near the heritage town of Braidwood, south of Canberra, where she wrote many of her nature poems. Judith was one of Australia’s most celebrated poets and one of the two to be considered for the Nobel prize. Her book ‘Birds’ was first published in 1962 and one of the poems is about the Magpie:
Along the road the magpies walk
with hands in pockets, left and right.
They tilt their heads, and stroll and talk.
In their well-fitted black and white.
They look like certain gentlemen
who seem most nonchalant and wise
until their meal is served – and then
what clashing beaks, what greedy eyes!
But not one man that I have heard
throws back his head in such a song
of grace and praise – no man nor bird.
Their greed is brief; their joy is long.
For each is born with such a throat
as thanks his God with every note.
When we were birding in Australia, we spotted the Australian Magpie on many occasions. When I read this poem I was struck as to how beautifully she has described the bird’s behaviour, especially in the first four lines. She then compares the bird to “certain gentlemen” who are greedy to just fulfil their need. Finally, she alludes to the magpies' remarkable singing abilities, which surpass even those of human beings. The poem ends with her thoughtful reflection that the magpie’s “greed is brief, their joy is long” and they “thank his God with every note.”
Judith died of heart attack in Canberra on June 26 at the age of 85. Her ashes were scattered around the mountain cemetery of Tamborine Mountain. Wright had owned a strip of rainforest nearby, which she donated to the state so it could be preserved as a national park.

26/06/24, 9:28 am - Dr Raguram: As we were birding around the Stow Lake in Golden Gate Park few months ago, the unmissable melodious note of the Song Sparrow drew our attention. Thoreau described it as “Maids! Maids! Maids! hang up your teakettle-ettle-ettle.” Some others compared it the opening notes of Beethoven’s Fifth Symphony! It was flitting through low branches, occasionally moving onto open ground in search of food, pumping its tail up. It was foraging on the ground kicking away debris by hopping forward while sweeping both feet quickly back along the ground, a move often described as ‘song sparrow samba’! Soon, it perched on a stump and started singing. 
Most of what we know about the song sparrow emerges from the work of one amateur ornithologist, Margaret Morse Nice. She shifted the focus away from collection, description of bird specimens and emphasized on close observation on bird behaviour in their natural setting. She observed and compiled a detailed study of the song sparrow in her own backyard. She marked each bird with a coloured band and managed to follow and study 336 individual birds in detail. And one of them, which she named 4M, remained in her study area for seven years. She described her technique as a “phenomenogical method.” Interestingly, it is through the phenomenological approach as mental health professionals, we explore and understand the lived experience of people in throes of psychological distress. Her study, which spanned eight years, detailed the daily activities and territorial behaviour of several generations of song sparrows.  Though she lacked a professional position and funding, she published 250 articles, five monographs and single-handedly initiated a new era in American ornithology. 
In the words of Margaret Morse, “the study of nature is a limitless field, the most fascinating adventure in the world.” There are plenty of birds like the song sparrow right in our backyards/environs and her work should inspire us that we can learn a lot about them through careful observation. 
With tongue in cheek, she observed, “I decided it would be better to be a bird. Birds are very busy at one period each year caring for babies, but this lasts only a few weeks with many of them, and then their babies are grown and gone. Best of all, they leave their houses forever and take to camping for the rest of the year. No wonder they are happy.”
(Margaret Morse Nice 6th December 1983 – 26th June 1974) 
Dr Raguram

27/06/24, 9:13 am - Dr Raguram: Another bird that caught my attention down under, because of it gruesome ways of having food was the butcherbird. When it caught a prey, it hung it on a branch and scythed the meat away, just like a butcher. It kept any uneaten bits of food between the twigs in a tree and came back to eat the leftovers, later. Though aggressive in its behaviour, I was quite surprised to see the bird visit the kitchen window in a friend’s house regularly and savoring the cooked rice!
Many works of fiction have been woven around the butcher bird, often in the genre of fantasy and horror. It also figured in the poems of Charles Causley, the Cornish poet, who was profoundly influenced and impacted by the World War I. His father returned from the war as an invalid. As an only child, Causley spent his first seven years watching his father slowly die. He also witnessed the suffering shell-shocked soldiers who walked aimlessly around the town. These experiences found expression in his poems. In a poem titled “Recruiting Drive,” bristling with images of violence and deception, he uses the metaphor of the butcher bird as someone who lures young men to their deaths in battle.
RECRUITING DRIVE
“Under the willow
I heard the butcher-bird sing,
Come out you fine young fellow
From under your mother’s wing.
I’ll show you the magic garden
That hangs in the beamy air,
The way of the lynx and the angry Sphinx
And the fun of the freezing fair.
Lie down lie down with my daughter
Beneath the Arabian tree,
Gaze on your face in the water
Forget the scribbling sea.
Your pillow the nine bright shiners
Your bed the spilling sand,
But the terrible toy of my lily-white boy
Is the gun in his innocent hand.”

29/06/24, 12:02 pm - Dr Raguram: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry was born on this day in 1900. He was a precocious, talented child, who attached wings to his bicycle, to fulfil his dreams of becoming a pilot. He wrote only one children’s book, ‘The Little Prince’, in his lifetime and it is one of those rare gems. The strength of any great work of literature is that it can be read and reflected upon at many levels.  The book is both an engaging children’s fantasy and yet at the same time a philosophical fable on various aspects of life. 
For me personally, there are two important inspirational dimensions embedded in this timeless tale.
The first theme is about the power of enduring love. The Little Prince has many encounters, one of which is with a Rose. She is delicate, vulnerable, needs watering and protection. She has only four thorns to protect herself and Little Prince dutifully cares for her. But then he must move on. Accepting his departure, the Rose comments, “Well, I must endure the presence of a few caterpillars if I wish to become acquainted with the butterflies.” A message as important as in any great philosophical tome. The little prince then encounters the fox who tells him that love is when you care enough to tend to someone who needs care. 
The second theme is one of separation from a loved one, of loving someone with the inevitability of losing that friend. In a beautiful, poignant passage, the writer reflects, “Bit by bit… it comes over us that we shall never again hear the laughter of our friend, that this one garden is forever locked against us. And at that moment begins our true mourning, which, though it may not be rending, is yet a little bitter. For nothing, in truth, can replace that companion. Old friends cannot be created out of hand. Nothing can match the treasure of common memories, of trials endured together, of quarrels and reconciliations and generous emotions. It is idle, having planted an acorn in the morning, to expect that afternoon to sit in the shade of the oak. So life goes on. For years we plant the seed, we feel ourselves rich; and then come other years when time does its work and our plantation is made sparse and thin. One by one, our comrades slip away, deprive us of their shade.”
And I keep reflecting on these timeless words of the author, “What is essential is invisible to the eye.” It emphasizes the importance of looking beyond the surface and relying on intuition, empathy, and emotions to truly understand and appreciate what is essential in life.

02/07/24, 8:09 am - Dr Raguram: When poets write about nature, it is not merely about the landscape around them, but on how they perceive it. Wislawa Szymborska, the Polish Nobel Laureate’s poem, ‘View with a Grain of Sand’, is a poem painted with an engaging palette of words. The poet makes us think differently about objects and things we see and name. The objects we see do not know their names or their purposes. Likewise, sand does not know that it is sand. We give it an identity and call it sand within the frameworks of our language. Wislawa Szymborska draws our attention not just to the sand, but how we understand, comprehend and construct a sense of identity about objects around us. 
A few lines from the poem;
“We call it a grain of sand,
but it calls itself neither grain nor sand.
It does just fine without a name,
whether general, particular,
permanent, passing,
incorrect, or apt.
Our glance, our touch mean nothing to it.
It doesn't feel itself seen and touched.
And that it fell on the windowsill
is only our experience, not its.
For it, it is no different from falling on anything else
with no assurance that it has finished falling
or that it is falling still”.
The tapestry of words that she weaves, is intricate and magical.
And I keep reading, re-reading and reflecting on these lines from another of her poem, ‘Water’
“There are not enough mouths to utter
all your fleeting names, O water.
Emerson said it succinctly “The world is emblematic. Parts of speech are metaphors, because the whole of nature is a metaphor of the human mind”.
Wisława Szymborska (2 July 1923 - 1 February 2012 )

04/07/24, 9:48 am - Dr Raguram: Van Mahotsav is an annual ritual, diligently observed by the state between July 1st and 7th, every year. The occasion is heralded with planting of trees. Unfortunately most of the saplings remain largely unattended thereafter and wither till it is time for the next Van Mahotsav.
The sad fact beyond these ceremonial occasions is that the forest cover in India is dwindling at an alarming rate. . According to the India State of Forest Report (ISFR) 2021, India has lost 2.33 million hectares of tree cover since 2000, with the highest loss in 2017 at 189,000 hectares. In 2023, the country lost 144,000 hectares, the highest in the last six years. In addition, the quality of India's forests has also deteriorated, with 9,117 square kilometres of forest turning into barren lands and scrubs between 2019 and 2021. Fixing the forest cover by planting a new one is an endlessly impossible task, as the life of the forest takes its own time. 
Forests are critical to reduce and sequester carbon dioxide, protect habitats for millions of species, and ensure the health and wellbeing of people. As we search for a route to a sustainable future, we need to halt deforestation. Keeping forests standing is the most cost-effective of celebrating Van Mahotsav
Gieve Patel, a poet and artist whom I admire immensely, describes the cruelty of man in killing/destroying the tree with a touch of irony in this poem;
ON KILLING A TREE
It takes much time to kill a tree,
Not a simple jab of the knife

Will do it. It has grown
Slowly consuming the earth,
Rising out of it, feeding
Upon its crust, absorbing
Years of sunlight, air, water,
And out of its leperous hide
Sprouting leaves.

So hack and chop
But this alone wont do it.
Not so much pain will do it.
The bleeding bark will heal
And from close to the ground
Will rise curled green twigs,
Miniature boughs
Which if unchecked will expand again
To former size.

No,
The root is to be pulled out -
Out of the anchoring earth;
It is to be roped, tied,
And pulled out - snapped out
Or pulled out entirely,
Out from the earth-cave,
And the strength of the tree exposed,
The source, white and wet,
The most sensitive, hidden
For years inside the earth.

Then the matter
Of scorching and choking
In sun and air,
Browning, hardening,
Twisting, withering,
And then it is done.

05/07/24, 8:28 am - Dr Raguram: On the 4th of July in 1855, Walt Whitman self-published his first edition of Leaves of Grass, a volume of twelve poems. He pronounced that “This is no book, / Who touches this touches a man.” It had a lengthy preface in which he reflected on various aspects of life “Love the earth and sun and the animals, despise riches, give alms to everyone that asks, stand up for the stupid and crazy, devote your income and labour to others, hate tyrants, argue not concerning God, have patience and indulgence toward the people, take off your hat to nothing known or unknown or to any man or number of men, go freely with powerful uneducated persons and with the young and with the mothers of families, read these leaves in the open air every season of every year of your life, re-examine all you have been told at school or church or in any book, dismiss whatever insults your own soul, and your very flesh shall be a great poem and have the richest fluency not only in its words but in the silent lines of its lips and face and between the lashes of your eyes and in every motion and joint of your body.”
The initial print run of the first edition was modest and the book did not sell well. It did receive a number of rave reviews in New York newspapers and some of them were written by Whitman himself. Whitman was undeterred and continued to add poems to ‘Leaves of Grass’ in four different editions and finished the last revision on his deathbed in 1892.
The poems in the ‘Leaves of Grass‘ represent Whitman's celebration of his philosophy of life and nature. Throughout the book, Whitman emphasizes the importance of connecting with nature and finding solace, inspiration, and spiritual fulfilment in the natural world. He sees nature as a source of wisdom and renewal, and encourages readers to forge a deeper connection with the environment around them. 
“Smile O voluptuous coolbreathed earth!
Earth of the slumbering and liquid trees!
Earth of departed sunset! Earth of the mountains misty-top!
Earth of vitreous pour of the full moon just tinged with blue!
Earth of shine and dark mottling the tide of the river!
Earth of the limpid gray of clouds brighter and clearer for my sake!
Far-swooping elbowed earth! Rich apple-blossomed earth!
Smile, for your lover comes!

07/07/24, 8:55 am - Dr Raguram: I was listening to Mahler’s ‘The Song of the Earth’ symphony the other day. It is interspersed with six songs. I couldn’t follow the lyrics and checked for them in the net. It was an interesting discovery! The songs are based on a set of poems, ‘The Chinese Flute’, dating back to the Tang dynasty. Curious to know further, I searched for their translation and found that each one of them was so meaningful. For instance, Mahler employed two poems; Mong Kao-Yen “Staying at a Teacher’s Mountain retreat and Awaiting a Friend in Vain” and Wang Wei’s “Farewell”. The final lines are:
“I shall no longer seek the far horizon
Still is my heart and awaits its hour….
The lovely earth everywhere blossoms and grows anew
Everywhere and forever the luminous blue of distant space….Forever…forever…”
The word forever is repeated nine times indication that forever there will be beauty, sadness, tears and happiness in all our life experiences.  
Listening to ‘The Song of the Earth’ was a revelation as to how poetry can be combined seamlessly with beautiful orchestration to create a magical listening experience.
I read further about Mahler and found that he experienced a slew of losses in his life; the death of his closest brother at the age of 13; his sister at the age of 26; and the suicide of another brother and the loss of his elder daughter. In addition, Mahler himself had serious health problems, sometimes life-threatening, throughout his life. 
This draws attention to the significant interface between adversity and creativity. Often a crucible of challenges is a fertile ground for the seeds of creativity to emerge and flourish. Creativity also serves as a coping mechanism in the face of adversity, providing individuals with an avenue for self-expression and can be a therapeutic outlet too. 
As the life of Gustav Mahler informs us, in the face of adversity creativity is a guiding light. 
(Gustav Mahler 7th July 1860 – 18th May 1911)

08/07/24, 9:04 am - Dr Raguram: With advances in health care, dying is increasingly becoming lonely, mechanical and dehumanized. To assist and help people cope with a demanding end of life process, one has to listen to them. This is what Elisabeth Kubler-Ross did. Along with four of her students she conducted a series of interviews with the terminally ill which resulted in her path breaking book, ‘On Death and Dying.’ The book outlined five stages of grief, popularly referred to as DABDA: Denial, Anger, Bargaining, Depression, Acceptance. 
Though her work brought death and dying out of the closet, Elisabeth Kubler-Ross’s legacy has been a mixed one. There has been critical re-examination of the stages she has outlined and whether these stages apply to everyone who is grieving, since her research focused only on those who were terminally ill. Empirical evidence for these stages was also scanty. The well conducted Yale Bereavement Study did not find support for Kübler-Ross’s five stage theory.  The findings indicated that acceptance was the most commonly reported reaction from the start, and yearning was the most common negative feature for the first two years. The other variables, such as disbelief, depression and anger were typically absent or minimal. Moreover, her model described how people with terminal illness face their imminent death. But strangely, it was soon adapted as a way of thinking about grief in general. The process of death and dying is not purely enacted within the individual and is impacted by a host of social, religious and cultural factors which is noticeably absent in her work. Perhaps the abiding appeal of her work is in its simplicity. 
Her later years were mired in scandals. She began to embrace spiritualism, claiming she had communicated with spirits of the dead with names like “Mario,” “Anka,” “Salem,” and “Willie.” She started believing in reincarnation, and told listeners she had lived during the time of Jesus, when she had been named Isabel. She involved herself in a cult-like retreat with a psychic called Jay Barham. and conducted séances which involved the widows/widowers ‘engaging’ with the departed. It was revealed that Barham molested female participants during séances, while pretending to be an "afterlife entity". Her professional reputation began to decline and she also became largely confined to bed due to a series of strokes. 
In the final stages of her life she observed, “I now know that the purpose of my life is more than these stages. I have been married, had kids, then grandkids, written books, and travelled. I have loved and lost, and I am so much more than five stages. And so are you.”
(Elisabeth Kubler Ross 8th July 1926 – 24th August 2004)

09/07/24, 9:28 am - Dr Raguram: I am besotted with gardens. When I walk through a garden I am enveloped in a symphony of colors, rustling leaves, bird and insect sounds wafting through the air. It is an immersive experience imbued with a sense of tranquillity. As Bacon commented, “it is the purest of human pleasure.” Gardens are often seen as a refuge, a place to forget the "real" life that lies outside. But they are also quintessential healing spaces. 
Oliver Sacks, the famed neurologist and author, whose birthday falls today, wrote a small, wonderful essay “Why We Need Gardens,” in his book “Everything in Its Place: First Loves and Last Tales,” which was published posthumously. Since his place of work was just across the road from the New York Botanical Garden, he noticed how patients who were unable to function inside a hospital setting seemed to come alive in the garden. An elderly lady with Parkinson’s disease, often frozen, unable to initiate movement was more mobile in the garden and even climbed the rocks up and down many times, unattended. Patients with very advanced dementia who had difficulty in even tying their shoe laces, when put in front of a flower bed with some seedlings knew exactly what to do. He described such deep bonds people have with gardens as “hortophilia.” In his words, “I cannot say exactly how nature exerts its calming and organizing effects on our brains, but I have seen in my patients the restorative and healing powers of nature and gardens, even for those who are deeply disabled neurologically. In many cases, gardens and nature are more powerful than any medication”. He went on to add, “In forty years of medical practice, I have found only two types of non-pharmaceutical ‘therapy’ to be vitally important for patients with chronic neurological diseases: music and gardens.”
Gardens saturate our awareness and the boundary between our self and the world fuses and we feel more alive and flourish in that moment. It leaves a lasting trace in the innards of our minds.
For Thich Nhat Hanh, garden was a metaphor for the mind. He wrote, “First, you have to take care of your own garden and master the art of gardening. In each one of us there are flowers and there is also garbage. The garbage is the anger, fear, discrimination, and jealousy within us. If you water the garbage, you will strengthen the negative seeds. If you water the flowers of compassion, understanding, and love, you will strengthen the positive seeds. What you grow is up to you.”

11/07/24, 8:45 am - Dr Raguram: People have been drawing and painting flowers for a very long time. In contrast to botanical illustration, botanical artwork emphasizes the aesthetic value of the plant or flower but without much of the details illustrated in the former. The artist tries to capture the essence of the dainty plant form in all its inherent beauty.
One of the most celebrated flower painter in the entire history of botanical art was Pierre-Joseph Redouté. Nicknamed “the Raphael of flowers,” he was one of the most talented botanical artists ever known. He was also arguably the most popular botanical artist in history. Redouté was patronized by the kings of France from Louis XVI to Louis-Philippe and their wives. In his lifetime, he produced over 2,100 paintings, depicting over 1,800 different species, many of which had never been rendered before. Even now, each of his paintings fetch incredible prices at auction. Fortunately many of his original works are available in the digital world for us to savour.
In the accompanying image, Redoute’s painting of a tulip is on the left and on the right is one of my photographs of the flower. What I captured through my lens is a pale image of the flower lusciously portrayed in exquisite detail by the talented Redoute.
As Edvard Munch commented, “Nature is not only all that is visible to the eye… it also includes the inner pictures of the soul.” And a flower seen through a painter’s eyes has a transcendental quality which a photograph can rarely match.
(Pierre-Joseph Redouté July 10, 1759 - June 20, 1840)

12/07/24, 9:53 am - Dr Raguram: I've read DT Suzuki’s book on Zen Buddhism long time ago. I am not sure what led me to pull the book out of the shelf a few days ago. And on the page I randomly picked, there was this comment, “Outwardly, be open; inwardly, be deep.” And it resonated with me in an inexplicable way.
I consider Zen to be the best source of guidance for people like me who do not strictly adhere to any religious camp but drawn by a spiritual quest. I especially like that Zen has no need for God or any other supernatural entity. The quirky Zen tales and anecdotes fascinate me, even though I have trouble grasping them, sometime. 
DT Suzuki is responsible for a clear and simple introduction to the essentials of Zen Buddhism. Carl Jung wrote a remarkable foreword to Suzuki's Introduction to Zen Buddhism. Zen is an experience not confined to the intellect. As Jung wrote in the introduction, “A monk once went to Gensha, and wanted to learn where the entrance to the path of truth was. Gensha asked him, "Do you hear the murmuring of the brook?" "Yes, I hear it," answered the monk. "There is the entrance," the master instructed him. 
Zen Buddhism aspires to seek meaning without insisting upon belief. As Suzuki wrote perceptively, “The idea of Zen is to catch life as it flows. There is nothing extraordinary or mysterious about Zen. I raise my hand; I take a book from the other side of the desk; I hear the boys playing ball outside my window; I see the clouds blown away beyond the neighbouring wood: — in all these I am practising Zen, I am living Zen. No wordy discussion is necessary, nor any explanation. I do not know why and there is no need of explaining, but when the sun rises the whole world dances with joy and everybody’s heart is filled with bliss. If Zen is at all conceivable, it must be taken hold of here.”
As for me, all of us live our lives on the edge of the vast sea of consciousness, sometimes caressed by waves of awareness and it is a zen moment.
(DT Suzuki 18th October 1870 – 12th July 1966)

16/07/24, 9:50 am - Dr Raguram: Goddess Kali is the first of the Dasa Mahavidyas, the ten aspects or forms of Shakti.  She is the quintessential embodiment of Shakti embodying the power of creation and destruction in one entity. She is perceived as Mother Nature, primordial, nurturing, creating, and devouring all at once. In Sri Ramakrishna Paramahamsa’s words she is “the benign all-loving Mother.” He felt in her breath “the soothing touch of tender love and saw in her the seed of immortality.” 
There is a carefully chiselled sculpture of her in the Hoysaleshewara temple at Halebidu. She is seen holding a trident, damaru, knife and a severed head in her four hands. A garland of severed heads adorns her. Around her are corpses and one of them is seen dancing too.  
Looking at her, I wonder whether the severed head is indicative that we should severe the human ego in order to exit from the cycle of life and rebirth.
Mary Starton was a gifted writer and she was best known and most highly regarded as a poet. In a collection of her poetry ‘A Grain of Mustard Seed’, she wrote an evocative poem about Goddess Kali. 
INVOCATION TO KALI
“Kali, be with us.
Violence, destruction, receive our homage.
Help us to bring darkness into the light,
To lift out the pain, the anger,
Where it can be seen for what it is—
The balance-wheel for our vulnerable, aching love.
Put the wild hunger where it belongs,
Within the act of creation,
Crude power that forges a balance
Between hate and love.
Help us to be the always hopeful
Gardeners of the spirit
Who know that without darkness
Nothing comes to birth
As without light
Nothing flowers.
Bear the roots in mind,
You, the dark one, Kali,
Awesome power.”
(Mary Starton May 3, 1912 - July 16, 1995)

18/07/24, 9:41 am - Dr Raguram: Why are people so besotted with the weddings of the “rich and famous?” I am a strong advocate of Kuvempu, one of the greatest poets of Kannada, who propounded the idea of a distinctly different kind of marriage which he called, ‘Mantra Mangalya’. It is a revolutionary approach to bring back marriage to the folds of personal Dharma freed from the clutches of hedonism and ritualistic customs. It is a simple marriage ceremony devoid of pomp to teach couples the seriousness and sacredness of marriage, encouraging them to adopt the values inherent in this method throughout their lives. 
Mantra Mangalya is available as a manual. It has three sections. The first one explains what Mantra Mangalya is, “It is a type of marriage in which the bride and the groom invoke the power symbolising all the values worshipped by Indians since times immemorial”. It goes on to add, “The objective of Mantra Mangalya is to liberate Indians from the rituals which are indirectly responsible for evils of caste system, gender inequality and untouchability. As this mode of marriage has to be simple, no part of the wedding shall be expensive or ostentatious. No one shall receive dowry in any form.” 
The next section has meticulous instructions on the conduct of the ceremony. The total number of invitees including parents and relations should not exceed 200. Gifts are prohibited. No particular time is auspicious or inauspicious. Mantra Mangalya believes that the whole life of man is auspicious for making life fruitful. Photographs of four Mahapurushas such as Ramakrishna Parmahamsa and Sharada Devi or of any ideal couple shall be placed as spiritual witnesses. 
The third section is titled “Marriage Code”. It is an extra-ordinary set of statements meant to be administered to the bride and groom. It reiterates that the wife is equal to the husband, enjoying the same freedom and emphasizes the crucial role of affective bond between the spouses as an important aspect to sustain relationship. It ends by stating that “the bride and groom who are now unfettered from all religions, rituals, and ignorance, should continue this sacred duty of unfettering humanity. There is no need to belong to any religion. There is no need to belong to any sect. There is no need to follow any rituals. The aforementioned oaths are the guiding lights in your life.”
(Mantra Mangalya is available in amazon)

19/07/24, 10:34 am - Dr Raguram: After completing PUC, I had quite a bit of time before venturing into a professional course and I spent most of this time cycling to Eswari Lending Library in Chennai. One day when I was browsing, I noticed AJ Cronin’s ‘The Citadel’, in one of the shelves. I’ve never heard of him before. I brought it back home and finished reading it in one setting. 
‘Citadel’ tells the story of Andrew Manson, a young, idealistic doctor, who moves to a small mining town. He soon finds that he is dealing with more than what he’d bargained for. There is a lot of poverty in the town, many miners suffering from lung diseases. He begins to notice how doctors often lack clinical competence and are part of the system which really doesn’t help the people the way it should. He carefully studies the lung afflictions of the miners and completes his thesis detailing it. The research gains him a post with the "Mines Fatigue Board" in London, but he resigns after six months to set up a private practice. Seduced by the thought of making easy money from wealthy clients, he drifts away from the principles he started with and is estranged from his wife. When he notices the death of a patient because of a surgeon's ineptitude, he abandons his practice and returns to his wife to begin his life afresh. Tragically she is run over by a bus and dies. 
In this novel, Cronin draws attention to the moral dilemmas that beset the doctors and the conflicts between the demands of private medicine as a business and of medicine as a Platonic ideal. He deftly identifies many of the issues in clinical practice which needs to be tackled like adequate training of doctors to prepare them for the reality of practice in the community, better supervision of young doctors, importance of team based care and the crucial role of ethics in medicine. As Cronin commented, “I have written in ‘The Citadel’ all I feel about the medical profession, its injustices, its hide-bound unscientific stubbornness, its humbug… The horrors and inequities detailed in the story I have personally witnessed. This is not an attack against individuals, but against a system.”
In choosing the title for the novel, I wonder whether Cronin is prescient in alluding that modern health care system has become an impenetrable citadel where doctors ensconce and fortify themselves in defensive practices, highlighting in the process, the importance of opening the doors of the fortress.
Reading, for me is like stepping into worlds that I am not aware of. As a youngster, ‘Citadel’ opened my eyes to the varied landscapes of the practice of medicine and perhaps also played a role in my choice of the profession.
Stories can change lives… 
(AJ Cronin Born On 19th July 1896)

20/07/24, 8:06 am - Dr Raguram: Literature is replete with evocative portraits of romantic love in its many facets. The Greeks had three expressions to designate love: Eros, Philos and Agape. Eros is love between two persons that perpetuates the human race. Philos is the sentiment that we dedicate to our friends. Finally, Agape, which contains both Eros and Philos, is total love; the love that we give spontaneously to others, regardless of reciprocation, which devours those who feel it. 
One of the most endearing expression of love in literature is that of Petrarch. He was an Italian scholar and poet and is considered as one of the founders of the Renaissance movement in arts and literature. His most famous work is his ‘Canzoniere’, a collection of love poems written in the vernacular which revolve around an unknown and unobtainable woman called Laura.
In sonnet 353, titled ‘The Wandering Bird’ he articulates poignantly, his love for Laura and the unbearable loss after her demise. 
“Sweet wandering bird that singest on thy way,
Or mournest yet the time for ever past,
Watching night come and spring receding fast,
Day’s bliss behind thee and the seasons gay,—
If thou my griefs against thine own couldst weigh,
Thou couldst not guess how long my sorrows last;
Yet thou mightst hide thee from the wintry blast
Within my breast, and thus my pains allay.
Yet may not all thy woes be named with mine,
Since she whom thou dost mourn may live, yet live,
But death and heaven still hold my spirit’s bride;
And all those long past days of sad decline
With all the joys remembered years can give
Still bid me ask “Sweet bird! with me abide!”
Petrarch is so consumed by grief following the death of the woman he loves that he begins to see sorrow in the world around him. He hears the song of the bird and imagines that every note is stricken with grief. The bird is a symbol of the deep pain and suffering Petrarch endures after the death of Laura. He talks to the bird and hopes that the bird can sympathize with his pain because there is no one else to talk with. 
When poets dip their pen in emotions deeply entrenched in the innermost recesses of their hearts, love, longing and loss comes alive… 
( Petrarch. July 20, 1304 - July 19, 1374)
Dr Raguram

21/07/24, 6:48 am - Dr Raguram: Today is dedicated to expressing gratitude and reverence to teachers. The term Guru is derived from the Sanskrit, ‘Gu’ meaning darkness and ‘ru’ signifying light. 
Guru Paduka Stotram is a hymn which draws attention to the importance and influence of a Guru in one’s life. One day, Adi Shankaracharya was travelling across the country in search of his Master, Govind Bhagavatpada when he came upon a cave on the banks of River Narmada. He saw a pair of padukas or sandals outside the cave and immediately recognized them as that of his Master. Filled with abundant joy, he penned the ‘Guru Paduka Stotram.’ Padukas are symbolically representative of the ‘the boat to help cross the endless ocean of life’. It is a beautiful hymn which ends with these verses.
कामादिसर्प व्रजगारुडाभ्यां विवेकवैराग्य निधिप्रदाभ्याम् ।
बोधप्रदाभ्यां दृतमोक्षदाभ्यां नमो नमः श्रीगुरुपादुकाभ्याम् ॥
That which is the Garuda which drives off the serpents of passion,
That which provides one with the treasure of wisdom and renunciation,
That which blesses one with refined wisdom,
And that which blesses the aspirant with speedy salvation,
Salutations to such sacred sandals of my revered Guru.
Sri Dakshinamurthy is regarded as the quintessential  guru, an embodiment of knowledge and the destroyer of ignorance. These images of Sri Dakshinamurthy are from Brahmapureeswarar temple at Pullamangai. In the Koshtam on the southern side, there is an entrancing idol of Sri Dakshinamurthy with two more depictions of the Lord, above, in the Vimana.
तस्मै श्रीगुरुमूर्तये नम इदं श्रीदक्षिणामूर्तये 
Salutations to Him, the Personification of Our Inner Guru Who Awakens Knowledge through His Profound Silence; Salutation to Sri Dakshinamurthy.

24/07/24, 9:05 am - Dr Raguram: Hermits have been around in every historical era, across all geographical locales. In nearly all cultures of the world, we find people who chose to live differently, often in solitary existence. Japan has a long tradition of hermits and Kamo no Chomei was a famous recluse during the medieval times. After living through calamitous time, at the age of fifty, Chomei renounced the world, became a hermit and built a small hut for himself in the mountains. In this retreat, he spent his time, observing signs of change in the seasons: wisteria blossoms in spring, summer cuckoos, autumns insect chirping, and snow in winter and meditating. Chomei was a poet and he wrote about his experiences in a book, ‘Hojoki.’ It’s opening phrases are lyrical, 
“The flowing river 
never stops
and yet the water
never stays
the same. 
Foam floats
upon the pools
scattering, re-forming
never lingering long. 
So it is with man
and all his dwelling places
here on earth.”
Writing about life spent in quietude, he observes:
“Fish do not hate the water.
But then, none can know
the happiness of the fish
unless he is one.
Birds love the woods.
If you are not a bird
you will not know its truths.
A quiet life is much the same. 
How would anyone know it 
without living it?”
Having spent his life in seclusion, Chomei is profoundly reflective in the final passages of the ‘Hojoki’ wondering whether he has adhered to the essential teaching of the Buddha.
“The moon of my life is setting. 
The life now left me sinks into the hills. 
Any time now I may descend
to the darkness of the river below.
To what end do I pour this out?
Buddha taught we must not be attached.
Yet the way I love this hut is itself attachment.
To be attached to the quiet and serene
must likewise be a burden”
(Kamo no Chomei died on July 24, 1216)

25/07/24, 9:00 am - Dr Raguram: Birds are nature’s original poems. Once you start to hear birds, notice them, learn their habits, the world around you opens up in beautiful ways. Our lives would be charmless without them. Their songs give solace to the weary soul. There are thousands of beautiful poems written about birds by poets all over the world. Many turned to them for inspiration at various points in their writing as birds provide boundless metaphors. For example, the singing of the nightingale becomes a metaphor for writing poetry in Shelley’s works, “A poet is a nightingale, who sits in darkness and sings to cheer its own solitude with sweet sounds; his auditors are as men entranced by the melody of an unseen musician, who feel that they are moved and softened, yet know not whence or why.” 
The nightingale is a recurrent theme in poetry. Samuel Taylor Coleridge (21 October 177 - 25 July 1834), famed author of ‘Rime of the Ancient Mariner’ lived in the Chanters House which had a Victorian bird house with an aviary. He wrote about the nightingale too;
“Many a nightingale perch giddily
On blossomy twig still swinging from the breeze,
And to that motion tune his wanton song
Like tipsy Joy that reels with tossing head.”
Poetry for Coleridge, “has been to me its own exceeding great reward; it has given me the habit of wishing to discover the good and beautiful in all that meets and surrounds me.”
(The accompanying image is that of the Northern Mockingbird which is commonly called the “American Nightingale.” It lives up to its nickname, singing during the day and sometimes at night, varying its songs from spring to fall. The Northern Mockingbird can sing up to 30 differing bird songs)
