26/07/24, 9:41 am - Dr Raguram: There are two books of CG Jung which I treasure and value deeply. One is Volume 16 of his Collected Works which explores psychotherapy and the other one is the autobiographical ‘Memories, Dreams and Reflections.’ The latter book offers fascinating glimpses about his evolution as a mental health professional.
Jung spent some time at the famous ‘Burgholzi’. He describes his experiences there with extraordinary candour: “Psychiatry teachers were not interested in what the patient had to say, but rather in how to make a diagnosis or how to describe symptoms and to compile statistics. From the clinical point of view which then prevailed, the human personality of the patient, his individuality, did not matter at all. Rather, the doctor was confronted with Patient X, with a long list of cut-and-dried diagnoses and a detailing of symptoms. Patients were labelled, rubber-stamped with a diagnosis, and, for the most part, that settled the matter. The psychology of the patient played no role whatsoever.”
There is also a vivid account of an extraordinary encounter with a patient. A young woman was admitted with the diagnosis of ‘dementia praecox.’ Jung felt that it was a case of depression but did not voice his opinion, fearing rebuke from seniors. He sat with the patient over many days, gently exploring the background to her distress and it revealed a dark story. Before her current marriage, she was keen to marry the son of a wealthy industrialist.  Five years later, an old friend visited her and he said to her, "When you got married it was quite a shock to your Mr. X.”  She started brooding about the loss of her love. She lived in a place where the water supply was not perfectly hygienic; there was pure spring water for drinking, and impure water from the river for bathing and washing. While she was bathing her young daughter, she saw the child sucking at the impure water but did not stop her as she was quite preoccupied. A short time later the girl came down with typhoid fever and died. She was tremendously distressed and was admitted in Burgholzi. Jung started speaking to her over the next few weeks and she was able to acknowledge and work through her distress and guilt. She got better and was discharged. 
In Jung’s words, “In many cases in psychiatry, the patient who comes to us has a story that is not told, and which as a rule no one knows of. To my mind, therapy only really begins after the investigation of that wholly personal story. It is the patient's secret, the rock against which he is shattered. If I know his secret story, I have a key to the treatment. The doctor's task is to find out how to gain that knowledge. In therapy the problem is always the whole person, never the symptom alone.”
This facet of Jung, not so well known, draws attention to importance of the transformative power of narration in psychotherapy. Stories that are told in therapy are the stories that cannot be told in everyday life. The role of the therapist is to offer a space to share such stories and facilitate emergence of alternate versions and make them feel confident to try them out in their lives.

27/07/24, 9:24 am - Dr Raguram: Mangroves are enchanting places. Our sojourn amidst the mangroves of the Zuari river remains deeply etched in memory. Zuari River is the largest river in Goa which divides the state into two parts; North Goa and South Goa. It’s a tidal river, which sustains this important ecosystem. We boarded the boat at the Courtalim ferry pier and as we slowly coursed along the wide swatches of mangroves, a wide array of birds kept us company. Numerous species of water birds were foraging the shallow marshy banks for food. One of the birds that caught our attention was the black capped kingfisher which was perched on a swaying branch. As we were leaving an Indian Mugger Crocodile cast a lazy glance at us from its muddy abode.
Mangrove forests are among the planet’s most complex ecosystems. The word "mangrove" comes from the Portuguese word mangue, which means "tree", and the English word "grove", which refers to trees and shrubs in sandy, muddy, or shallow areas. Mangroves are survivors flourishing in environmental conditions that would swiftly kill most other types of vegetation. Known as the dancing trees, mangroves are regularly battered by cyclonic winds, especially along the coasts of India, but their intertwined breathing root system anchors them firm on the soil. They play a crucial role in protecting coastal areas from tsunamis. Mangroves are critical ecosystems sustaining a wide array of biodiversity.  
Let me end this post paying obeisance to a remarkable man who was instrumental in developing and conserving mangroves in Kerala. Pokkudan, who grew by the lap of the estuaries and the rich rivers of Ezhom recognized the importance of mangroves. With remarkable determination, he would set out on his country boat everyday along the waters to plant saplings of mangroves in the marshes.  He not only planted acres of mangrove saplings but ensured their protection against tremendous odds, until they emerged as teeming mangrove forests. Over a span of two and a half decades, Pokkudan had planted over hundreds of thousands of mangrove saplings along the banks of the Pazhayangadi River in the Kannur district, which earned him the sobriquet as ‘Kandal Pokkudan’ (Kandal is mangrove in Malayalam). Pokkudan describes his efforts poetically in his autobiography, ‘Kandalkadukalkidayil Ente Jeevitham’ (My Life Among the Mangrove Forests) “I began by planting 300 mangrove plants to prevent the sea from eroding the coast and to shield the children walking to the school from the gusts of wind. And to soak in their beauty when they grew up.” He passed away in 2015 leaving behind a great legacy. 
(26th July, International Day for the Conservation of the Mangrove Ecosystem).

28/07/24, 6:17 pm - Dr Raguram: Grandmothers are endless sources of engaging stories and delectable food. When we were young, there was no concept of an evening ‘tiffin’. Instead of tea and biscuits, the leftover food from the morning will take a new mouth-watering avatar in the evening. All the kids of the house will sit around the grandmother as she placed a dollop of delicious, recycled food in our hands while narrating a story. It was always a very special moment for all of us.
I travelled back in time reminiscing about these moments when I read the poem “Butterfly Laughter" by Katherine Mansfield.
“In the middle of our porridge plates
There was a blue butterfly painted
And each morning we tried who should reach the
          butterfly first.
Then the Grandmother said:  "Do not eat the poor
          butterfly."
That made us laugh.
Always she said it and always it started us laughing.
It seemed such a sweet little joke.
I was certain that one fine morning
The butterfly would fly out of our plates,
Laughing the teeniest laugh in the world,
And perch on the Grandmother's lap.”
The grandmother has made a porridge for the children and she painted a blue butterfly on top of it to make the food attractive. There is a competition among all the children as to who will eat that butterfly first. When the grandmother remarks, "Do not eat the poor butterfly", they start laughing. The poet wonders what the grandmother’s reaction would be if the butterfly comes alive and sits on her lap! 
“That butterfly
Will land on us
One day
When wrinkles arrive
And we get old”
(28th July is World Grandparent’s Day)

02/08/24, 8:39 am - Dr Raguram: It is a harrowing sight to see the immense devastation and intense human suffering in Wayanad. It is difficult to express their pain and travails in words. Sometimes poets express it poignantly. Pablo Neruda wrote a poem; 
FLOOD
“The poor live on low ground waiting for the river
to rise one night and sweep them out to sea.
I’ve seen small cradles floating by, the wrecks
of house, chairs, and a great rage of ash—
pale water draining terror from the sky:
this is all yours, poor man, for your wife and crop,
dog and tools, for you to learn to beg.
No water climbs to the homes of gentlemen
whose snowy collars flutter on the line.
It feeds on this rolling mire, these ruins winding
their idle course to the sea with your dead,
among rough cut tables and the luckless trees
that bob and tumble turning up bare root.”
Pablo Neruda draws attention to the effects of flooding on poor communities. The poor often live in low-lying areas that are periodically flooded due to heavy rains because these are the only places they can afford. These floods often result in the loss of lives and belongings. Neruda contrasts the terror and losses from flooding that the poor endure with that of the rich, who can afford to build houses on higher ground where no rising waters come close to their homes.

05/08/24, 8:51 am - Dr Raguram: Hyde Park was a favourite haunt of mine during my fellowship years in London, decades ago. It is an urban oasis in the midst of busy, bustling London. The park is dotted with monuments and statues and on one occasion I came across an intriguing relief, which I couldn’t figure out. Later, I discovered that it depicts a mysterious girl, ‘Rima’ from the book ‘Green Mansions’ written by WH Hudson. Curious to find out more about the author, I learnt that he was a founder-member of the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds (RSPB), in 1889. RSPB had 20,000 members at that time, majority of them women. Hudson was a meticulous observer of nature and during a sojourn to Patagonia, he identified a flycatcher which is named after him. He also authored a series of ornithological studies. 
Hudson’s writings are quite lyrical, ”The blue sky, the brown soil beneath, the grass, the trees, the animals, the wind, and rain, and stars are never strange to me; for I am in and of and am one with them; and my flesh and the soil are one, and the heat in my blood and in the sunshine are one, and the winds and the tempests and my passions are one.”
I particularly like his observation about the humming bird, “Have you ever observed a humming-bird moving about in an aerial dance among the flowers--a living prismatic gem that changes its colour with every change of position.”
Hudson was ahead of his time and believed in studying his subjects in the field, not just in the laboratory. He would spend long hours quietly watching, listening, and being with nature. “when walking there one day, the loveliness of that green leafy world, its silence and its melody and the divine sunlight, so wrought on me that for a few precious moments it produced a mystical state, that rare condition of beautiful illusions when the feet are off the ground, when, on some occasions, we appear to be one with nature, unbodied like the poet's bird, floating, diffused in it.”
He was admired by Virginia Woolf and Joseph Conrad, who declared that he wrote ‘as the good God makes the grass grow’. 
(W H Hudson. Born on 4 August 1841)

06/08/24, 8:11 am - Dr Raguram: When we were in Bandipur some months ago, I noticed this little bird peeping out of its nest and I was reminded of a simple, beautiful poem by Alfred Tennyson whose birthday is today.
WHAT DOES THAT LITTLE BIRDIE SAY
“What does little birdie say,
In her nest at peep of day?
“Let me fly,” says little birdie—
“Mother, let me fly away.”
“Birdie, rest a little longer,
Till the little wings are stronger.”
So she rests a little longer,
Then she flies away.
What does little baby say
In her bed at peep of day?
Baby says, like little birdie,
“Let me rise and fly away.”
“Baby, sleep a little longer,
Till the little limbs are stronger.
If she sleeps a little longer,
Baby, too, shall fly away.”
It is a touching poem about a bird's desire to leave the nest and experience the world. The mother, gently advises the young bird to stay and rest, as its wings are not yet strong enough to fly. The poem ends by hinting that eventually the little bird will soon fly away. All of us aspire for independence and exploration, but need the guidance and protection of our parents till we find the metier to be on our own.
All of us are born to fly. As the master strategist Napoleon Bonaparte is said to have commented, “Until you spread your wings, you’ll have no idea how far you can fly.”  
(I scrupulously avoid nest photography and this was taken from a distance with utmost care that the bird doesn’t sense my presence!)

07/08/24, 10:21 am - Dr Raguram: India is a land of festivals. Traditions and rituals associated with it vary across the vast cultural landscape of India. For instance, today is celebrated as Hariyali Teej in many states in Northern India to commemorate the union of Shiva and Parvati.
Triyuginarayan temple is situated at the confluence of Mandakini and Son-Ganga river in Rudraprayag district of Uttarakhand. It is a much sought after wedding destination as it is said to be the place where the celestial marriage of Shiva and Parvati took place. Parvati, daughter to Himavat was keen to marry Shiva and undertook rigorous penance to prove her love and dedication to Shiva at Gauri Kund, which is not very far from Triyuginarayan. Gauri Kund temple, which dedicated to Parvati, is also the base camp for trekking to Kedarnath Temple. Mythology states that Shiva proposed to Parvati at Guptakashi and got married in the Triyuginarayan temple. A holy fire still burns perpetually in front of the temple and the ashes from this fire are supposed to promote conjugal bliss. 
There are many sculptural depictions of the celestial event of the marriage of Shiva and Parvati. Perhaps one of most beautiful one is at the 10th century Bhoganandishwara temple near Bangalore. In this relief one can see Lord Brahma on the extreme right and next to him is Vishnu who is blessing the couple. In the middle are the couple, Shiva and Parvati. Next to the couple is the father of Parvati offering Kanyadan and adjoining him is Parvati’s mother. 
Embedded in rich mythological tapestry, the marriage of Shiva and Parvati is a tale that resonates with devotion, perseverance, and the enduring power of love.

08/08/24, 10:15 am - Dr Raguram: A movie that left a deep impression on me was ‘Charly’ directed by Ralph Nelson. Based on the novel ‘Flowers for Algermon’ by Daniel Keyes, It had a beautiful musical score by Pandit Ravi Shankar. It’s a timeless story that explores the experiences of Charlie Gordon, a 32-year-old man with a learning disability who undergoes surgery in an effort to make him “smarter” and more “normal.” Since the same procedure worked well on Algernon, a lab mouse, the scientists have high hopes for Charlie’s transformation. After the operation, Charlie’s intelligence begins to steadily increase and he is functionally a genius after a few months. As his intelligence grows, he finds it increasingly difficult to connect with others at an emotional level and realizes that he is losing touch with his own emotional needs and desires, “I don’t know what’s worse; to not know what you are and be happy, or to become what you’ve always wanted to be, and feel alone.” The researchers present Charlie and their findings at a scientific convention. Meanwhile Charly comes to know that Algernon has lost its enhanced intelligence and died, facts that the research team kept away from him. He starts wondering whether he will undergo a similar decline and reflects, “The problem, dear professor, is that you wanted someone who could be made intelligent but still be kept in a cage and displayed when necessary to reap the honours you seek. The hitch is that I'm a person.” Soon Charly regresses to his previous level of intelligence, but finally feels himself at home, happier than before. 
The story explores themes that are still relevant today, including intelligence, empathy, and the ethical implications of scientific advancement. More importantly, it seeks out the unflinchingly honest message that our humanity is not measured by how smart we are, but rather by our kindness, love and interaction with others.
In the era of Neurolink, the daunting question is “Does intelligence alone makes us better people?”
Charly reminds us that, “Intelligence is one of the greatest human gifts. But all too often a search for knowledge drives out the search for love. This is something else I've discovered for myself very recently. I present it to you as a hypothesis: Intelligence without the ability to give and receive affection leads to mental and moral breakdown, to neurosis, and possibly even psychosis. And I say that the mind absorbed in and involved in itself as a self-centered end, to the exclusion of human relationships, can only lead to violence and pain.”
(Daniel Keyes: 9 August 1927 - 15 June 2014)

10/08/24, 8:54 am - Dr Raguram: Just finished reading Rachel Aviv’s “Strangers to Ourselves”, a moving account of five people who were in throes of various kinds of psychological distress. The book begins with Rachel’s account of her own tryst with Anorexia Nervosa when she was young. Her disinclination to eat occurred on the background of her parents’ divorce and her role as a pawn in their custody battle. The anorexia resolved within the year, and her doctors ended up seeing it as a coping mechanism during a demanding phase in her life. Rachel reflects, “For a child, solipsistic by nature, there are limits to the ways that despair can be communicated. Culture shapes the scripts that expressions of distress will follow. In both anorexia and resignation syndrome, children embody anger and a sense of powerlessness by refusing food, one of the few methods of protest available to them. Experts tell these children that they are behaving in a recognisable way that has a label. The children then make adjustments, conscious and unconscious, to the way that they've been classified. Over time, a willed pattern of behaviour becomes increasingly involuntary and ingrained.” As the poet Louise Gluck who was anorexic, wrote, “The tragedy of anorexia seems to me that its intent is not self-destructive, though its outcome so often is. Its intent is to construct, in the only way possible when means are so limited, a plausible self.”
All five people Rachel writes about are products of their life stories, circumstances over which they had little control. She richly documents each of their journeys in the “psychic hinterlands, the outer edges of human experience, where language tends to fail.” 
I was particularly moved by the narrative about Bapu. Her rich parents married Bapu to a man who was more keen on her money. She had to endure much abuse in the new household and sought solace in religion. She believed Lord Krishna to be her true husband who would offer unconditional love and wrote poems about him. As she merged her life with that of Lord Krishna, she abandoned the household duties, became uncommunicative, attempted multiple times to run away. She was found living on the street with other pilgrims and later confined to a mental health facility. She was taken care by her son and daughter in law. Sometime later she had a stroke, slipped into coma and died a few days later at home. After her demise, her daughter Bhargavi (whom I had known) started the Bapu Trust in Pune focusing on developing community based programs facilitating the autonomy and independence of persons living with a mental health issues 
Rachel comments perceptively, “Mental illnesses are often seen as chronic and intractable forces that take over our lives, but I wonder how much the stories we tell about them, especially in the beginning, can shape their course. People can feel freed by these stories, but they can also get stuck in them.”
In the words of Paulo Coelho, “Sometimes, we need to be strangers to ourselves. Then the hidden light in our soul will illuminate what we need to see.” 
It is a deeply moving and insightful narrative of lived experiences of people with psychological distress and needs to be widely read by all mental health professionals.

12/08/24, 9:44 am - Dr Raguram: Elephants have the longest gestation period compared to any other animal. Usually a female gives birth to a single calf, occasionally two. Calves nurse for the first six months of life, drinking about 10 litters of milk per day. Elephant milk is high in fat and protein, hundred times more than cow's milk. Calves are weaned slowly and may continue to nurse until they reach puberty or the mother gives birth again. The young ones begin to experiment with their trunks around four to six months and start picking leaves and grasses to supplement their diet.  They follow their mothers' responses to learn who is a friend or relative, and who might be a threat. The bond between a mother elephant and her calf is special because it's very strong and nurturing. The mother elephant takes care of her calf with a lot of love and protection, ensuring its safety and teaching it essential skills for survival. 
Interestingly, Priyanka Sharma wrote an article, “Being an Elephant Mom in the time of the Tiger Mother.” She observed that compared to the ‘Tiger Mums’ who push their children to make choices, behave like adults and minimize relying on parents, an ‘Elephant Mom’ parenting style is flexible; it allows children to reach out for help providing comfort and warmth to the young. This parenting style is filled with encouragement and protection. While Tiger moms prepare their children for independence and the harsh realities of life from a young age, Elephant moms strive to support their children emotionally, and create a warm and loving environment for their kids to grow. They will nurture and protect their little ones through hard time, compared to a tiger mom style, which is a parenting style that is formed on the basis of tough love.
Watching a young calf gently ambling along the mother in the wild is a sight to behold!
(12th August is World Elephant Day)
Dr Raguram

13/08/24, 8:56 am - Dr Raguram: Otters are some of the most adorable aquatic animals. One can spend endless hours watching their energetic play as they wrestle, play and slide down the slippery rocks. ‘Tarka the Otter’, by Henry Williamson is a lovely novel about them. When the novel was published, otters were declining in numbers and by the 1960s it seemed possible that they would become extinct in England. Their recovery was much assisted by an increase in public awareness, facilitated in part by the popular success of Williamson’s novel. He describes the hunting behaviour of the otters like a trained naturalist, “Filling her lungs with new air, she slipped into the water and swam to the other end of the islet, where a scour had been formed by the flood-rains of the last south-westerly wind. Here the grown family of the moorhen was paddling. When almost under them, the otter saw the legs and the images of legs joined to them, black in silhouette against the less dark surface. She seized one of the moorhens and drew it under, releasing it to bite it in her jaws, and carried it back to her cubs, swimming with her nose, whiskers, eyes and part of the dead fowl out of the water.”
Williamson was quite productive with over fifty novels and essays. A keen observer of the landscape around him, his forte was writing about nature in its myriad expressions, “When the bees’ feet shake the bells of the heather, and the ruddy strings of the sap-stealing dodder are twined about the green spikes of the furze, it is summertime on the commons.”
Though there was a darker side in his life, Williamson is still considered by many as a pioneer in the genre of nature writing. Even a simple description of an icicle is imbued with lyricism, “Music comes from an icicle as it melts, to live again as spring water.”
(Henry Williamson 1 December 1895 - 13 August 1977)

14/08/24, 10:30 am - Dr Raguram: Nature offers some of the world's purest and simplest joys. Many writers have tried to distil that experience in words. Continuing my explorations into this genre, I discovered the writings of Richard Jefferies. He was highly regarded for his essays on nature and the English countryside. When I read his works I was amazed as to how effortlessly he succeeds in translating the inherent splendour of nature into exceptionally poetic prose. His oeuvre is an exquisite eulogy for the way forays into nature dissolves the boundary between ourselves and the world. He describes such experiences eloquently, “It is eternity now. I am in the midst of it. It is about me in the sunshine; I am in it as the butterfly in the light-laden air. Nothing has to come; it is now. Now is eternity; now is the immortal life.”
His words throb with exquisite energy, “As the wind, wandering over the sea, takes from each wave an invisible portion, and brings to those on shore the ethereal essence of ocean, so the air lingering among the woods and hedges—green waves and billows—became full of fine atoms of summer. Swept from notched hawthorn leaves, broad-topped oak-leaves, narrow ash sprays and oval willows; from vast elm cliffs and sharp-taloned brambles under; brushed from the waving grasses and stiffening corn, the dust of the sunshine was borne along and breathed. Steeped in flower and pollen to the music of bees and birds, the stream of the atmosphere became a living thing. It was life to breathe it, for the air itself was life.”
The beauty of nature lingers on in his writings…
(Richard Jefferies 6 November 1848 - 14 August 1887)

16/08/24, 10:27 am - Dr Raguram: Varalakshmi Puja is celebrated mostly in South India. Goddess Varalakshmi represents prosperity and divine grace. The name 'Varalakshmi' itself signifies her nature; 'Vara' meaning boon or blessing, and 'Lakshmi' referring to the goddess of wealth. This form of the goddess is particularly revered for her role in granting wishes and bringing prosperity. It is believed that worshipping the Goddess Varalakshmi on this day is equivalent to worshipping Ashtalakshmis; the eight goddesses of Wealth, Earth, Wisdom, Love, Fame, Peace, Contentment, and Strength.
There are iconographic variations in depiction of the Goddess. In this sculpture from Nuggehalli, Karnataka, she is found seated and has four arms. The four arms are symbolic of the four goals of humanity: dharma (pursuit of ethical, moral life), artha (pursuit of wealth, means of life), kama (pursuit of love, emotional fulfillment), and moksha (pursuit of self-knowledge, liberation). Her front right hand is held up in the abhaya mudra while her left hand is in the varada mudra giving boons to her devotees. 
Muthuswami Dishidhar composed a beautiful song ‘Sri Varalakshmi Nama Sthubhyam’ in praise of the Goddess. Most appropriately it is set in the raga Sri (one of the names of Lakshmi). It starts with the pallavi 
श्री वर लक्ष्मि नमस्तुभ्यं वसु प्रदे
श्री सारस पदे रस पदे सपदे पदे पदे
Interestingly the pallavi starting from sArasa is in form of Gopuccha Yati which begins with a set of syllables and gets one syllable smaller with each repetition. The syllables are arranged similar to a cow’s tail, which is broad at the beginning gradually tapering to the bottom. 
The pallavi translates as; 
I bow down to you, O eminent Goddess Lakshmi, the giver of boons!
O bestower of fortunes! O Sri with feet as soft as a lotus, you are the bestower of affection, be my companion at every step.

17/08/24, 9:24 am - Dr Raguram: During my earlier days at NIMHANS, I was shocked by an incident that happened not very far away from the campus. One evening when a woman was walking along the busy Double Road, she was forcefully taken away and raped. She was a married working woman who was walking home after the day’s work. I was troubled and wondered about the mind-set of the person who did the dastardly act. Wanting to understand more about rape, I went over to the Select Bookshop and asked Mr Murthy whether he could suggest a book that could offer me a broader perspective about this inhuman act. He rummaged through the crowded bookshelves and handed over a copy of Susan Brownmiller’s ‘Against Our Will’ which was published in 1975. 
It is not an easy read as it is filled with incidents and details of rape through0ut history. Susan Brownmiller outlines the history, politics, and sociology of rape and the and how it continues to profoundly affect women’s lives. What was profoundly insightful was reframing rape as an act of power, fundamental to the patriarchal domination of women. The chapter ‘Power: Institution and Authority’ best expresses the main thesis of the book that rape is the primeval and the ultimate act of subjugation. Surveys show that a vast majority of rapes are planned. This goes to disprove the theory that the rapist is usually ‘provoked’ by the flimsy clothing worn by the victim, and is overcome by an overpowering physical urge. In fact, the rapist is asserting his power and urge to dominate, “Man’s discovery that his genitalia could serve as a weapon to generate fear must rank as one of the most important discoveries in prehistoric times, along with the use of fire and the first crude stone axe. From prehistoric times to the present, rape has played a crucial function. It is nothing more or less than a conscious process of intimidation by which all men keep all women in a state of fear. ...That some men rape provides a sufficient threat to keep all women in a constant state of intimidation...”
She goes on to comment, “A world without rape would be a world in which women moved freely without fear of men. That some men rape provides a sufficient threat to keep all women in a constant state of intimidation, forever conscious of the knowledge that the biological tool must be held in awe for it may turn to weapon with sudden swiftness borne of harmful intent.”
In light of the recent event in Kolkata her observation is quite prescient, “All rape is an exercise in power, but some rapists have an edge that is more than physical. They operate within an institutionalized setting that works to their advantage and in which a victim has little chance to redress her grievance.”
Even though there have been some criticisms of her perspective on rape, I agree with her that “Oppression thrives on silence. In order to resist, we must break the silence and speak out against injustice.”

18/08/24, 8:02 am - Dr Raguram: Today is the birthday of Sampooran Singh Kalra, known popularly as Gulzar. 
One of the poetic forms that he experimented with was Triveni.  Composed of three lines, it is different from other three line verses like Haiku which are governed by a fixed syllable structure. As Gulzar commented, “I called it triveni because the first two lines meet like the Ganga and the Yamuna and complete a thought, it forms a poem on its own. But beneath the two there is the subterranean flow of another, the Saraswati. Hidden. Not visible to the eye. The triveni intends to reveal the Saraswati. The third line, lost in the first two, either changes the meaning of the poem altogether, its focus, or gives it a surprising twist, in the process creating an entirely new poem altogether.”
One of the best examples of his triveni is this one, in which he describes the flight of a bird as it leaves a branch.
उड़ के जाते हुए पंछी ने बस इतना ही देखा
देर तक हाथ हिलती रही वह शाख़ फ़िज़ा में

अलविदा कहने को ? या पास बुलाने के लिए ?
The bird in flight saw only this:
A branch waving its arm for long
To say goodbye? Or to call it back?
So many times I have seen a bird leaving a branch in a tree, like this one from the Bhoramdeo Wildlife Sanctuary in Chattisgarh, but only a gifted poet like Gulzar can embellish the experience in just three magical sentences.
In the garden of language, he's a singing bird. 
Dr Raguram

19/08/24, 9:57 am - Dr Raguram: Trees are the living energy of earth. With their roots deeply entrenched in the earth, they struggle with all the forces of nature to represent and express themselves. In the forest no two trees are alike. Each one has a distinctive presence. During an early morning walk amongst the wooded terrain of the Golden Gate Park, I saw this gnarled tree with a contorted trunk and twisted branches. It communicated something that a perfectly grown tree will never convey. 
As Tom Waits observed, “In the forest, there was a crooked tree and a straight tree. Every day, the straight tree would say to the crooked tree, "Look at me...I'm tall, and I'm straight, and I'm handsome. Look at you...you're all crooked and bent over. No one wants to look at you." And they grew up in that forest together. And then one day the loggers came, and they saw the crooked tree and the straight tree, and they said, "Just cut the straight trees and leave the rest." So the loggers turned all the straight trees into lumber and toothpicks and paper. And the crooked tree is still there, growing stronger and stranger every day.”
Photography is not about capturing the perfect but embracing the imperfect to see the world differently.
(Penned on the World Photography Day)

20/08/24, 7:37 am - Dr Raguram: Yesterday was the birthday of one of my favourite poets, Ogden Nash. He wrote a lot of poems about birds and as a birdwatcher, I find his take on the twitchers delightfully playful!
UP FROM THE EGG
“Bird watchers top my honors list.
I aimed to be one, but I missed.
Since I’m both myopic and astigmatic,
My aim turned out to be erratic,
And I, bespectacled and binocular,
Exposed myself to comment jocular.
We don’t need too much birdlore, do we,
To tell a flamingo from a towhee;
Yet I cannot, and never will,
Unless the silly birds stand still. 
And there’s no enlightenment in a tour
Of ornithological literature.
Is yon strange creature a common chickadee,
Or a migrant alouette from Picardy?
You can rush to consult your Nature guide
And inspect the gallery inside,
But a bird in the open never looks
Like its picture in the birdie books –
Or if it once did, it has changed its plumage,
And plunges you back into ignorant gloomage.
That is why I sit here growing old by inches,
Watching a clock instead of finches,
But I sometimes visualize in my gin
The Audubon that I audubin.”

22/08/24, 10:37 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
22/08/24, 10:37 am - Dr Raguram: Every time I visit the Bronze Gallery in the Chennai Museum I am totally entranced by the depictions of the dancing Siva in sculptural forms.  Each one of them is so alive, and yet so balanced, so powerful and yet so effortlessly graceful. One can spend hours just looking at their transcendental beauty. It is a difficult task to portray the infinite divine in finite forms. Sankaracharya articulated it perceptively, “O Lord, pardon my three sins: I have in contemplation clothed in form Thyself that hast no form; I have in praise described Thee who dost transcend all qualities; and in visiting shrines I have ignored Thine omnipresence.”
It is indeed an extremely challenging undertaking to portray and convey the manifestation of the Divine in tangible forms, especially the ‘Dance of Shiva’ in his avatar as Nataraja. The primal rhythmic energy of the dancing Shiva found its ultimate expression in the bronzes of the Chola period.  Shiva's dance is set within a flaming halo. The god holds in his upper right hand the damaru (hand drum that made the first sounds of creation). His upper left hand holds agni (the fire that will destroy the universe). With his lower right hand, he makes abhayamudra (the gesture that allays fear). The dwarflike figure being trampled by his right foot represents apasmara purusha (illusion, which leads mankind astray). Shiva's front left hand, pointing to his raised left foot, signifies refuge for the troubled soul. The energy of his dance makes his hair fly to the sides. 
There have been many interpretations of the Dance of Shiva. Ananda Coomaraswamy (who was born on 22nd August in 1877) wrote a brilliant essay detailing it, in the book ‘The Dance of Shiva’, which was published in 1918. He offers a detailed analysis of the five types of dance Shiva does, with extensive and fascinating quotes from mythical literature. Coomaraswamy sees the dance of Shiva as an interplay of Prakriti and Purusha, “The Essential Significance of Shiva’s Dance is threefold: First, it is the image of his Rhythmic Play as the Source of all Movement within the Cosmos, which is Represented by the Arch: Secondly, the Purpose of his Dance is to Release the Countless souls of men from the Snare of Illusion: Thirdly the Place of the Dance, Chidambaram, the Centre of the Universe, is within the Heart. He rises from His rapture, and dancing sends through inert matter pulsing waves of awakening sound, and lo! matter also dances appearing as a glory round about Him. Dancing, He sustains its manifold phenomena. In the fullness of time, still dancing, he destroys all forms and names by fire and gives new rest. By these means, our Father scatters the darkness of illusion (maya), burns the thread of causality (karma}, stamps down evil (mala, anava, avidyfi), showers Grace, and lovingly plunges the soul in the ocean of Bliss (ananda).”
Coomaraswamy concludes by saying, “The image of Shiva as Nataraja is indelibly stitched into the Indian imagination…Whatever the origins of Shiva's dance, it became in time the clearest image of the activity of God which any art or religion can boast of.”
As Thirumular describes in Thirumanthiram;
“The dancing foot, the sound of the tinkling bells, 
The songs that are sung and the varying steps, 
The form assumed by our Dancing Gurupara — 
Find out these within yourself, then shall your fetters fall away.” 
Dr Raguram

25/08/24, 9:11 am - Dr Raguram: Ahalya and myself went for a ‘Tree Walk’ organized by ATREE yesterday morning at Lalbagh. Lalbagh is home to a vast variety of trees from different parts of the world and it is fascinating to observe their details. There are about fifteen silk cotton trees spread around the garden and I am particularly drawn to a white silk cotton tree near the west gate. It is immensely huge, sprawling majestically across a vast space. The board near the tree informs that it is over two centuries old and it is not clear as to who would have planted it, though the folk lore suggests that it may be Tipu Sultan. To prevent the tree from falling during gusty storms, the tree has huge buttresses which extend for several feet around the trunk. These buttresses are akin to a mother rearing and supporting a child as it grows, develops and matures over the years. Whenever I look at them, I keep wondering about what kinds stories would be hidden within its withered, wrinkled, folds. 
As Herman Hesse wrote in ‘Wanderings; Notes & Sketches’, “Trees are sanctuaries. Whoever knows how to speak to them, whoever knows how to listen to them, can learn the truth. They do not preach learning and precepts, they preach, undeterred by particulars, the ancient law of life.”

26/08/24, 9:14 am - Dr Raguram: Krishna Janmashtami, celebrates the birth of Krishna. Stories of Krishna's childhood are illustrated in numerous paintings and sculptures. This small sculpture at Amrutheshwara temple at Amruthapura in Karnataka depicts an interesting episode during his childhood. 
The village that Krishna lived in, Gokula, was a land of cow herders. Hence, not surprisingly, there was an abundance of milk, curds, and butter in the village. Krishna was very fond of butter and would make use of every opportunity to steal butter from his mother or from any of the place in the village. Many of them started tying pots of butter to the ceiling so that Krishna or his friends couldn’t reach them. Undeterred by this, Krishna would team up with his friends to reach these pots by climbing on the shoulders of his friends.  People found out that Krishna was the prime culprit for these acts and complained to Yashoda. One day, Yashoda lost her patience and tied him up in a heavy grindstone in the courtyard and went inside to attend to her domestic chores. Left alone, Krishna happily and effortlessly dragged the grindstone and passed through the gap between two Arjuna trees. But the grindstone got stuck in between and when Krishna pulled the mortar with all his strength the roots of the two trees get uprooted and they fell to the ground with a loud crash. The twin trees were, in fact, the two sons of Kubera, the god of wealth, Nalakubara and Manigriva. They were cursed by the sage Narada to be born as two Arjuna trees in Gokula. When Krishna pulled down the two trees they got liberated from the curse. 
Since Yashoda tied him to the mortar with a rope, Krishna is also called as Damodara (dam + udara = rope + stomach). Sri Damodarastakam is a poem written by Sri Satyavrata Muni that describes his love for Sri Damodara. The poem is made up of eight verses and is found in the Padma Purana by Krishna Dwaipayana Vyasa. In the poem, Satyavrata Muni prays to Sri Damodara to appear to him in his eternal form as a young cowherd-boy and bestow his blessings. The 7th verse states:
कुबेरात्मजौ बद्ध-मूर्त्यैव यद्वत्
त्वया मोचितौ भक्ति-भाजौ कृतौ च
तथा प्रेम-भक्तिं स्वकां मे प्रयच्छ
न मोक्षे ग्रहो मेऽस्ति दामोदरेह ॥ ७॥
O Lord Damodara, in Your form as a baby, Mother Yasoda bound You to a grinding stone with a rope. You then freed the sons of Kuvera, Manigriva and Nalakuvara, who were cursed to stand as trees and You gave them the chance to become Your devotees. Please bless me in this same way. I only long for this and have no desire for any kind of liberation.  
Dr Raguram
27/08/24, 10:27 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
27/08/24, 10:27 am - Dr Raguram: Many of us might have grown up savouring every page of Chandamama comics with enchanting tales of mythology, folklore, and adventure. I was recollecting today about one particular story of Krishna and the sparrow.
Kurukshetra was being prepared for the big battle with elephants being used to uproot the trees and clear the space. When one such tree was uprooted, it disturbed a family of sparrows and all of them fell down along with their nest which ensured that they were unharmed. The mother sparrow looked around for some help as she feared that the young ones would be crushed in the ensuing battle. She noticed Krishna and pleaded that he save them all. Krishna responded saying that the law of nature would take its own course, he could not interfere with it and advised that she stock food for the next three weeks. The mother sparrow responded that she trusted Krishna and that the fate of her family rests in his hands and flew away.
When the battle commenced, Krishna asked Arjuna for his bow and arrow and took aim at an elephant. The arrow hit the massive bell around its neck which then fell down. When Krishna told Arjuna that the elephant was the one which brought down the sparrow’s nest, Arjuna wondered why Krishna did not kill it. 
The Pandavas won the ensuing war in which numerous lives were lost. Krishna asked Arjuna to steer the chariot through the battleground which was littered with scores of bodies. He stopped at one place and asked Arjuna to lift an elephant bell which lay on the ground. Arjuna was puzzled as to why Krishna asked him to lift the bell when so many other things needed clearing. When he got down and lifted the bell all the young sparrows flew out with their mother. A single bell brought down by Krishna had saved the lives of the family of sparrows.  
When I read it as a child, I was struck by the fact that Krishna found time amidst the great battle, to save a group of helpless sparrows. Its significance expands when I reflect on it now. We are much like the sparrows caught in the battlefield of life, over which we have little control. It is faith in ourselves and trust in a greater force that often helps us to navigate through the tribulations of life. It is the choices we make which define and guide us.

28/08/24, 7:51 am - Dr Raguram: You cannot miss the Dark Eyed Junco. They have a charm all of their own, with their black hood and unusual metallic chipping song, For the most part, they seem quite content to forage on the ground, kicking up the leaves to garner whatever morsels are hidden below. The flash of their characteristic white outer tail feather is unmistakable when they take to flight. They are quite handsome looking with their black heads and white plumage, like the old saying “dark skies above, snow below.” In some parts of North America, they are strongly associated with winter and are often referred to as snowbirds. 
Junco attracted the attention of poets like William Stafford (17 January 1914 - 28 August 1993). Stafford’s poems are characterized by simple language, unadorned imagery and a conversational tone. He was deeply attached to nature, as he mentioned in one of his works.
“I like to live in the sound of water,
in the feel of mountain air. A sharp
reminder hits me: this world still is alive;
it stretches out there shivering toward its own
creation, and I’m part of it.”
He wrote a small, beautiful poem about the Junco:
“They operate from elsewhere,
some hall in the mountains –
quick visit, gone.
Specialists on branch ends,
craft union. I like their
clean little coveralls.”
Canadian singer Anne Murray wrote a song about it, which won the 1971 Juno Award (the Canadian music award) for Best Produced Single. The song ends with these lines:
“Spread your tiny wings and fly away
And take the snow back with you
Where it came from on that day
The one I love forever is untrue
And if I could you know
that I would fly away with you
yah if I could, you know that I would fly away with you.”
There is always an unmeasurable joy in watching birds and reading what the poets say about them!

29/08/24, 8:19 am - Dr Raguram: Eyes, often referred to as the windows to the soul, have captivated artists throughout history. Eyes convey a wide range of emotions powerfully. In any work of art, especially paintings, eyes nudge us to connect with the subjects at an intimate level. In the hands of a skilled artist, eyes capture and convey the individual personality of the subject, with much ease. The gaze of a subject in an artwork can be quite captivating. One such painting which illustrates this is the ‘Laughing Cavalier’, painted by Franz Hal. I haven’t seen this painting in any gallery (so far!). But whenever I see it in the net, I keep wondering whether he is actually laughing or is it a smirk? Is that a mischievous smile we are seeing? His eyes seem to follow us from whichever direction we view the painting. It appears as if he is observing us intently. His gaze engages us in mysterious ways! 
Every time I look at this painting, I am reminded of Ralph Waldo Emerson’s observation that eyes "speak all languages."  
(Franz Hal 1581 - 29th August 1666)

30/08/24, 7:06 am - Dr Raguram: An author whom I admire deeply is Oliver Sacks, who eloquently explored the interface between mind and brain in his works. I am captivated by Dr Sacks’ beautiful stories and his loving portrayals of his patients. Referred to as the ‘poet laureate of modern medicine’, he died from ocular cancer on August 30, 2015, at the age of 82. We lead a finite existence and letting go can often be hard. It is an arduous task to negotiate the irreversible trajectory of impending death. 
An anonymous scholar writing in the 15th century wrote a poignant tract on how to prepare oneself for a good death, entitled Ars Moriendi (Latin for ‘the art of dying’). The work instructs as to how one can prepare for their final hours on this earth. It emphasizes the importance of allowing a dying person to experience the emotions they feel without pathologizing those emotions. The possibility of being overwhelmed with existential despair is lessened by allowing a dying person to grieve in their own way, allowing them to focus on the things and people that matter to them most. As the text suggests, most importantly, death is about coming to terms with our transcendental nature. 
After learning of his terminal diagnosis, Sacks reflected on these aspects with remarkable candour which was condensed into a book, ‘Gratitude’. He wrote: 
“Over the last few days, I have been able to see my life as from a great altitude, as a sort of landscape, and with a deepening sense of the connection of all its parts. This does not mean I am finished with life. On the contrary, I feel intensely alive, and I want and hope in the time that remains to deepen my friendships, to say farewell to those I love, to write more, to travel if I have the strength, to achieve new levels of understanding and insight. This will involve audacity, clarity and plain speaking; trying to straighten my accounts with the world. But there will be time, too, for some fun (and even some silliness, as well). ..And now, weak, short of breath, my once-firm muscles melted away by cancer . . . I find my thoughts drifting to the Sabbath, the day of rest, the seventh day of the week, and perhaps the seventh day of one’s life as well, when one can feel that one’s work is done, and one may, in good conscience, rest.”
In these writings, Oliver Sacks reminds us that we are visitors here, passing through the great mystery of life. Every moment of life including the final ones is a gift and one can face death with poise and equanimity.  
In his interesting book, ‘Musicophilia’, Oliver Sacks wrote, “It really is a very odd business that all of us, to varying degrees, have music in our heads.” That music never dies…

31/08/24, 7:22 am - Dr Raguram: It has been cloudy on most evenings in Bangalore, with an occasional rain drenching the parched earth. Clouds appearing in a vast array of shapes have been fascinating to watch. Slowly the fluffy white clouds give way to dark clouds, foreboding the arrival of rain. Poets and writers feel inspired to use them as metaphors of human emotions ranging from the joyous to the melancholic. Poems about clouds capture their ethereal beauty, ever-changing nature, and their symbolic significance. Shelley’s joyful poem, ‘The Cloud’, starts with the beautiful line, “I bring fresh showers for the thirsting flowers”.  Wordsworth conveyed a sense of loneliness describing clouds floating over fluttering daffodils in his poem, “I wandered lonely as a cloud.” In Rabindranath Tagore’s words, “Clouds come floating into my life, no longer to carry rain or usher storm, but to add color to my sunset sky.” Mark Strand evocatively described clouds as being “drawn by invisible birds’ and “If a parrot is lost in a cloud, it turns into a rainbow.”
Clouds are moving poetry. As Thich Nhat Hanh commented. “If you are a poet, you will see clearly that there is a cloud floating in this sheet of paper.” 
They teased my imagination too! 
Rainclouds
Caress gently
The boundless sky.

01/09/24, 11:41 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
01/09/24, 11:41 am - Dr Raguram: Gibbons may be the most endangered groups of primates on Earth. Hoolock Gibbon is the only ape species in India. Ahalya and myself were keen to have a glimpse of this rare species and we headed to The Hollongapar Gibbon Sanctuary, a habitat of the endangered Western hoolock gibbon in Assam. After finishing the formalities in the office at the entrance of the sanctuary, we made our way, accompanied by a forest guard. The only way to explore the forest is by walk. The sun was playing hide and seek through the thick trees covered with lush green foliage. As we were walking, we heard an unusual loud call. The guard whispered that it is the call of the gibbon. We walked further for an hour, but couldn’t spot any. Suddenly the guard noticed some activity in the higher reaches of the trees. We stood there for a while, keenly looking for its presence. Slowly a huge, glossy, black figure emerged, hanging from a branch in the tree with its long arm. It swung from one branch to another, adeptly, with sinuous movements. Soon several others joined and they were darting from one tree to another like skilled acrobats. It was so wonderful to watch their graceful movements. With their short torso, long legs, they almost looked like us!
The gibbons are arboreal animals, preferring to stay in the higher reaches of tall Hollong trees. They barely come down to the forest floor. As they are canopy dwellers, it is difficult to have a good look at them. One has to keep craning the neck all the time to spot them. It is also difficult to photograph them amidst the dark green cover. With some effort and lots of luck, I was able to freeze the experience through the lens!
Life is a collection of moments and our tryst with the Hoolock Gibbon was one of the most memorable experience in our sojourns into the wild. As Oscar Wilde commented, “memories are the diary we all carry with us” and our visit to the Hoollongapar Sanctuary will remain as a cherished entry in it. 
(It is so apt to pen these reminiscences on the International Primate Day, especially when the theme this year is “Connecting with Wild Primates.”

02/09/24, 10:41 am - Dr Raguram: We are living in a period in time when differences that separate and divide us have become more salient than commonalities that can bind us together. How should we steer ourselves amidst this unsettling terrain and find some meaning in life? Viktor Frankl (whose death anniversary is today) faced such a dilemma when he was imprisoned in several concentration camps and wrote an inspiring tome, ‘Man’s Search for Meaning’. This book has had an enduring impact in me. Every time I pick up the book I feel inspired by these words, “When we are no longer able to change a situation, we are challenged to change ourselves…we needed to stop asking about the meaning of life, and instead to think of ourselves as those who were being questioned by life—daily and hourly. Our answer must consist, not in talk and meditation, but in right action and in right conduct. Life ultimately means taking the responsibility to find the right answer to its problems and to fulfill the tasks which it constantly sets for each individual.” His advice is quite akin to that of Nietzsche, "He who has a why to live for can bear almost any how”
Frankl was witness to the most horrible suffering that man can inflict on others. In the midst of it all, he noticed that prisoners who had a sense of purpose were more resilient. This informed him that that a resilient, purposeful, proactive attitude is the most important value in life, “Everything can be taken from a man but one thing: the last of the human freedoms — to choose one’s attitude in any given set of circumstances, to choose one’s own way.”

04/09/24, 8:28 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
04/09/24, 8:28 am - Dr Raguram: Auroville came into existence when I was doing medicine at JIPMER. I used to cycle there on most weekends to have a look at the emerging settlement which was dotted with very imaginative structures. During one such visit I walked into the ‘Last School’. It was a very unusual, creative building, with no resemblance to any school structure I was familiar with. There was a small stream flowing inside and children were making paper boats and floating them in the water. There was a person who was telling them about boats and how they are carried further in waterways. I was attracted to its imaginative and inventive concept. I came to know that Mother called it the ‘Last School’, to emphasize that once the community took shape, learning would continue outside of formal schools. 
 A couple of years later, I was introduced to the work of Ivan Illich by Prof Moris Carstairs who was a visiting professor at NIMHANS. I reviewed Illich’s ‘Limits to Medicine’, which was chaired by him (I wrote about it two years ago). He urged me to read Illich’s other book, ‘Deschooling Society’. In this most unusual book, he articulated ideas which mapped onto the vision of the Mother. Deschooling is not about abolishing education altogether, but rather about reimagining and restructuring the way we learn. It emphasized the importance of self-directed learning, individual autonomy, and community-based education. To quote Illich, “What is a child, what is a teacher, what is education? Why, in particular, do we tend to think of learning primarily in the context of the school – a particular kind of institution, with a very specific form and organisational structure? What, indeed, are schools actually for? Most learning is not the result of instruction. It is rather the result of unhampered participation in a meaningful setting. Teaching, it is true, may contribute to certain kinds of learning under certain circumstances. But most people acquire most of their knowledge outside school.”
Illich offered a passionate critique of  a formalized, institutionalized educational system and its limitations. It may not be an easy exercise to reshape schools as places of informal, guided, learning habitats focussed on individual skill building. There have been many innovative attempts to create such spaces. The dilemma has always been what happens after such schooling? How do the children from these learning spaces negotiate their lives in the demanding job market outside which is not attuned to such orientations? Many don’t want to be just “another brick in the wall’ and some perhaps find new imaginative paths to explore in their lives.
Unfortunately education has become an industry and there is an urgent need to think creatively about the role and purpose of schools. Illich’s book may be a catalyst in that direction.
As Margaret Mead commented, “Children must be taught how to think, not what to think.”
(Ivan Illich 4th September 1926 - 2 December 2002)

05/09/24, 7:31 am - Dr Raguram: Teacher’s Day is about paying tribute with an abiding sense of gratitude to teachers who have shaped our journey in learning.
Our formal education starts within the premises of a school. I was fortunate to be a student in the Ramakrishna Mission School, North Branch, Chennai. Among all the teachers who taught us, the one who left a deep impact on me was Sri TS Ranganathan Sir, referred to TSR. He had a commanding presence and when he entered the classroom we were over awed with his demeanor. He was a science teacher but he could also teach us about English literature, geography and human anatomy with ease and élan. He was a polymath. He shared with us anecdotes from forgotten pages of history and opened our minds to explore unknown landscapes of learning. I was learning tennis and one day he called to ask me whether I would like to join him on the tennis court. The school had a tennis court not far away from his home. When I reached the place, I found him dressed in his usual attire, an immaculate panchakacham. Panchakacham is not a regular dhoti and has five pleats delicately tucked in, much akin to a nine yards’ saree worn by women in traditional attire. It took me a while to register that he was going to play tennis in this rather complicated outfit. My reservations were put to rest however when he started to serve. It was a booming service that would be the envy of any seasoned tennis player. I struggled to return it. He didn’t make it easy but egged me on to respond to it. At the end of an hour I was sweating profusely! He patted me and said, “Good start!”. Sometimes he would ask me to tabulate the results of the exam papers in his home and on completion of the task, I would be enthralled listening to him playing the harmonium. 
TSR lit the fire to awaken the joy of learning which was not just confined to the classroom. Borrowing a saying from Robert Frost, he was “not a teacher, but an awakener.”

06/09/24, 8:10 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
06/09/24, 8:10 am - Dr Raguram: Mahakuta, an important centre of Chalukya art and architecture is nestled amidst a grove of kadamba trees in a peaceful village, not very far away from Badami. Within the temple complex there are a number of temples, situated around an ancient water tank. Unfortunately, most of the sculptures in the temples have eroded with time. When I walked over to the small Sangameshwara temple, I found a few delicately carved sculptures on its outer wall. The most striking one among them was that of Bhu Varaha. There are three common depictions of Varaha: Bhu Varaha is usually represented standing while that of Pralaya Varaha and Yajna Varaha are in sitting forms. In this stunning sculpture, Bhu Varaha is shown with the head of a boar and the body of a man with four hands. Two hands are holding the shankha and chakra. He is lifting the goddess of earth, Bhudevi, who is safely ensconced in his folded elbow of his left upper hand. The right lower hand rests on his leg. At the bottom are the naga and nagini, with hands folded in devotion. The ornamentation, though delicate, is quite sparse. The graceful, kinetic energy in this depiction has a lasting allure. 
There are several versions of the Varaha legend right from the Shatapatha Brahmana. The most commonly associated legend is that of Varaha lifting the earth, personified as the goddess Bhudevi, out of the cosmic ocean. When the demon Hiranyaksha stole the earth and hid her in the primordial waters, Lord Vishnu appeared as Varaha to rescue her. Varaha slew the demon and retrieved the Earth from the ocean and restored Bhudevi to her place in the universe.
What is interesting is how geological events and processes become part of thos narration. Varaha as an avatar of God Vishnu saved the Earth by lifting it out of the cosmic ocean and restoring it back.   While the legend symbolizes the triumph of good over evil it also emphasizes the need to protect and restore the environment, especially on the background of increasing climate change now. With 70 percent of the planet being covered in water, the oceans are important drivers of the global climate. Increasing greenhouse gases from human activities are altering the oceans before our eyes. Greenhouse gases trap energy from the sun, which the oceans absorb, causing them to warm. As the excessive heat and energy warms the ocean, the change in temperature leads to unparalleled cascading effects, including rise in sea levels. 
Today as our earth faces serious threats from climate change, we should draw inspiration from the legend of Varaha to be proactive in saving the planet. 
(Penned on the occasion of Varaha Jayanthi, which is observed on 6th September 2024)

07/09/24, 7:56 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
07/09/24, 7:56 am - Dr Raguram: Nritya Ganapati is the 15th among the 32 forms of Ganesha. This exquisitely carved sculpture of Nritya Ganapati (Dancing Ganesha) is from Chennakeshava temple at Somanathapura. A significant aspect of Nritya Ganapati’s imagery is the setting of his dance, beneath the Kalpavriksha, or the wish-fulfilling tree. This choice of location is not arbitrary. The Kalpavriksha in Hindu mythology is known to grant all wishes. Nritya Ganapati’s dance under this tree thus becomes a metaphor for the joyous and bountiful nature of the cosmos. He is depicted with four hands. His left foot is firmly placed on the ground whereas the right one is lifted up and bent sideways at the knee. He is bejewelled and intricate ornaments decorate various parts of his body. Despite his bulky disposition, there is a lightness in his stance.
Oothukadu Venkata Subba Iyer, popularly known as Venkata Kavi, was a brilliant composer of the 18th Century who made immense contributions to the Carnatic Music repertoire. One of his memorable composition is on Nritya Ganapati, titled ‘Anandha Narthana Ganapathim’ in the raga Naatai, which begins with these lines:
आनन्द नर्तन गणपतिं भावये – (परम् / सदा )
चिदाकार मूलाधार ॐ कार गजवदनं परमम् परम् (आनन्द)
Ananda nartana gaNapatim bhAvayE
chidAkAra mUlAdhAra OmkAra gajavadanam paramam param (Ananda)
I meditate on the joyous dancing Ganapati always
Whose form is pure consciousness, who lives in the muladhara chakra and who is the form of Om, the elephant faced one, the supreme one.
Though we recognize Ganesha in various forms, in Adi Shankara’s words, he is formless Supreme Brahman. 'Ajam Nirvikalpam Niraakaaramekam,' Ganesha is Ajam (unborn), Nirvikalpa (attributeless), Niraakaar (formless) and he symbolizes Brahman, the absolute consciousness.

09/09/24, 10:33 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
09/09/24, 10:33 am - Dr Raguram: Literacy is more than just reading and writing. At its simplest, it is a tool for meaningful engagement with society. It shapes and enhances our experience of the world.  
Kerala had 49.5% literacy rate before independence. This has scaled up in the ensuing years and now Kerala has the highest literacy rate among the states of India. Kerala's literacy success can be attributed to a number of factors, including its history, social reform, and the Kerala Education Act of 1958. As of March 2023, the literacy rate in Kerala was 94%. In spite of this remarkable achievement there are pockets where literacy hasn’t made inroads as anticipated. For instance, in Wayanad which has 36 per cent of the state's tribal population, the literacy rate amongst tribals is lower than the district's average literacy rate and the literacy rate of the general population. 
It is on this background that we got involved with the education of tribal children in the region. Wayanad Girijana Seva Trust was initiated by two youngsters who have been committed to this cause and we started working with them. The need was for a secure, hospitable environment where these children could stay and learn. Hence, in the initial phases the focus was on infrastructure, furnished class rooms, hostel, kitchen etc. With the help of volunteers and committed teachers, the educational input has also scaled up over the years. A few years back we added a learning resource centre, fully equipped with laptops to advance their learning.
What I have noticed in the past two decades, is the cascading impact of formal education among the children. Children, especially the girls, have become more assured, confident while keeping alive their tribal identity. Literacy has expanded their ambit of learning and capabilities. 
It has been a journey of learning for us too and there are continuing challenges in maintaining and sustaining the process. We have built bridges of learning for these marginalized children with the fond hope that it kindles the spirit of enquiry to discover and realize the potentials within.
And the spirit flows on…
(8th September was the International Literacy Day)

11/09/24, 10:19 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
11/09/24, 10:19 am - Dr Raguram: Mahadevi Varma was one of the four pillars of Chhayavaad, the neo-romantic movement of Hindi literature. She wrote a series of eleven radical essays titled Shrinkhala Ki Kadiyan (Links In My Chain) which is often compared to Beauvoir’s seminal text, ‘The Second Sex’. Married off at an early age, she chose to lead an ascetic life, later on in her life. She was deeply influenced by Buddhism and even wanted to become a monk. There is an interesting anecdote about a particular meeting with her Buddhist guru, when she noticed that he was hiding his face from her with a palm leaf. Shocked by this, she walked out and later said that someone who could not trust himself with a woman had nothing to teach her. 
Mahadevi Varma took an active part in the freedom movement and also wrote eloquently about women’s issues and social reform. A strong believer in gender equality, she was among the first Indian poets to delve into the subject of women rights and their place in society. She powerfully emphasized in her writings, that women deserved every opportunity to flourish in a world that had suppressed their freedom and potential. 
In an essay, ‘अतीत के चलचित्र’ she wrote;
“युगों से पुरुष स्त्री को उसकी शक्ति के लिए नहीं, सहनशक्ति के लिए ही दण्ड देता आ रहा है।”
“For ages, men have been punishing women not for their strength but for their endurance.”
Her works are a living testament to the power of the written word to drive social change.
Dr Raguram

12/09/24, 8:43 am - Dr Raguram: Mahakavi Bharathiyar was a champion of women’s rights, much like Mahadevi Varma, about whom I had posted yesterday. நிமிர்ந்த நன்னடை நேர்கொண்ட பார்வையும், 
நிலத்தில் யார்க்கும் அஞ்சாத நெறிகளும், 
திமிர்ந்த ஞானச் செருக்கும் இருப்பதால் 
செம்மை மாதர் திறம்புவ தில்லையாம்;
Her head held high, she walks while looking everyone in the eye
She is a fearless possessor of integrity
She is a proud possessor of wisdom born out of conviction
The resolute woman does not falter or feel inferior
Bharathiyar was a strong advocate of gender parity:
ஆணும் பெண்ணும் நிகரெனக் கொள்வதால்
அறிவி லோங்கி இவ் வையம் தழைக்குமாம்
Recognizing men and women as equals 
Will result in empowered knowledge and sustain the world 
These powerful words are still deeply relevant today and will continue to inspire people to strive for a society that is free from fear, oppression, and discrimination on the basis of gender.

13/09/24, 10:26 am - Dr Raguram: Both Ahalya and myself are in the midst of looking closely at our collection of books and deciding which ones to hold onto and which ones to give away. In the process we discover that it is not as easy as it appears. When I pick up a book, weathered with ages, a flood of memories ensues. It is not merely a physical process of giving away the books, but also letting of the memories associated with them. Like the books, emotionally too we cling to myriad stories in our lives, often encompassing resentments, anger and a range of other negative feelings. Letting go is loosening those knots, freeing our energies to flow in the sea of life. It creates newer spaces for fresh beginnings. We have to open the cages of our mind and free the birds that are not meant to be caged. 
As Herman Hesse remarked, “Some of us think holding on makes us strong, but sometimes it is letting go.”

14/09/24, 9:18 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
14/09/24, 9:18 am - Dr Raguram: One of the temples not often visited in Khajuraho is the Vamana temple. Set amidst a verdant, green landscape, it is a sight to behold with its spire reaching up like a beautiful mountain. Like rest of the temples in Khajuraho, the outer walls of the sanctum are adorned with intricate carvings depicting scenes from Hindu mythology. In the sanctum is a striking idol of Vamana, the fifth incarnation of Lord Vishnu. Vamana is the first incarnation whem Lord Vishnu appeared in a full human form, as a dwarf.
The legend of the Vamana avatar is narrated in the Rigveda and other scriptures. Mahabali, son of Virochan and grandson of Prahlad, was a generous, mighty monarch who was adored by his subjects.  He was granted the boon of immortality by Lord Brahma and he continued to expand the frontiers of his empire. He conquered all the three realms: Heaven, Earth and the Underworld. Immensely troubled by growing powers, the Devas appealed to Lord Vishnu to intervene and restore the balance of power. Responding to their prayers, Lord Vishnu incarnated as Vamana, the dwarf and went to the Yaga that was being performed by Mahabali. During the Yaga, people could ask Mahabali for and receive anything they wanted. Mahabali bade Vamana to ask for anything that he wanted, like jewels, land, forests etc, without hesitation. Vamana denied all these politely and asked merely for three paces of land. Looking at Vamana’s diminutive stature, Bali said, ‘So be it; pace and take it.’ The dwarf Vamana suddenly grew in size into a giant and with one step measured the Earth and with another the entire Heaven. As there was no room left for the third step that had been granted, Mahabali humbly knelt under Vamana’s foot and offered his head. As Bali sank deep into the underworld, he heard his subjects wailing in grief for their much loved king. Seeing this, Vamana granted Mahabali one last boon. The boon was the permission to visit his subjects on Earth once a year. Thus, Mahabali returns every year to visit his people and the land that he had once ruled. Onam commemorates the annual visit of this legendary king from the underworld to his former kingdom, the land of Kerala. 
Parsva Ekadashi which is observed today is also associated with the legend of Mahabali and Vamana Avatar of Lord Vishnu and is also referred to as Vamana Ekadashi. It is fascinating to note that the Onam festival follows the same legend and takes place around the same time of year.

18/09/24, 7:54 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
18/09/24, 7:54 am - Dr Raguram: William Carlos Williams was a full-time practicing physicians who was also a prolific writer across many literary genres. He regarded art and medicine as “two parts of a whole.” Williams rejected traditional conventions of rhyme and meter, masterfully blending colloquial idioms which lent a conversational tone to his poems. Often referred to as the “Master of the glimpse,” Williams painted verbal pictures with crisp, vivid word images in poems like, “The Red Wheelbarrow.” The subject of Williams’s poetry is quite varied; crowds attending baseball games, trains pulling into station, wheelbarrows, fire trucks, and a host of everyday subjects. He drew inspiration from grounded images from any source, in unexpected places.
Even though he was incapacitated by a stroke, he continued to type with his non dominant hand and completed his and Pulitzer Prize-winning “Pictures from Brueghel.”  Additional small strokes resulted in more deficits, but he kept on writing. 
I particularly like his poem “The Fool’s Song”
I tried to put a bird in a cage.
                O fool that I am!
         For the bird was Truth.
Sing merrily, Truth: I tried to put
                 Truth in a cage!
And when I had the bird in the cage,
                 O fool that I am!
          Why, it broke my pretty cage.
Sing merrily, Truth: I tried to put
                  Truth in a cage!
And when the bird was flown from the cage,
                  O fool that I am!
            Why, I had nor bird nor cage.
Sing merrily, Truth: I tried to put
                   Truth in a cage!
             Heigh-ho! Truth in a cage.
Much like the bird in the poem, each of us tussle with some deep secret or truth which we want to hide from others. But truth is hard to reveal and often cannot be hidden. As Leo Tolstoy observed, “Very often, all the activity of the human mind is directed not in revealing the truth, but in hiding the truth.”

21/09/24, 9:53 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
21/09/24, 9:53 am - Dr Raguram: As a birder, I am appalled at the sight of birds being confined to cages. Nature had assigned them the open sky and they do not deserve to be in such confined, claustrophobic spaces. When captured and put into cages, these birds become depressed and withdrawn. Their frustration at being restrained often leads to a form of self-mutilation called ‘feather-plucking’. As an Italian proverb states, “The bird in its cage sings not for joy but in rage.” Sometimes we struggle like a caged bird battling enforced isolation in our lives. 
Stevie Smith, a talented, but largely unknown poet, gave expression to these experiences in her poems, like this one titled, ‘The Parrot’. 
“The old sick green parrot
High in a dingy cage
Sick with malevolent rage
Beadily glutted his furious eye
On the old dark
Chimneys of Noel Park
Far from his jungle green
Over the seas he came
To the yellow skies, to the dripping rain,
To the night of his despair
And the pavement of his street
Are shining beneath the lamp
With a beauty that's not for one
Born under a tropic sun
He has croup. His feathered chest
Know no minute of rest
High on his perch he sits
And coughs and spits,
Waiting for death to come.
Pray heaven it won't be long.”
The parrot's helpless rage parallels the poet’s existential angst as she continuously feels caged in her personal life. Stevie Smith lived a largely secluded and celibate life and it was an unceasing saga of illness, abandonment and confinement. Beset with depression, she was preoccupied with the thought of death. The caged parrot is a metaphor for her life constrained by despair and depression, conveying the feeling of death as a release. 
There is always the perennial question whether creativity occurs in spite of illness or because of it. Karl Jaspers in his ‘General Psychopathology’, commented, “Was the morbid event only destructive or was it an ally in positive creation? Many more examples could be quoted and they cannot be subject to a single, common and exhaustive interpretation. But it is certain that some hidden correlation often stood in the background between the fact of illness and the profoundest of human possibilities, between human folly and wisdom."
I also wonder whether in battling her sadness Stevie Smith also draws attention to our confined, isolated urban existence in these times…

22/09/24, 9:22 am - Dr Raguram: Like William Carlos William, Dannie Abse (22 September 1923 - 28 September 2014), was a physician poet. Unlike the former, who largely kept medicine out of his poetry, Abse wanted to “hear the heartbeat of words” and wrote about patients and the diseases they had, with tenderness. Even a stethoscope is infused with poetic insights, transmitting sounds “over young women’s tense abdomens . . . of creation and in a dead man’s chest, the silence before creation began.”
His poem, ‘Portrait of an Old Doctor” begins with these beautiful, reflective lines:
“Lover of music more than his textbooks’
arrythmic prose and dated, almost dangerous
his Conybeare and his Boyd’s Pathology.
(Notes in the margin by the student he was)
What was it all about? Blunderbuss drugs
prescribed to ease the patient. And moonbeams.
A composer—a Beethoven, a Smetana—it seemed, could be deaf, but not a doctor.
He had been a conﬁdence man for the patient.
That’s how it was in the Theatre of Disease
and, at the ﬁnal act, he had lifted
his stethoscope to listen
as if to Mozart.
Then, silently, relatives and friends ﬁled out.
No applause. None for Hippocrates’ art.”
Let me end this post with this poignant poem of Abse
‘Moonbright’
Afterwards, late, walking home from hospital,
that December hour too blatantly moonbright
 - such an unworldly moon so widely round,
an orifice of scintillating arctic light -
I thought how the effrontery of a similar moon,
a Pirandello moon that would make men howl,
would, in future, bring back the eidolon
of you, father, propped high on pillow
your mouth ajar, your nerveless hand in mine.
At home, feeling hollow, I shamelessly wept
- whether for you or myself I do not know.
Tonight a bracing wind makes my eyes cry
while a cloud dociles an impudent moon
that is and was, and is again, and was.
Men become mortal the night their fathers die.”
Lastly, at this stage in my life, these lines from his poem ‘Talking to Myself’ “In the mildew of age/all pavements slope uphill’ touch a deep chord within…
