23/09/24, 9:14 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
23/09/24, 9:14 am - Dr Raguram: On September 21, Max Schur, Freud’s personal physician visited him and was aghast to see him looking pale and quite wasted.  Freud took his doctor’s hand and said, “My dear Schur, you certainly remember our first talk. You promised me then not to forsake me when the time comes. Now it is nothing but torture and makes no sense anymore.” Schur responded stating that he had not forgotten the promise he made. Freud thanked him and told Schur to “talk it over with Anna, and if she thinks it’s right, make an end of it.” Schur spoke to Anna and she sorrowfully concurred with her father’s wish. Then Schur gave Freud an injection of three centigrams of morphine, a dose much stronger than he would have used if the objective had only been to relieve pain. He was now assisting him to die a peaceful death. He gave Freud another injection that day, then a third on September 22. Freud lapsed into a coma, but he held on to life. At 3AM in the morning on Saturday, September 23, 1939, Sigmund Freud breathed his last. Three days later, his body was cremated and his ashes placed in an ancient Greek urn, originally gifted to him by his friend Marie Bonaparte.
Many years before, Freud had made it abundantly clear as to how he wanted to die as he never wanted to live without his mental capacities intact. He wrote to his friend Oskar Pfister, “With all the resignation before destiny that suits an honest man, I have one wholly secret entreaty: only no invalidism, no paralysis of one’s powers through bodily misery. Let us die in harness, as King Macbeth says.”
Freud left the world with a certain degree of composure. In Nietzsche’s words, “The most fortunate author is one who is able to say as an old man that all he had of life giving, invigorating, uplifting enlightening thoughts and feelings still lives on in his writings, and that he himself is only the gray ash, while the fire has been rescued and carried forth everywhere.”
The last book Freud read was Balzac’s La Peau de Chagrin (The Wild Ass’s Skin). The protagonist, Rapheal de Valentin, gains possession of a wild donkey’s skin and is granted all he wishes. The magical object has the power to fulfil its owner's every wish but carries a heavy price: With every wish the owner's remaining time in life is reduced. On finishing the book, Freud told Schur, “This was the proper book for me to read.”
Mark Edmundson has written a very perceptive book on Freud’s last days, ‘The Death Of Sigmund Freud.’ The book ends with these words “Toward the person who has died we adopt a special attitude: something like admiration for someone who has accomplished a very difficult task.”
In the words of Sheena Blackhall
“It was Saturday, under the sign of Libra
When he crossed, with the aid of morphine,
(that child of Morpheus, Greek God of Dreams)
Into the world of the dead.”

25/09/24, 9:17 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
25/09/24, 9:17 am - Dr Raguram: Internet is an immense ocean swirling with humongous amount of information. Sometimes by sheer coincidence an unknown pearl emerges from its depth. A few days ago, I was typing the word luminous in the search box and by mistake typed ‘n’ instead of ‘l’ and a mysterious word ‘numinous’ emerged. Curious to know further I googled about the word and found that it is credited to Rudolf Otto who was an eminent German theologian in the early part of twentieth century. Rudolf is regarded as one of the most influential scholars of comparative religion. He travelled to India twice, mastered Sanskrit and translated many ancient Hindu texts into German.
I also came across an interesting book summarizing his work, ‘India's Religion of Grace and Christianity Compared and Contrasted’ which was dedicated to Sri Krishnaraja Wadiyar. When I was reading the book, I got to know more about his concept of the ‘Numinous’, an experience that, in his view, underlies all spiritual quests. According to him, it has three components, each designated with a Latin phrase: mysterium tremendum et fascinans. As mysterium, the numinous is entirely different from anything we experience in ordinary life. It evokes a reaction of transcendental silence. But the numinous is also a mysterium tremendum. Initially it provokes terror because of its overwhelming power. Finally, the numinous presents itself as fascinans, as merciful and gracious. Rudolf emphasized that it is essentially nonrational, subjective, and cannot be expressed in language. In his opinion, the numinous is a universal aspect of human spirituality and is at the core of all spiritual experience across various cultures and religions. His notion of the numinous remains an important framework for understanding the deeply transformative and awe-inspiring aspects of human spirituality.
I found his concept of ‘Numinous’, quite interesting as it is reflective of the perennial human quest to explore the deeper aspects of individual consciousness and seek its connection to something vast and infinite. For me I often have a glimpse of that state in my sojourns in nature. We only have to lift our accustomed veils to experience it. 
(Rudolf Otto; September 25th 1869 - March 6th 1937)

How Birds Sing 
“One is not taxed;
one need not practice;
one simply tips
the throat back
over the spine axis
and asserts the chest.
The wings and the rest
compress a musical
squeeze which floats
a series of notes
upon the breeze.”

30/09/24, 8:49 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
30/09/24, 8:49 am - Dr Raguram: Today is the birthday of Rumi whose works continue to have a deep impact on me. His poems encompass a rich and complex tapestry of themes and ideas, all deftly woven together. Personally they have been inspiring signposts which gently guided me to discover myself anew. 
Last week I spoke about the travails of the survivors of suicide in a CME. Suicide destroys the fabric of existence of the survivors and their lives become frayed at the edges. Embracing the reality of loss is not an easy task. It is an extremely poignant journey.
In this particular poem, Rumi explores the nature of grief and loss, suggesting that it can be a catalyst for self-discovery and growth. 
“Your grief for what you’ve lost lifts a mirror
up to where you are bravely working.
Expecting the worst, you look, and instead,
here’s the joyful face you’ve been wanting to see.
Your hand opens and closes, and opens and closes.
If it were always a fist or always stretched open,
you would be paralyzed.
Your deepest presence is in every small contracting and expanding,
the two as beautifully balanced 
and coordinated 
as birds' wings.”
Often the survivor’s world becomes constricted in the absence of the person and they withdraw into themselves. Through the evocative use of the metaphor of bird’s wings, Rumi extols the virtue of spreading the wings open, ‘contracting and expanding’ them, to experience the transformative power of loss. 
I have observed in my clinical work that the person whom the survivors think that they have lost, continues to live amidst their own feathers of memory and I strive to urge them to find strength in them, balance themselves and soar again.

HALLELUIAH by Mary Oliver
Everyone should be born into this world happy
and loving everything.
But in truth it rarely works that way.
For myself, I have spent my life clamoring toward it.
Halleluiah, anyway I’m not where I started!
And have you too been trudging like that, sometimes
almost forgetting how wondrous the world is
and how miraculously kind some people can be?
And have you too decided that probably nothing important
is ever easy?
Not, say, for the first sixty years.
Halleluiah, I’m sixty now, and even a little more,
and some days I feel I have wings.

03/10/24, 10:53 am - Dr Raguram: Yet another Gandhi Jayanti has passed by with ritual obeisance and hollow homilies uttered by politicians. An epitome of humility, compassion, forgiveness and tolerance, Mahatma Gandhi brought morality into the forefront of political life. There have been very few in public life who have embodied these values. It was my privilege to have met one such person, Sri HS Doreswamy. My first meeting is deeply entrenched in my memory. He was dressed in a simple khadi dhoti and jubba with a towel strung around his neck. Though bent with age, he was deceptively frail looking and the sparkle in his eyes told a different story. After that initial encounter, we met on several occasions. He faced scores of tribulations in life and shared many of the most poignant moments in life freely with me. His innate resilience in the face of hosts of adversities in his life, never dampened his remarkable resolve to serve the people. He was deeply concerned about the malignant influence of money power over the electoral process and the fragmentation of the society across caste and religious divides. 
Sri Doreswamy never held any political position and his power came from his unwavering commitment to social harmony, environmental protection, safeguarding of the constitution and serving the downtrodden.  He led a very simple, spartan life and remarked once that “a social worker should live in voluntary poverty.”
This eminent Gandhian who battled many odds in his life, including Covid infection, died of cardiac problems at the age of 103, a few years ago. 
As a mental health professional I like listening rather than talking. In the process, invariably I tune into the life stories and connect with the heart of people whom I meet. I take a moment today to acknowledge the impact of this special person whose unparalleled resilience and courage of conviction, continues to inspire me.

06/10/24, 8:20 am - Dr Raguram: There was quite a heavy downpour in Bengaluru last evening and the meteorologists predicted that more will be on the anvil. Forecasting weather can be quite dicey, even with machine learning techniques which are making steady inroads to predict rainfall, more accurately.
Sometimes an experienced farmer can foresee the onset of rain more accurately than any algorithm. Once we went in search of the most elusive bird in India, the Great Indian Bustard, in the Desert National Park. We got the permission with some difficulty and proceeded to a little village Khuri where we stayed with a farmer in his simple homestay. We spent a night in the midst of the desert with his assistance and it was an experience to cherish. Next morning we were to proceed to the national park. As we were taking leave from the farmer, he looked up in the sky (which incidentally was totally clear), and said, much to our dismay that it will rain in the park area in an hour or two. True to his words, as we neared the national park, it started raining, gathering strength in few minutes. We waited for a while, hoping that it will abate and after some time, rain stopped. But unfortunately we couldn’t enter the park as the tracks inside were muddy and not suitable for the only vehicle that is allowed inside, camel drawn cart, to venture in. Needless to say, it was a huge disappointment. But till this day it amazes me as to how the farmer forecasted the rains so accurately, by just looking at the sky! (I did catch up with the elusive bird, year later and that’s another story!)

08/10/24, 9:10 am - Dr Raguram: Navratri is devoted to the worship of Goddess Durga in her various forms.  Katyayani is one among the Navadurgas, the nine forms of the Goddess, who is worshipped on the sixth fay of Navratri. She is a fierce manifestation of Shakti, the divine female power.
In the Devi Bhagavata Purana, it is mentioned that Rishi Katyayana was a great devotee of Mother Shakti. He wished for the goddess to be born in his household in the form of his daughter. For this, Sage Katyayana did severe penance for years. Meanwhile, the malevolent Mahishasura was wreaking havoc, tormenting the gods relentlessly. Seeking a solution, the divine trinity of Vishnu, Shiva, and Brahma emitted flames that coalesced into the formidable form of Goddess Katyayani. Each of them gifted her a weapon to vanquish Mahishasura. She then embarked on a mission, engaged Mahishasura in a fearsome battle, defeated and vanquished him. Hence, she is also referred to as Mahishasura Mardhini.
This delicately sculpted panel in the inner wall of the Chidambaram temple depicts Katyayani with eighteen hands, her leg firmly entrenched on the neck of Mahishasura. 
The legend of Katyayani is not merely a relic of a bygone era but an inspiring metaphor of resilience and empowerment, which women can draw upon in their daily lives even now. In a world beset with discrimination, inequality, and injustice faced by women, her story illustrates that courage, coupled with an unshakable resolve, can be a continuing source of motivation to conquer adversities and challenge norms even in the face of seemingly insurmountable odds.

09/10/24, 10:13 am - Dr Raguram: This leaf, gnarled and frayed at the edges, will soon plummet gently to the earth at any moment.  It’s limitedness, makes me aware of our own impermanence. As Robert Frost wrote;
“Nature's first green is gold,
Her hardest hue to hold.
Her early leaf's a flower;
But only so an hour.
Then leaf subsides to leaf.
So Eden sank to grief,
So dawn goes down to day.
Nothing gold can stay.” 
Impermanence is the essence of life. We build castles on the shifting sands of life hardly realizing their ephemeral nature. It when we recognize the ever changing tides of life, however painful they may be and flow with them, we can truly appreciate the beauty of our temporary existence. In Jimi Hendrix’s words, “Castles made of sand, slip into the sea, eventually.”
Just as this branch will soon release these leaves without resistance, won’t it be wonderful to adapt to the impermanence of our lives with grace?

10/10/24, 10:17 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
10/10/24, 10:17 am - Dr Raguram: On this World Mental Health Day, let me draw attention to Dorothea Buck, an inspiring figure who espoused the cause of the mentally ill with extraordinary zeal and commitment. 
When Dorothea was just 19 years old, she was emotionally distraught at the prospect of yet another war and the attendant suffering. She was diagnosed as schizophrenic and was confined to an asylum for nine months where she was subjected to a range of harsh physical treatments. Under the Nazi-era “hereditary health law” protocols, which had been imposed to prevent so-called genetic impurities from being transmitted to future generations, she was also sterilized.  When she was released, she was barred from marrying and denied a career as a teacher. She continued to have periods of psychotic episodes which were poorly treated. Undeterred by these adversities, she started writing about mental health, giving lectures, holding seminars and helping to start organizations to protect the rights of mentally ill persons. 
In her talks and writings, Dorothea continuously emphasized that mental health professionals should provide a safe space and hear the stories of personal suffering, rather than seeing them as soulless objects of study. She drew attention to the importance of a three-way discourse in clinical settings involving the patients, their key relatives and their doctors. She called this process as a “trialogue.”
Dorothea trained herself to be a sculptor and this work of hers is called, “Mother and Child.” Speaking about, it she remarked that such kind of intimate personal relationship between doctors and psychotic patients is “missing in today’s psychiatry… the unrelatedness of psychiatrists to their patients contradicted everything human.”
Dorothea died on Oct. 9, 2019, at the age of 102.
Dorothea’s autobiography “On the Trail of the Morning Star: Psychosis as Self-Discovery”, was originally published in German. Translated into English in 2024, it is available as a free download in Research Gate. It is one of the most moving accounts of her lived experiences and tryst with mental illness and I would urge every mental health professional to read it.
Advocacy about mental health is not merely in the realm of professionals. There is an urgent need to provide spaces, where the voice of people who enter and pas through the gates of immense emotional suffering can be heard. 
Dr Raguram

12/10/24, 9:06 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
12/10/24, 9:06 am - Dr Raguram: Vijayadashami commemorates the triumph of Lord Rama over Ravana. The Yudh Kanda section of the Ramayana is replete with details of the fierce battle which lasted for nearly seven days. The duel was so intense that both the armies stood watching the ferocious exchanges. Ravana fought valiantly and fired his arrows in the direction of the flagstaff fixed on Rama's chariot. But none of his arrows could reach the Indra's chariot that Rama rode on. All of Ravana's arrows fell to the ground. Rama's arrows, however, tore asunder Ravana's flag-staff which fell and entered the earth. Overcome with rage, Ravana showered a stream of arrows aiming them at the horses that pulled Rama's chariot. But they had no impact on the horses. This enraged Ravana further and he rained a number of objects in the direction of Rama's chariot. That included gadaa (maces), hathora (iron bludgeons), chakras (discs), mountains and uprooted trees, axes etc. When even that failed, Ravana covered the sky with his missiles. Ravana then tried to attack Matali, Indra’s charioteer. This angered Rama and he aimed the arrows at Ravana's heads. The heads fell down one by one, but they grew back.  Finally, Matali, suggested that "To kill Ravana you must use the dreaded arrow of Brahma, given to you by Agastya Muni, which never misses its target". Heeding to his advice, Rama shot the divine arrow, which found its mark and pierced Ravana in the heart, finally killing him.
Amruteshwara Temple in the Chikkamagalur district of Karnataka is embellished with some of the most beautiful carvings of scenes from Ramayana and Mahabharatha. These friezes are quite small in size and showcase the extraordinary skill and craftsmanship of the sculptors. This particular one depicts the battle scene between Rama and Ravana. I have merged two adjacent panels together to form a composite image. The size of the actual panel is as depicted in the photograph!

13/10/24, 11:53 am - Dr Raguram: Migratory birds are a mesmerizing and astonishing aspect of nature that never ceases to amaze me. These remarkable creatures embark on incredible odysseys, spanning thousands of miles annually, between their breeding grounds in the north and wintering grounds in the south. Their epic migrations are a testament to their remarkable adaptations and the formidable obstacles they overcome in an ever-changing world. Their movements are an indispensable part of numerous ecosystems worldwide. 
Ruffs are migratory birds that travel to India from their breeding grounds in northern Europe and Asia. They breed in wetlands and marshes across a vast range that extends from Scandinavia and Russia to eastern Siberia. During the autumn migration, ruffs undertake a long journey, flying southwards to reach their wintering grounds in Africa and South Asia. During their migration, ruffs face a range of threats, including habitat loss and degradation, hunting, and climate change.
Mangalajodi is a magical bird paradise and Ruffs migrate to its wetlands during winter. It is a wonderful sight to see scores of them amidst the marshes and reed beds. Ruffs generally leave India in the months of March and April, as they begin their return journey to their breeding grounds in northern Europe and Asia.
Here is a beautiful poem about migratory birds like Ruff by Nehal;
“These days
My thoughts are like
Migratory birds
Visiting me from
Far far away, unknown regions
Fill the sky of my mind
With their
Beauty, sounds and movements 
of their wings
And when they leave
They leave without a trace
Can't keep them even in my memory
And I start waiting
For
One more winter! 
( 12th October is the World Migratory Day)

14/10/24, 10:16 am - Dr Raguram: José Emilio Pacheco, revered as one of Mexico’s literary giants, deftly wove the rich tapestry of Mexican culture and its landscapes in his works. His poems offer vivid descriptions of Mexico’s diverse ecosystems. These landscapes are not mere settings but are intertwined with his deep reflections about their ecosystem. This particular poem is a living testimony to the transformative power of his words;
INSISTENCE
“Let’s talk about snow once more let’s say
its cardinal virtue is that it’s quiet 
It knows how to be born with impeccable smoothness in the night
and when we wake we see it has claimed
the earth and the trees
The snow is all around you today, where will it go?
The snow that spins interminably around the city
and the house
will take off into thin air
again be cloud and water
then snow once more
You don’t have its easy adaptable nature
You’ll go on and die and be buried
You will be the clod of earth the snow settles on”
When we read a poem like this, we enter the imaginative world of the author. It is a kind of conversation, a sharing of experiences. As Pacheco commented, "I like poetry to be the interior voice, the voice no one hears, the voice of the person reading it. That is how the 'I' becomes 'you', the 'you' becomes 'I', and in the act of reading is born the 'we' that only exists in that intimate, full moment of reading."

15/10/24, 1:23 pm - Dr Raguram: I understand that today is World Students’ Day to commemorate Dr Abdul Kalam’s birthday. He was a great motivator of students and always encouraged them to ask questions in his interactions with them. He also had a website wherein students could raise question on a wide variety of subjects. He even dedicated his book ‘Ignited Minds’ to a class XII student, Snehal Thakkar. According to him, “ a  very important characteristic of a student is to question.”
During our training period in NIMHANS, we were enveloped in an ambiance of open discussion that encouraged questioning. Seminars, case conferences were active crucibles replete with thoughtful and engaging questioning by trainees. On many occasions, these would spill over to the hostel mess for more animated exchanges!
Questioning lies at the heart of active learning. It is like planting seeds of thought. They can create spaces to reflect on new ideas and perceptions. Unfortunately, the trend to question seems to be declining. In many academic presentations across various settings, I invariably notice that students are reticent to ask questions. Is it because as a culture, we overvalue speaking and privilege it over questioning? Or is it because we are educated in a system that implicitly silences questioning and assigns value only to ‘correct answers’? Perhaps teachers and ‘gurus’ feel uneasy being challenged and implicitly discourage questioning?
Historically, the art of questioning was valorised as an important avenue of learning especially in the spiritual realm, across all cultures. For instance, Prashna Upanishad consists of a series philosophical poems presented as questions (prashna) posed by various seekers and responded to by Sage Pippalada. Perhaps it is time to revitalize the ‘Art of Questioning’!
In the words of Naguib Mahfouz, the Nobel Laureate, “You can tell whether a man is clever by his answers. You can tell whether a man is wise by his questions.”

17/10/24, 11:21 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
17/10/24, 11:21 am - Dr Raguram: Valmiki Jayanti commemorates the birth anniversary of the Adi Kavi, Valmiki. The sage’s inspiration to write the epic, Ramayana, is said to have come from a pair of Krauncha birds. One day when the sage was walking towards the river to take a dip, he noticed two birds, a male and female, completely engrossed in each other. Suddenly a hunter emerged from nowhere and killed the male bird.  The female bird was quite distraught and let out a loud cry. Overcome with deep anguish,  Valmiki uttered a shloka, the first ever Sanskrit verse.
मां निषाद प्रतिष्ठां त्वमगमः शाश्वतीः समाः।
यत्क्रौंचमिथुनादेकम् अवधीः काममोहितम्॥
mā niṣāda pratiṣṭhāṁ tvamagamaḥ śāśvatīḥ samāḥ
yat krauñcamithunādekam avadhīḥ kāmamohitam
The verse roughly translates as, “Oh hunter, may you repent for life and suffer, find no rest or fame, for you have killed one of the unsuspecting, devoted and loving krauncha couple.” 
The identity of the kraucnha bird has been a subject of intense debate. It has been variously described as a dove, flamingo, swan, snipe, curlew or a demoiselle crane. The matter was finally settled by Julia Leslie who wrote an interesting paper, “A bird bereaved: The Identity and Significance of Valmiki's Krauncha”. After considering thirty-two species of birds, she established beyond doubt that the bird described by Valmiki was that of a Sarus Crane.   
Sarus Crane is considered as a symbol of eternal love. Emperor Jahangir was very fond of these birds and kept a pair of them which he called, Laila and Majnu!
(This painting is from the National Museum, New Delhi)
Dr Raguram

19/10/24, 12:39 pm - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
19/10/24, 12:39 pm - Dr Raguram: Sir Thomas Browne (October 19, 1605 - October 19, 1682), was a physician and philosopher, who wrote on a wide array of subjects, including science, medicine, religion, and the esoteric. One particular work that I personally find fascinating to read is ‘Religio Medici’, a book of his reflections. Translated as "The Religion of a Doctor," it offers an interesting perspective of views on various scientific and religious subjects; “Not picked from the leaves of any author, but bred amongst the weeds and tares of mine own brain.” William Osler, who is credited as "the father of modern medicine," considered ‘Religio Medici’ so influential to his career that he reportedly memorized it by heart. 
I would like to draw attention to two of his reflections that made an impact on me. Cleaving a boundary between the personal attitudes and beliefs and professional responsibilities can often be a daunting task especially in clinical work. Browne urges that there needs to be a clear separation between the spheres of religion and that of science, especially in the field of medicine. He underscores the importance that a doctor must not only tolerate but also respect individual patients' religious beliefs, even if they conflict with his own. Physicians personal, religious beliefs should not impact the way he treats his patients. This stems largely from Browne's own belief that individual churches and sects should not "usurp the gates of heaven, and turn the key against each other; and thus we go to heaven against each other’s' wills, conceits, and, with as much uncharity as arrogance, do err." 
In a period where the moral aspects of medical practice are under strain, Browne draws attention to the fact that a strong moral component is at the core in the practice of medicine. To him, medicine is more than a trade, it is a moral pursuit built on a foundation of service to others. "For by compassion," Browne writes, "we make others' misery our own, and so, by relieving them, we relieve ourselves also." When a disease was beyond Browne's capacity to cure, he felt uneasy and was reluctant to charge the patient any fee, calling this "scarce honest gain." 
“Who in the world am I? Ah, that's the great puzzle” pondered Alice in Wonderland. Often, our ideas, beliefs and perspectives about life become clear when we introspect and ‘Religio Medici’ is one such example. Sir Thomas Browne is like a person who is sitting on the edge of a stream, looking at his reflection in the ripples of water, plunging himself in the process into the depths of self-introspection, articulating them with clarity and insight in this small book of memoirs.
As Browne observes in this book,  we must “Be able to be alone. Lose not the advantage of solitude. and the society of thyself.” Often the privacy of aloneness provides a space for deep, perceptive reflections.
( When I was typing these lines, my attention was drawn to this small terracotta figure on the desk and I thought that this image adeptly epitomizes Browne’s observations)

22/10/24, 8:44 am - Dr Raguram: It has been raining continuously over the past few days in Bangalore and the sun is finally up today. Rains are an abiding source of inspiration for poets. It is used as a metaphor for a wide range of emotions: renewal, cleansing, melancholy amongst others. This particular poem ‘The Rainy Day’ by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow was written after the death of his first wife. It is a contemplative poem representing the feelings of sadness and isolation of the poet on a gloomy, rainy day. The sun peeking from behind the clouds offers a glimmer of hope. The poem ends with the evocative line "Into each life some rain must fall”, meaning that anyone of us might feel despondent (some days must be dark and dreary), at some time in our life, but the “the shining sun” will always be around to dispel the dark clouds within.
THE RAINY DAY
The day is cold, and dark, and dreary;
It rains, and the wind is never weary;
The vine still clings to the mouldering wall,
But at every gust the dead leaves fall,
And the day is dark and dreary.

My life is cold, and dark, and dreary;
It rains, and the wind is never weary;
My thoughts still cling to the mouldering past,
But the hopes of youth fall thick in the blast,
And the days are dark and dreary.

Be still, sad heart, and cease repining;
Behind the clouds is the sun still shining;
Thy fate is the common fate of all,
Into each life some rain must fall,
Some days must be dark and dreary.

23/10/24, 9:06 am - Dr Raguram: Robert Bridges was another physician poet who was also the Poet Laureate of England for over a decade from 1913. He was a conscientious doctor and often found it difficult to use the stethoscope because of the noise in the overcrowded hospital. He described the vivid soundscape of a Victorian hospital ward, poetically: ‘…the rattle of carts in the street, the hum of voices inside, the slamming of doors, the noise of people walking about, the coughings of all kinds, the crying of babies, the scraping of impatient feet, the stamping of cold ones, the chinking of the bottles and zinc tickets, and, after eleven o’clock, the hammering, sawing, and tinkering of the carpenters and blacksmiths who came not unfrequently at that hour to set things generally to rights.” Unfortunately, he contracted a serious lung infection at the age of 38 and retired from the medical profession, immersing himself fully in literary pursuits. 
Bridges had a deep love for all things in nature; “I love all beauteous things, I seek and adore them..” I particularly like his shorter poems, especially this one:
I WOULD BE A BIRD, AND STRAIGHT ON WINGS I ARISE
I would be a bird, and straight on wings I arise
I would be a bird, and straight on wings I arise,
And carry purpose up to the ends of the air:
In calm and storm my sails I feather, and where
By freezing cliffs the unransom'd wreckage lies:
Or, strutting on hot meridian banks, surprise
The silence: over plains in the moonlight bare
I chase my shadow, and perch where no bird dare
In treetops torn by fiercest winds of the skies.

Poor simple birds, foolish birds! then I cry,
Ye pretty pictures of delight, unstir'd
By the only joy of knowing that ye fly;
Ye are not what ye are, but rather, sum'd in a word,
The alphabet of a god's idea, and I
Who master it, I am the only bird.
(Robert Bridges born on 23rd October, 1844)

28/10/24, 8:57 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
28/10/24, 8:57 am - Dr Raguram: Just came back after an enthralling sojourn at Ellora and Ajanta. After spending more than two hours savouring the majestic Kailasa temple, we made our way to other caves. Amongst them Cave 10 stands out an enchanting edifice. It is also called The Vishwakarma Cave and is locally known as the Sutar-ka-jhopra (Carpenter's hut). Constructed around 7th century AD, this is the only chaitya in these series of caves in Ellora.
Once we entered the massive cave, we were overwhelmed by its sheer architectural beauty. The apsidal hall is quite long and at the far end of the cave was a huge stupa with a simple circular base, hemispherical dome and a square structure on top. In front of it is a colossal Buddha seated with the Dharmachakra mudra. Dharmachakra mudra holds deep metaphysical significance in Buddhism. It embodies the union of method (Upaya) and wisdom (Prajna), which are essential in pursuing enlightenment. By positioning the hands in front of the heart or the left side of the chest, the mudra signifies teachings emanating directly from Buddha's compassionate heart. A large Bodhi tree is carved at the back and on both sides are the attendants. The outstanding feature of the chaitya is it’s a vaulted roof in which ribs (known as triforium) have been carved in the rock imitating the wooden beams. Even the wooden pins at the joints of beams and lintels have been carefully sculpted in stone.
There was hardly anyone around and the guide asked us to stand with our back aligned to the stone pillars. He then stood in a corned are slowly started chanting, “Buddham Charanam Gachchami” in a soft, low voice. The rhythmic, repetitive chanting reverberated in a magical way in the vast hall and we were immersed in that hypnotizing soundscape. We could feel the vibration of the mellifluous chants cruising through the stone pillars, energizing us. It was not merely a vibrant realm of sacred sounds but a sonic journey that unlocked the doors within.  
Dr Raguram
29/10/24, 8:54 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
29/10/24, 8:54 am - Dr Raguram: The first cave one comes across in Ajanta is cave 1. It is not the first one built chronologically and perhaps the last one to be completed. It is the first cave one encounters when approaching the complex from the north side of the horseshoe-shaped cliff. The construction of the cave started around 466 CE and there were several disruptions. Emperor Harisena of the Vakataka  dynasty played a crucial role in executing it.
As we entered the cool, dark interior of the cave, our attention was drawn to the colossal sculpture of the Buddha in the sanctum. He is seated on a throne in the padmasana, with his hands in the Dharmachakra Mudra. Dharmachakra in Sanskrit means the 'Wheel of Dharma'. This mudra symbolizes one of the most important moments in the life of Buddha, the occasion when he delivered his first sermon after his Enlightenment in the Deer Park at Sarnath.
On the left wall adjoining the sanctum is the painting of Padmapani. It is perhaps one of most iconic paintings of Ajanta and has adorned the walls of many houses. I stood in front of it, totally transfixed, devouring as much as I could of its stately elegance. Padmapani, the bearer of the lotus is portrayed holding the flower in his right hand. There is an unbroken flow of the body which is gracefully inclined slightly to the right side. The left-arm is tied with a ribbon. A high crown adorns his head and around his neck is a pearl necklace. There is a long string of jewellery over the left shoulder, falling across the chest. The long, sharp nose, highlighted  with warm colours and inward shading, enhances the serene beauty of his face.
I closed my eyes for a moment and then looked at the deeply introspective, lotus-shaped, half-closed eyes. This is often referred to as the ‘adamantine’ gaze. I wonder whether through his half closed eyes, Padmapani is urging us to withdraw our awareness from the distractions of the outside world and look within, indicating that all the answers we seek are inside us. I was immersed in the overwhelming aura of boundless compassion radiating from Padmapani’s visage and it was difficult to prise myself away from the celestial painting.  As I was leaving the cave, I was reminded of Rumi’s counsel, “Listen with ears of tolerance. See through the eyes of compassion. Speak with the language of love” 
Dr Raguram
30/10/24, 8:51 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
30/10/24, 8:51 am - Dr Raguram: In the adjoining wall to the right of the main sanctum in Cave 1 is an interesting painting of Vajrapani, one of the earliest bodhisattvas in Mahayana Buddhism. He is the protector of Buddha and symbolizes the Buddha's power. Padmapani manifests Buddha's compassion and Vajrapani establishes Buddha’s power as well as the power of all five Tathagatas. It is interesting to note tht Indra and Brahmā, are recast as Vajrapaṇi and Padmapaṇi, bearers of the vajra and lotus respectively.
In this painting, Vajrapani is bejewelled, regally attired with an elaborate crown. There is an understated aura of a stately presence. Despite his power, Vajrapani has a peaceful countenance. 
Vajra Vidarana Sutra, explains Vajrapani’s nature thus;
“Condensed within you alone,
Is the power and strength of all the Buddhas.
Manifesting in the form of the enlightened Vajra,
I pay homage to you Vajra Vidarana, the Subduer.”
Vajrapani’s energy is not mere force, not even power in any sense. It is what the Buddhist tradition calls Virya: “energy in pursuit of the good.” Most of this energy remains dormant within us. In Vajrayana meditation, visualizing Vajrapani and chanting the mantra, “Om Vajrapani Hum” ushers a vajra-like enlightened awareness to negotiate the inner and outer fears with a sense of spiritual empowerment.

02/11/24, 8:50 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
02/11/24, 8:50 am - Dr Raguram: Balipadyami is observed the day after Diwali in Karnataka. On this day let us recall the story of Mahabali. According to the legend, once upon a time, there was an asura called Bali, also known as Mahabali, who conquered three worlds and was famous for his generosity. Over the course of time he annexed the celestial world too. Unhappy with it, Indra, king of the celestial regions, requested Vishnu to deal with Bali. Vishnu took the form of a dwarf, Vamana, and asked Mahabali for three paces of land. Mahabali granted it without a second thought. The dwarf then suddenly transformed into a giant, and with two paces, he claimed the sky, the earth, and all possessions that Mahabali had. Vamana then asked him where should he take the third step. The only thing Mahabali had left was his body. So he told Vamana to step on his head. Vamana did so and pushed Bali underground into Patal. Mahabali, however, was granted a wish to visit the earth once a year to meet the people who loved him very much.
One of the most beautiful depictions of this myth is in Cave II in Badami: the Vamana-Trivikrama sculpture is carved on the western wall of the mukhamandapa. In the centre of the panel Vishnu is portrayed as Trivikrama. Eight-armed, his right leg is placed firmly on the ground, while the left leg is raised up to the level of chest, with Mahabali underneath it. Of the eight hands, seven hold khadga, bana, gada, chakra, sankha, khetaka and chapa. The remaining left hand is stretched out parallel to the raised leg. A soldier with a sword is shown falling upside down, failing in his attempt to attack Vishnu. A dwarfish person who is portrayed in a royal outfit holds the right leg of Trivikrama firmly, to obstruct his measuring the paces; he is identified as Namuchi, the son of Bali. On the lower left part of this panel, Vamana’s figure has been unfortunately defaced and he can be identified only by his umbrella. Sukracharya is shown by his side pouring water into the hand of Vamana while Bali stands behind with his wife Vindhyavali. Strangely Shukracharya has a Buddha like demeanour. 
What does the story of Balipadyami inform us? Mahabali was caught in the trappings of his ego, craving for more power and perceiving himself as invulnerable. When Trivikrama asked him “where can I place the third step?” he broke free from the fetters of ego and surrendered himself to the divine, cosmic power. When we light the lamp on Balipadyami, let us strive to renew our deeper connection with the divine through transcending the trappings of our ego. It is a path to tread in a period of time when narcissistic patterns are so salient and on the rise. 
Dr Raguram

04/11/24, 8:31 am - Dr Raguram: One has to take the electric buggy or walks some distance to reach Cave 29. The location of the cave is the most picturesque of all the caves with a large waterfall plunging into the gorge next to it. This cave is planned in the shape of a cross and has massive friezes of Shiva & Parvati adorning the walls. Prominent among them is this large sculptural depiction of the marriage of Shiva and Parvati, officiated by Lord Brahma. Many poets have described this scene in the verse form. I am particularly drawn to this poem titled ‘Mahadev-ji ka Byah’ (Wedding ceremony of Lord Mahadev ) written by Nazeer Akbarabadi.  A Muslim by birth, Nazeer Akbarabadi, predates Ghalib.  He wrote on a wide variety of subjects and on religious subjects ranging from Islam, Hinduism to Budhism.  Nazeer strongly opposed religious orthodoxy and was a strong advocate of the syncretic culture of the land. Here is the wonderful poem about the marriage of Shiva and Parvati. 
“पहले नाँव गणेश का, लीजिए सीस नवाए 
जा से कारज सिद्ध हों, सदा महूरत लाए 
बोल बचन आनंद के, प्रेम, पीत और चाह 
सुन लो यारो, ध्यान धर, महादेव का ब्याह 
जोगी जंगम से सुना, वो भी किया बयान 
और कथा में जो सुना, उस का भी परमाण
सुनने वाले भी रहें हँसी ख़ुशी दिन रैन 
और पढ़ें जो याद कर, उन को भी सुख चैन 
और जिस ने इस ब्याह की, महिमा कही बनाए 
उस के भी हर हाल में, शिव-जी रहें सुहाए 
ख़ुशी रहे दिन रात वो, कभी न हो दिल-गीर 
महिमा उस की भी रहे जिस का नाम 'नज़ीर'” 
“Before you begin, honour Ganesh and bow with grace
so your tasks are completed and good fortune you embrace 
Utter the words of joy, love, affection and attachment
My friends, attentively listen to the story of the wedding of Mahadev
Those who listened from hermits narrated it
And those who listened as the story also certify
Those who listen remain cheerful day and nigh
Those who read and memorize are also happy
Whoever narrates the glory of this wedding
Lord Shiva remains happy with him
This exercise brings the happiness that one doesn’t feel sad
Glory to the narrator whose name is ‘Nazeer’”
Our worldview often becomes restricted by our personal beliefs, religious values and political orientations. The strength of poems like this lies in its ability to transport us beyond these confines especially in times when inclusive principles and pluralistic perspectives are under strain. 
In Kavi Pradeep’s words from the movie Nastik, “Dekh tere sansar ki halat kya ho gayi bhagwaan kitna badal gaya insaan...” (Look at what has happened to your world, O god. Man has changed so much).

06/11/24, 8:14 am - Dr Raguram: Decades ago, in the busy outpatient wing of NIMHANS, I noticed an elderly man who was drumming his hands vigorously on his head. I called him inside and asked him as to why he was doing so. He turned to me and said, “I was listening to music.” It was the first case of musical hallucinations I had ever seen and I reported it as a case study in a journal. There have been many reports of such phenomenon with varied hypotheses as to its causation. It left me wondering as to what would happen if a musician were to have musical hallucinations? Will it be an inspiration, finding its way to his/her musical creations, or will it be a curse?
These questions resonated within me for long, till I chanced upon a wonderful 1958 recording of Robert Schumann’s Symphony No 2, by the Cleveland Orchestra conducted by George Szell. It’s deeply affective sombre opening notes, slowly flow into brighter phase with repartees between strings and winds, ending with a hymn like finale. I must have listened to it many times and was curious to find out more about its composer. I was surprised to read about the inspiration for this symphony. It was a piece of auditory musical hallucination that Schumann experienced. In his words, “For several days, drums and trumpets in the key of C have been sounding in my mind. I have no idea what will come of it”: they found their place in Symphony No 2. 
Schumann battled various physical and psychiatric illnesses all through his life, prominent among them being syphilis. He wrote that his illness, “hearing problems, depression, dizziness, rheumatism is inscribed in the fabric of the piece. I would say that my resistant spirit had a visible influence on it and it is through that that I sought to fight my condition. The first movement is full of this combativeness, is very moody and rebellious in character."
During his final days when he was incarcerated in a mental asylum, he was hearing a musical pitch or an entire orchestra. As his wife recorded in a note, Schumann experienced “very strong and painful auditory disturbances” during this time period. The music sounded in his head, day and night, and sometimes went on for days. 
Though the melodic hallucinations formed a kernel of this inspiring composition, Symphony No 2, Schumann was drowned in a sea of musical hallucinations at the end of his life, probably related to the final stages of the syphilitic infection. That raises a question: Are musical hallucinations a ‘royal road’ to a person’s unconscious creative mind or are they merely discordant notes from a disharmonious brain in disarray?

08/11/24, 9:03 am - Dr Raguram: Sometimes even a desolate landscape can kindle the creative spirit in a poet. An example is this poem, “No Birds in Sight, The Forest Withers Slowly” by Ivan Bunin. Ivan was the first Russian author to be awarded the Nobel Prize in 1930. He wrote this poem when he was just 19 years old.
NO BIRDS IN SIGHT, THE FOREST WITHERS SLOWLY
No birds in sight. The forest withers slowly,
Resigned to utter emptiness and chill.
No mushrooms, but there comes from out a gully
Of mushroom damp the strong and tangy smell.

The  scrub is lighter and less tall, the greying
Grass near the bushes droops, seems trampled down;
Beneath the autumn  rain the leaves, decaying,
In mouldy  heaps lie of a darkish brown.

But in the fields the wind is fresh and biting.
I lead my stallion out and ride from home,
And, in the freedom of the steppe delighting,
Far from the villages till nightfall roam.

Lulled by my mount's slow, easy pace, I listen
With joy-tinged, quiet sadness to the hum
Of wind as it invades with singsong whistle
And drawn-out moan the barrels of my gun.
As the poet makes his way through the forest, he is surrounded by barren trees that have shed their foliage. There an overwhelming silence as the woods are shorn of bird calls. The mouldering leaves form a crumbling pile on the moist undergrowth of the woods. There is a touch of melancholic beauty around him. Absence of any human or animal activity around him enhances his perceived isolation. But as he rides with his mount across the landscape the wind serenading through the trees buoys up his spirit.
The inner and outer landscape merge and blend seamlessly in this enchanting little poem. As Thoreau reflected, “Am I not partly leaves and vegetable mounds myself?” 
Ivan Bunin (October 22, 1870 - November 8, 1953)

11/11/24, 9:17 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
11/11/24, 9:17 am - Dr Raguram: Banteay Srei is a small temple near Angkor Thom in Cambodia and is considered to be the “jewel of Khmer art.” Exquisitely carved in the mid-10th century, it is the first temple in Angkor to depict mythological scenes, each one of them superbly carved.
This particular panel depicts the story of Lord Krishna slaying Kamsa. Kamsa was the tyrannical ruler who took over the kingdom of Mathura after overthrowing his father, Ugrasena.  Narada Muni had prophesized that Kamsa’s sister Devaki's eighth child would kill him. Kamsa imprisoned Devaki and Vasudev, and killed seven of the children that Devaki gave birth. When the eighth child, Lord Krishna was born, Vasudev took the child out of the prison safely to Gokul, his friend Nanda’s home. Nanda’s wife Yashoda had also given birth to a girl and Vasudev took the girl child back to the prison. When Kamsa came to know about the birth, he rushed to the prison and tried to kill the baby. But the baby slipped from his hand and was transformed into the goddess Yogamaya, who told Kamsa: “O foolish! What will you get by killing me? Your nemesis is already born somewhere else.” After hearing that Lord Krishna was alive, Kamsa sent many Rakshas to kill him but they all met their demise. Frustrated with this, he came up with a masterplan to kill his nephew in his kingdom. He announced a wrestling match with demon brothers Mushtika and Chanura. Hearing of this, Lord Krishna went over to Mathura with Balarama. When they reached the arena, Kamsa ridiculed them and sent the demon brothers to the arena. After a fierce fight, Lord Krishna and Balrama slew the wrestler demons. Seeing this and filled with rage, Kamsa stormed to the arena himself. Lord Krishna grabbed him, threw him down on the ground and beheaded Kamsa.
The final battle between Lord Krishna and Kamsa is depicted with much detail in this particular panel in Banteay Srei. The event takes place in Kamsa’s beautifully carved palace. Large number of women witness the event and one can notice the agitation on their faces. At the bottom of the panel, Lord Krishna and Balarama arrive at the palace in their horse drawn carriage. The entire episode is intricately sculpted with much attention to detail.
Kamsa Vadh is celebrated today in Mathura, primarily by the Chaturvedi community. On the next day of Kamsa Vadh, ‘Teen Van Parikrama’ is performed in Braj region. It covers three towns namely Mathura, Vrindavan and Garun Govind. It is believed that Lord Krishna performed this Parikrama to absolve the sins of killing Kamsa.

19/11/24, 9:40 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
19/11/24, 9:40 am - Dr Raguram: One of the major factor impacting access to and utilisation of mental health services is stigma. Overcome with shame and isolation, people with mental illness feel discriminated from the rest. It has a cascading effect on their social relationships, wellbeing and quality of life. 
Erving Goffman was perhaps the first sociologist to dwell into it in his book, ‘Stigma, Notes on the Management of Spoiled Identity.’ According to him, stigma essentially conveys a devalued stereotype, an “attribute that is deeply discrediting.” The discredited attributes can include race, religion, ethnicity, physical deformity and mental illnesses. Stigmatized people feel stigmatized in relation to a group of people who are deemed to be normal, and normal people consider themselves normal in relation to people who viewed as less than normal and stigmatized. According to him stigma exists in a relationship between an attribute and frames of understanding and society which views that attribute as representative of a deviance from social norms. In his words, “By definition, of course, we believe the person with a stigma is not quite human. On this assumption we exercise varieties of discrimination, through which we effectively, if unthinkingly, reduce his life chances. We construct a stigma-theory, an ideology to explain his inferiority.” 
I was wondering whether there is a biographical context to Goffman’s explorations into aspects of stigma. Was it the anti-Semitic discrimination which he experienced early in his life as an immigrant Jew or his lived experience of tending to his life who had a lifelong mental illness and died by suicide.
Perhaps much of our efforts to understand human behaviour and the social world around us often emerges from our own personal experiences.
Erving Goffman (born June 11, 1922 - died Nov. 19, 1982)

When I continued to gaze on the Buddha, the sounds from the transitory world outside slowly faded away and I was transported into an inexplicably serene realm. It was a strange feeling and quite indescribable too. 
As I made my way outside of the dark cave, my heart was filled with an ineffable light.

26/11/24, 9:14 am - Dr Raguram: Trees are being felled at alarming rate in Bengaluru. The iconic tree lined avenues have faded away, and linger only in memory. Sometimes what we glimpse through eyes can find their way through a poet’s heart and find expression in haunting words, like in this poem ‘The Poplar Field’ by William Cowper.
“The Poplars are fell’d, farewell to the shade
And the whispering sound of the cool colonnade
The winds play no longer and sing in the leaves,
Nor Ouse on his bosom their image receives.
Twelve years have elapsed since I last took a view
Of my favourite field and the bank where they grew,
And now in the grass behold they are laid,
And the tree is my seat that once lent me a shade.
The black-bird has fled to another retreat
Where the hazels afford him a screen from the heat,
And the scene where his melody charm’d me before,
Resounds with his sweet-flowing ditty no more.
My fugitive years are all hasting away,
And I must e’er long lie as lowly as they,
With a turf on my breast and a stone at my head
E’er another such grove shall arise in its stead.
’Tis a sight to engage me if anything can
To muse on the perishing pleasures of Man;
Though his life be a dream, his enjoyments, I see,
Have a Being less durable even than he” 
The poet describes the destruction of a field of poplar trees which no longer offer him shade. The birds too have flown away. Reflecting on the passage of time, the poet wonders with a touch of melancholy, whether he too will return to earth soon. The degradation of the outer landscape and its liminality is symbolic of the tribulations that Cowper went through all his life. His life was one long tryst with pain as he suffered from recurrent attacks of severe depression, “lying down in horror, and rising up in despair” resulting in several suicidal attempts. He found succour in the company of John Milton who wrote the ‘Amazing Grace’. 
Cowper died from dropsy on April 25th 1800. He summed up his life in these words;
“I, who scribble rhyme
To catch the triflers of the time,
And tell them truths divine and clear
Which, couched in prose, they would not hear.”

29/11/24, 9:37 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
29/11/24, 9:37 am - Dr Raguram: Elephants are magical. Their footprints are deeply imprinted in the cultural, collective consciousness and in individual memories of each one of us.
Mythical stories narrated in the Purāṇas mention that the weight of the world rested on divine elephants. Hence not surprisingly, the giant pachyderms figure prominently in temple architecture all around the country. In Hindu temples, they are found primarily in the Adhisthana, the base of the structure on which the superstructure of the temple rests and on Upapitha (sub-base or plinth) of the shrine. 
There are two ways in which elephants figure in these structures. Gajapitha, consists of a row of standing elephants holding the pitha. The most wonderful example is in the Kailasa temple at Ellora. Rising from the middle of the rock-cut courtyard, the monolithic temple conveys the impression of being borne aloft on the backs of dozens of life-sized elephants. Beautifully sculpted from the black basalt, they seem to hold the temple up with consummate ease. Though many of them have borne the vagaries of time, there is an unmistakable grace and power in them. (Photograph on top is from Kailasa temple).
A different way in which elephants figure in temple structure is that of Gajathara. It consists of a horizontal frieze of elephants, generally in the lowermost portion of the Adhisthana. The adhisthana usually comprises a remarkable array of horizontal bands depicting at the base, a row of elephants, symbolizing stability. Over this, scrollwork containing delicately carved figures of birds, animals and mythical animals and over these another row of miniature pillars, with a row of miniature temple vimanas. At the highest level are figures of dancers and musicians. The whole adhisthana enclosing the temple is thus transformed into a gallery of intricate sculptural art with miniature carving at its best. The elephants in the bottom layer are usually rendered in profile, marching in procession or in war and hunting scenes. An outstanding example is in the Hoysala temples, especially in Belur and Halebid. (Glimpses of this in the bottom photo from Halebid)
The symbolism of the elephant in Hindu mythology and temple architecture encompasses wisdom, dignity and strength. Its portrayal in these sculptural forms reflects these qualities while also serving as a reminder for us to strive for these virtues in our own lives. 
Dr Raguram
30/11/24, 9:01 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
30/11/24, 9:01 am - Dr Raguram: Often writers choose pseudonyms in their writings, to conceal their true identities and they use them for a variety of reasons. For instance, Isaac Asimov used the fictitious name of Paul French to publish a series of science fiction books early in his career. Fernando Pessoa, the famous Portuguese writer ventured in the opposite direction, using heteronyms. In his own words, “A pseudonymous work is, except for the name with which it is signed, the work of an author writing as himself; a heteronymic work is by an author writing outside his own personality: it is the work of a complete individuality made up by him, just as the utterances of some character in a drama would be…  I break my soul into pieces, and into different persons.” More than 72 heteronyms have been identified in Fernando Pessoa’s writing! Sometimes he even thought that, at times, he could see and hear the heteronyms he had created. 
Basically a heteronym is an imaginary character created by a writer to write in a different style. The writer becomes a virtual subject, who starts inhabiting the character's life first-personally. As a consequence, the characters in heteronym have their own individual identity, which is expressed in writing.  Viewed this way I was wondering whether heteronym is a precursor to Avatar!
Pessoa’s famous work is the ‘Book of Disquiet’ which has an unusual structure. It is totally nonlinear and a fusion of poetry and prose in which the author reflects on various aspects of life. In an interesting comment, the author states, “My soul is a hidden orchestra; I know not what instruments, what fiddlestrings and harps, drums and tamboura I sound and clash inside myself. All I hear is the symphony.” 
(Fernando Pessoa: June 13 1888 – November 30 1935)

02/12/24, 9:34 am - Dr Raguram: ‘Come to the Edge’ is a poem often attributed to Guillaume Apollinaire but actually written by poet, activist, Christopher Logue (23rd November 1926 – 2nd December 2011). Whenever I read this poem, a series of images and meanings keep swirling through my mind. Quite often we feel contented, settling into our own comfort zones. Life is often a delicate dance between the possible and the impossible. Logue urges us to venture further and discover uncharted territories that we feel hesitant to explore. 
Years ago I went along with my friend to explore the caves in the Antaragange hill near Kolar. It was the first time I attempted to climb a hill. The guide reassured me that it shouldn’t be too difficult. Encouraged by his reassurance I started the climb. The first few ascents were a bit difficult but when we entered the caves on the top, the cool morning breeze was quite refreshing. The difficulty started when I started to climb down. I felt that the rocks might give way and was overcome with intense fear that I would tumble down the hill. It was at that time, the guide came over and whispered in my ears, “Doctor, the mountain is in the mind.” I felt energized by that comment and made my way down with much greater ease. The dreadful consequences I had anticipated vanished into thin air. Crossing the threshold of fear opened my mind to lurking possibilities within. To this day, these words resonate deeply within and swell to contain the anxiety whenever I face uncertainties in life. 
Often the most profound experiences lie beyond the familiar and have a way of keeping us afloat.
COME TO THE EDGE
Come to the edge.
We might fall.
Come to the edge.
It's too high!
COME TO THE EDGE!
And they came,
and he pushed,
And they flew.

04/12/24, 9:34 am - Dr Raguram: Kandariya Mahadeva Temple is the largest and most ornate temple at Khajuraho. Every inch of its exterior walls is adorned with a mesmerizing profusion of sculptures. Deities from the Hindu pantheon like Brahma, Vishnu, and Ganesha grace the walls, their expressions radiating serenity and power. Geometric patterns and floral motifs add a touch of elegance, while friezes depicting scenes from mythology offer a glimpse into ancient Hindu epics. Interspersed with these are the celestial nymphs (apsaras) in their flowing attire adorned with intricate jewellery. They are shown in various poses, such as playing instruments, dancing, beautifying themselves, or removing a thorn from the foot. 
I was totally bewitched on seeing the depiction of a voluptuous apsara with a scorpion sculpted on her left thigh. Intricately carved, it seems to be traveling up. It doesn’t appear to be a decorative motif and seemed to be associated uniquely with the celestial beauty. Strangely, there is no fear or apprehension on the apsara’s face.  What could be the association of a sensuous beauty with a scorpion? In Indian mythology, Vrischika has multiple and diverse symbolic meanings, ranging from fear to allure. In Vedic astrology Vruschika Rashi embodies intensity, passion, and transformation. Could the scorpion be a metaphor for female arousal? Al-Biruni, in his book written in 1029 A.D. just around the time that the Kandariya Mahadeva temple was constructed and shortly after his own trip to India, states that in India, scorpions were associated with the genitals, fertility, progeny.
I searched far and wide to understand and unravel the iconographic background of the association of scorpion with sensuality and it still remains an unfathomable mystery to me!

05/12/24, 9:41 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
05/12/24, 9:41 am - Dr Raguram: Yesterday was the World Wildlife Conservation Day. It is celebrated to raise awareness about the importance of protecting the earth's endangered species and ecosystems. It’s main aim is to encourage people to conserve wildlife and their natural habitats.
Vultures figure prominently among the endangered species in India. Though they play a crucial role in the ecosystem, they are one step away from total extinction. In an earlier post, I had drawn attention to the silent, committed work by Sri Bharathidasan and his colleagues at Arulagam, an environmental organization based in Coimbatore.  Bharathi and his colleagues have been working actively over the past decade to protect and increase the critically endangered vulture population in Tamil Nadu. They educate the local communities through awareness campaigns about the importance of vultures in the ecosystem, advocating for the elimination of harmful veterinary drugs that are poisoning vulture food sources. 
When we went along with them in the Satyamangalam Tiger Reserve recently, we sighted around 120 white-rumped, long-billed, and red-headed vultures. More than sighting a large flock, it was the age group of vultures that was remarkable; there were juveniles, sub adults and adults, many of them perched on trees. Bharathi was moved by the sight as it was the first time that such large number of vultures were sighted in Tamil Nadu.
India, owes much of its natural splendour to the selfless efforts of group of remarkable individuals like Bharathi and his dedicated team. These unsung heroes have dedicated their lives to the cause of protecting and preserving the nation's precious wildlife like vultures. Their efforts are a living testimony that it is feasible to transform potential conflicts into collaborative solutions ensuring the conservation of precious species in the ecosystem.
As Margaret Mead commented, “Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world; indeed, it's the only thing that ever has.”

06/12/24, 7:46 am - Dr Raguram: Rumi is not merely a poet; he is also a spiritual guide. I dip into his works often and the ‘doors of perception’ start opening. If I have to choose just one poem to illustrate this, it is this one. 
“Out beyond ideas of wrongdoing and rightdoing,
there is a field. I’ll meet you there.
When the soul lies down in that grass,
the world is too full to talk about.
Ideas, language, even the phrase “each other”
doesn’t make any sense.
The breeze at dawn has secrets to tell you.
Don’t go back to sleep.
You must ask for what you really want.
Don’t go back to sleep.
People are going back and forth across the doorsill
where the two worlds touch.
The door is round and open.
Don’t go back to sleep.”
Often we get enmeshed in binaries in our lives: good/bad, right/wrong, proper/improper, valid/invalid etc. Such a position often results in a judgmental stance and we start viewing the world around us through these prisms. Basically a sense of duality shapes our worldviews. Rumi wonders whether there is a realm of experience beyond this. Is it possible for us to be in a more unified space where we can aspire to free ourselves and savour a more unified reality? In that mind space void of labels and judgements, duality dissolves and we can realize our ‘oneness’. 
Thanks to Rumi, whenever I find myself quick to judge, I pause and reflect.

09/12/24, 9:50 am - Dr Raguram: Despite being an acclaimed poet in Persian, Sadi Shirraj or Sa’di, felt that he had written nothing of consequence and resolved to spend rest of his life in silence. One day, he broke his vow at the insistence of his close friend when both of them went for a stroll in the garden. Sadi noticed that that his friend was gathering rose petals and putting them into his robes. Sadi wondered why his friend was collecting and storing them carefully when they would dry very soon and will not be of much use. He told his friend that, instead, he would write a book called the Gulistan, (Garden of Roses), whose folios would last forever. The Gulistan remains one of the most beloved works of Persian literature. It consists of parables interspersed with short poems. In one of his most beautiful poems in the book, he wrote; 
“Human beings are members of a whole
In creation of one essence and soul
If one member is afflicted with pain
Other members uneasy will remain
If you have no sympathy for human pain
The name of human you cannot retain”
The flowers of Gulistan's poems are still fresh today and can be savoured in a wonderful translation by Richard Burton.

10/12/24, 9:47 am - Dr Raguram: I just finished reading a deeply moving book, “Why do you fear my way so much?” by GN Saibaba. He was 90% paralysed and had spent over 10 years in jail, till the Division Bench of the Bombay High Court acquitted him of all charges. Saibaba died on October 12, 2024.
This particular passage from the book is heart rendering;
“I have lived all my conscious life on the campuses of learning and teaching in search of knowledge, love and freedom. In the course of this search, I learnt that freedom for a few was no freedom. I began to study histories, philosophies and literatures with more eagerness and critical engagement. That led me to look around myself closely. I travelled across and met people living in sub-human conditions. I realised that they never tasted freedom very much like me. I understood that castes and freedom can never co-exist. I began to speak to myself. Then I slowly started to speak to my fellow beings on my journey. I grasped of a great void of silence around me. I saw a society of silence. I dashed myself against the boulders of silence. I brutally wounded myself”….
“I reel under excruciating relentless pain. One after the other, my organs started bursting. The closure of my voice within me explodes into shooting pain. My vocal chords acquired lesions making my voice a thin and inaudible squeak. My heart broke with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. My brain has started having blackouts with a condition called syncope. My kidneys are silted with pebbles; my gallbladder gathered stones and pancreas grew a tail of pain called pancreatitis. Nerve lines in my left shoulder broke under the conditions of my arrest, known as brachial plexopathy. More and more organs of silence replaced the original. I have been living with explosive and shooting pain day in and day out. I am living on the margins of life.” 
And he quotes a verse from Faiz Ahmad Faiz
“My pain, a voiceless song,
my being a nameless mote.
If only my pain could speak,
I’d know who I am.
And if myself could find its essence,
I’d unravel the mystery of this world.
If I could seize this hidden mystery,
my silence would find expression.”

13/12/24, 9:40 am - Dr Raguram: Separation is a poignant theme across all creative oeuvres. It encompasses a range of emotions involving intense longing as well extreme sadness. The anguish and emotional turmoil of separation is particularly well expressed in the realm of poetry. Often described as ‘viraha’, where lovers experience intense pain due to physical separation, evocative descriptions are aplenty in works like Kalidasa's ‘Meghaduta’, Jayadeva's ‘Gitagovinda’ and in Tamil Sangam poetry. In the latter, where different landscapes are associated with specific emotions, separation is described on the background of ‘neithal’, where the separation of lovers is associated with the vastness and loneliness of the sea and in exquisite detail in the ‘paalai’ landscape which symbolizes complete separation and the harshness in a desolate, barren environment.  
The torment of separation plays out powerfully in the palette of Expressionist painters like Edvard Munch (12 December 1863 - 23 January 1944), who is often remembered for his iconic painting ‘The Scream’. In a painting titled ‘Separation’ he portrayed a man and a woman in the process of parting. Our eyes are drawn to the striking colour contrast between the two.  The man, ostensibly overwhelmed with emotions of sadness and despair is painted in black. On the other hand, the woman is painted with a brighter yellow colour, symbolic of happiness and optimism.  While the man is static, the woman seems as though she is ready to move on from him and cross the black line of separation. While the man is still caught in the web of the past, suffering from the memories of what they once had together, the woman looks far across the line, awaiting the future. What is also interesting is that the man’s right hand is painted with the colours of the woman, indicating how the man fails to let go of the woman from his heart which seems to be bleeding. Colours are not merely aesthetic choices in art; they hold the power to evoke powerful feelings. Edvard Munch utilizes intense hues as a powerful tool in this painting to convey emotional tribulations lurking within the individuals in throes of separation, so effectively. 
Only Pablo Neruda can voice these in verse, 
“..Tonight I can write the saddest lines.
To think that I do not have her. To feel that I have lost her.
To hear the immense night, still more immense without her.
And the verse falls to the soul like dew to the pasture.
What does it matter that my love could not keep her.
The night is shattered and she is not with me.
This is all…”

16/12/24, 9:48 am - Dr Raguram: Confronting mortality is not an easy task. Very few musicians have ventured into this landscape and prominent among them is Mahler. He explored the vicissitudes of life and death in his masterly Second Symphony. It is a work that explores mortality and inevitably of death and ends with an affirmation of a transcendent, everlasting life. The first eight lines from the final movement were taken from the poem, ‘Die Auferstehung’, by Friedrich Gottlieb Klopstock and Mahler wrote the rest himself; 
“Rise again, yes, rise again,
Will you, my dust, after a brief rest!
Immortal life! Immortal life
Will he who called you, give you.
You are sown to bloom again!
The lord of the harvest goes
And gathers sheaves,
Us, who have died.
O believe, my heart, O believe:
Nothing is lost to you!
Yours, yes yours, is what you desired
Yours, what you have loved
What you have fought for!
O believe,
You were not born for nothing!
Have not lived for nothing,
Nor suffered!
What was created
Must perish;
What perished, rise again!
Cease from trembling!
Prepare yourself to live!
O Pain, you piercer of all things,
From you, I have been wrested!
O Death, you conqueror of all things,
Now, are you conquered!
With wings which I have won for myself,
In love’s fierce striving,
I shall soar upwards
To the light which no eye has penetrated!
I shall die in order to live.
Rise again, yes, rise again,
Will you, my heart, in an instant!
That for which you suffered,
To God shall it carry you!”
(Dedicated to Ustad Zakir Hussain, whose dancing fingers on the tabla will continue to entrance us)
Do close your eyes and listen to this exceptional recording of Mahler’s 2nd symphony by Otto Klemperer.

17/12/24, 8:27 am - Dr Raguram: I first came across the name of Kirkbride in a book tantalizingly titled, “Madhouses, Mad doctors and Madmen.” Kirkbride (July 31, 1809 - December 16,1883), was one of the thirteen founders of the Association of Medical Superintendents of American Asylums for the Insane (now the American Psychiatric Association), and was its president from 1862 to 1870. He was a passionate advocate of ‘moral treatment’ of the insane and argued that the place where the mentally ill are placed, must further this cause. Towards this end he spent considerable amount of time to develop an architectural plan for these buildings which is often referred to as a the ‘Kirkbride Plan.’
When I had a look at the ‘Kirkbride Plan’ I was struck by its similarity to wings of a bird! From the central administrative block two wings extend out in a staggered fashion. The idea behind was that the living quarters of the patients should have maximum light and ventilation, with high ceilings. Each ward would be a self-contained unit with all facilities under one roof. Kirkbride paid meticulous attention to each aspect of the design, including the design and placement of the windows, plan of the bathrooms and even recommending particular building materials and colours of paint. He specially emphasized that the living quarters should open into large outdoor landscape and foliage, so that all the patients could be part of it. Patients were segregated by their condition; those who were quite disturbed were kept in the pavilions furthest from the centre. 
‘Kirkbride Plan’ was adopted in several asylums in US. Except for a few which have been declared as heritage structures, the rest have been pulled down and demolished in the era of deinstitutionalization. 
Even though no mental hospitals are being built now, ‘Kirkbride Plan’ is a remarkable document from a certain time in history of care of the mentally ill, which emphasizes the important role of architecture in facilitating a healing environment. 
Dr Raguram

18/12/24, 9:07 am - Dr Raguram: It is a sight to behold when the majestic purple heron takes to the sky. It may look somewhat gawky when perched on the ground, but it is such winsome bird in flight, looking so effortless as its wings languidly rise and fall with those long legs trailing behind.
Mary Oliver is a favourite poet of mine. She effortlessly captures the most tranquil moments in nature and weaves them in words, like in this poem;
HERON RISES FROM THE DARK, SUMMER POND
“So heavy
is the long-necked, long-bodied heron,
always it is a surprise
when her smoke-colored wings
open
and she turns
from the thick water,
from the black sticks
of the summer pond,
and slowly
rises into the air
and is gone.
Then, not for the first or the last time,
I take the deep breath
of happiness, and I think
how unlikely it is
that death is a hole in the ground,
how improbable
that ascension is not possible,
though everything seems so inert, so nailed
back into itself —
the muskrat and his lumpy lodge,
the turtle,
the fallen gate.
And especially it is wonderful
that the summers are long
and the ponds so dark and so many,
and therefore it isn’t a miracle
but the common thing,
this decision,
this trailing of the long legs in the water,
this opening up of the heavy body
into a new life: see how the sudden
gray-blue sheets of her wings
strive toward the wind; see how the clasp of nothing
takes her in.”
At one level the poem is a vivid description of a heron taking flight. For me, the metaphor in the poem is one of ‘Being and Becoming.’ From ‘being’ in the dark pond of life, there is always an innate transformative quest in us to ‘becoming’ one with the vast “clasp of nothing.”

20/12/24, 9:29 am - Dr Raguram: Cintio Vitier was a Cuban poet, essayist, and novelist, often referred to as "one of the most important writers of his generation". His abundant love of the ordinary people and his firm conviction that without roots in those people, nothing can be created, finds expression in his poems. He wrote, “Soul of the nation lived in the quiet suffering of the poor or middle-class family, in its capacity for resistance and hope, in its irrepressible popular laugh, in its unbeatable music, in the lamp of the intellectual, in poetry.” 
“My words verge on silence
like great birds that disappear
into the early evening: their
strenuous white wings
carry off the intense sweetness
of dusk, visible then
in starlight.
My words turn toward the night
with no look back
at what is lost or won, or
what is missing, like those workers,
who, utterly fatigued
by a long day, return home
so the household once again can rest
and the strength that comes
with morning be restored.”
Here, the poet wonderfully transposes the metaphor of the birds with that of workers who toil tirelessly. I always feel that there are birds lurking within us, resting and finding a moment to recoup the strength to fly again and again in the vast sky of life.

06/01/25, 8:19 am - Dr Raguram: 5th January is celebrated as National Bird Day in USA. Every time when we are there, we manage to do some bit of birding. Last year we visited Lake Placid, which is nestled in the heart of New York state's scenic Adirondack Mountains. One morning when I was sitting on the deck, I heard a very unusual bird call. It was like a guttural squeak, ending with a long whistle. Curious to locate it, I saw a bird sitting on the tree ahead which was emitting the call. It had a glossy-iridescent body, with purplish-blue head, neck and breast. Its eyes were like intense little black beads that seemed to look at me sideways. Quickly I searched the net and found that it was a grackle. I sat for a while observing it closely as it was joined by scores of its ilk, it was sheer grackophony!
Once I was back in the room, I was curious to know whether this bird has caught the attention of poets. In a short poem published in 1958, Lisel Mueller described what I witnessed a few minutes ago.
“Watching the black grackle
come out of the gray shade
into the sun, I am dazzled
by an unexpected sheen,
yellow, purple, and green,
where the comb of light silkens
unspectacular wings —
until he, unaware
of what he means at this one
peculiar angle of sun,
hops back to his modest dark
and leaves the shining part
of himself behind, as though
brightness must outgrow
its fluttering worldly dress
and enter the mind outright
as vision, as pure light.” 
When the poets dips their pen in ornithology, the results can be quite enchanting!
