10/01/25, 11:24 am - Dr Raguram: The Padma Purana narrates the history of Vaikunta Ekadasi through the episode of the asura Muran, who secures Vishnu’s blessings but abuses his power. Vishnu Himself engages him in a combat. When Vishnu rests briefly in a cave, the asura tries to ambush Him at which point, a female form springs from Vishnu’s chest and kills Muran on the 11th day of Margazhi sukla paksham. Vishnu names her as Ekadasi. She seeks Moksha for Muran and anyone who prays to Vishnu on this day. It is believed that Vishnu opens the north gate of heaven, Vaikunta vaasal for those who pray to him on this day. Vaishnavite temples replicate this practice by opening the Sorga Vaasal.
Lord Vishnu has five states. Param, Vyuham, Vibhavam, Antaryami and Archam. The first state Param is the state known as Paramapadam, Vaikuntam or Moksam, which is located in a space beyond all worlds. This is a sculptural depiction of Para-Vasudeva from cave 3 at Badami. He is shown here with four arms, seating on Sheshanaga (serpent), also known as Ananta, who symbolises primordial principle of time. Vishnu is seated on the coils of Ananta, in a relaxed manner with his left leg folded over the coils and right leg resting down. His upper two hands hold shankha and chakra while his lower-right hand is placed on the coils and lower-left hand rests on the left leg. The five hoods of Ananta serve as a parasol over his head. The sculpture is exquisitely carved with fine ornamentation and eye for detail.

13/01/25, 8:12 am - Dr Raguram: Music and dance are not merely aesthetic forms but also serve as conduits for realizing the divine presence. For instance, Arudra Darisanam which is observed today, celebrates the cosmic dance of Lord Shiva as Nataraja. Nataraja’s dance is not just a physical expression but signifies the underlying vibrations that sustain the universe, embodying creation, preservation, destruction, release, and embodiment, often referred to as Panchakrityas.
One of the beautiful expression of Nataraja’s dance is in the form of Alidhanrita Shiva. This sculpture is from Kailasanathar Kovil in Kancheepuram. Here he is depicted in a Swastika Mudra. On the right side is Parvathi with an adoring expression relishing the dance, with a Nandi below her. On the left is a musician playing the drums. The animated Shiva Ganas are dancing with sheer abandon at the bottom. Right on top is a small, exquisitely carved Ganesha. 
Kaviyogi Sri Suddhananda Bharathi composed a beautiful song about the dancing Shiva, ‘தூக்கிய திருவடி' “tUkkiya tiruvaDi’ in raga Shankarabharanam. He pays obeisance to the Lord in the opening line;
“தூக்கிய திருவடி துணை என நம்பினேன் துரிய நடராஜனே” 
“I seek salvation in your raised foot, Oh Supreme Lord, Nataraja.”
This particular verse in Thevaram by Tirunavukkarasar, beautifully articulates our abiding quest for salvation from the Lord;
மனமெனுந் தோணி பற்றி
மதியெனுங் கோலை யூன்றிச்
சினமெனுஞ் சரக்கை ஏற்றிச்
செறிகட லோடும் போது
மதனெனும் பாறை தாக்கி
மறியும்போ து அறிய வொண்ணா(து)
உனையுனும் உணர்வை நல்காய்
ஒற்றியூ ருடைய கோவே.

16/01/25, 8:51 am - Dr Raguram: There is something ineffable when I see a vibrant flower, glowing in the morning sun. Rhododendron is not an uncommon flower; there are more than six hundred varieties of it. But sometimes it’s gorgeousness holds my attention as I immerse and lose myself amidst layers of its elegant petals.
One day when Ralph Waldo Emerson took a stroll in the woods, he was drawn by the exquisite beauty of the flower and wrote a lovely poem, ‘The Rhodora’.
“In May, when sea-winds pierced our solitudes,
I found the fresh Rhodora in the woods,
Spreading its leafless blooms in a damp nook,
To please the desert and the sluggish brook.
The purple petals fallen in the pool
Made the black water with their beauty gay;
Here might the red-bird come his plumes to cool,
And court the flower that cheapens his array.
Rhodora! if the sages ask thee why
This charm is wasted on the earth and sky,
Tell them, dear, that, if eyes were made for seeing,
Then beauty is its own excuse for Being;
Why thou wert there, O rival of the rose!
I never thought to ask; I never knew;
But in my simple ignorance suppose
The self-same power that brought me there, brought you.”
We might often wonder what purpose this flower serves in the garden when no one notices its beauty. The poet answers succinctly;
“Tell them, dear, that, if eyes were made for seeing,
Then beauty is its own excuse for Being;”
Philosophical tomes vary in their interpretation of what constitutes beauty. To me it is merely a transcendental experience. Something that is felt deeply within the echelons of the heart which communicates with the spirit of the natural world. In the poet’s words;
“The self-same power that brought me there, brought you.”
As John Ruskin observed, “Nature is painting for us, day after day, pictures of infinite beauty.”

17/01/25, 9:37 am - Dr Raguram: Every time I read a poem by Mary Oliver, I feel a deeper connection with nature. In spite of a difficult early life, she had an abiding passion for nature and began writing at an early age.  Influenced by both Whitman and Thoreau, she was an ardent observer of the natural world. Many of her poems are grounded in her experiences and interactions with animals, plants, and the landscapes which she explored all through her life. In her work, she invites us to slow down, pay attention, and savour the beauty of the natural world. An avid walker, she once commented, “For me the door to the woods is the door to the temple.” Her integration with nature comes alive in a lively poem, ‘Sleeping in the forest’
“I slept as never before,
a stone on the riverbed, nothing
between me and the white fire of the stars
but my thoughts, and they floated
light as moths among the branches
of the perfect trees.”
On her death anniversary today, let me recall these poignant words of her;
“When it's over, I want to say all my life
I was a bride married to amazement.
I was the bridegroom, taking the world into my arms.”

19/01/25, 8:33 am - Dr Raguram: Tulips are native to Central Asia, particularly the mountainous regions of Turkey. They were introduced to the Netherlands in the 15th century from the Ottoman Empire and the flower has been a Dutch icon ever since. In the 17th century, tulips became so valuable that they caused a craze known as "tulip mania". People traded valuables and paid huge amount of money for tulips. It is often cited as an example of greed, excess, with the prices of flower bulbs reaching extraordinary heights fuelled by crowd psychology. Unfortunately, the bubble burst, leading to what historians now call the first economic bubble in history. 
In Persian folklore, the first tulip is said to have bloomed from the blood of star crossed lovers, Farhad and Shirin, in a tale reminiscent of the infamous Romeo and Juliet. The first recorded mention of the tulip in human history comes from the Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam;
“As then the Tulip for her morning sup
Of Heav'nly Vintage from the soil looks up,
 Do you devoutly do the like, till Heav'n
To Earth invert you—like an empty Cup.” 
The 13th-century Persian poet Saadi Shirazi often referenced tulips in his writings.;
“Perhaps the tulip know the fickleness
Of Fortune's smile, for on her stalk's green shaft
She bears a wine cup through the wilderness.” 
Poet Allameh Muhammad Iqbal, urged to “create poetry from the silence of tulips and roses,” and wrote;
“My heart is restless, 
Like the west wind in a field of tulips. 
The moment my eyes light upon a pretty face, 
My heart begins to long for one prettier still.”
The genus Tulipa comprises around 75 species, each contributing to the tulip’s rich tapestry of forms and colours. This particular one I saw in Filoli Historic Garden in San Francisco is called ‘Lady Tulip.’
(The start of tulip season is celebrated during the third saturday in January in Netherlands as the ‘National Tulip Day’. This year it was dedicated to Amsterdam’s 750th anniversary. ) 
Dr Raguram

20/01/25, 9:21 am - Dr Raguram: Disability is often associated with the wheelchair. in 2004 Annie Hopkins who was physically impaired, created the “wheelchair heart symbol” while she was an undergraduate student at the University of Illinois. Annie felt that by replacing the wheel with a heart, the stigma associated with the wheelchair will also be removed. She considered it is a symbol of society accepting people with disabilities as equals and a symbol that people with disabilities accept their challenges and embrace them, whole heartedly. Her slogan was 3E; “Embrace diversity. Educate your community. Empower each other.” 
Annie passed away at a young age in 2009 and her legacy is kept alive by celebrating January 20th as the ‘International Day of Acceptance.’ 
Unfortunately, the reality on the ground in India is an unsettling one. In spite of legal provisions about the rights of persons with disabilities, they continue to face discrimination. The disabled are the invisible citizens of India. The state has failed them. Even access to common facilities is a distant dream. Lack of mobility continues to be a major barrier and it becomes very difficult for people with disabilities to navigate due sparse ramps in public places. 
Any one of us can become disabled at any point in our lives and at that moment what we’ll seek is some form of acceptance by the society around us, which often can prove to be elusive. Few years ago, a bright young medical graduate sought my help. When he was young, his right hand had to be amputated when he tried to retrieve a kite from the power line. Undeterred by it, he learnt to write and perform actions of everyday life with his left hand. Though he secured a very high rank in CET examinations for post graduate courses, he was denied the opportunity as he was considered physically unfit to pursue postgraduate studies. He pleaded with the authorities that he will choose a discipline which doesn’t involve use of his right hand, but all his pleas fell on deaf years. He was devastated. Recouping from it, he wrote the competitive exams to go to US and not surprisingly scored very well. Once he went to US, he did his psychiatry residency and now occupies an important position in one of the committees of the American Psychiatric Society. He took inspiration from Stephen Hawking, who observed, "My advice to other disabled people would be, concentrate on things your disability doesn't prevent you doing well, and don't regret the things it interferes with. Don't be disabled in spirit."

26/01/25, 9:27 am - Dr Raguram: Plato’s ‘Republic’ is perhaps the most important philosophical work dating back to thousands of years. In it, I am particularly drawn to the passages from the ‘Allegory of the Cave.’  It challenges us to question our perceptions and seek truth beyond appearances. 
The story is told as a dialogue between philosophers Glaucon and Socrates, as narrated by Socrates. A group of prisoners live in a cave. A bright fire is burning inside prevents them from escaping. They spend their time watching a series of people they can't see as projected shadows in the wall in front of them. Since they have lived there since early childhood, they believe this to be their world. However, one prisoner manages to escape, and somebody drags another one and they come out into the real world. Once they escape the Cave, they are upset because their eyes burn in the overwhelming sunlight. But eventually, their eyes adjust, and they see the world for what it is, a new reality. They feel that if they try to go back into the Cave to rescue other prisoners, they would not be able to do it as their eyes, having adjusted to the sunlight, would not be able to see in the darkness of the Cave. 
Plato points out that our senses can often be deceiving, and what we perceive as reality might only be the shadows of the true world. Though stepping out of the cave and gaining new knowledge can be initially painful and disorienting, it opens up new avenues which facilitate deeper understanding beyond what appears on the surface.  Plato urges us to push the boundaries of knowledge and expand its realms. It is a powerful and enduring metaphor to live by.  
Plato's Allegory of the Cave is so relevant now, providing us a compelling analogy, and warning, of the dangers of social media. It highlights how social media can create a distorted sense of reality, reinforce existing biases, influence us through external forces, lead to addiction, and disconnect individuals from reality.

27/01/25, 10:53 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
27/01/25, 10:53 am - Dr Raguram: I was listening to Mozart’s Sonata for Two Pianos in D Major (K448). It’s interlocking melodies had an inexplicable soothing effect on me. Curious to find out more about the impact of listening to it, I searched the net and came across “the Mozart effect”. It refers to the observation that people notice brief,10-15 minutes, improvements in visual-spatial reasoning after listening to it. So impressed with this finding, in 1998, Georgia governor Zell Miller launched a program to distribute classical music CDs to every new-born in his state. 
The moot question is whether the noticed impact is solely due to this particular composition of Mozart. Researchers have noticed that other types of music, including rock music, can produce similar results. So the effect seemed to depend on the kind of music that has a particular emotional impact and not on listening to Mozart’s sonata specifically. 
On the other hand, there is growing evidence for the efficacy of Mozart’s Sonata for Two Pianos in D Major (K448), at reducing ictal and interictal epileptiform activity, especially in those with refractory seizures. This is often referred to as Mozart K448 effect. Little is known about the mechanism underlying this beneficial for persons with epilepsy. Nevertheless, that Mozart can bring relief to refractory epilepsy patients must be music to their ears!

29/01/25, 9:02 am - Dr Raguram: Anton Chekhov, incorporated themes related to psychiatry into many of his works, particularly in War No. 6". It is a remarkable and thought-provoking short story.
Dr Ragin is the medical superintendent of a hospital in a small provincial town. Though he is a compassionate, caring physician, he finds himself unable to effect any meaningful changes in the system and is quite disillusioned. He starts talking to Gromov a patient in the section of the hospital which for the mentally ill.  Gromov, challenges many of Ragin’s views, “You're conversant with reality only in theory. And why is it you despise suffering, why don't you ever feel surprise?” Gromov himself was labelled as being mentally ill and incarcerated due to his outspoken views about society and he astutely observes “sanity is a precious illusion, a fragile membrane between us and the void.”
As Ragin starts spending more and more time with Gromov, authorities start suspecting his sanity and he is advised to go on vacation. On his return, he finds himself marginalized in the hospital and starts isolating himself. The changes in his behaviour convince the authorities that Gromov has himself become insane and he is forcefully committed as the sixth patient in the ward for psychiatric patients. Unable to bear this, he attempts to escape and is beaten by an attendant. He dies the next day.
Chekhov deftly explores the boundaries between sanity and insanity and questions the validity of the practices employed within the healthcare system to label as mental illness, behaviours which do not conform to the expectations and standards of the society. Chekhov narrates with much sensitivity the isolation, despair and the sense of alienation faced by the patients in Ward 6, “the walls of Ward No. 6 are not made of bricks, but of despair and forgotten dreams…. Its  walls speak volumes, if only we would listen.”
It is a sombre tale of the travails of the human psyche. It is not merely a critique of institutionalization and the dehumanization experienced by patients in the mental health care system but also a poignant examination of the depths of human suffering. It raises important philosophical questions about the nature of reality, the meaning of life, and the inherent loneliness and suffering that individuals grapple with at some time in their lives.
As Chekhov writes, “We are all inmates of our own minds, forever locked in the prison of our thoughts…in the darkest corners of our minds, madness lurks, waiting to claim us.”

01/02/25, 7:07 pm - Dr Raguram: In her budget proposals today, the FM announced the formation of a Nuclear Energy Mission with an outlay of Rs 20,000 crore on the background of continuing concerns about the safety of nuclear energy. 
Hiroshima opened our eyes to the enduring impact of the nuclear fallout. One of the most incisive accounts about the aftermath of the horrific event is a small book of essays ‘Hiroshima Notes’, by the Nobel Laureate Kenzaburo Oe. Prior to his visit to Hiroshima, Oe had a son who was born with brain hernia and he had great difficulty in coming to terms with it. However, his perspective about his son underwent a significant transformation after the visit. The astonishing bravery of the Hibakusha, atomic bomb survivors filled him with shame about his own attitude to his son. When the agonized victims had every reason to commit suicide but did not, when the doctors had every reason to give up but never faltered in trying to heal and comfort their patients, how could he deny the travails of his very own son?
Hikari, his son, had severe deficits and was mostly unresponsive to events around him. One day, much to the astonishment of the parents, he began responding to the sound of a wild bird’s call coming from the television. They bought a recording of wild birds’ calls, and played it in the room throughout the day. Eventually, Hikari learned to remember these bird calls and call out their names too. Encouraged by this, his mother started playing music by Mozart, Beethoven and noticed that Hikari had an intense interest in listening to them. The parents arranged for a piano teacher, and instead of speaking, Ōe began to express his feelings in music and learnt to transfer those chords through writing in spite of difficulties in hand eye coordination. Slowly, over time, Hikari started composing music in his head, without a piano, at the age of 13, drawing upon the vast array of notes stored in the depths of his memory. He composed a piece for a school event at age 18 and started performing in small concerts. He released his first album, “Music of Hikari Ōe”, when he was just 29. The album sold over a million copies and won Japan's top prize for classical Japanese music. He became famous even before his father won the Nobel Prize. Today, Hikari is Japan’s most famous savant composer. He can recognize and recall any piece of music he has ever heard and transcribe it from memory. It is a remarkable example of artistic expression despite overwhelming deficits and handicaps. 
Kenzaburo chose to commit himself to cherish and nurture a brain-damaged son. This choice replenished him, giving him new power and creative direction and even a sort of spiritual meaning for a confirmed agnostic. “I felt I was reborn,” he remarked, “If we can live through our difficulties, we can find a new dimension in life.”

02/02/25, 10:40 am - Dr Raguram: Today is Vasant Panchami, the most picturesque season which lends itself to beautiful descriptions across varied literary genres. It is a symbol of hope and fresh start. In ‘Ritusamhara’, Kalidasa writes, 
"Oh, dear, in Vasanta, Spring, trees are with flowers and waters are with lotuses, hence the breezes are agreeably fragrant with the fragrance of those flowers, thereby the eventides are comfortable and even the daytimes are pleasant with those fragrant breezes.”
There is a wonderful shabad ‘Dekh Phool Phool Phool’ by Guru Arjan Dev in Raag Basant on Ang 1185 of Sri Guru Granth Sahib. The literal translation is ‘Look, the flowers are blooming,’ but the deeper meaning is about observing the transformative power of nature and applying that concept to one's own spiritual growth. It is a call to appreciate the divine presence in all creation, especially through the imagery of blooming flowers symbolizing the flourishing of inner beauty.  
“Behold the flowers flowering, and the blossoms blossoming forth!
Renounce and abandon your egotism.
Grasp hold of His Lotus Feet.
You meet with God, O blessed one.
O my mind, remain conscious of the Waheguru Almighty.
The tender young plants smell so good, while others remain like dry wood.
The season of spring has come; it blossoms forth luxuriantly.
Now, the Dark Age of Kali Yuga has come. 
Plant the seed of Waheguru’s Naam, the Name of the One Lord. 
It is not the season to plant other seeds. 
Do not wander lost in doubt and delusion. 
One finds Waheguru the Almighty with Guru’s help
O mortal, this is the season of the Naam. 
Nanak utters the Glorious Praises of the Lord Waheguru.”

03/02/25, 7:20 pm - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
03/02/25, 7:20 pm - Dr Raguram: Norman Rockwell (3 February 1894 - 8 November 1978), is considered by many to be one of America's greatest artists. He was a master storyteller via canvas and paint and created more than 300 covers for The Saturday Evening Post. One day we made our way through the scenic Berkshire countryside to the Norman Rockwell museum which is situated in Stockbridge. It is set in a beautiful 36-acre site overlooking the Housatonic River Valley. Norman Rockwell's home and studio are also located in the museum grounds. The museum houses the world’s largest collection of Rockwell’s works, including more than five hundred of his original paintings. 
As I was walking through its carefully curated collections, I was drawn to one particular painting, ‘The Triple Self Portrait’.  Self-portraitures are the original selfies! It captures a version of how the artist sees himself/herself. As Frieda Kahlo observed, “I paint myself because, I am so often alone, because I am the person I know best.” The master of self-portrait Rembrandt, painted hundreds of his own images on canvas. Artists often paint themselves by looking at the mirror. Hence you don’t see their hands, only their faces on the canvas.
Rockwell’s self-portrait is different. There are three Rockwells in the painting. One is seated at the easel with his back to the viewer. The other is the painted image of himself as seen in the mirror and then there is a drawing of him in the canvas. It is essentially Rockwell painting a portrait of himself painting a portrait of him painting a portrait of himself painting a portrait of him. Actually there are more! When I looked carefully at the top left hand side of the canvas there are least four drawings of himself! Each one of these self-portraits seem to have a distinctive individuality of their own. In the process, the artist is also paying tribute to some masters of self-portraiture like Rembrandt, Vincent van Gogh and Picasso whose faces are seen on the right edge of the easel. 
I personally feel that through this intricate composition Rockwell seems to draw attention to the dynamic nature of identity. The truth is that all of us have multiple identities, within a single self. We all have many identities, some fixed and some fluid, that help us make sense of ourselves and our experiences in the world. As Walt Whitman articulated beautifully, “I am large, I contain multitudes.”
(Incidentally this image is a photograph I took while watching the ‘The Triple Self Portrait.’)

09/02/25, 5:55 pm - Dr Raguram: In the place where we stay, we hardly hear the loud, harsh, repetitive "caw" sound of the crows. Its place has been taken over by the prolonged ‘cooing’ sound of hordes of common pigeons. There could be many reasons for the seemingly declining population of crows in Indian cities. Even though crows seem to be rather scarce, they have made their presence in the works of many creative artists. Recalling two of them…
Mahakavi Bharathiyar sought the formless divine presence in the shining plumage of the crow in his poem “Kaakai Siraginile." It is one of his most beautiful poem; 
காக்கைச்  சிறகினிலே நந்தலாலா-நின்றன் 
கரியநிறந் தோன்றுதையே நந்தலாலா
“In the shining dark feather of a crow I see your radiant presence, Nandalala."
RK Laxman whose death anniversary is today, was besotted with crows. They were the subjects of some of his most wonderful drawings. He declared that crows were far more intelligent than human beings. In his words, " I am also very fond of crows and have painted hundreds of them – singly and in groups. I have been fascinated with the crow from my childhood. I like its colours and how it contrasts with everything. It is a very intelligent bird and has tremendous character; in fact, the common crow is a very uncommon bird. As a child, crow attracted me more than any other bird because it was alive on the landscape."
Both of them have flown away, but the crows linger on in their works for us to cherish.

12/02/25, 10:37 am - Dr Raguram: This majestic sculpture of Subrahmanya is at the Kudimiyamalai temple in Pudukottai district. The twelve handed Lord is shown seated with his left leg folded, on a peacock. The right hand is depicted in Abhaya Mudra and the left hand in Varada Mudra. The Makara Thoranam encircling the beautifully carved sculpture is adorned with a Kirti Mukha on top.
The word ‘Subrahmanya’ itself means the One who originated from ‘Brahman’ in joy and is inseparable from the Bliss of the ultimate Reality. He is the effulgence of Brahma. Adi Shankara composed ‘Subrahmanya Bhujangam’ in praise of the Lord;
मयूराधिरूढं महावाक्यगूढं
मनोहारिदेहं महच्चित्तगेहम् ।
महीदेवदेवं महावेदभावं
महादेवबालं भजे लोकपालम् ॥३॥
Salutations to Sri Subrahmanya mounted on a peacock representing the deepest Secret of the Upanishadic Maha Vakyas,
Whose beautiful body dwells within the great heart of divine Consciousness,
Who is the great god of the devas and conveys great Vedas,
I worship that son of Mahadeva, who is the Protector of the World.
Subrahmanya is worshipped by different names, like Skanda, Kartikeya, Subrahmanya, Sanat Kumara, Swami, Muragan, Shanmukha or Arumugha, Swaminatha, Guru Guha and so on. He is worshiped as the king of serpents, too. His worship waned over time in northern India where he is regarded primarily as Kartikeya and Murugan eventually found his way back into the Tamil heartland, where he began his journey as Seyon many centuries ago during the Sangam era. During this period, the land was classified into five types, according to its primary geographical feature or tinais. These were Mullai (forest land), Marutham (agricultural land), Neithal (coastal land), Paalai (dry, arid land), and Kurinji (hilly land). Each of them was associated with a guardian god who and it was Seyon (or Murugan) in Kurinchi. The earliest poem of the Sangam Age, Thirumurugatrupadai, is dedicated to the glory of Murugan, . The momentum was sustained by Arunagirinathar, who composed Thiruppugal, Devaraya Swamigal who penned the popular hymn Kanda Sasthi Kavasam and many other savants. 
Thai Pusam was celebrated with much fervour yesterday in Tamil Nadu, especially in Thiruchendur, where the final battle between Murugan and the demon king Surapadman is said to have taken place. Armed with a mighty vel (spear) given by Goddess Parvati, Murugan confronted Surapadman, who transformed into a massive tree. Murugan struck the tree with his spear, splitting it into two halves and vanquished Surapadman who sought forgiveness from the Lord. Murugan pardoned him and transformed his two halves into a rooster and a peacock. The rooster became his banner and the peacock became his vahana.

14/02/25, 8:00 am - Dr Raguram: Love is in the air once again and let us cast our glance beyond red roses and chocolates and delve deeper to unearth its roots in the vast and vibrant tapestry of Indian culture. 
Rig Veda in Nasadiya Sukta comments on the origin of the universe, wherein desire is recognized as the primal source:
तम॑ आसी॒त्तम॑सा गू॒ळ्हमग्रे॑ऽप्रके॒तं स॑लि॒लं सर्व॑मा इ॒दं।
तु॒च्छ्येना॒भ्वपि॑हितं॒ यदासी॒त्तप॑स॒स्तन्म॑हि॒ना जा॑य॒तैकं॑
काम॒स्तदग्रे॒ सम॑वर्त॒ताधि॒ मन॑सो॒ रेत॑: प्रथ॒मं यदासी॑त्।
स॒तो बन्धु॒मस॑ति॒ निर॑विन्दन् हृ॒दि प्र॒तीष्या॑ क॒वयो॑ मनी॒षा॥४॥
There are numerous, often varying interpretations of these verses. In essence it states that “in the beginning, darkness was hidden by darkness with no distinguishing sign; all of this was water. The life force that was covered with emptiness arose through the power of heat. Desire (kama) arose in it in the beginning; that was the first seed of the mind. Wise sages seeking in their hearts, with wisdom, found it to be the bond that connects existence with non-existence.”
It is a phenomenally perceptive way to describe the origin of desire and its influence.
The formless desire had to find a form and the Hindu pantheon found its own cupid, Kamadeva.
Kamadeva and Rati weave a tale beyond mere desire. It's a passionate love story, defying death and destiny. Kamadeva is an alluring deity, wielding a bow and arrow adorned with flowers and bees, capable of kindling the flames of love in any heart. In one notable tale, the gods, seeking to preserve the cosmic equilibrium, wished for Shiva, the Destroyer, to rediscover love. Engrossed in profound meditation, Shiva remained oblivious to such desires. To provoke him, Kamadeva took action, striking the meditative god with an arrow of love. The repercussions of this act were unexpected. Shiva, disturbed from his deep meditation, became enraged. He activated the formidable power of his third eye, reducing Kama to ashes. Overwhelmed with grief, Rati fell at the feet of the Lord and beseeched him to spare her husband. Touched by her desperate pleas, Shiva revoked his actions and brought Kamadeva back to life, with a rider that he would be formless from that day onwards. Though remaining unseen, he wields his arrow bursting with blossoming flowers and bees to kindle and awaken the spirit of love in humans. 
In verse 6 of Saundarya Lahari, Adi Shankaracharya writes:
धनुः पौष्पं मौर्वी मधुकरमयी पञ्च विशिखाः
वसन्तः सामन्तो मलयमरु-दायोधन-रथः ।
तथाप्येकः सर्वं हिमगिरिसुते कामपि कृपां
अपाङ्गात्ते लब्ध्वा जगदिद-मनङ्गो विजयते
“Oh ,daughter of the mountain of ice,
With a bow made of flowers,
Bow string made of honey bees,
Five arrows made of only tender flowers,
With spring as his minister,
And riding on the chariot of breeze from Malaya mountains
The god of love who does not have a body,
Gets the sideways glance of your holy eyes,
And is able to win all the world alone.”
This sculpture from Khajuraho has beautifully captured the rapturous expression of love in Kamadeva and Rati.

15/02/25, 8:57 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
15/02/25, 8:57 am - Dr Raguram: We relate and discover the world around us in different ways. Artists express it through subjective, intuitive approaches whereas the scientist relies on objective, measurable methods. Both art and science venture into the frontiers of the unknown, exploring and trying to grasp its essence. Galileo, whose birthday is today, blended these two perspectives remarkably in his works. 
As a youngster, he was trained in music and became adept at the lute. He also had a keen eye and was quite skilful in drawing. Galileo emphasized on a methodical approach to the study of the universe, and inspired the modern scientific method that remains a bedrock of scientific inquiry even now. He was the first man to raise a telescope to the skies and see beyond the limited boundaries of the Catholic Church. To his great dismay, he was ordered to stop believing what he could see with his own eyes. He was summoned to see the Pope, tried by the Papal court, and was condemned to spend the rest of his life in his house under armed guard. After the Inquisition, overwhelmed with the fear of being burned at the stake, Galileo recanted his theories and writings, asked for forgiveness and his life was spared. He spent much of his final years, blind and ailing. In those dark days, the aging scientist again found solace in his lute. 
Galileo utilized a scientist’s keen eye to discern the secrets of the universe, and an artist’s to make them intelligible to the world. The epitaph on his tombstone succinctly summarizes his work, “But The Earth Does Move.”
Galileo lived in a period where the church was dominant and people blindly followed their ideologies while the church was afraid that his radical discovery would change the world order. Bertolt Brecht wrote a brilliant play, ’Life of Galileo’ in which through the story of Galileo he wanted the audience to question the role of totalitarianism and its impact on scientific endeavours. It is a truism that the scientific community is a part of the structure of the government and its orientation and survival depends on the power and ideological framework of the government. Galileo’s life is a stark reminder that it is an unremitting struggle to protect science from religious chauvinism and the power of those who govern.

18/02/25, 8:34 am - Dr Raguram: Saints and seers have drawn inspiration and spiritual knowledge from objects of nature. Often our spiritual journey has been described by mystics as the flight of a bird.
Birds played a crucial role in Sri Ramakrishna’s life. When he was a six-year-old, he was walking along the fields and suddenly the sky was overcast with thick black clouds. A flock of white birds flew across the clouds. When Sri Ramakrishna saw this, (his name was Gadadhar then), he was totally absorbed in the sight, was motionless and he became unconscious. Later on he said, “That was my first ecstasy.” It was his first spiritual, mystic experience which caste its impact in many of his sayings & teachings.
In one of the prayer meetings, he narrated a story, “A bird sat on the mast of a ship. When the ship sailed through the mouth of the Ganges into the 'black waters' of the ocean, the bird failed to notice the fact. When it finally became aware of the ocean, it left the mast and flew north in search of land. But it found no limit to the water and so returned. After resting a while it flew south. There too it found no limit to the water. Panting for breath the bird returned to the mast. Again, after resting a while, it flew east and then west. Finding no limit to the water in any direction, at last it settled down on the mast of the ship. What a man seeks is very near him. Still he wanders about from place to place. As long as a man feels that God is 'there', he is ignorant. But he attains knowledge when he feels that God is 'here'.”
There was an interesting incident when Sri Ramakrishna mentioned that a devotee is like a ‘chataka’ bird. This bird will drink only rainwater, as it falls from the clouds. So it is always watching the sky. As the bird watches the sky, so the devotees always look to God to appease the thirst of learning. Naren, (Swami Vivekananda) was listening and he exclaimed: "Sir, though it is the common belief that the ‘chataka’ bird drinks only rainwater, it is not a fact that it does not take other kinds of water. I have seen these birds drink water from rivers and ponds." Sri Ramakrishna said: "Is that so? Do they drink like other birds? Then I am mistaken. If you have seen it, then there is no doubt about it." But Sri Ramakrishna, was a little disturbed, "If I am mistaken in this, then I may also be mistaken in other ways too." After a few days Naren called Sri Ramakrishna and said: "Sir, see a ‘chataka’ bird is drinking Ganga water." Sri Ramakrishna rushed out of the room and said: "Where? Where?" When they came near the spot, what they saw was just a small bat. Sri Ramakrishna laughed and said: "You rogue; it is a bat. You have given me so much trouble for nothing. Now I shall be wiser and not believe everything you say!”
Sri Ramakrishna also used the analogy of the mythical ‘Homa Bird’ to explain the intense renunciation and spiritual aspiration of the seeker. The bird lives quite high up in the sky and lays egg at that height. Because of the height the egg keeps falling for many days.  While falling, it hatches and the chick continues to fall.  This goes on for many days. One day the chick opens its eyes and realizes about the impending death if it hits the ground.  Then it gives a shrill cry and shoots up towards its mother. It keeps going in the upward direction and does not look behind. Sri Ramakrishna used to call Naren who later became Swami Vivekananda as a ‘Homa Bird.’ 
When I looked at the logo of Ramakrisha Math (which was designed by Swami Vivekananda), I was struck with its striking similarity with the logo of my alma mater, NIMHANS, except for the serpent encircling it. It is believed that when milk diluted with water is given to the swan, it sips only the milk, leaving the water behind. Water represents ignorance and the milk symbolizes knowledge. The image of the swan signifies the discerning mind that is in pursuit of the Real.
According to the ancient tradition, ascetics who strive to gain liberation are classified into four classes. They are kuṭīcakas, bahūdakas, haṃsas and paramahaṃsas. Paramahamsa refers to the highest level of spiritual development of an enlightened, exalted soul.
(Penned on the birthday of Sri Ramakrishna Paramahamsa)
Dr Raguram

24/02/25, 10:13 am - Dr Raguram: Ibn Battuta was a medieval Muslim explorer, scholar and an intrepid traveller. He began his travels in the 14th century when he was just 20 years old and over the course of the next 29 years he travelled about 75,000 miles, visiting 44 countries. Near the end of Ibn Battuta's life, the Sultan of Morocco insisted that he dictate the story of his travels and today we can read translations of that account, which is generally referred to as Ibn Battuta’s ‘Rihla’, or journey. It is available online and makes a fascinating read. 
Ibn Battuta’s travels in India were mostly in the north and towards the end of his stay, he came down to the Malabar coast. When I was reading about the accounts of his sojourn in the Malabar coast, I was astonished by his keen sense of observation about people and places. He gives an accurate description of the most important produce of the region, pepper.
“The pepper-bushes look like vines. The natives plant them opposite the coco-nut trees around which the pepper-bushes climb like vines; but they have no tendrils ('aslūj) as in the case of vines. The leaves of the bush look like leaves of asafoetida and also like the leaves of the blackberry bush. The pepper-bush bears small bunches of fruit, the grains of which resemble those of abūqinnina as long as they are green. When autumn comes the pepper is plucked and exposed on reed-mats to the sun just as is done with grapes when they are turned into raisins. It is continually turned round until it is completely dry and becomes black; then it is sold to the merchants. The common people in our country think that it is roasted by the fire, whence the wrinkles on the pepper-grains come. But it is not so, since the wrinkles are caused by the sun. I saw the pepper grains in the city of Calicut (Qālıqül) emptied out into bushels as is done with the millet in our country.”
Reading ‘Rihla’ I felt as if I was following the footsteps of this peripatetic traveller who remarked, “traveling, it leaves you speechless, then turns you into a storyteller”
(Ibun Battuta born on 24 February 1304, Tangier, Morocco)

25/02/25, 8:17 am - Dr Raguram: Pain and distress is inevitable as we course along in life. It is our innate vulnerability. Sometimes it results in withdrawal from the world outside of us. On those occasions an overwhelming sense of isolation can envelop us. Artists give expression to it in myriad ways. Visually, Vincent van Gogh conveyed those moments through his arresting palette. Many poets and writers narrated it powerfully in their works. And talented musicians strum our chords within, with such experiences.
Ahalya and myself are avid aficionados of Simon and Garfunkel. Today, by chance we listened to the epochal song, ‘I Am a Rock’. The heartfelt lyrics of Paul Simon are embedded in sublime music in his mellifluous voice. It is sheer poetry. Even though there is no particular rhyming scheme, there are lines that significantly rhyme. Each verse peels back another layer of deeper meaning. 
‘I Am a Rock’ is more than just a song; it’s a window into the soul of a remarkably talented artist who expresses the indefinable feeling of the human need to retreat inward in a most poignant manner. 
I AM A ROCK By Paul Simon
A winter's day
In a deep and dark December
I am alone
Gazing from my window to the streets below
On a freshly fallen silent shroud of snow
I am a rock I am an island
I've built walls
A fortress deep and mighty
That none may penetrate
I have no need of friendship, friendship causes pain
It's laughter and it's loving I disdain
I am a rock I am an island
Don't talk of love
Well I've heard the word before
It's sleeping in my memory
I won't disturb the slumber of feelings that have died
If I never loved I never would have cried
I am a rock I am an island
I have my books
And my poetry to protect me
I am shielded in my armor
Hiding in my room safe within my womb
I touch no one and no one touches me
I am a rock I am an island
And a rock feels no pain
And an island never cries

26/02/25, 9:43 am - Dr Raguram: Mahashivaratri commemorates the wedding of Shiva and Parvati. It has profound spiritual, cultural, and philosophical significance as it venerates the holy union of two greatest forces of the universe; masculine and feminine energies.
Cave 21 in Ellora, also known as Rameshwara Cave, is located midway between Cave 16 and 29. and was excavated in the late 6th century AD. It is dedicated to Lord Siva and a Nandi is placed just in front of the cave over a raised platform. Stunning sculptures adorn the walls of the huge mantapa. On the northern wall, there is a beautiful panel which depicts the marriage of Shiva and Parvati. Shiva is seen holding the hands of Parvati who is tilting her head toward him bashfully. Vishnu and Lakshmi are seen to the left and Brahma is officiating the marriage on the bottom right. On top on either side are celestial beings and divinities watching the holy union. 
Kalidasa begins his famous epic poem Raghuvamsa with this verse 
वागर्थाविव संपृक्तौ वागर्थप्रतिपत्तये ।
जगतः पितरौ वन्दे पार्वतीपरमेश्वरौ ।।
“I bow to the mother and father of the world, Parvati and Parmesvara (Shiva), who are inseparably conjoined, just like a word and its meaning are inseparably bonded.”

27/02/25, 8:42 am - Dr Raguram: We all long for the home. It is less a physical space than a place filled with enduring memories. Those memories never fade completely and have the power to catapult us back through time. Its centripetal force has an irresistible allure. 
Sometimes, home can be elusive. Particularly when one is living far away and keeps longing to return to a land which is in throes of conflict. Often there is a deep yearning for that familiar, comforting place, especially when the situation doesn’t fulfil the need to return. There is a beautiful Welsh word ‘Hiraeth’ that has no direct English translation. It refers to a homesickness tinged with grief and sadness.  A poet who gave expression to that feeling most powerfully in modern times was Mahmoud Darwish, a Palestinian author. He spent most of his time as a refugee and spent his final days in the US.  Mahmoud Darwish died on 9 August 2008 and his mortal remains were buried next to the Palace of Culture at Ramallah.
Mahmoud Darwish’s “To My Mother” is one of the most poignant poems I have ever read and the following lines resonate deeply within. 
“I am old
Give me back the stars of childhood
That I may chart the homeward quest
Back with the migrant birds,
Back to your awaiting nest.”
I was reminded of these lines when I saw a sunbird making frequent sorties to feed and nurture it’s chick. The chick would be quiet most of the time and the moment she heard the fluttering wings of the mother, would start making a low pitched chirping noises. In a few days, as its wings grow stronger, it will fly away from the nest but memories of the nest would remain deeply etched in its being.

03/03/25, 9:18 am - Dr Raguram: Travels in India are always a revelation. Ahalya and myself just returned after savouring some of the most beautiful sculptures in two monuments: Chinthala Venkataramana Swamy and Bugga Ramalingeswara Swamy temples in Tadapatri. Tadapatri is small little town in the hinterlands of Andhra Pradesh and off the tourist radar. Both places which are ASI monuments, are adorned with exquisite sculptures. I will be posting them in detail later.
One of my passions in the past decade has been to see and record mural paintings in South India. After the Cholas, Vijayanagara and Nayak kings had a distinct penchant to embellish the places of worship with stunning paintings, usually done with vegetable dyes. I have documented several of these treasures during our travels.
Since both these temples were built during the Vijayanagara period I was keen to see whether there were some murals on the ceilings of the structures. It was much akin to a search for an elusive bird. To my great dismay in both places, the plaster has fallen off from the ceiling or has been painted over. After a fervent and losing struggle, I spotted this one. It portrays a bejewelled, saree clad lady. The ornamentation and attention to detail was quite striking. Despite the ravages of time and callous neglect, there was a sempiternal charm that percolated through the peeling layers of paint.
Beauty fades but often the soul shines on…
(The sole remnant of a mural from the ceiling of Chinthala Venkataramana Swamy temple at Tadapatri)

04/03/25, 9:34 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
04/03/25, 9:34 am - Dr Raguram: I was not aware of the teachings of Baba Shaikh Farid till I read the book about him edited by Prof Gurbachan Singh Talib. Baba Farid was a great Sufi mystic, teacher and poet. He was born in the month of Ramadan in the year 1173 CE at a place near Multan called Kotheval.  He was named after the Sufi poet Fariduddin Attar. Farid in Arabic language means 'Unique'. He came to be known also as Shakarganj or Ganj-i-Shakar (Treasury of Sugar). There is an interesting story behind this nickname. Farid’s mother Qarsum Bibi, used to place a small packet of sugar under the prayer mat as a reward for the child to say his prayers regularly. Once she forgot to put it under the mat. To her great surprise a packet of sugar appeared in the usual place. Following this miracle, he came to be known as ‘Shakarganj.’ Another explanation attributes the title 'Shakarganj' to the blessing which Farid received from his spiritual teacher, Khwaja Qutubuddin Bakhtiyar Kaki (the famous Qutb Minar in Delhi was built in his name) who praised the sweetness of Farid’s disposition and remarked; "You shall be sweet like sugar."
There is a beautiful story attributed to Baba Farid;
“Once a king came to see him. He had brought a present for Farid. It was a beautiful pair of scissors, golden, studded with diamonds. It was very valuable, rare and unique. He touched Farid’s feet and gave him the scissors. Farid looked at it and gave it back to the king, and said, “Sir, many many thanks for the present that you have brought. It is a beautiful thing, but utterly useless for me. It will be better if you can give me a needle. Scissors I don’t need: a needle will do.” The king said, “I don’t understand. If you need a needle, you will need scissors too.” Farid said, “I don’t need scissors because scissors cut things apart. I need a needle because it can put things together. My whole teaching is based on love, bringing people together. I need a needle so that I can stitch them together. The scissors are useless; they cut, they disconnect. Next time when you come, just an ordinary needle will be enough”.
These lines are so pertinent now in a world brimming with growing distrust. Too often we underestimate the power of compassion that can bind us together. Let us untether the love deeply buried in our hearts and heal ourselves and the ‘others’.
In Rumi’s eloquent words;
“I will soothe and heal you,
I will bring you roses.
I too have been covered with thorns.” 
Dr Raguram
06/03/25, 9:57 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
06/03/25, 9:57 am - Dr Raguram: Michelangelo famously observed that "Every block of stone has a statue inside it and it is the task of the sculptor to discover it." For him, the process of sculpting involved bringing out the ideal form lurking inside. Each one of us has an ideal self and our aspiration in life is to actualize it. Relationships, especially close, intimate ones like in marriage have an important role in facilitating the emergence of the ideal self in each other. The process would involve identifying qualities in our partners that already exist within them, but remain latent. Like sculpting a statue from marble, couples can gently chip away at each other’s rough edges to reveal their inner beauty. This is often referred to as the ‘Michelangelo Phenomenon.’ Just as Michelangelo saw the process of sculpting as releasing the ideal forms hidden in the marble, close partners sculpt one another to bring out the best in each other. Like the sculptor, the partner doesn't create something out of nothing, he or she brings out qualities that inherently exist.
We all hold visions of our “ideal selves” that long to be realized. Our partners can be the chisels and mallets that gently unveil our inner potential through affirmation and support over the course of a relationship. In this way partners can affirm and empower each other’s growth. 
However, wielding the chisel is a delicate process. When one partner imposes his/her vision of the ‘ideal self’ onto the other, it can lead to deep resentment in the partner, leading onto tremendous strain and distress. There is also the possibility that one might subjugate the real, aspiring self to meet the partner’s expectations. 
We are all capable of breaking free from the limitations that hold us back to discover the beauty that is confined inside of us. A caring, sensitive partner can play a catalysing role in facilitating that process.
In the words of Michelangelo, “I saw the angel in the marble and carved until I set him free”

08/03/25, 8:11 am - Dr Raguram: The Vedic period witnessed the advent of highly intelligent, erudite women seekers. The Rig Veda mentions around 27 to 30 Rishikas or women seers and they were known as Brahmavadinis, women of high scholarship. Brahmavadinis dedicated their entire lives to learning, teaching and spreading knowledge through their tapasya. The 125th hymn from Book 7 of the Rig Veda, the Devi Suktam, is credited to Rishika Vak Ambhrini, the daughter of the great seer Ambhrina. It is also known as Vak Suktam. She is among the most ancient women poets of the world.
The Vak Suktam abounds with divine energy. She has not composed it as one would compose poetry. It is a spontaneous outpouring of her realizations and divine experience. She identifies herself as the Supreme Goddess herself, embodying the divine feminine consciousness. It celebrates the divine feminine, celebrating the cosmic power, nurturing presence, and boundless strength of the goddess. The verses describe Devi as the supreme source of creation and sustenance, embodying qualities of both a fierce protector and a gentle nurturer. Each line acknowledges her presence in all forms of life, as well as her ability to guide us through life’s challenges with grace and resilience. When we chant the Vak Suktam, we align ourselves with this powerful feminine force, energizing our inner strength and resilience. 
अ॒हं राष्ट्री᳚ सं॒गम॑नी॒ वसू᳚नां चिकि॒तुषी᳚ प्रथ॒मा य॒ज्ञिया᳚नाम् ।
तां मा᳚ दे॒वा व्य॑दधुः पुरु॒त्रा भूरि॑स्थात्रां॒ भूर्या᳚ वे॒शयन्᳚तीम् ॥ (Verse3)
“I am the ruling Queen, the authority and amasser of treasures, full of wisdom, first of those who are worthy of worship through Yajna. It is me, the Devas have installed in many places, in many directions, with many homes for me to enter and abide in.”
On this International Women’s Day let us invoke the universal feminine energy that exists within and surrounds us all.

09/03/25, 10:26 am - Dr Raguram: Ukraine's history has been marked by conflict and hardship, with periods of occupation, famine, and war, leaving a "blood-soaked" legacy. It was ruled by various empires, including the Mongols, the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, and the Russian Empire, till it declared independence in 1991.
The tragic history of Ukraine found its expression in many outstanding works of writers and poets who were detained and executed by the Soviet authorities. Prominent among them was Taras Shevchenko, a Ukrainian poet, writer, artist, folklorist, and ethnographer. He is considered as a founder of the modern Ukrainian literature and a major symbol of Ukrainian nationhood. 
In spite of the current disposition of policy makers towards Ukraine, various leaders in USA had honoured Shevchenko and the aspirations of the people of Ukraine. Harry Truman was an honorary head of the Shevchenko Monument Committee. Dwight Eisenhower cleared the way for the monument to be installed in Washington and John F. Kennedy facilitated implementation. In his letter, he called Shevchenko’s poetry a “noble part” of American historical heritage. Lyndon B. Johnson said:  "He was more than a Ukrainian, he was a statesman and citizen of the world. He was more than a poet, he was a valiant crusader for the rights and freedom of men. He used verse to carry on a determined fight for freedom.”
The Taras Shevchenko Memorial is a bronze statue which stands in the Dupont Circle neighbourhood of Washington, D.C. George HW Bush invoked this verse of Shevchenko written more than a century ago which inscribed on the monument:
“Our soul shall never perish,
Freedom knows no dying,
And the greedy cannot harvest
Fields where seas are lying;
Cannot bind the living spirit,
Nor the living word,
Cannot smirch the sacred glory
Of the almighty Lord”

10/03/25, 10:32 am - Dr Raguram: I was listening to a podcast which was a three hour long conversation between podcaster Joe Rogan and Elon Musk. It left me wondering whether he has walked out of the pages of Ayn Rand’s works like ‘Atlas Shrugged" and "The Fountainhead.’
Ayn Rand’s philosophy of “Objectivism” focused on reason over emotion, highlighting Individual self-interest and happiness over collective happiness. Objectivism emphasizes individualism, capitalism, and rational self-interest. Rand observed, “My philosophy, in essence, is the concept of man as a heroic being, with his own happiness as the moral purpose of his life, with productive achievement as his noblest activity, and reason as his only absolute.” Musk has often expressed his admiration for Ayn Rand's writings and has indicated that her ideas resonate with his own views.
Musk undoubtedly is a talented and an inspired innovator. Yet his ruthless selfishness and intellectual precocity is unmistakable, especially in this statement about empathy. Equating empathy with weakness is a perilous perspective. Empathy builds bridges, and the strong ties that bind together society. Lack of empathy can result in dehumanization and fuel brutality. Psychologist Gustave Gilbert, who interviewed Nazi leaders during the Nuremberg trials, observed “It’s the one characteristic that connects all the defendants, a genuine incapacity to feel with their fellow man. Evil, I think, is the absence of empathy.”

18/03/25, 9:59 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
18/03/25, 9:59 am - Dr Raguram: John Updike is a favourite author of mine. I have assiduously devoured most of his large literary oeuvre. He is an astute chronicler of the American middle class, especially in his Rabbit series novels. 
A few years ago, I accidently picked up his little known book, ‘Self-Consciousness: A Memoir’. One of the essays in the books is titled ‘At War with My Skin’, which is a poignant description of his lifelong personal struggle with psoriasis. Writing about a chronic debilitating condition like psoriasis is not an easy task. As Updike reflects, “It pains me to write these pages. They are humiliating —‘scab¬picking,’ to use a term sometimes levelled at modern autobiographical writers.” 
Updike started developing psoriasis when he was just six years old. Both his mother and grandmother were similarly afflicted. Psoriasis is a condition that is not contagious, painful, or debilitating; yet it has the volatility of a disease with an unpredictable fluctuating course.  Often the first response is one of concealment: "Psoriasis keeps you thinking. Strategies of concealment ramify, and self-examination is endless. You are forced to the mirror again and again. Psoriasis compels narcissism, if we can suppose a Narcissus who did not like what he saw." The sufferer feels alienated and pines for relief and cure: "One hates one's abnormal, erupting skin but is led into a brooding, solicitous attention toward it. One hates the nature that has imposed this affliction, but only this same nature can be appealed to for erasure, for cure." 
Updike attributes the reason he became a writer to his psoriasis: “Because of my skin, I counted myself out of any of those jobs – salesman, teacher, financier, movie star – that demand being presentable. What did that leave? Becoming a craftsman of some sort, closeted and unseen – perhaps a cartoonist or a writer, a worker in ink who can hide himself and send out a surrogate presence, a signature that multiplies even while it conceals”. He relates his productivity to psoriasis: “What was my creativity, my relentless need to produce, but a parody of my skin’s overproduction? Was not my shamelessness on the page a distraction from my real shame?”
An illness like psoriasis is a rift in one’s life trajectory. They are like rocks in the quickly moving stream of life which we have to negotiate and cross. Personal narratives as articulated in ‘At War with My Skin’ provide metaphorically, buoys through which individuals in the throes of an ailment chart and steer through the turbulent eddies of the illness-waters that we will all face at some time in our lives. 
Dr Raguram

20/03/25, 9:13 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
20/03/25, 9:13 am - Dr Raguram: Ovid was a Roman poet who lived and worked during the reign of the emperor Augustus. He is widely considered as one of the top three Roman poets, along with Virgil and Horace. He wrote many works, but his most famous one was the ‘Metamorphoses’, which is considered his magnum opus. Ovid's ‘Metamorphoses’ is a book that is challenging to classify as it doesn't have the same sense of cohesive narrative like many other epic poems. It is a collection of approximately 250 sections, written in verse, some of which span many pages while others are much shorter in length. The poems move in chronological order from the creation of the world to the coronation of Julius Caesar. Each section deals with some myths and in each myth, there is a significant change in form, like the metamorphosis of one character into another body or figure. These often provide resolution or closure, as in stories where women, pursued by attackers, transform themselves into birds, trees, or other creatures in order to avoid being abused and exploited. 
It is a daunting task to read the original and I settled for an excellent abridged translation by Ted Hughes. The key undercurrent in the work, as I gather after reading it, is that nothing remains static in life and change is inevitable. Every ending heralds something anew to unfold.
Dr Raguram

The Japanese have a wonderful word, ‘Komorebi’, to describe the dappled light filtering through leaves.

As J Krishnamurti observed, “Love not the shapely branch, nor place its image alone in your heart. It dies away. Love the whole tree; then you will love the shapely branch, the tender and withered leaf, the shy bud and the full-blown flower, the falling petal and the dancing night, the splendid shadow of full love. Ah, love life in its fullness. It knows no decay.” 
(Reflections on the International Day of Forests)

23/03/25, 9:36 am - Dr Raguram: These are times when people are busy on the hedonistic treadmill, testing their prowess in the social media with sheer abandon. The climactic scene of the father tearfully tucking his son’s childhood teddy bear into his bed and apologising to it saying, “Sorry, son, I should’ve done better” is devastating and will remain etched in memory for long.
I strongly feel that it should be widely seen by parents, teachers, educationists and mental health professionals alike.

24/03/25, 9:22 am - Dr Raguram: I first read David Suzuki’s ‘The Sacred Balance: Rediscovering Our Place in Nature’, a decade ago. It is a passionate exploration of our connection with nature that surrounds us and how best to conserve it. He emphasizes that we have to shift our perspective from ‘anthropocentrism to ecocentrism.’ Suzuki links care for the environment to our fundamental human physical, social and spiritual needs. He writes eloquently, “Every breath is a sacrament, an affirmation of our connection with all other living things, a renewal of our link with our ancestors and a contribution to generations yet to come. Our breath is a part of life's breath, the ocean of air that envelopes the earth.” He is deeply concerned about global warming and observes, “We're in a giant car heading towards a brick wall and everyone is arguing over where they're going to sit.”
We all focus on economic growth and worry about GDP. GDP calculations must incorporate environmental costs and benefits and quantify the contribution of the ecosystem in monetary terms, so that we recognize its importance in development. It is time to put ‘eco’ back into economics and in all aspects of our daily lives.

25/03/25, 9:55 am - Dr Raguram: As we were scanning the canopies in Manas National Park, we noticed a flurry of activities. A pair of Malayan Giant Squirrels were leaping across the trees and chasing one another like adept athletes. It was a wonderful sight to them both. After this, one was resting comfortably in a tree branch while the other was going up and down in the tree trunk. I had closer look at both of them. They were more than a foot and half in size with deep brown colour on the back and creamy underparts. There was a distinct black marking below the eyes. I had never seen such a large squirrel before! It is the largest of India’s giant squirrels. It is considered an ‘indicator species of a healthy forest ecosystem.  The Malayan Giant Squirrel is considered as ‘near threatened’ according to IUCN. A study by the Zoological Survey of India has projected that numbers of the Malayan Giant Squirrel could decline by 90% in India by 2050. According to researchers of the study, if conservation efforts are not in place, we may lose the Malayan Giant Squirrel altogether.

27/03/25, 9:04 am - Dr Raguram: On the way back to Guwahati from the Manas National Park, I was keen to have a glimpse of the Greater Adjutant. I had seen them in the huge dump yard on the outskirts of the city several years ago and wrote about them. This time around when we tried to locate the dump yard, we came to know that it has expanded to two sites, indicating the amount of waste generated by the city. With some help from the locals and losing the way often, finally we located the earlier dump yard. Massive piles of rubbish like a small mountain with an overwhelming stench welcome us. The Greater Adjutants were right on top with their unmistakable, tall, imposing presence. Their numbers seemed to be much less compared to our earlier visit. 
The Greater Adjutant is called ‘Garuda’ locally. It is one of the most endangered bird species and its major habitat is in the Brahmaputra valley of Assam. The birds are found mostly in three districts of Assam; Guwahati, Morigaon, and Nagaon. With rapid decline in the wetlands, which are essential for them to forage for food, they are now forced to rely on garbage dumps. Purnima Barman who is affectionately known as “Hargila Baideu”, ‘Stork Sister’, has done remarkable, pioneering work in the conservation of these birds which are deemed to be on the “EDGE” (Evolutionarily Distinct and Globally Endangered) species, close to extinction.
As we were leaving,  the birds were soaring high on the sky, with hopes ensconced in their majestic eight feet wing span.

28/03/25, 11:25 am - Dr Raguram: One of the most vital tenet of mysticism is its call for self-annihilation as an important prerequisite for the ultimate union with the Divine. It emerged in life and writings of two women who lived far apart and could not possibly have known of each other; St Teresa of Avila and Akka Mahadevi. 
St. Teresa of Avila, was a 16th-century Spanish mystic and a Catholic saint, who was born on this date in 1515. She wrote a book, the "Interior Castle" to describe the individual soul's journey towards its unification with God. Reading through it, I was struck by her use of the metaphor that the castle has seven mansions, each representing a different stage of spiritual development. I thought that these seven mansions are akin to transiting through seven planes of consciousness to realize the Divine. St Teresa of Avila provides practical advice and insights as to how prayer, meditation further the path towards the ultimate merger with God. The final stage is one intense ecstasy of realisation of the deepest amalgamation with the Divine. St. Teresa of Avila emphasized that it is only through complete renunciation and total surrender to God, one can experience the Divine. 
Like her, Akka Mahadevi relinquished all worldly possessions, including her clothing, in a radical act of spiritual devotion. This decision was not merely an act of defiance against societal expectations but emerged from profound spiritual convictions. She believed that true devotion to God necessitated annihilation of self and complete detachment from materialistic trappings. Her Vachanas are replete with her deep desire to merge with her beloved Chennamallikarjuna. She writes;
“How can milk swallow ghee and remain separate?
Who can separate fire from the sun’s radiance?
Chennamallikarjuna,
Great One without bounds
seeing how you are hidden within me not separated
I opened my eyes.”
Both St Teresa of Avila and Akka Mahadevi forged an inseparable bond with the God spirit through unflinching devotion and a life of ultimate renunciation, summarized eloquently in a Vachana by Akka Mahadevi;
“Like treasure hidden in the ground, 
like flavour in the fruit, 
like gold in the rock 
and oil in the seed, 
the Absolute is hidden in the heart.”

02/04/25, 9:11 am - Dr Raguram: Literature has provided us with rich insights into the landscape of mental health Through the written word, authors have been able to delve into the depths of the human psyche, providing insights into the inner struggles, triumphs, and vulnerabilities of individuals grappling with mental illness.
I was reading Nikolai Gogol’s powerful story ‘Memoirs of a Madman’, which was published in 1835. The story follows the descent into insanity of Poprishchin, a low-level civil servant who becomes convinced that he is the rightful heir to the Spanish throne; “Spain has a king. He has been found. I am that king. Only this very day did I learn of it. I confess, it came to me suddenly in a flash of lightning. I don’t understand how I could have thought and imagined that I was a titular councillor”. He starts hearing dogs speak to one another. More interestingly, he hears them discussing letters they have written to each other; “I confess, lately I had begun sometimes to hear and see things no one had ever seen or heard before. Ah, you pup! I was very surprised to hear her speak in human language. But later, when I’d thought it over properly, I at once ceased to be surprised”. The hallucinations and delusions became more frequent, he was taken to the hospital; “I think I’m safe in hazarding a guess that I’ve fallen into the hands of the Inquisition, and the person I thought was a minister of state was really the Grand Inquisitor”. His stay in the hospital was not too pleasant as he was subjected to various kinds of physical treatments; “they began dripping cold water on my head. I’ve never experienced such hell before… Judging by all probabilities, I guess I may have fallen into the hands of the Inquisition”.
The story ends on a poignant note; “O mother, mother, save your unhappy son! Let a tear fall on his aching head! See how they torture him! Press the poor orphan to your bosom! He has no rest in this world; they hunt him from place to place. Mother, mother, have pity on your sick child!”
The story is a moving portrayal of Poprishchin’s delusions of grandeur, hallucinations, and finally his complete break with reality. As Ben Okri commented, “The fact of storytelling hints at a fundamental human unease, hints at human imperfection. Where there is perfection there is no story to tell.”
(Nikolai Gogol born on 1st April 1809)

03/04/25, 9:08 am - Dr Raguram: Victoria Chang is a talented young poet and is the Bourne Chair in Poetry at Georgia Tech and also the Director of Poetry@Tech. Georgia Tech has an endowed chair in poetry, one of the few in the country. Its mission statement states the reason of it eloquently, “nothing antithetical in a major university known the world over for its engineering/architecture/computational science/management, and other related subjects of study, also making available to its students writing, literature, and the arts in general. The making of art (let’s use poetry as an example!) is a task that requires a kind of engineering, a kind of architecture, and very real and complex technical skills. Good poems, historically, are made; they don’t flow down the arm of the dreamy poet to the page. Good poems are the result of planning, rigor, attention, intuition, trial and error, discipline, and the luck that sometimes comes when all of the above are applied. A flawless architectural design, an elegant chemical equation, a good poem is supposed to seem simple, spontaneous, fluid. To achieve his or her goals, that precision, that truth, the engineer, the chemist, the architect, the poet usually must work diligently, must sweat blood.” 
In other words, good poems emerge from inspired engineering!
Victoria Chang wrote a wonderful book, “The Trees Witness Everything” and I am particularly drawn to these lines from it;
“Every leaf that falls
never stops falling. I once
thought that leaves were leaves.
Now I think they are feeling,
in search of a place..”

06/04/25, 10:07 am - Dr Raguram: There was once a yaksha, named Suketu, who had no children. Craving for children, he performed a yaga. 12/04/25, 10:04 am - Dr Raguram: Parasrampura is a nondescript village in Jhunjhunu district, near Nawalgarh in the Shekhawati region of Rajasthan. We were keen to see the Chhatri (cenotaph) erected in 1750 in memory of Thakur Shardul Singh which is said to house some of the oldest frescoes of the region. When we reached the place we found it to be overgrown with weeds and poorly maintained. But once we cast our glance inside the dome, we were transported into a magical realm, the likes of which we had never set our eyes on before. Miniature paintings adorned the entire ceiling. Each and every inch was decorated with intricate paintings done in ochre tones. They depicted events in the life of Thakur Shardul Singh, interspersed with episodes of Hindu mythology, especially the penultimate battle of the Ramayana.
During the battle of Lanka, Lakshman was grievously wounded by Indrajit, son of Ravana. Seeing Lakshman was close to death, Jambavan commanded Hanuman to fetch immediately ‘Sanjivani booti’, a powerful medicinal herb that has the power to revive the dead found only on the Dronagiri mountain. Hanuman leapt up and soared through the skies across a great distance to Dronagiri to fetch the life-saving herb. But having reached Dronagiri mountain Hanuman could not identify the plant Sanjivani. As he could not afford to waste time searching for the herb, he quickly tore up part of the whole mountain The villagers of the tiny hamlet of Dronagiri in Uttarakhand, identify a nearby mountain as the mythical Dronagiri mountain mentioned in the Ramayana. But they have a totally different take on this tale. They are angry and refuse to forgive Hanuman for mutilating the right flank of their precious mountain. As per the local beliefs, when Hanuman flew into the region in search of the Sanjivani plant to revive Lakshman, the villagers of Dronagiri did not reveal the identity of the magical mountain to him as it was sacred to them. But time was running out and Lakshman was near death, so Hanuman disguised himself as an old sage and begged an elderly woman in the village to help him identify the magical mountain where the herb grew. The woman took pity on the sage and pointed out the mountain which was thickly populated by various shrubs and trees. Hanuman then proceeded to uproot half of the mountain and carried it away along with the magic herb. The villagers were furious and punished the old woman. Reportedly, since Hanuman destroyed a part of their sacred mountain, the villagers of Dronagiri village do not keep an idol of Hanuman in their homes even today.
This section of the fresco depicts Hanuman carrying the Sanjeevi Parvatha with portrayal of the Thakur Shardul Singh’s court on the left side of the panel.

15/04/25, 9:47 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
15/04/25, 9:47 am - Dr Raguram: Each year, on 15 April, World Art Day is celebrated to draw attention to the links between artistic creations and society and encourage greater awareness of the diversity of artistic expressions. This date was specifically chosen to honour the birthday of Leonardo da Vinci.
The artistic traditions in India has a vast repertoire, comprising of painting, sculpture, architecture, and performing arts. Many of these traditions are deeply rooted in the country's cultural and religious heritage, with styles evolving over time. These art forms have been passed down through generations, with artists often learning their skills from their families. 
Indian mural art, in particular, boasts a rich history dating back to the 2nd century BC, with examples found in various locations across the country, including caves and temples. These murals depict religious and secular themes, reflecting the diverse cultural landscape of India. Different regions have unique mural traditions. Over the years, I have been documenting the mural paintings during the Vijayanagar and later Nayak period 16th through 18th centuries.
On this day, let me draw attention to this enchanting mural dating back to the first half of 18th century in the Ramalinga Vilas Palace at Ramanathapuram. It depicts the celebration of Vasantostava. The king Muthu Vijaya Raghunatha is astride a navanari kunjara (elephant formed by nine women) and his queen is riding panchanari turaga (horse formed by five women). The king is depicted as Manmatha and the queen as Rati and they are shooting flowery arrows at each other.
Nava Nari Kunjara, meaning ‘elephant made of nine women,’ is a recurring motif in Indian art, particularly in Mughal miniature paintings and Pattachitra paintings of Odisha and West Bengal. It depicts an elephant formed from the intertwined figures of nine women, often symbolizing the nine Rasas (emotions) in Hindu aesthetics. In Panchanari Turaga a horse is depicted comprising five female figures. It is believed to symbolize the power and beauty of female energy. 
Do have a careful look at the painting and marvel the skill of the unknown artist. 
Dr Raguram
17/04/25, 9:51 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
17/04/25, 9:51 am - Dr Raguram: When we walked into the Japanese Tea Garden around this time last year, the cherry blossoms were blooming in full glory. The Yoshino cherry (also known as the Japanese flowering cherry) is the darling of the flowering tree world and the star of such renowned events as the National and International Cherry Blossom Festivals. This striking tree is known for its vibrant display of white-pink blossoms and faint almond fragrance in the springtime. Japanese legend states that each spring a fairy maiden hovers low in the warm sky, awakening the sleeping cherry trees with her delicate breath. The legend surrounding the Yoshino cherry blossoms, particularly on Mount Yoshino, centres around Enno Gyoja, the founder of Shugendo, who carved the mountain deity Zao-Gongen from a cherry tree, making these trees sacred. The preservation and care of these trees are entrusted to dedicated cherry blossom guardians known as Sakuramor. 
The ephemeral nature of the blossoms, which last only a week or so, is often portrayed in Japanese art and literature as a symbol of the transience of beauty and life itself. They inspired me too!
“Cherry blossoms
Fluttering in the breeze
Feathered petals”
