19/04/25, 9:08 am - Dr Raguram: Yet another World Heritage Day (18th April), has passed on. It raises an uncomfortable question, have we really taken care of the plethora of ancient gems which crave for attention all over the country? In our travels we found that many of these historically invaluable monuments are in a severe stage of neglect.
For instance, when we were travelling in Tirunelveli district we were keen to visit the Sathya Vageeswarar Temple in Kalakad. In addition to beautiful sculptures it is said to have more than 200 mural paintings, which are 400 years old. With great effort we got the necessary permission and when we visited it, there was no one around. We went around the temple savouring all the wonderful sculptures and after an hour, an official arrived. These murals are on the inner walls of each of the nine tiers of the temple’s gopuram. We climbed the inside of the gopuram in darkness. The steps were quite high and narrow. The official led the way with a torch with an intimidating stick. I wondered why he was carrying it. Our doubts were answered when we arrived at the first tier of the gopuram. Countless bats were hovering around us and there were resident monkeys who were making threating sounds. Fortunately, the official kept them at bay with the stick. The floor was littered with bat droppings and we gingerly made our way around them. There was no light inside and we started scanning the walls with the light from our mobile phones. Every inch of the wall was covered with murals depicting scenes from the Ramayana, the Mahabharata and episodes from the life of Saivite saints of Tamil Nadu. We were deeply saddened to see their derelict condition. Even though the paint had worn off due to years of neglect their innate beauty shone through layers of the murals. We climbed all the nine tiers and seeing the murals on each tier, was like watching a moving gallery of fading images which glowed in the light from our mobiles. 
We slowly climbed down with a deep sense of disquiet. These priceless repositories of the past crave for attention and careful restoration. It is a sad story of monumental neglect. Without concentrated efforts at conservation these murals will just fade away. If we create awareness about these treasures and integrate their histories into our educational systems, perhaps there might be a greater urgency to preserve them. It is also important not to leave this responsibility to governmental agencies with are already functioning on a shoe string budget. Involvement of the local community is extremely crucial to conserve these sublime remains of the past. 
Unfortunately, it is the same story in many monuments of interest. When our son Rahul was young we had taken him to the Chennakesava Temple at Somanathapura, near Mysore. There were two beautifully carved elephants flanking the steps and we had taken a photo of him with them. When we visited years later both of them were missing. I called the ASI person and asked him and he staunchly defended that no such sculpture ever existed there! 
It is a sad fact that we have failed in our moral responsibility to take care and preserve many of the beautiful monuments across the country.
Hope we are able to break this circle of neglect…at some time!
(The attached mural is one among the few which are relatively in good condition. The rest are not!)

22/04/25, 12:42 pm - Dr Raguram: The phrase "Earth laughs in flowers" comes from the poem "Hamatreya" by Ralph Waldo Emerson, wherein flowers are presented as a symbol of the earth's resilience and joy, often interpreted as a mockery of human attempts to dominate nature. Emerson believed that humans are ultimately transient and will return to the earth. The origin of the poem's title is unclear, because there is no Hindu word or name "Hamatreya." Perhaps it is an adaptation of "Maitreya," one of the characters in the Hindu text “Vishnu Purana”, who is engaged in a dialogue with the Vishnu. Vishnu tells Maitreya about the Hindu kings who mistakenly believed themselves as the possessors of the Earth. But the kings have disappeared, while the Earth endures. Vishnu recites the chant of the Earth and pities the egotistical kings and their blindness to their mortality. Human efforts to build empires and leave their mark on the earth will ultimately be futile. The earth, on the other hand, with its natural cycles of rejuvenation will always be alive, communicating joy and happiness through its flowers.
(Penned on the Earth Day 22nd April 2025)

Each book is like a stepping stone offering a new perspective and a fresh lens to view the world and oneself. As I venture further, I start feeling at home in that inward journey.

26/04/25, 8:34 am - Dr Raguram: Situated besides the Nambi river and against the backdrop of the Western Ghats (Mahendragiri) in Tirunelveli district is the Azhagiya Nambi Rayar temple at Thirukkurungudi. Nindra Nambi or Azhagiya Nambi is also called as “Sundara Paripoornam”, meaning “Perfect and complete beauty”. It is one of the most beautiful temple I had ever visited. Every corner of the temple premises is decorated with exquisite sculptures. Some of the most delicate carving are in the Chitra Gopuram. 
This particular panel illustrates the story of Gajendra Moksham. It is a small rectangular panel. Dominant figure is that of eight armed Vishnu, seated on Garuda, who is depicted with human face and body and wings. Garuda has infinite strength, so he comfortably bears Vishnu. Vishnu’s kirita makuta is a fascinating contrast to the jatamakutas which adorn Siva. Gajendra is beseeching Vishnu to deliver him from the clutches of the crocodile which has as strangle hold on its legs. On the top are munis, hands in worship who are witnessing this event.
Gajendra Moksha, meaning "the liberation of the elephant," is a story from the Bhagavata Purana about a king named Indradyumna, who was cursed in a past life to be born as an elephant named Gajendra. In his present life, Gajendra is attacked by a crocodile while at a lake, and he prays to Lord Vishnu for help. Vishnu, upon hearing Gajendra's prayer, intervenes and frees Gajendra from the crocodile's grasp, granting him liberation.
The Gajendra Moksha story, highlights the importance of surrendering to Lord Vishnu for liberation from suffering and the cycle of rebirth. Gajendra, the elephant, is rescued by Vishnu after being captured by a crocodile, symbolizing the release from ignorance and material attachments. The story emphasizes the power of devotion and the importance of seeking refuge in the divine during times of distress. The water symbolises our material world or samsara. The crocodile is maya which forever tries to pull the soul into samsara and its bondage.
The Gajendra Moksha Stotra, a prayer within the Srimad Bhagavatam, captures this dialogue between the devoted soul and the divine. The hymn highlights the transformative power of unwavering devotion, which offers liberation. 
मादृक्प्रपन्नपशुपाशविमोक्षणाय मुक्ताय भूरिकरुणाय नमोऽलयाय
O Lord of great compassion, liberated from the shackles of surrendered animals like me, I offer my obeisance to You. 
(Penned on the International Sculpture Day)

28/04/25, 7:39 am - Dr Raguram: It must have been a beautiful morning when scores of people made their way to Baisaran which is often referred to as "Mini-Switzerland". Reportedly it is one of the most scenic places near Pahalgam. When people settled down in the lovely large green meadow with the grand backdrop of pine trees and mountains they would have hardly anticipated the turn of events. Suddenly, bullets rained down on unsuspecting people, mostly men, who were shot at very close range. Horror and terror must have engulfed their companions who ran to safety. In that moment their lives changed for ever. The emotional trauma they experienced will leave a lasting impact among the survivors.
Even on reading about the incident and the experiences of the survivors, one is overwhelmed with a deep sense of anguish. Often it is difficult to express that pain in words. Sometimes, creative artists unmask that feeling in paintings. I recall the iconic painting of Edward Munch, ‘The Scream’. It features a figure with a terrified expression, surrounded by a swirling, vibrant landscape that reflects the emotional intensity of the moment. Munch used a distorted form and intense colours to unveil that moment of intense dread. In his words, “I felt tired and ill. I stopped and looked out over the fjord — the sun was setting, and the clouds turning blood red. I sensed a scream passing through nature; it seemed to me that I heard the scream. I painted this picture, painted the clouds as actual blood. The color shrieked.” 
‘The Scream’ stands as a timeless reminder of the existential dread that can make inroads into our lives and overwhelm us at the most unanticipated moments in our lives. The painting’s shriek, echoes deeply within our hearts. It unites us all in collective empathy and determination to respond to the anguish and pain with renewed resilience. 
Sometimes the most painful tears are not the ones that fall from our eyes. They're the ones that tumble from our hearts and find their way to those in throes of unbearable anguish.

29/04/25, 8:51 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
29/04/25, 8:51 am - Dr Raguram: As I was ambling through the vast Angkor Wat temple complex, savouring myriad sculptures that adorn it’s walls, I was particularly drawn to thousands of intricate stone carving that depict the dance of the Apsaras. The term "Apsara" refers to celestial nymphs or divine dancers in Hindu and Buddhist traditions, and are believed to be supernatural beings who entertain gods and kings with their graceful movements. The Apsara dance is a traditional Cambodian (Khmer) classical dance deeply rooted in Hindu and Buddhist mythology. It dates back to at least the 7th century and flourished during the Angkorian era (9th–15th centuries), particularly under King Jayavarman VII (12th century), whose court reportedly included over 3,000 Apsara dancers. The dance was performed at royal courts for ceremonies, festivals, and religious rituals, symbolizing a connection between the divine and human realms. The dance nearly vanished during the Khmer Rouge regime (1975–1979), when many artists were killed. It was revived in the mid-20th century and one can watch its performance at Siem Reap. Unfortunately, we know very little about the meanings and gestures of dance in ancient Cambodia. While a Sanskrit dance treatise, the Natyasastra, sheds light on ancient dance in India, no such text has survived in Cambodia.  While the legacy of dance was transmitted orally and bodily, the Apsara dance performed today is often a modern reinvention. This particular dance form was created in the late 1950s by Queen Kossamak.  The frontal focus, the twisted movement of bodies, and the flexible hand gestures seen in contemporary Apsara dance are derived from and inspired by the different poses depicted on Angkorian stone reliefs. 
The Apsara dancers of Angkor Wat are more than just exquisite carvings on temple walls; they are symbols of Cambodia’s enduring spirituality, artistry, and cultural identity. Rooted in Hindu mythology yet shaped by Cambodian creativity, these Apsaras embody ideals of grace, beauty, and spirituality in a dance form that resonate across generations.
As Martha Graham commented, “Dance is the hidden language of the soul.”
The attached image from Bayon temple is just a small sampler! 
(Penned on the International Dance Day 29th April)

30/04/25, 9:11 am - Dr Raguram: On the occasion of Basava Jayanthi let us recall the life and works of Lord Basaveshwara, also known as Basavanna or Basava. Born in 1134 AD in Basavana Bagewadi, Vijayapur District, Karnataka, he stands as a remarkable 12th-century social reformer. His works and revolutionary ideas transcended borders, advocating for equality through challenging caste and gender-based discrimination. His Vachanas blend spiritual devotion to Lord Shiva, advocating equality and rejecting caste and ritualism. Basavanna envisioned a society where all are equal under Siva’s divine kinship, like in this Vachana.
“ಇವನಾರವ, ಇವನಾರವ ಇವನಾರವನೆಂದೆನಿಸದಿರಯ್ಯಾ,
ಇವ ನಮ್ಮವ, ಇವ ನಮ್ಮವ, ಇವನಮ್ಮವನೆಂದೆನಿಸಯ್ಯಾ,
ಕೂಡಲಸಂಗಮದೇವಯ್ಯ ನಿಮ್ಮ ಮನೆಯ ಮಗನೆಂದೆನಿಸಯ್ಯಾ.”
“Do not ask, “Who is this man, who is he?”
Say instead, “He is one of us, he is ours.”
O Lord of the meeting rivers,
Proclaim him as a son of your house.”
A timeless message which is so pertinent in these times, which emphases the importance of  universal brotherhood, urging us to transcend social divisions”

01/05/25, 8:36 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
01/05/25, 8:36 am - Dr Raguram: Today is International Workers' Day, which honours the contributions of the workforces globally. Worker bees, though small, are nature’s ultimate labourers. A worker bee is a female honey bee that performs various tasks to maintain the hive. Unable to lay eggs, she takes on roles like foraging for nectar and pollen, cleaning the hive, feeding larvae, producing wax, and guarding the entrance. Their work shift with age: younger bees handle hive duties, while older one’s forage. Each hive has thousands of workers, forming the backbone of the colony's survival. Worker bees are vital pollinators, supporting 75% of global food crops through pollination, ensuring food security and biodiversity. This critical role is much akin to the indispensable contributions made by human workers in various walks of life. Like human workers facing exploitation or poor conditions, worker bees too endure threats like pesticides, habitat loss, and climate change, which shorten their lives. Worker bees embody the essence of labour. 
Like the worker bees labouring selflessly, let us work for common good in the hive of our lives.

02/05/25, 8:51 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
02/05/25, 8:51 am - Dr Raguram: Kalabhairava is a fearsome, yet revered, form of Lord Shiva. He is known as the destroyer of time, a protector, and a guardian against negative forces. He is also considered a deity who removes fear and protects devotees from enemies like greed, anger, and lust. 
This beautifully chiselled Kalabhairava sculpture is at Halebidu's Hoysaleshwara Temple. He is depicted with multiple arms holding various weapons. There is a dog licking the blood from a decapitated head on the bottom right. The sculpture also features Kali, the Goddess of time and destruction, dancing on Bhairava's side, symbolizing the cosmic dance of creation, preservation, and dissolution. The KalaBhairava sculpture in Halebidu is a powerful representation of Bhairava's role as a destroyer, a guardian, and a symbol of the transformative power of time and nature. The sculpture's intricate details and symbolic elements make it a captivating work of art and a testament to the rich artistic traditions of the Hoysala period.
The Kalabhairava Ashtakam, was composed by the revered Adi Shankaracharya, in 8th Century CE. It is a powerful prayer to Lord Kalabhairava, and consists of eight stanzas (Ashtakam) that praise the attributes of Kalabhairava and seek his grace and protection. The Ashtakam is believed to offer protection from negativity, enhance courage, and promote spiritual growth. One of the ashtakam states;
शूलटपाशदण्डपाणिमादिकारणं 
श्यामकायमादिदेवमक्षरं निरामयम् । 
भीमविक्रमं प्रभु विचित्रताण्डवप्रियं 
काशिकापुराधिनायकालभैरवं भजे ॥ 
I worship Lord Kalabhairava. Who holds (in His hands) the trident, the axe, the noose and the rod and who, is the Primal Cause of the Universe, who the Primeval God has a blue body, and who, is imperishable and pure, and the Lord of terrific prowess, fond of the wonderful dance. 
(May 2 is observed as Adi Shankaracharya Jayanti 2, marking the 1237th birth anniversary of the revered philosopher and spiritual reformer.)

03/05/25, 7:15 am - Dr Raguram: Vietnam war culminated on April 30, in 1975. It remains an outstanding example of squandered military valour. But more than that it was a vast preventable tragedy. The death toll is estimated to be around 1 to 3.8 million.  Not all of these were military personnel; nearly half of the deaths of the Vietnam War were the deaths of civilians caught in the fighting. 
There have been many literary accounts of the futility of war. For me personally Joseph Heller’s ‘Catch 22’ was a very incisive fictionalized narration of the realities and absurdities of war. Set on an island off the coast of Italy during World War II, it tells the story of Yossarian, an American bomber who is coming to grips with the dehumanizing impact of war on people. It is a unique fusion of satire, surrealism, and black humour to illustrate the terrible psychological effects of war. Heller reveals the brutalizing effects of combat, the deterioration of morals, and the loss of personal agency suffered by those caught up in war. It is a satirical and anti-war masterpiece. The phrase ‘Catch-22’ is used in the novel to describe a bureaucratic paradox that Yossarian and his fellow soldiers are trapped in. It often creates a situation where a soldier is caught in a catch-22 position: he can’t be grounded if he’s sane, but asking to be grounded is evidence of his sanity. Basically it draws attention to a plight when one is damned if they do and damned if they don’t, and the futility of trying to escape a situation that is inherently contradictory. 
As Heller observes "Outside the hospital the war was still going on. Men went mad and were rewarded with medals. All over the world, boys on every side of the bomb line were laying down their lives for what they had been told was their country, and no one seemed to mind, least of all the boys who were laying down their young lives…..It doesn't make a damned bit of difference who wins the war to someone who's dead."
(Joseph Heller 1 May 1923 - 12 December 1999)

08/05/25, 8:52 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
08/05/25, 8:52 am - Dr Raguram: Rabindranath Tagore was an ardent lover of nature. For him the wide-open skies and tranquillity of the countryside symbolised freedom. Not surprisingly, he envisioned education as a holistic process with close linkages with nature, fostering creativity and personal growth. Tagore saw the traditional formal education system as overtly focused on rote memorization and exams, which stifled creativity, alienating students from their cultural roots and the natural world around them. 
Tagore articulated his perspective about education through a short story "The Parrot's Training," It is a powerful satire that exposes the flaws of an inflexible educational system. The story depicts a king who orders his nephew to "educate" a parrot by forcing it to learn from books. The parrot initially considered "illiterate," is confined to a golden cage and subjected to rote memorization. With text-book in one hand and baton in the other, the pundits forced the bird to learn the lessons. It ultimately loses its natural singing voice and becomes a sad mimic. Unable to cope up with this forced tutelage, the parrot finally dies. The king orders the bird to be brought to him and when he pokes its lifeless body, he finds that its innards are stuffed with books: “only its inner stuffing of book-leaves rustled.” 
Tagore uses the parrot as a metaphor of a child in the formal education system. The parrot represents a child who is forced to conform to a rigid system that stifles creativity, natural learning, and individual needs, leading to a loss of natural abilities. In his view, “education is not the filling of a pail but the lighting of a fire.” 
I wonder whether we have heeded to the prescient message of Tagore. The learning spaces of today have metamorphosed into commodified, shiny concrete cages that are adoringly fitted with modern gadgets with a draconian emphasis on ‘performing well’ that sucks away the vibrant spirit of learning. 
Dr Raguram

10/05/25, 9:15 am - Dr Raguram: During our sojourn in the Rann of Kutch we were keen to have a glimpse of the Grey Hypocolius. We drove around on an early morning and spotted it, perched on the higher branches of ‘Salvadora Persica’, also known as the Miswak tree. Its twigs and roots are used to clean teeth due to their antibacterial properties. Prophet Muhammad reportedly recommended its use to maintain oral hygiene. 
Hypocolius are generally shy birds and it so wonderful to see it. It was oblivious to our presence and was savouring the berries in a leisurely fashion. Hypocolius migrates from West Asia to Western India during winter, with the Greater Rann of Kachchh being a major wintering ground. They breed in areas like Iraq, Iran, Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Turkmenistan, and winter in the Arabian Peninsula, Pakistan, and Western India.
War significantly impacts bird migration. The sounds of blazing guns and flashing lights from the bombs often frighten the birds, forcing them to search out new migratory routes and some of them might perish during the journey. In spite of it, they make the journey with hope tucked in their feathers. 
These migratory birds connect people, ecosystems and nations. They are symbols of peace in a world in throes of turmoil.
(Penned on the occasion of World Migratory Bird Day) 
Dr Raguram
11/05/25, 11:10 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
11/05/25, 11:10 am - Dr Raguram: Hoysala art is known for its intricate and detailed carvings, and Narasimha sculptures are no exception. Narasimha, the man-lion incarnation of Vishnu, whose advent is celebrated today, is prominently featured in many Hoysala temples throughout Karnataka. There are two representations of Narasimha; Ugra (fierce) and Yoga (meditative). The former is much more common.
The Kedareshwara Temple is just a kilometre away from the main Hoysaleswara Temple in Halebidu, but it is not as well known. Many people who visit Hoysaleswara Temple miss out on seeing this beautiful temple. Dedicated to Lord Shiva, it is a brilliant example of medieval Indian temple design. This particular panel depicts Ugra Narasimha as a fearsome form with a lion head, a human torso, and a powerful physique, with multiple arms. Two of his hands are holding Hiranyakashipu, the demon king, firmly on his lap. With two other hands he is opening the abdomen of Hiranyakashipu and one can see the intestines coming out, which Ugra Narasimha is wearing as a garland around him. 
Ugra means "ferocious" and this image of Ugra Narasimha devouring Hiranyakashipu symbolizes the destruction of negative forces and the triumph of good over evil. By vanquishing the demon, Ugra Narasimha re-establishes order and harmony in the cosmos, restoring the balance that was disrupted by the evil forces. Ugra Narasimha transcends mere visual representation. He urges us to stand up for what’s right and embrace our own inner strength in the face of injustice.

12/05/25, 9:28 am - Dr Raguram: Buddha Jayanti honours three major events in the Buddha's life: his birth in Lumbini, his attainment of enlightenment under the Bodhi tree in Bodhgaya, and his Mahaparinirvana in Kusinaga. When Buddha is meditating under the Bodhi tree, Mara tries to tempt and distract him. Buddha's encounter with Mara is a pivotal moment in Buddhist history, encapsulating the core of his spiritual journey, facing and transcending obstacles on the path to enlightenment.
In cave number 26 at Ajanta, there is an elaborate relief panel which depicts how Mara confronts and disturbs Buddha who is in deep meditation. In the centre of the panel, Buddha is in the varada (bestowing gifts) mudra and sits under the Bodhi tree. In the upper left half of the panel, the evil demon Mara is seen sitting astride a large elephant.  His fearsome forces are shown all around, trying to defeat the Buddha before he achieves enlightenment. Mara’s three daughters Rati (lust), Trishna (thirst), and Arati (delight) dance at the Buddha’s feet, with hopes of breaking his meditation with lustful advances. In the bottom right hand corner, a dejected and defeated Mara is portrayed with his hand to his head beside his daughters. 
The tale of the Buddha's victory over Mara is a timeless narrative that captures the core of the Buddhist journey to enlightenment. In Buddhist teachings, Mara's temptation symbolizes the obstacles and distractions that hinder spiritual progress. It teaches that the quest for truth and liberation demands unwavering determination, the capacity to conquer desire, fear, and doubt, and the readiness to turn adversity into spiritual growth. 
Buddhacarita, is the poetic narrative of the life of the Buddha by the Sanskrit poet Ashvaghosha, and is one of the finest examples of Buddhist literature. Chapter 13 details the defeat of Mara and ends with this sloka;
“tathāpi pāpīyasi nirjite gate diśaḥ praseduḥ prababhau niśākaraḥ |
divo nipeturbhuvi puṣpavṛṣṭayo rarāja yoṣeva vikalmaṣā niśā”
“When the wicked one thus fled vanquished, the different regions of the sky grew clear, the moon shone forth, showers of flowers fell down from the sky upon the earth, and the night gleamed out like a spotless maiden.”

18/05/25, 8:17 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
18/05/25, 8:17 am - Dr Raguram: Endangered Species Day is observed annually on the third Friday of May, and is dedicated to raising awareness about threatened species and the importance of conserving these species. At least 900 species are already extinct till date, while at least 28,5000 others are listed as endangered or critically endangered by the IUCN, the International Union for Conservation of Nature, which is the global wildlife conservation authority. It classifies species into one of nine Red List Categories: Extinct, Extinct in the Wild, Critically Endangered, Endangered, Vulnerable, Near Threatened, Least Concern, Data Deficient and Not Evaluated. 
The red-headed vulture is listed as being Critically Endangered on the IUCN Red List. This classification reflects the species' precarious population status and high risk of extinction. This is one of the 9 species of vulture which are found in India. It is also called the Asian King vulture or Pondicherry Vulture. The red-headed vulture is one of the few species of large vultures that does not live in big groups and is usually found alone or as a breeding pair. With its wingspan of over two metres the red-headed vulture is truly impressive especially when it is flying. Like most vultures their diet consists of carrion and they have been observed feeding on the carcasses of cattle. They play a crucial role in the ecosystem by cleaning up animal remains. This species has experienced a dramatic decline in both population size and distribution. In India it has been estimated that the population decreased by over 90% in just 10 years. This decline has been largely attributed to the use of the drug Diclofenac by veterinarians. 
Mr Bharatidasan through his NGO ‘Arulagam’ has played a stellar role in drawing attention to the importance of conserving this species through consistent, dedicated, efforts in the field. He along with his team has been educating the villagers about the consequences of usage of diclofenac through conducting village meetings, programs in the schools and involving senior members of the community in the conservation efforts. I had known him for over a decade and he is truly an inspiration. It was a privilege to accompany him to his field area and observe the tangible impact of his efforts. I will never forget the experience of seeing at least a hundred of various vultures, including the Red headed vulture, which are considered to be critically endangered.
In the Ramayana, there are references to two vultures, Jatayu and Sampati. While the tale of the former is rather well known, the role of Sampati, remains largely overlooked. Sampati sacrifices his wings to shield Jatayu from the sun's heat, leading to his own loss of ability to fly. Later, with his exceptional eyesight, he spots Sita in Lanka and guides Hanuman and the Vanara army towards her location. Though Jatayu and Sampati are key figures in the epic which is read widely, vultures have had a negative reputation in the minds of people as they feed on carcases. Often referred to demeaningly as "nature's garbage collectors", it fails to acknowledge the crucial importance of vultures in sustaining our environment.
Vultures like the Red headed ones are the unsung heroes of our ecosystem and saving them should be our responsibility and a top priority. 
“Soaring high above
They scan the ground with ancient skill
Clean the earth with quite will
Yet remain unloved and misjudged”
Dr Raguram
20/05/25, 9:23 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
20/05/25, 9:23 am - Dr Raguram: Every time I watch the bees, I am amazed how seamlessly and effectively they seem to carry out their job. They flit from blossom to blossom and when they had gathered enough, they take off and fly, heading to their hive. Bees, whose brains only have about 1 million neurons compared to the 86 billion or so in the human brain, navigate the world, avoid collisions and escape danger while accomplishing a task. I am sure that they have an accurate conceptual mental map of the space they have to negotiate. I wonder whether they have been the inspiration for robotic drones which are being used in many different ways…from warfare to agriculture.
More importantly, bees draw attention to the importance of collaborative existence. Each bee has a specific role; worker, drone, or queen and they function as a cohesive unit for the colony's survival. Grounded in millions of years of evolutionary experience, bees highlight the power of working as a unified whole while respecting individual differences and valuing varied contributions. 
Perhaps, it is an important reminder on the World Bee Day for our leaders to adopt a "queen bee" mind set, which is not authoritarian, but inspiring and unifying purposeful co-existence for common good. 
Dr Raguram

22/05/25, 8:53 am - Dr Raguram: While birding in Munnar, I suddenly heard a distinctive, repetitive clicking sound and I knew that the Malabar Giant Squirrel was somewhere in the midst of the canopy. 23/05/25, 9:26 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
23/05/25, 9:26 am - Dr Raguram: I am besotted with the hornbills, particularly the Great Indian Hornbill. My first sighting of this majestic bird was in Karian Shola in Anamalai Tiger Reserve, near Coimbatore. The stately bird with a commanding presence flew in to feed the chick in the nesting hole, high up in the tree. Over the years many more sightings ensued, almost all of them alone or in pairs. It was different when we went birding recently in the Royal Manas National Park. There were scores of them flying around and perching on trees. I have never seen so many of them together in my life. The forest came alive in their colourful presence.
The Great Indian Hornbill plays a crucial role in sustaining biodiversity by acting as a key agent in seed dispersal, which is crucial for forest regeneration and the overall health of the ecosystem. They are referred to as "farmers of the forest" or "engineers of the forests" because they play a vital role in dispersing seeds of various tropical trees. They consume a wide variety of fruits, including figs, and then disperse the seeds through their droppings in different locations, away from the parent plant. This helps in preventing competition among seedlings and aids in forest regeneration. By dispersing seeds, they help establish new tree populations and ensure the diversity of plant life in the jungle. Their presence and activity contribute to a healthy ecosystem by supporting the growth and diversity of plant life, which in turn supports other wildlife. 
In India we are blessed with a wide variety of biomes ranging from driest deserts to the moist rain forests, which harbour an astounding variety of flora and fauna.  It is a sad fact that we have lost 90% of them which are biodiversity hotspots. Ravaging the biosphere in the guise of ‘development’ will leave lasting impact on the health of the planet and our wellbeing too.
The life around us is an intricate, diverse, beautiful web. On this day let us commit ourselves not to fray it further.
(Penned on the occasion of International Day of Biodiversity, 22nd May)
Dr Raguram

“I asked the stand of maples behind the house,

27/05/25, 9:40 am - Dr Raguram: On her birthday today, 27th May, let us recall Rachel Carson whose work profoundly shaped the environmental movement. In her most influential work ‘Silent Spring’, Carson’s drew attention to the devastating effects of pesticides, particularly DDT, on ecosystems, wildlife, and human health. The book documented how indiscriminate pesticide use harmed birds, fish, and other organisms, disrupting food chains and causing widespread ecological damage. Its evocative title referred to a future where birdsong might vanish due to pesticide-induced deaths. The book’s impact was monumental. It sparked national debate and led to the eventual U.S. ban on DDT in 1972. It also drew attention to the fact that we are part of an interconnected ecosystem and how indifferent actions can have a rippling effect endangering it. 
Insecticide use is a double-edged sword. While they offer benefits like increased crop yields and disease control, they also pose risks to human health and the environment. Unfortunately, pesticide use in India has significantly increased, especially in recent decades, driven by factors like climate change, the need for increased agricultural output, and the adoption of high-yielding crop varieties. There is growing concern about their impact on human health and the environment, including potential contamination of soil and water. 
On this background, the stellar contributions of Rachel Carson are all the more relevant now. If we don’t pay heed to her observations, we will end up in a world where “the sedge has withered from the lake/ And no birds sing.” These lines are from John Keats' poem "La Belle Dame Sans Merci". It describes the withering of the sedge (a type of grass) at the lake, signifying a sense of desolation and decay in a barren and bleak landscape devoid of the rejuvenating songs of the birds.
In every brilliantly veined leaf, in every grain of food that we partake, there is a beautiful story of the earth which we have to attune ourselves to. 
Dr Raguram

28/05/25, 9:06 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
28/05/25, 9:06 am - Dr Raguram: We reached Elkhorn Slough early in the morning to have a good glimpse of its rich aquatic life. We got into the boat and made our way through its tidal flats, creeks and marshes, all teeming with amazing variety of aquatic plants and animals. 
It was a beautiful clear blue sky and we saw scores of pelicans, herons. As we were busy training our binoculars on them, I spotted a southern sea otter who was leisurely cruising on its back. Soon we saw several of them swimming together, rolling around in the water playfully and watching us right back. One of them was using a stone to crack open some shelled prey and devouring it, using its tummy as a dinner plate. Once it finished eating, it spent a few minutes rigorously cleaning its dense coat with its teeth and paws. Sea otters have the thickest fur of any animal and were hunted extensively for it. Elkhorn Slough has one of the largest resident colony of southern sea otters. 
Southern sea otters are considered as keystone species, as they play a crucial role in maintaining the health and balance of the marine ecosystems, particularly kelp forests. They help regulate the population of sea urchins, which can overgraze and destroy kelp forests, by preying on them. This helps to maintain the biodiversity of kelp forests and supports a wide variety of other marine life that rely on them. 
It was fascinating to watch the otters dipping, diving playfully. Seamus Heaney offers a wonderful description of them, in his poem ‘The Otter’:
“Turning to swim on your back,
Each silent, thigh-shaking kick
Re-tilting the light,
Heaving the cool at your neck.
And suddenly you're out,
Back again, intent as ever,
Heavy and frisky in your freshened pelt” 
(28th May is World Otter Day)
Dr Raguram

29/05/25, 9:23 am - Dr Raguram: Whenever I read Paul Lawrence Dunbar’s poem, "Sympathy", it leaves me deeply moved. The poet uses the symbol of a caged bird to voice his angst against societal oppression. The bird suffers from the “old, old scars” of past and it beats itself against its cage until its “blood is red on the cruel bars.” But in spite of it, it keeps singing. It is a song of pain.
No wonder this poem was the inspiration to Maya Angelou, to title her poignant autobiography, ‘I know why the caged bird sings.’ Among others, it is a searing account of her abuse and rape very early in life and ensuing trauma which cast a long shadow in her life. Angelou gave voice to countless survivors of sexual assault who, like her, endured years of trauma and silence. “Write so that perhaps people who hadn’t raped anybody yet might be discouraged, people who had might be informed, people who have not been raped might understand something, and people who have been raped might forgive themselves.” Her memoir powerfully conveys a message of resilience and revival, which she poetically refers as, “the honeycomb of determination”. Angelou also movingly describes the trials and tribulations of growing up as a black adolescent in a crushing climate of overt racism and inherent discrimination. 
The publication of this book paved way for countless women to feel inspired to narrate and share aspects of their lives that had long been shrouded in euphemism, secrecy, and shame.
Angelou summarizes her perspective succinctly, “My mission in life is not merely to survive, but to thrive; and to do so with some passion, some compassion, some humour, and some style.” 
(Maya Angelou 4 April 1928 - 28 May 2014)

30/05/25, 9:04 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
30/05/25, 9:04 am - Dr Raguram: Every time I am in a jungle, I try to spot the dholes. They are interesting animals to watch. Often I see them in groups, sauntering around the jungle, till one of them spot a prey. Then it makes a call that is described as ‘whistle of the woods’, to draw the attention of the groups. Only once I saw them in action. The moment they spot a prey, they hunt as a pack, sealing off all the routes of escape. Once the prey is brought down, other members join in to eat the prey and they eat very quickly. They finish off in a few minutes, leave the kill in the open and wander away. In Nagarhole, we saw a vulture clean off the remnants with just the bones left behind.  
The term ‘Dholes’ originated from the ancient Asiatic origin; which means “reckless” or “daring”, and it does fit in with their unbridled, courageous behaviours. Dholes are considered as an endangered species in India and figure in the IUCN Red List. While we do not have exact population counts, experts believe there may be 4000-10,000 Dholes left in the wild, with only 1000-2000 adult individuals capable of reproducing. This decline is primarily attributed to habitat loss due to deforestation and fragmentation of forest corridors. 
"Red Dog" in Kipling's story is a literary character that embodies certain traits of the dhole. 
The poem reads;
“For our white and our excellent nights, for the nights of swift running,
Fair ranging, far seeing, good hunting, sure cunning!
For the smells of the dawning, untainted, ere dew has departed!
For the rush through the mist, and the quarry blind-started!
For the cry of our mates when the sambhur has wheeled and is standing at bay!
For the risk and the riot of night!
For the sleep at the lair-mouth by day!
It is met, and we go to the fight.
Bay! O bay!”
(28th May was the World Dhole Day!)

01/06/25, 10:32 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
01/06/25, 10:32 am - Dr Raguram: A friend asked a question this morning as to why I didn’t post anything on the World Milk Day! In the process of getting to know about the history of milk production in India, I discovered that the history of dairy in the Indian subcontinent goes back roughly 8,000 years to the first domestication of zebu cattle, which is thought to have originated in India. By the beginning of the Indus Valley civilisation (c. 3300 – c. 1300 BCE), zebu cattle had been fully domesticated and used for their milk. They were known to produce dairy products, including milk. This is evidenced by the analysis of lipid residues on pottery shards from the Kotada Bhadli archaeological site in Gujarat. These analyses revealed the presence of milk-related lipids, suggesting the earliest direct evidence of dairy processing in the Indus Valley Civilization. The study also suggested that milk may have been boiled before consumption. There is also a suggestion that milk production may have been in surplus, potentially leading to trade and exchange between settlements. The majestic zebu bull, with its heavy dewlap and wide curving horns is perhaps the most impressive motif found on the Indus seals. 
Dr Raguram

04/06/25, 9:22 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
04/06/25, 9:22 am - Dr Raguram: During my early adolescent years, my uncle presented me with a BSA bicycle. I didn’t know how to ride one at that time. The task then, was to learn to ride it and in the process I fell down many a time and finally found the right balance to steer it. I often use this analogy in therapy to address the trauma and pain due to unfortunate tribulations in life which dawn upon us. These can unsettle us, but if we choose to, only briefly. The task is to unearth the emotional balance within, to navigate through the situation. The seeds for this perspective were sown through a painting of Claude Bernard outside our lecture theatre in JIPMER. Claude Bernard's concept of "milieu intérieur" meaning "internal environment" is a fundamental principle in physiology and medicine. It describes the body's ability to maintain a stable internal environment (homeostasis) despite external changes. Our task is to harness it, sometimes through external support and help. 
Another important learning curve for me when I started cycling was that the bicycle becomes a part of you. It merges with the rhythm of pedalling and the diktats of the driver. Personally it broadened my urban and inner landscape, much as outlined in ‘Zen and the art of motorcycle maintenance’. Cycling is as close to flying, you feel free, your mind feels free and your spirits take flight. It was through cycling I discovered the nooks and corners of the city and its people. I took great pride in cleaning it meticulously and taking care of it, till I handed it over to my nephew.
There is a lovely quote attributed to Mehmet Murat ildan:
Four wheels move the body, Two wheels move the soul.
Every time you miss your childhood, ride on a bicycle!
( Reflections on my cycling days, on 3rd June, the World Bicycle Day) 
Dr Raguram

05/06/25, 10:22 am - Dr Raguram: The Tamil Sangam poetry (circa 1st to 4th century CE) is a unique literary tradition among various streams of Indian literature. Devoid of mythological and religious allusions. It focused more on the environment and its impact on the individual. While the broad Sangam literature is generally categorized into akam (inner) and puram (outer), what is of great importance is that these two categories of poetry were painted on the ecological canvas of “tinais”. Tinais refer to five different environments; kurinji (mountainous regions), mullai (pastoral regions), marutham (riverine agricultural regions), neidhal (coastal regions) and palai (arid, desert regions). Sights and sounds of the environment is manifested in different locations like the mysterious mountain peaks, murmuring cool ponds and rivers, noisy sea shore, dry soulless desert land and rich agricultural pastures.
In Puranānūru 2, Poet Muranjiyur Mudinākanār writes;
மண் திணிந்த நிலனும்,
நிலன் ஏந்திய விசும்பும்,
விசும்பு தைவரு வளியும்,
வளித் தலைஇய தீயும்,
தீ முரணிய நீரும், என்றாங்கு
ஐம் பெரும் பூதத்து இயற்கை போல
These verses describe a king by comparing his nature to the five elements, “Your nature is like the five elements – the earth filled with sand,
the sky raised above the earth, wind that blows in the sky, fire that
sweeps up the wind, and water that contrasts from that fire.”
The poem draws attention to the intricate relationship between us and the environment we live in. It is imperative then to value and cherish this association.
(Penned on 5th June, World Environment Day)

06/06/25, 7:35 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
06/06/25, 7:35 am - Dr Raguram: During my Commonwealth Fellowship at the University College London, one day I was walking around the college when I spotted an unusual seated figure in a glass cage. Curious, to know what the figure was, I enquired with my colleagues and was told that it is the preserved body of Jeremy Bentham known as the ‘auto icon.’ It consists of Bentham's skeleton dressed in his own clothes, with a wax head on top, as he requested in his will.  Bentham is often considered a spiritual founder of UCL, as he advocated for the general availability of education and was a prominent voice for utilitarianism, a philosophy that seeks to maximize happiness for the greatest number of people. 
Bentham’s philosophical orientation has been contentious, but he was an ardent advocate of women’s rights, freedom of expression and argued for the decriminalisation of homosexuality. He strongly believed that education should be accessible to all races and across all political beliefs. UCL was the first UK university to accept students regardless of gender, class or religion, pioneering a move towards inclusivity in higher education. Bentham was also a strong advocate of transparency and accountability in law and stressed the importance of public access to legal processes. 
Bentham’s work laid the foundation for the concept of ‘bounded reality.’ He drew attention as to how humans make decisions not based on perfect logic and complete information, but rather with limitations in their cognitive abilities, time constraints, and available information. He felt that limited recognition of available alternatives, incomplete knowledge of possible consequences, and imperfect anticipation of the values associated with future consequences often skews moral attitudes and the decision making processes. A concept that we witness being enacted around us all the time. 
(Jeremy Bentham; February 15, 1748 - June 6, 1832)

08/06/25, 10:05 am - Dr Raguram: Point Lobos State National Reserve in California is dramatically situated at the edge of the Pacific Ocean. It is often referred to as the “greatest meeting of land and water in the world”. Its rocky coastline offers a superb habitat for a huge diversity of plants animals and birds. Every time we visit the place, we feel mesmerized by its dramatic landscape. This enchanting landscape is a haven of tranquillity. At times one can hear the ocean's voice as a chorus of deafening roars when its powerful waves crash upon the rocks. But soon the waves start lapping gently against the rocks as if they are in a whispered conversation. 
As I was scanning the oceanscape, I noticed a groups of Brandt’s cormorants perched on the craggy surface of the rocks. They are the largest cormorants on the Pacific Coast. Brandt's cormorants are fascinating seabirds with unique diving abilities and can often dive deep to catch fish. They roost together as groups on rocks and forage in flocks. It was a fascinating sight when they suddenly took to the sky, flying in long lines over the rippling waters of the ocean. 
The Pacific Ocean in Point Lobos is a vast expanse mirroring the endless blue sky above, its surface a restless expanse of waves shimmering in sunlight. Watching it, I was reminded of a poem ‘Once By The Pacific’ by Robert Frost.
“The shattered water made a misty din.
Great waves looked over others coming in,
And thought of doing something to the shore
That water never did to land before.
The clouds were low and hairy in the skies,
Like locks blown forward in the gleam of eyes.
You could not tell, and yet it looked as if
The shore was lucky in being backed by cliff,
The cliff in being backed by continent;
It looked as if a night of dark intent
Was coming, and not only a night, an age.
Someone had better be prepared for rage.
There would be more than ocean-water broken
Before God's last Put out the light was spoken.”
(8th June is World Oceans Day)

09/06/25, 9:15 am - Dr Raguram: All through history there have been narcissistic leaders., characterized by being unduly vain and conceited with an overwhelming sense of false pride. With their insatiable need for adoration, they seek attention and constant validation, often resorting to manipulation to maintain their image. One of the greatest example of it is the Roman emperor, Nero, who died on this date of suicide. Nero surrounded himself with sycophants who only told him what he wanted to hear. This environment stifled honest feedback, preventing him from confronting unpleasant truths. As a result, Nero's leadership became increasingly erratic, culminating in a series of disastrous decisions. His response to the Great Fire of Rome exemplifies his incompetence. Instead of uniting the people, he scapegoated Christians, initiating a wave of persecution that would last for centuries. 
More importantly, narcissistic leaders like Nero destabilize institutions, prioritizing personal ego over the common good. Throughout history many political leaders have traversed this territory with disastrous consequences in governance. There is an urgent need of leaders who embody virtue, courage and wisdom. Only then can we safeguard the institutions and freedoms we hold dear. 
Perhaps our leaders need to look back at people like Nero, learn and unlearn important lessons from history, to govern us with sensitivity and equanimity.

11/06/25, 9:02 am - Dr Raguram: We are all dreamers of dreams. Though it is a part of our real world experience, dream is also a window into our subconscious mind. Sometimes, our minds teeter on the edge of two worlds; the reality outside of us and the dreamscape within. In that state, we are neither fully immersed in the dreamscapes of our subconscious nor fully anchored in the rationality of waking life. Often it is a fertile breeding ground for deep reflection.
Zhuangzi, a foundational figure in Daoist philosophy, is famous for his parable of the butterfly dream. The story blurs the boundary between self and other. Zhuangzi wonders if he can truly know whether he is the dreamer or the dreamed, highlighting the limits of human understanding and the need to embrace uncertainty. He implies that life is a series of transformations, a constant flux of existence, wherein the distinction between the self and the other dissolves, leading to a newer level of awareness.  Zhuangzi’s uncertainty about whether he is the dreamer or the dreamed also draws our attention to the perennial question, what defines the self? 
In her travels in the wonderland, Alice had to confront this perennial question. She comes across a Caterpillar that is resting on top of a giant mushroom and smoking a hookah pipe. The two stare at each other in silence for a while before the Caterpillar asks Alice, “Who are you? This was not an encouraging opening for a conversation. Alice replied, rather shyly, “I--I hardly know, sir, just at present-- at least I know who I WAS when I got up this morning, but I think I must have been changed several times since then.”
Both Zhuangzi and Lewis Carroll indicate that the concept of self is often fluid and dynamic. 
As Carl Rogers commented, "A person is a fluid process, not a fixed and static entity; a flowing river of change…continually changing constellation of potentialities".

16/06/25, 8:36 am - Dr Raguram: When we were in Wayanad a month ago, there was a prediction that the monsoon will arrive soon. Once we entered the Nagarhole forest, we were greeted with thousands of butterflies on their annual seasonal journey during pre-monsoon period. It was so wonderful to see them fluttering around in hordes. The raucous call of the peahen resonated across the forest.  I recalled that the word "Mylapore" in Chennai is derived from the Tamil phrase "Mayil ārpparikkum ūr," which translates to "land of the peacock scream." As we ventured further, a peacock flew in front of us, looked around for a while, and then began its elegant, dazzling dance. Slowly, it lifted its tail to form a semi-circular fan, which rippled in iridescent colours. I noticed that when they strum and flicker the feathers, strangely, the eyespots at the end seemed to remain relatively still. 
It is a commonly held belief that peacocks respond to the change of seasons and their dance heralds the arrival of monsoon. This has been one of the favourite subjects in Indian poetry. 
In the poetry of the Sangam era (300BCE-300CE), peacocks and the monsoon are often associated, with peacocks symbolizing the joy and vibrancy of the monsoon season. The monsoon is a time of renewal and abundance, and peacocks, known for their beauty and flamboyant display, are seen as messengers of its arrival. A lovely poem in Ainkurunooru; 492, states;
“நின்னே போலும் மஞ்ஞை ஆல நின்
நன்னுதல் நாறும் முல்லை மலர
நின்னே போல மா மருண்டு நோக்க
நின்னே உள்ளி வந்தனென்
நன்னுதல் அரிவை காரினும் விரைந்தே”
“When a peacock dances like you,
And fragrant jasmine blooms 
like the scent of your forehead,
When a doe gazes timidly like you,
I rush home thinking of you,
Swifter than a monsoon cloud.” 
In a 16th century poetic work, Mayurasandesa (The Peacock’s Message) written by Udaya in Malayalam, the poet writes, “In order to bring joy to the world, you dance, creating happiness. You, the descendant of Indira, offer solace to those in woe and brighten their world, much like the sun casting its rays on the lotus to bloom”.
In a beautiful poem, ‘New Rain’, Rabindranath Tagore writes;
“My heart dances today — dances like a peacock.
Like the shimmer of its plumes,
My heart glistens with rapturous colours.
When I see the sky, my longing loses itself in euphoria.
My heart dances today — dances like a peacock.”
The peacock’s brilliant hues as it dances does not merely reside in the pigment of its feathers but is due to refraction of light streaming through its plumage.  As I watched it, I wondered as to how important it will be for us to let the light of awareness permeate and transform our inner selves and set it aglow.

17/06/25, 10:01 am - Dr Raguram: The crocodile has had a strange relationship with the people of India. It has been both revered and feared, considered a protector and a menace.  It figures in puranas and in various mythological accounts. The most well-known mention about the crocodile is in Bhagavat Purana, as the legend of Gajendra Moksha. Gajendra, in his previous life as King Indradyumna, had neglected his duties and was cursed by Agastya to become an elephant. While fetching lotus flowers, he was seized by a crocodile and struggled to free himself, even trying to escape with his own strength for 1000 years. His friends and family also tried to help, but were unsuccessful. Finally, realizing his limitations, Gajendra prayed to Vishnu for help, offering a lotus flower as a symbol of devotion. Lord Vishnu, pleased with his prayer, appeared on Garuda and killed the crocodile, liberating Gajendra. 
There is an extraordinary depiction of this legend in Hoysaleshwar temple, Halebidu. Perhaps this is one of the most detailed depiction of the Gajendra Moksham. Vishnu is seated in Lalitasana and is holding an arrow, mace, and is Sudarshan Chakra. Garuda is carrying Vishnu and is covered with various ornaments. One can also see his wings on both sides. Bellow him, is the elephant struggling to survive. He is holding a lotus and presenting it to Vishnu. Under the right knee of Garuda, is the crocodile holding down the elephant in his killer jaws. 
The overarching message of Gajendra Moksham is a spiritual one, reminding us to prioritize the eternal connection with the divine over transient material pursuits. It encourages a deeper reflection on the impermanence of life and the importance of turning towards a higher power for solace and liberation from the cycle of suffering. 
As Srimat Bhagavatam states in verse 8.3.25
जिजीविषे नाहमिहामुया कि-
मन्तर्बहिश्चावृतयेभयोन्या ।
इच्छामि कालेन न यस्य विप्लव-
स्तस्यात्मलोकावरणस्य मोक्षम् 
I do not wish to live anymore after I am released from the attack of the crocodile. What is the use of an elephant’s body covered externally and internally by ignorance? I simply desire eternal liberation from the covering of ignorance.
(June 17th is celebrated as the World Crocodile Day)
Dr Raguram

19/06/25, 8:29 am - Dr Raguram: We are in throes of yet another war. As missiles soar in the sky, screams fill the air and blood wets the ground, will the futility of war ever descend upon us all? I wonder. 
One of the most unsettling portrayal of war and its aftermath is a painting, ‘The Face of War’ by Salvador Dali. Dali was profoundly impacted by the events of the Spanish Civil War and World War II and he gave expression to his personal angst in his own unique way in this painting. It is a surrealistic portrayal of the impact of war on the human psyche. In this painting there is a disembodied, withered face, resembling a corpse, on the background of a barren, desert landscape. There is an unmistakable expression of fear, misery and agony on the face. The sockets of the eyes and mouth contain smaller faces which in turn have more faces within them, suggesting the infinite number of people who suffer the tragedy of war.  Swarming around the face are serpents, representing relentless attacks by malevolent forces. Dali left his handprint in the lower right corner of the canvas to convey that this painting came from his own deep agony about the impact of war. 
Whenever I see this painting, I can’t take my eyes off the haunting forms which are manifestations of the dread spawned by war. It is a chilling portrayal of the psychological trauma inflicted by the harshness of war. The wounds of battles are not merely physical. They leave behind craters smouldering with intense pain, unfathomable anguish and deep despair. As the world crumbles all around, the minds of people left behind after the war crumble too. 
As Aldous Huxley observed, "The most shocking fact about war is that its victims and its instruments are individual human beings, and that these individual beings are condemned by the monstrous conventions of politics to murder or be murdered in quarrels not their own."  
Amy Patterson, whose son returned from the war, deeply traumatized wrote these poignant lines in her poem, ‘A Mother’s Tear.’
“He screams in the night,
for the battle still roars,
as he lays in his bed,
he re-lives all the horror.
Nobody heard the fight,
he still fights,
except for his Mama,
who comforts him every night.
He never will be,
the son I once knew,
the war killed that part,
for freedom, for you.
Great Nation, Great Leaders,
and all those who will hear,
Freedom began
On a mother’s first tear.”
Dr Raguram

20/06/25, 8:41 am - Dr Raguram: When I think of the current war scenario, I am reminded of an Aesop fable, ‘Birds, The Beasts and The Bat.” 
The fable reads, “The Birds and the Beasts declared war against each other. No compromise was possible, and so they went at it tooth and claw. It is said the quarrel grew out of the persecution the race of Geese suffered at the teeth of the Fox family. The Beasts, too, had cause for fight. The Eagle was constantly pouncing on the Hare, and the Owl dined daily on Mice. It was a terrible battle. Many a Hare and many a Mouse died. Chickens and Geese fell by the score—and the victor always stopped for a feast. Now the Bat family had not openly joined either side. They were a very politic race. So when they saw the Birds getting the better of it, they were Birds for all there was in it. But when the tide of battle turned, they immediately sided with the Beasts. When the battle was over, the conduct of the Bats was discussed at the peace conference. Such deceit was unpardonable, and Birds and Beasts made common cause to drive out the Bats. And since then the Bat family hides in dark towers and deserted ruins, flying out only in the night.”
The fable highlights the problems associated with trying to remain neutral in a conflict. If one constantly switches allegiances, it can lead to losing the trust and support from either side. The bat's attempts to benefit from both sides ultimately results in him having no friends or allies." 
“A Beast he would be, or a bird,
As might suit, thought the Bat: but he erred.
When the battle was done,
He found that no one
Would take him for friend at his word.”

24/06/25, 8:57 am - Dr Raguram: <Media omitted>
24/06/25, 8:57 am - Dr Raguram: I used to make frequent forays into the Moore Market in Chennai (till it was burnt down) in search of books. Often I would find books by authors whom I had never heard of. During one such visit I picked up Ambrose Bierce’s ‘Devils Dictionary’ and ‘Selected Stories.’ The former was fun to read. Bierce’s humorous and satirical definitions of common words were quite engaging. The stories were markedly different. Frequent themes in his stories were about the horrors of war, which is best exemplified in a short story ‘Chickamauga.’ It seems so relevant to retell this tale now.
In this story which is set during the American Civil War, a six-year old child in Georgia wanders into the forest carrying a wooden toy sword playing a game as a soldier. Soon he is lost in the woods and sleeps off. When he wakes up, he is frightened by a strange moving object which at first he cannot identify. He fears it might be another wild animal like a dog, pig, or bear. He then realizes that this is not one creature, but many creatures, one followed by another. He finally realizes that these are hundreds of soldiers, creeping on their hands and knees instead of walking. He places himself in the lead and directs the march of the crawling, staggering soldiers. As they march ahead, the child sees a building on fire. When he goes near, he discovers that it is his own home and to his great shock also perceives his mother who has suffered a gruesome death. The author now reveals that the child who is deaf and mute, utters a series of inarticulate and indescribable cries when brought face to face with the horrific reality of war closer home. 
Bierce describes in graphic detail, the battlefield which is littered with the wounded who drag themselves through the mud and the dying who are left unattended. The child is totally oblivious to the destruction and suffering around and he even rides on a gravely wounded soldier. For the child it is akin to a war game as he “places himself in the lead, his wooden sword still in hand, and solemnly directs the march.” Bierce is deftly alluding to the fact that generals and politicians who lead men into wars are like this deaf child, who has little understanding of what he is doing. Reality doesn’t dawn on the child until he sees his burning home and his dead mother. That is when the horror of war becomes a reality to him. 
There was a real Battle of Chickamauga in which more than 40,000 people lost their lives. It was the second costliest battle of the Civil War, ranking only behind Gettysburg and was by far the deadliest battle ever fought in the nation. It is rather disquieting then, when the country that has witnessed such human tragedy is groping its way across yet another foreign locale, hardly learning from scores of its misadventures in the past. In Bierce’s words, the boy was committing “the common enough military error of pushing the pursuit to a dangerous extreme.” 
Dr Raguram

25/06/25, 10:53 am - Dr Raguram: I first heard the Beatles way back in 1975: it was the album, ‘Sgt Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band.’ I had never heard anything like it before. I was mesmerized by its unique instrumentation, the harmonic tones and the lovely vocals. I’ve heard this album so many times and find something new every time I hear the songs. The album left a lasting impression on me and I was hooked to the Beatles. Over a course of time, Ahalya and myself started collecting their albums and these vinyl records have a special place in our home. Their repertoire is vast and stunning, from love songs to deeply reflective, introspective lyrics which explore themes of loneliness like in ‘Eleanor Rigby.’  To me their songs are sheer poetry. For instance, the song, “She’s Leaving Home” stands out as one of their loveliest and saddest songs. It is like a short story in a musical form, narrating the plight of a young girl who feels unloved at home: ‘She’s leaving home after living alone for so many years’, to embark on a journey to find solace with her new companion. Each of their albums is a creative gem to cherish. 
Like me, Murakami also seems to have had an abiding love for the Beatles. It seeps through many of his works. There is a short story titled ‘Yesterday’ and another one titled, ‘With The Beatles’, in which narrator's fondest memories is of a girl he encounters in the school corridor, clutching an LP of “With The Beatles”. I am particularly fond of his novel whose title is based on a Beatle song, ‘Norwegian Wood’ from the album ‘Rubber Soul.’ The novel begins with the main protagonist, Toru Watanabe, arriving at Hamburg Airport while the Beatles’ song “Norwegian Wood” is playing on the speakers. The song’s opening line (“I once had a girl, or should I say she once had me.”) succinctly captures the melancholic tone in the relationship of the two main characters Toru and Naoko. There is beautiful part in the novel when Toru asks, “What happens when people open their hearts?” and Reiko responds, “They get better.” And the Beatles achieve this seamlessly in their songs. 
(It was on 25th June that the Beatles participated in the BBC show ‘Our World’ in 1967, performing, “All You Need Is Love” to an international audience which is  now commemorated as the World Beatles Day).

07/07/25, 9:46 am - Dr Raguram: Whenever I course along the Big Sur, I am reminded of authors, artists and spiritual seekers who had made this pristine stretch their creative abode. I had written sometime back about Jack Kerouac who wrote his novel, ‘Big Sur’ in a cabin under the picturesque Bixby Creek Bridge. Another author who found a sanctuary there was Henry Miller. I have read many of his novels, including his controversial novel, ‘The Tropic of Cancer.’ But one work of his which left a lasting impression on me is the ‘The Air-Conditioned Nightmare.’ 
The book is a travelogue of his journey across US in the 40s. When I re-read it now many of his observations ring so true about the nation. He finds USA, vapid and soulless, a nation of people who are a “vulgar, pushing mob whose passions are easily mobilized by demagogues, newspaper men, religious quacks, agitators and such like. To call this a society of free peoples is blasphemous. What have we to offer the world beside the superabundant loot which we recklessly plunder from the earth under the maniacal delusion that this insane activity represents progress and enlightenment?” 
At times he may sound like a grumpy old man, feeling a deep sense of disquiet observing a nation where giant industries which pollute the environment and are impervious to the lives of their workers, and a population entrapped in a fast web of material comforts and relentless mass consumerism. He finds the people totally unaware of the world outside who, “bludgeon one another with facts and theories gleaned from cursory readings of newspapers, magazines, and digests.” He observes the giant, corporate American who is “seated in a comfortable chair in New York, Chicago or San Francisco, a man surrounded by every luxury and yet paralyzed with fear and anxiety, controls the lives and destinies of thousands of men and women whom he has never seen, whom he never wishes to see and whose fate he is thoroughly uninterested in.” Writing in 1940s, he laments, ‘The world meanwhile looks to us with a desperation such as it has never known before. Where is the democratic spirit? Where are the leaders?”
Even though his narration might sound bleak, he notices a nation “still intact, like a piece of music which goes on being played forever. The instruments wear out, and the players too, but the notes are eternal, and you are made of nothing but invisible notes which even the faintest zephyr can shake a tune out of.” 
Dr Raguram
